column1: The '''effects of climate change''' span the impacts on [[physical environment]], [[ecosystems]] and human societies due to ongoing human-caused [[climate change]]. The future impact of climate change depends on how much nations reduce [[greenhouse gas emissions]] and [[Climate change adaptation
column2: adapt]] to climate change.<ref name=""adaptation and mitigation"">Oppenheimer, M., ''et al.'', ''Section 19.7.1: Relationship between Adaptation Efforts, Mitigation Efforts, and Residual Impacts,'' in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf Chapter 19: Emergent risks and key vulnerabilities] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1080–1085, in {{harvnb

column1: </ref><ref>Oppenheimer, M., ''et al.'', ''Section 19.6.2.2. The Role of Adaptation and Alternative Development Pathways,'' in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf Chapter 19: Emergent risks and key vulnerabilities] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1072–1073, in {{harvnb
column3: 2014}}</ref> Effects that scientists predicted in the past—loss of sea ice, accelerated [[sea level rise]] and longer, more intense [[Heat wave
column10: url-status=live }}</ref> The changes in climate are not expected to be uniform across the Earth. In particular, land areas change more quickly than oceans, and northern high latitudes change more quickly than the [[tropics]]. There are three major ways in which global warming will make changes to regional climate: melting ice, changing the [[hydrological cycle]] (of evaporation and precipitation) and changing [[Ocean current

column1: Physical changes include [[extreme weather]], [[Retreat of glaciers since 1850
column2: glacier retreat]], sea level rise, [[Arctic sea ice decline
column3: declines in Arctic sea ice]], and changes in the timing of seasonal events (such as earlier spring flowering). Since 1970, the ocean has absorbed more than 90% of the [[ocean heat content
column4: excess heat]] in the climate system. Even if global surface temperature is stabilized, sea levels will continue to rise and the ocean will continue to absorb excess heat from the atmosphere for many centuries.<ref name=""ReferenceA"" /> The uptake of [[Carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere
column5: carbon dioxide from the atmosphere]] is leading to [[ocean acidification]].<ref name=""ReferenceA"">{{cite book

column2: degraded land]] by raising temperatures, [[Water scarcity
column3: drying soils]] and increasing [[wildfire]] risk.<ref name=""ReferenceB"">{{cite book
column6: page=9}}</ref> Recent warming has strongly affected natural biological systems.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts"" /> Species worldwide are migrating poleward to colder areas. On land, species move to higher elevations, whereas marine species find colder water at greater depths.<ref name="":8"" /> Between 1% and 50% of species on land were assessed to be at substantially higher risk of [[extinction]] due to climate change.<ref name="":1"" /> Coral reefs and shellfish are vulnerable to the combined threat of ocean warming and acidification.<ref name="":14"" />

column1: [[Food security]] and access to fresh water are at risk due to rising temperatures. Climate change has profound impacts on human health, directly via heat stress and indirectly via the spread of infectious diseases.

The vulnerability and exposure of humans to climate change varies from one economic sector to another and will have different impacts in different countries. Wealthy industrialised countries, which have emitted the most CO<sub>2</sub>, have more resources and so are the least vulnerable to global warming.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=The Industries and Countries Most Vulnerable to Climate Change
column11: website=International Director}}</ref> Economic sectors that are likely to be affected include [[Effects of climate change on agriculture
column38: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column65: last15=Seneviratne}}</ref> Some groups may be particularly at risk from climate change, such as the [[Climate change and poverty
column68: children]] and [[Climate change and indigenous peoples
column69: indigenous peoples]].<ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts"">{{citation
column76: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Distribution of Impacts, in: Sec 19.3.7 Update on 'Reasons for Concern']
column77: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column89: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-2-5.html Sec 7.4.2.5 Social issues and Sec 7.4.3 Key vulnerabilities]
column95: url-status=live}}</ref> These groups have much higher levels of [[vulnerability]] to [[environmental determinants of health]], [[wealth]] and other factors. They also have much lower levels of capacity available for coping with environmental change. This can result in [[environmental migration]], especially in developing countries where people are directly dependent on land for food, feed, fibre, timber and energy.<ref>{{cite book
column98: page=7}}</ref><ref>[https://www.nrdc.org/onearth/climate-change-already-driving-mass-migration-around-globe Climate Change Is Already Driving Mass Migration Around the Globe] {{Webarchive
column100: date=18 December 2019}}, Natural Resources Defense Council, 25 January 2019</ref>

column5: Average surface air temperatures from 2011 to 2021 compared to the 1956–1976 average. Source: [[Goddard Institute for Space Studies

column1: Global warming affects all elements of Earth's [[climate system]].<ref name="":10"">{{Cite book
column5: title=WMO statement on the State of the Global Climate in 2018
column16: publisher=Chairperson, Publications Board, World Meteorological Organization
column24: url-status=live}}</ref> Global surface temperatures have risen by 1 °C and are expected to rise further in the future.<ref name="":10"" /><ref name="":11"">IPCC, 2013: [https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/2018/02/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf Summary for Policymakers.] {{Webarchive
column26: date=26 July 2019}} In: Climate Change 2013: The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of Working Group I to the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change p.20</ref>  Night-time temperatures have increased faster than daytime temperatures.<ref>{{Cite journal
column38: title=Diurnal asymmetry to the observed global warming
column46: doi-access=free}}</ref> The impact on the environment, wildlife, society and humanity depends on how much more the Earth warms.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities"">{{citation
column48: title=Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 2007
column51: chapter=Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change

column1: One of the methods scientists use to predict the effects of human-caused climate change, is to investigate past natural changes in climate.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=To Predict Effects Of Global Warming, Scientists Looked Back 20,000 Years
column11: website=NPR}}</ref> To assess changes in Earth's [[paleoclimate
column12: past climate]] scientists have studied [[tree rings]], [[ice core]]s, [[coral]]s, and ocean and lake sediments.<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data"">{{citation
column14: title=NOAA Paleoclimatology Global Warming – The Story: Proxy Data
column18: publisher=NOAA Paleoclimatology Program – NCDC Paleoclimatology Branch
column21: url-status=live}}</ref> These show that recent warming has surpassed anything in the last 2,000 years.<ref name=""phys.org"">[https://phys.org/news/2019-07-20th-century-hottest-years.html The 20th century was the hottest in nearly 2,000 years, studies show] {{Webarchive
column23: date=25 July 2019}}, 25 July 2019</ref> By the end of the 21st century, temperatures may increase to a level not experienced since the mid-[[Pliocene]], around 3 million years ago.<ref name=""jansen pliocene"">{{cite book
column45: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch6s6-3-2.html Sec. 6.3.2 What Does the Record of the Mid-Pliocene Show?]
column66: last10=Rahmstorf}}</ref> At that time, mean global temperatures were about 2–4 °C warmer than pre-industrial temperatures, and the global mean sea level was up to 25 meters higher than it is today.<ref>{{Cite book
column90: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column111: last13=Marzeion}}</ref>[[File:Global mean near-surface air temperature and thermosteric sea-level rise anomalies relative to the 2000–2019 mean for RCP climate change scenarios.webp
column116: Projected]] temperature and sea-level rise relative to the 2000–2019 mean for [[Representative Concentration Pathway
column117: RCP]] [[climate change scenarios]] up to 2500.<ref>{{cite news
column118: title=By 2500 earth could be alien to humans
column121: work=Scienmag: Latest Science and Health News
column154: title=Climate change research and action must look beyond 2100

column1: How much the world warms depends on [[Climate change scenario
column2: what humans do or not to limit GHG emissions]], and how [[climate sensitivity
column3: sensitive the climate is to greenhouse gases]].<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum"">{{cite book
column4: title=Global Climate Change Impacts in the United States
column14: url-status=live}}</ref> Scientists are pretty sure that with double the amount of GHG in the atmosphere the world would warm by 2.5 °C to 4 °C; but how much more humans will emit is less certain.<ref>{{Cite web
column16: title=In-depth Q&A: The IPCC's sixth assessment report on climate science
column20: language=en}}</ref> The projected magnitude of warming by 2100 is closely related to the level of cumulative emissions over the 21st century (total emissions between 2000 and 2100). The higher the cumulative emissions over this time period, the greater the level of warming is projected to occur.<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions"">

column3: title=The Emissions Gap Report: Are the Copenhagen Accord pledges sufficient to limit global warming to {{val
column10: chapter=Ch 2: Which emissions pathways are consistent with a {{val
column14: u=°C}} temperature limit?: Sec 2.2 What determines long-term temperature?
column18: url-status=dead}}, p.28. This publication is also available in [http://www.unep.org/publications/ebooks/emissionsgapreport/ e-book format] {{webarchive

column1: If emissions of {{CO2}} were to be abruptly stopped and no [[negative emission technologies]] deployed, the Earth's climate would not start moving back to its pre-industrial state. Instead, temperatures would stay elevated at the same level for several centuries. After about a thousand years, 20% to 30% of human-emitted {{CO2}} will remain in the atmosphere, not taken up by the ocean or the land, committing the climate to a warmer state long after emissions have stopped.<ref>{{Cite book
column25: chapter=Chapter 12: Long-term Climate Change: Projections, Commitments and Irreversibility

column1: Mitigation policies currently in place will result in about 2.7 °C (2.0–3.6 °C, depending on how [[climate sensitivity
column2: sensitive the climate is to greenhouse gas emissions]]) warming above pre-industrial levels. If all unconditional pledges and targets made by governments are achieved the temperature will rise by around 2.4 °C. If  additionally all the countries that adopted or are considering to adopt net-zero targets will achieve it the temperature will rise by a median of 1.8 °C. There is a substantial gap between national plans and commitments and actions so far taken by governments around the world.<ref>{{cite web

column1: The lower and middle atmosphere, where nearly all of the weather occurs, are heating due to the enhanced [[greenhouse effect]]. Increased greenhouse gases cause the higher parts of the atmosphere, the [[stratosphere]] to cool.<ref name=""Hausfather_2017"">

column5: title=Study: Why troposphere warming differs between models and satellite data

column1: </ref> The heated atmosphere contains more [[Water vapor
column2: water vapour]], which is itselfs also a greenhouse gas and [[Water vapour feedback
column3: acts as an self-reinforcing feedback]].<ref name=""Royal_Society_basics"">

column2: title=Climate change: evidence and causes {{!}} Royal Society

column1: Global warming leads to an increase in [[extreme weather]] events such as heat waves, droughts, cyclones, blizzards and rainstorms.<ref name="":12"" /> Such events will continue to occur more often and with greater intensity.<ref>[https://www.livescience.com/37057-global-warming-effects.html Effects of Global Warming] {{Webarchive
column3: date=6 December 2019}}, Live Science, 12 August 2017</ref> Some individual [[Extreme event attribution
column4: extreme weather events are caused by climate change]].<ref>[https://www.ucsusa.org/sites/default/files/attach/2018/06/The-Science-Connecting-Extreme-Weather-to-Climate-Change.pdf The science connecting extreme weather to climate change] {{Webarchive
column6: date=25 September 2019}}, Fact sheet: Union of Concerned Scientists, June 2018.</ref>

column2: Effects of climate change on the water cycle}}

column1: Warming by greenhouse gas forcing has increased contrasts in rainfall amounts between wet and dry seasons.<ref name=""IPCC AR6 Ch8"">{{Harvnb
column4: p=8-6, line 51}}</ref> This means colloquially: ""wet seasons are getting wetter, dry seasons are getting drier"". Warming has also resulted in a detectable increase in the precipitation of northern [[Polar regions of Earth

column1: Higher temperatures lead to increased evaporation and surface drying. As the air warms, its water-holding capacity also increases, particularly over the oceans. Air holds 7% more [[water vapour]] for every degree Celsius it is warmed.<ref name=""IPCC AR6 Ch8_b2"">{{Harvnb
column4: p=8-6,8–119}}</ref> Changes have already been observed in the amount, intensity, frequency, and type of precipitation. Widespread increases in heavy precipitation have occurred even in places where total rain amounts have decreased.<ref>{{citation

column1: Global warming is expected to be accompanied by a reduction in rainfall in the subtropics and an increase in precipitation in subpolar latitudes and some [[equatorial region]]s. In other words, regions which are dry at present will generally become even drier, while regions that are currently wet will generally become even wetter. This projection does not apply to every locale, and in some cases can be modified by local conditions. Drying is projected to be strongest near the poleward margins of the subtropics (for example, [[South Africa]], [[southern Australia]], the [[Mediterranean basin
column3: south-western U.S.]]), a pattern that can be described as a poleward expansion of these semi-arid zones.<!-- This entire paragraph is based on the following reference --><ref name=""NOAA_GFDL_b"">

column2: title=Will the wet get wetter and the dry drier?

column1: In the case of [[precipitation]], the rising temperatures will intensify the Earth's [[water cycle]], increasing evaporation. Increased evaporation will result in more frequent and intense downpours and cause extended droughts in certain regions. As a result, storm-affected areas are likely to experience increases in precipitation and an increased risk of flooding. In contrast, areas far away from storm tracks are likely to experience less precipitation and an increased risk of drought.

Changes in regional climate are expected to include greater warming over land, with most warming at high northern [[latitudes]], and least warming over the [[Southern Ocean]] and parts of the North Atlantic Ocean.<ref name=IPCC_synthesis_2007>

IPCC, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spm.html Synthesis Report Summary for Policymakers], [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts], in {{Harvnb

</ref> Future changes in precipitation are expected to follow existing trends, with reduced precipitation over [[subtropical]] land areas, and increased precipitation at subpolar latitudes and some [[equator]]ial regions.<ref name=NOAA_GDFL_c>

column2: title=Will the wet get wetter and the dry drier?

column1: [[File:20211109 Frequency of extreme weather for different degrees of global warming - bar chart IPCC AR6 WG1 SPM.svg
column4: The [[IPCC Sixth Assessment Report]] (2021) projects large increases in both the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, for increasing degrees of global warming.<ref name=""IPCC6AR_ExtremeEvents"">{{cite book
column6: title=Climate Change 2021: The Physical Science Basis

column1: Global warming boosts the probability of [[extreme weather]] events such as [[heat wave]]s<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/11/science/earth/global-warming-makes-heat-waves-more-likely-study-finds.html ''Global Warming Makes Heat Waves More Likely, Study Finds''] {{Webarchive
column3: date=7 August 2018}} 10 July 2012 [[The New York Times]]</ref><ref>{{cite journal
column12: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
column20: doi-access=free}}</ref> where the daily maximum temperature exceeds the average maximum temperature by 5 °C (9 °F) for more than five consecutive days.<ref>[https://www.britannica.com/science/heat-wave-meteorology Heat wave: meteorology] {{Webarchive
column22: date=15 February 2020}}. Encyclopedia Britannica. Retrieved 1 April 2019.</ref> In the last 30–40 years, heat waves with high humidity have become more frequent and severe. Extremely hot nights have doubled in frequency. The area in which extremely hot summers are observed has increased 50–100 fold. Heat waves with high humidity pose a big risk to human health while heat waves with low humidity lead to dry conditions that increase [[wildfires]]. The mortality from extreme heat is larger than the mortality from hurricanes, lightning, tornadoes, floods, and earthquakes together.<ref name=""Heat Waves: The Details"">{{cite web

column1: It was estimated in 2013 that global warming had increased the probability of local record-breaking monthly temperatures worldwide by a factor of 5.<ref name=""Coumou_2013"">

column9: title=Global increase in record-breaking monthly-mean temperatures

column1: </ref> This was compared to a baseline climate in which no global warming had occurred. Using a medium global warming scenario, they project that by 2040, the number of monthly heat records globally could be more than 12 times greater than that of a scenario with no long-term warming.
Future climate change will include more very hot days and fewer very cold days.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes"">

IPCC (2013), Table SPM.1, in [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf Summary for Policymakers, p. 5] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140226155600/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb

</ref> The frequency, length and intensity of [[heat wave]]s will very likely increase over most land areas.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes"" /> Higher growth in anthropogenic GHG emissions would cause more frequent and severe temperature extremes.<ref>Stocker, T.F., ''et al.'' (2013), Temperature Extremes, Heat Waves and Warm Spells, in: TFE.9,  in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf Technical Summary, p. 111] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221070705/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
</ref> Globally, cold waves have decreased in frequency.<ref>{{cite book
column3: title=Climate Change 2021: The Physical Science Basis
column10: page=SPM-10}}</ref> There is some evidence climate change leads to a weakening of the [[polar vortex]], which would make the [[jet stream]] more wavy.<ref>{{Cite web
column17: language=en}}</ref> This would lead to outbursts of very cold winter weather across parts of Eurasia<ref>{{Cite web
column19: title=How global warming can cause Europe's harsh winter weather
column25: title=Climate change: Arctic warming linked to colder winters
column43: title=Linking Arctic variability and change with extreme winter weather in the United States
column55: title=Winters get warmer with climate change. So what explains Texas' cold snap in February?

column6: Frequency (vertical axis) of local June–July–August temperature anomalies (relative to 1951–1980 mean) for Northern Hemisphere land in units of local [[standard deviation]] (horizontal axis). The distribution of anomalies has shifted to the right due to global warming, meaning that unusually hot summers have become more common. This is analogous to the rolling of a die: cool summers now cover only half of one side of a six-sided die, white covers one side, red covers four sides, and an extremely hot (red-brown) anomaly covers half of one side.<ref name=Hansen_2012>

column2: title=The New Climate Dice: Public Perception of Climate Change
publisher=Dr James E. Hansen, Columbia University

column1: Global warming not only causes changes in tropical cyclones, it may also make some impacts from them worse via sea level rise. The intensity of tropical cyclones (hurricanes, typhoons, etc.) is projected to increase globally, with the proportion of [[Saffir–Simpson scale
column2: Category 4 and 5]] tropical cyclones increasing. Furthermore, the rate of rainfall is projected to increase, but trends in the future frequency on a global scale are not yet clear.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones"">Christensen, J.H.,''et al.'' (2013), Cyclones, in: Executive Summary, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf Chapter 14: Climate Phenomena and their Relevance for Future Regional Climate Change, p. 1220] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221075046/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column22: chapter=Chapter 6: Extremes, Abrupt Changes and Managing Risks
column28: url-status=live}}</ref> Changes in tropical cyclones vary by region.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones"" />

column1: Increases in temperature are expected to produce more intense convection over land and a higher frequency of the most severe storms.<ref name=""Genio_2007"">

column5: title=Will moist convection be stronger in a warmer climate?

column1: [[File:4207Typhoons Krosa Lekima & monsoon tidal flooding in Calumpit, Bulacan 19.jpg
column5: High tides flooding]] is increasing due to sea level rise, land subsidence, and the loss of natural barriers.<ref>{{Cite web
column15: alt=A large flat sheet of water reflects a grey sky with green tropical vegetation in the background]][[File:Flooding in the US Midwest June 2008.jpg
column18: Flooding in the [[Midwestern United States]], June 2008]]Increased rainfall intensity due to climate change can worsen flooding.<ref name=""IPCC AR6 Ch8_b"">{{Harvnb
column21: p=8-6, line 28; 8–119, line 18}}</ref> Sea level rise further increases risks of flooding: if sea levels rise by a further 0.15 m, 20% more people will be exposed to a 1 in a 100 year coastal flood, assuming no population growth and no further adaptation. With an extra 0.75 m, this rises to a doubling of people exposed.<ref>{{cite book
column24: title=Climate Change 2022: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability

column1: It has been determined that climate change and variability have the potential to drastically impact human exposure to flood hazards, but this comes with a lot of uncertainty due to multiple climate models.<ref>{{Cite journal
column7: title=The impacts of climate change on river flood risk at the global scale
column16: doi-access=free}}</ref> Similar to droughts, climate change has also been shown to have the potential to increase the frequency of bigger storm events.<ref>{{Cite journal
column34: title=Global flood risk under climate change
column43: issn=1758-6798}}</ref> This increase in the frequency of large storm events would alter existing [[Intensity-duration-frequency curve
column44: Intensity-Duration-Frequency curves (IDF curves)]] due to the change in frequency, but also by lifting and steepening the curves in the future.<ref>{{Cite journal
column52: title=Climate change impact on short-duration extreme precipitation and intensity–duration–frequency curves over Europe

column1: Between 1994 and 2006, satellite observations shows an 18% increase in the flow of freshwater into the world's oceans, partly from melting ice and partly from increased precipitation driven by an increase in global ocean evaporation. Much of the increase is in areas which already experience high rainfall. One effect, as perhaps experienced in the [[2010 Pakistan floods]], is to overwhelm flood control infrastructure.<ref>{{Cite journal
column13: title=Satellite-based global-ocean mass balance estimates of interannual variability and emerging trends in continental freshwater discharge
column14: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

column1: Climate change affects multiple factors associated with [[drought]]s, such as how much rain falls and how fast the rain [[Evaporation
column2: evaporates]] again. Warming over land drives an increase in atmospheric evaporative demand which will increase the severity and frequency of droughts around much of the world.<ref name=""IPCC AR6 WG1 Ch8_c"">{{Harvnb
column13: title=Climate Change and Drought: From Past to Future
column20: s2cid=53624756}}</ref> Due to limitations on how much data is available about drought in the past, it is often impossible to confidently [[Attribution of recent climate change
column21: attribute]] droughts to human-induced climate change. Some areas however, such as the [[Mediterranean Sea
column22: Mediterranean]] and [[California]], already show a clear human signature.<ref>{{Cite journal
column30: title=Climate Change and Drought: a Perspective on Drought Indices
column37: s2cid=134811844}}</ref> Their impacts are aggravated because of increased water demand, population growth, urban expansion, and environmental protection efforts in many areas.<ref>{{Cite journal

column1: In 2019 the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change issued a [[Special Report on Climate Change and Land]]. The main statements of the report include:<ref name=""IPCC SRCCL"">{{Harvnb
column7: p=7,8}}</ref> In the years 1960 – 2013 the area of drylands in drought, increased by 1% per year. In the year 2015 around 500 million people lived in areas that was impacted by [[desertification]] in the years 1980s – 2000s. People who live in the areas affected by land degradation and desertification are ""increasingly negatively affected by climate change"".

column1: [[File:Wildfire acres burned in the United States, OWID.svg
column4: Average U.S. acreage burned annually by wildfires has almost tripled in three decades.<ref name=""OWID_thru2021"">{{cite web
column6: title=Wildfire acres burned in the United States
column11: website=OurWorldInData}} Data published by National Interagency Coordination Center; National Interagency Fire Center. ([https://web.archive.org/web/20211011082005/https://www.nifc.gov/fire-information/statistics/wildfires archive of NIFC data])</ref>]]Globally, climate change promotes the type of weather that makes wildfires more likely. In some areas, an increase of wildfires has been attributed directly to climate change. That warmer climate conditions pose more risks of wildfire is consistent with [[Proxy (climate)
column12: evidence from Earth's past]]: there was more fire in warmer periods, and less in colder climatic periods.<ref name="":02"">{{cite web
column25: title=Climate Change Increases the Risk of Wildfires
column28: website=ScienceBrief}}</ref> Climate change increases evaporation, which can cause vegetation to dry out. When a fire starts in an area with very dry vegetation, it can spread rapidly. Higher temperatures can also make the fire season longer, the time period in which severe wildfires are most likely. In regions where snow is disappearing, the fire season may get particularly more extended.<ref name="":13"">{{Cite web
column32: title=Explainer: How climate change is affecting wildfires around the world

column1: Even though weather conditions are raising the risks of wildfires, the total area burnt by wildfires has decreased globally. This is mostly the result of the conversion of [[savanna]] into [[croplands]], after which there is less forest area that can burn. [[Prescribed burning]], an indigenous practice in the US and Australia, can reduce the area burnt too, and may form an adaptation to increased risk.<ref name="":13"" /> The carbon released from wildfires can further increase greenhouse gas concentrations. This feedback is not yet fully integrated into climate models.<ref>{{cite book
column3: title=Climate Change 2021: The Physical Science Basis

column4: Oceans have taken up over 90% of the excess heat accumulated on Earth due to global warming, reducing the amount of heat building up in the atmosphere.<ref name=""statecl"">{{cite book
column6: title=State of the Climate in 2009, as appearing in the July 2010 issue (Vol. 91) of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society (BAMS). Supplemental and Summary Materials: Report at a Glance: Highlights
column8: publisher=Website of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration: National Climatic Data Center

column1: [[File:Evidence of global warming - time series of seasonal (red dots) and annual average (black line) of global upper ocean heat content for the 0-700m layer between 1955-2008.gif
column3: alt=Refer to caption and adjacent text
column4: [[Time series]] of seasonal (red dots) and annual average (black line) global upper ocean heat content for the 0-700m layer between 1955 and 2008. The graph shows that ocean heat content has increased over this time period.<ref name=""NOAA_2010_FAQ_b"" />]]

column2: image1            = Diagram showing ten indicators of global warming.png
Effects of climate change on oceans}}

column1: The main physical effects of global warming on the world [[ocean]] are [[sea level rise]], [[ocean heat content
column3: loss of oxygen]], an increase in [[marine heatwave]]s,<ref name=""SROCC_SPM_20190925"">{{Cite report
column10: series=Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate (SROCC)
column12: url-status=live}}</ref> and changes to [[ocean currents]] including a possible slowdown or [[shutdown of thermohaline circulation]]. These physical changes disturb marine ecosystems, which can cause both extinctions and population explosions, change the distribution of species,<ref name=""SROCC_SPM_20190925"" /> and impact coastal fishing and tourism.

column1: Warming of the ocean surface due to higher air temperatures leads to increased water temperature stratification.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite book
column25: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column52: last11=O'Donoghue}}</ref> The decline in mixing of the ocean layers piles up warm water near the surface while reducing cold, deep water circulation. The reduced up and down mixing reduces the ability of the ocean to absorb heat, directing a larger fraction of future warming toward the atmosphere and land. Energy available for tropical cyclones and other storms is expected to increase, [[nutrient]]s for fish in the upper ocean layers are set to decrease, as well as the capacity of the oceans to [[Carbon sink
column57: title=Mixing of the planet's ocean waters is slowing down, speeding up global warming, study finds

column1: Warmer water cannot contain as much oxygen as cold water, changing the gas exchange equilibrium to reduce ocean oxygen levels and increase oxygen in the atmosphere. Increased thermal stratification may lead to increases in respiration rates of organic matter, further decreasing water oxygen content. The ocean has already lost oxygen, throughout the entire water column and [[oxygen minimum zone]]s are expanding worldwide.<ref name="":0"" /> This has adverse consequences for ocean life.<ref>{{Cite journal
column8: title=Abrupt Climate Change and Extinction Events in Earth History
column25: title=Long-term ocean oxygen depletion in response to carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels

column4: A part of the [[Great Barrier Reef]] in [[Australia]] in 2016 after a coral bleaching event]]

column5: This map shows the general location and direction of the warm surface (red) and cold deep water (blue) currents of the [[thermohaline circulation]]. [[Salinity]] is represented by color in units of the Practical Salinity Scale. Low values (blue) are less saline, while high values (orange) are more saline.<ref>{{cite web
column6: author=Riebeek, H.. design by R. Simmon
column8: title=Paleoclimatology: Explaining the Evidence: Explaining Rapid Climate Change: Tales from the Ice
column14: publisher=NASA Earth Observatory}}</ref>]]The [[Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation]] (AMOC), an important component of the Earth's climate system, is a northward flow of warm, salty water in the upper layers of the [[Atlantic ocean
column15: Atlantic]] and a southward flow of colder water in the deep Atlantic.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change"">

column4: title=Abrupt Climate Change. A report by the US Climate Change Science Program (CCSP) and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research

column3: date=November 2012}} Potential impacts associated with AMOC changes include reduced warming or (in the case of abrupt change) absolute cooling of northern high-latitude areas near Greenland and north-western Europe, an increased warming of [[Southern Hemisphere]] high-latitudes, tropical drying, as well as changes to [[marine ecosystem]]s, terrestrial vegetation, oceanic {{chem
column5: 2}} uptake, oceanic oxygen concentrations, and shifts in fisheries.<ref>{{citation
column11: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-5-3.html Sec. 19.3.5.3 Possible changes in the North Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (MOC)]
column12: chapter=Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change

column1: According to a 2019 assessment in the IPCC's [[Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate]] it is very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement) that the strength of the AMOC will decrease further over the course of the 21st century.<ref name="":6"">{{Cite book
column25: chapter=Chapter 6: Extremes, Abrupt Changes and Managing Risks
column47: last15=Abdulla}}</ref> Warming is still expected to occur over most of the European region downstream of the [[North Atlantic Current]] in response to increasing GHGs, as well as over [[North America]]. With medium confidence, the IPCC report stated that it is very unlikely (less than 10% probability) that the AMOC will collapse in the 21st century.<ref name="":6"" /> The potential consequences of such a collapse could be severe.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change"" />{{Rp

column2: Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate}}

column1: [[File:20210125 The Cryosphere - Floating and grounded ice - imbalance - climate change.png
column4: Earth lost 28 trillion tonnes of ice between 1994 and 2017, with melting grounded ice (ice sheets and glaciers) raising the global sea level by 34.6 ±3.1 mm.<ref name=""Cryosphere_20210125"" /> The rate of ice loss has risen by 57% since the 1990s−from 0.8 to 1.2 trillion tonnes per year.<ref name=""Cryosphere_20210125"">{{cite journal

column1: The [[cryosphere]], the area of the Earth covered by snow or ice, is extremely sensitive to changes in global climate.<ref>[https://serc.carleton.edu/eslabs/cryosphere/1c.html Getting to Know the Cryosphere] {{Webarchive
column3: date=15 December 2019 }}, Earth Labs</ref> Northern Hemisphere average annual snow cover has declined in recent decades. This pattern is consistent with warmer global temperatures. Some of the largest declines have been observed in the [[spring (season)

column2: title=NOAA: NESDIS: NCDC: Frequently Asked Questions: How do we know the Earth's climate is warming?
date=March 2022}}  During the 21st century, [[snow cover]] is projected to continue its retreat in almost all regions.<ref>{{Cite book

column1: Since the beginning of the twentieth century, there has been a widespread [[Retreat of glaciers since 1850
column3: title=Mass Balance of Mountain Glaciers in 2011
column10: 2012}}</ref>  The melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column11: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s will continue to contribute to sea level rise over long time-scales.<ref>{{Cite book
column35: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column59: last15=van de Wal}}</ref> The Greenland ice sheet loss is mainly driven by melt from the top, whereas Antarctic ice loss is driven by warm ocean water melting the [[Outlet glacier
column63: title=Climate Change 2021: The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of Working Group I to the [[IPCC Sixth Assessment Report
column64: Sixth Assessment Report]] of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate
column72: chapter=Chapter 9: Ocean, Cryosphere, and Sea Level Change

column1: Future melt of the [[West Antarctic Ice Sheet
column2: West Antarctic ice sheet]] is potentially abrupt under a high emission scenario, as a consequence of a partial collapse.<ref name="":2"">{{Cite book
column26: chapter=Chapter 6: Extremes, Abrupt Changes and Managing Risks
column48: last15=Abdulla}}</ref> Part of the ice sheet is grounded on [[bedrock]] below sea level, making it possibly vulnerable to the self-enhancing process of [[marine ice sheet instability]]. A further hypothesis is that ''marine ice cliff instability'' would also contribute to a partial collapse, but limited evidence is available for its importance.<ref>{{Cite book
column92: last13=Schuur}}</ref> A partial collapse of the ice sheet would lead to rapid sea level rise and a local decrease in ocean salinity. It would be irreversible on a timescale between decades and millennia.<ref name="":2"" />

column1: In contrast to the West Antarctic ice sheet, melt of the [[Greenland ice sheet]] is projected to be taking place more gradually over millennia.<ref name="":2"" /> Sustained warming between 1 °C (low confidence) and 4 °C (medium confidence) would lead to a complete loss of the ice sheet, contributing 7 m to sea levels globally.<ref>{{Cite book
column25: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column49: last15=van de Wal}}</ref> The ice loss could become irreversible due to a further self-enhancing feedback: the elevation-surface mass balance feedback. When ice melts on top of the ice sheet, the elevation drops. As air temperature is higher at lower [[altitude]], this promotes further melt.<ref>{{Cite book
column73: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities

column1: Sea ice reflects 50% to 70% of the incoming solar radiation, while 6% of the incoming solar energy is reflected by the ocean. With less solar energy, the sea ice absorbs and holds the surface colder, which can be a positive feedback toward climate change.<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title=Thermodynamics: Albedo {{!}} National Snow and Ice Data Center
column8: website=nsidc.org}}</ref> As the climate warms, snow cover and sea ice extent decrease. Large-scale measurements of [[sea ice
column9: sea-ice]] have only been possible since the satellite era. The age of the sea ice is an important feature of the state of the sea ice cover.<ref name=""NOAA_2013"">

column1: </ref> Sea ice in the [[Antarctic]] has hardly changed since those measurements began. Though extending the Antarctic sea-ice record back in time is more difficult due to the lack of direct observations in this part of the world.<ref name=""NOAA_2010_FAQ_a"">

column2: title=NOAA: NESDIS: NCDC: Frequently Asked Questions: Is the climate warming?

Arctic sea ice began to decline]] at the beginning of the twentieth century but the rate is accelerating. Since 1979, satellite records indicate the decline in summer sea ice coverage has been about 13% per decade.<ref>[https://www.carbonbrief.org/impacts-of-a-melting-cryosphere-ice-loss-around-the-world Impacts of a melting cryosphere  ice loss around the world] {{Webarchive
column12: 2012}}</ref> The thickness of sea ice has also decreased by 66% or 2.0 m over the last six decades with a shift from permanent ice to largely seasonal ice cover.<ref>{{Cite journal
column16: title=Arctic sea ice thickness, volume, and multiyear ice coverage: losses and coupled variability (1958–2018)
column23: doi-access=free}}</ref> While ice-free summers are expected to be rare at 1.5 °C degrees of warming, they are set to occur at least once every decade at a warming level of 2.0 °C.<ref>{{Cite book
column36: url-status=live}}</ref> The Arctic will likely become ice-free at the end of some summers before 2050.<ref name=""IPCC AR6 WG1 Ch9_a"">{{Harvnb

column3: Arctic methane emissions}}The southern part of the [[Arctic]] region (home to 4 million people) has experienced a temperature rise of 1 °C to 3 °C (1.8 °F to 5.4 °F) over the last 50 years.<ref name=""The_Guardian_2018"">

column5: title=Arctic warming: scientists alarmed by 'crazy' temperature rises

column1: </ref> Canada, [[Alaska]] and Russia are experiencing initial melting of [[permafrost]]. This may disrupt ecosystems and by increasing bacterial activity in the soil lead to these areas becoming carbon sources instead of [[Carbon sink

column4: title=How rapidly is permafrost changing and what are the impacts of these changes?

column1: </ref> Eastern [[Siberia]]'s permafrost is gradually disappearing in the southern regions, leading to the loss of nearly 11% of Siberia's nearly 11,000 lakes since 1971.<ref name=""The_Guardian_2015"">

column5: title=Shrinking lakes of Siberia blamed on global warming

column1: </ref> At the same time, western Siberia is at the initial stage where melting permafrost is creating new lakes, which will eventually start disappearing as in the east. Furthermore, permafrost melting will eventually cause methane release from melting permafrost peat bogs.{{excerpt

column2: Effects of climate change on ecosystems}}

column1: Recent warming has strongly affected natural biological systems.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts"">{{citation
column6: chapter=Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> Species worldwide are moving poleward to colder areas. On land, species move to higher elevations, whereas marine species find colder water at greater depths.<ref name="":8"">{{Cite journal
column35: title=Biodiversity redistribution under climate change: Impacts on ecosystems and human well-being
column50: hdl-access=free}}</ref> Of the drivers with the biggest global impact on [[nature]], climate change ranks third over the five decades before 2020, with only [[Land development
column51: change in land use]] and sea use, and direct exploitation of organisms having a greater impact.<ref>{{Cite book
column55: title=Summary for policymakers of the global assessment report on biodiversity and ecosystem services of the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services.

column1: The impacts of climate change in nature and nature's contributions to humans are projected to become more pronounced in the next few decades.<ref>{{Cite book
column5: title=Summary for policymakers of the global assessment report on biodiversity and ecosystem services of the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services.
column14: url-status=live}}</ref> Examples of climatic disruptions include fire, drought, pest [[infestation]], invasion of species, storms, and [[coral bleaching]] events. The stresses caused by climate change, added to other stresses on ecological systems (e.g. land conversion, [[land degradation]], [[harvest]]ing, and [[pollution]]), threaten substantial damage to or complete loss of some unique ecosystems, and [[extinction]] of some critically endangered species.<ref>Van Riper, Charles. (2014) [https://purl.fdlp.gov/GPO/gpo50857 Projecting Climate Effects on Birds and Reptiles of the Southwestern United States.] {{Webarchive
column16: date=23 July 2021 }} Reston, Va.: [[United States Department of the Interior
column17: U.S. Department of the Interior]], [[United States Geological Survey
column19: interactions between species]] within ecosystems are often disrupted because species from one location do not move to colder habitats at the same rate, giving rise to rapid changes in the functioning of the ecosystem.<ref name="":8"" /> Impacts include changes in regional rainfall patterns, earlier leafing of [[tree]]s and [[plant]]s over many regions; movements of species to higher latitudes and altitudes in the Northern Hemisphere; changes in [[bird migration]]s in Europe, North America and Australia; and shifting of the oceans' [[plankton]] and [[fish]] from cold- to warm-adapted communities.<ref name=""NASA_2008"">

column2: title=Science Briefs: Warming Climate is Changing Life on Global Scale
publisher=Website of the US National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Goddard Institute for Space Studies

column3: The Arctic is heating up twice as fast as the global mean. Seas are on track to rise one to four feet higher by 2100, threatening coastal habitats.<ref name=""February 23"">{{Cite web
column7: title=Global Climate Change: What You Need to Know

column2: Effects of climate change on terrestrial animals
column3: Effects of climate change on plant biodiversity}}

column1: Climate change has been estimated to be a major driver of [[biodiversity loss]] in cool [[conifer]] forests, [[savanna]]s, [[mediterranean climate
column2: mediterranean-climate]] systems, [[tropical forest]]s, and the [[Arctic tundra]].<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts"">{{citation
column4: title=Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 2007
column5: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch4s4-4-11.html Sec. 4.4.11 Global synthesis including impacts on biodiversity]
column6: chapter=Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column15: land-use]] change may be a stronger driver of biodiversity loss, at least in the near-term.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts"" /> Beyond the year 2050, climate change may be the major driver for biodiversity loss globally.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts"" /> Climate change interacts with other pressures such as habitat modification, pollution and [[invasive species]]. Interacting with these pressures, climate change increases extinction risk for a large fraction of terrestrial and freshwater species.<ref>{{Cite book
column37: chapter=Chapter 4: Terrestrial and Inland Water Systems
column46: url-status=live}}</ref> Between 1% and 50% of species in different groups were assessed to be at substantially higher risk of extinction due to climate change.<ref name="":1"">{{Cite book
column68: chapter=Chapter 4: Terrestrial and Inland Water Systems

column1: [[File:20210331 Global tree cover loss - World Resources Institute.svg
column4: The rate of global tree cover loss has approximately doubled since 2001, to an annual loss approaching an area the size of Italy.<ref name=WorldResourcesInst_202103031>{{cite news

column2: url-status=live }} ● ''Mongabay'' graphing WRI data from {{cite web
title=Forest Loss / How much tree cover is lost globally each year?
publisher=World Resources Institute — Global Forest Review

column1: Rainfall that falls on the [[Amazon rainforest]] is recycled when it [[evaporation
column2: evaporates]] back into the atmosphere instead of [[surface runoff
column3: running off]] away from the rainforest. This water is essential for sustaining the rainforest. [[Deforestation of the Amazon rainforest
column4: Due to deforestation]] the rainforest is losing this ability, exacerbated by climate change which brings more frequent droughts to the area. The higher frequency of droughts seen in the first two decades of the 21st century, as well as other data, signal that a [[Tipping points in the climate system
column5: tipping point]] from rainforest to [[savanna]] might be close. One study concluded that this ecosystem could enter a mode of a 50-years-long collapse to a savanna around 2021, after which it would become increasingly and disproportionally more difficult to prevent or reverse this shift.<ref>{{cite journal
column11: title=Amazon tipping point: Last chance for action
column22: title=Ecosystems the size of Amazon 'can collapse within decades'
column37: title=Regime shifts occur disproportionately faster in larger ecosystems

column2: Effects of climate change on oceans}}
Marine heatwaves]] have seen an increased frequency and have widespread impacts on life in the oceans, such as mass dying events and [[coral bleaching]].<ref>{{Cite journal
column27: title=Marine heatwaves threaten global biodiversity and the provision of ecosystem services
column41: Harmful algae blooms]] have increased in response to warming waters, loss of oxygen and [[eutrophication]].<ref>{{Cite book
column65: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column88: first14=T.}}</ref> Between one-quarter and one-third of our fossil fuel emissions are consumed by the earth's oceans, which are now 30 percent more acidic than they were in pre-industrial times. This [[Ocean acidification
column89: acidification]] poses a serious threat to aquatic life, particularly creatures such as oysters, clams, and coral with calcified shells or skeletons.<ref name=""February 23"" /> Melting sea ice destroys habitat, including for [[algae]] that grows on its underside.<ref name=""Riebesell"">{{Cite journal
column97: title=Sensitivities of marine carbon fluxes to ocean change
column105: doi-access=free}}</ref>  It is likely that the oceans warmed faster between 1993 and 2017 compared to the period starting in 1969.<ref>{{Cite book
column129: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities

column2: Warm water coral reefs]] are very sensitive to global warming and [[ocean acidification]]. Coral reefs provide a [[habitat]] for thousands of species and [[ecosystem services]] such as [[coastal protection]] and food. The resilience of reefs can be improved by curbing local pollution and overfishing, but 70–90% of today's warm water coral reefs will disappear even if warming is kept to 1.5 °C.<ref name="":14"">{{Cite book
column26: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column50: first18=G.}}</ref> Coral reefs are not the only framework organisms, organisms that build physical structures that form habitats for other sea creatures, affected by climate change: [[mangroves]] and [[seagrass]] are considered to be at moderate risk for lower levels of global warming according to the [[Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate]].<ref>{{Cite book
column74: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems

column2: Tipping points in the climate system
Self-reinforcing feedbacks]] amplify climate change.<ref>{{cite book
column23: chapter=Chapter 15: Potential Surprises: Compound Extremes and Tipping Elements
column31: url-status=live}}</ref> The climate system exhibits ""threshold behaviour"" or [[Tipping points in the climate system
column32: tipping points]] when these feedbacks lead parts of the Earth system into a new state, such as the runaway loss of ice sheets or the destruction of too many forests.<ref name="":3"">{{cite book
column53: chapter=Chapter 15: Potential Surprises: Compound Extremes and Tipping Elements
column62: title=Climate emergency: world 'may have crossed tipping points'
column71: url-status=live}}</ref> Tipping points are studied using data from [[Paleoclimatology
column72: Earth's distant past]] and by physical modelling.<ref name="":3"" /> There is already moderate risk of global tipping points at 1 °C above pre-industrial temperatures, and that risk becomes high at 2.5 °C.<ref>{{Cite book
column96: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems

column1: Tipping points are ""perhaps the most 'dangerous' aspect of future climate changes"", leading to irreversible impacts on society.<ref>{{Cite journal
column11: title=Stochastic integrated assessment of climate tipping points indicates the need for strict climate policy
column25: url-status=live}}</ref> Many tipping points are interlinked, so that triggering one may lead to a cascade of effects,<ref>{{Cite journal
column41: title=Climate tipping points — too risky to bet against
column49: bibcode=2019Natur.575..592L}}</ref> even well below 2 °C of warming.<ref>{{cite news
column52: title=Climate tipping points could topple like dominoes, warn scientists
column59: url-status=live }}</ref> A 2018 study states that 45% of environmental problems, including those caused by climate change are interconnected and make the risk of a [[domino effect]] bigger.<ref>{{cite journal
column68: title=Cascading regime shifts within and across scales
column81: title=Risks of 'domino effect' of tipping points greater than thought, study says

column1: There are a number of climate change impacts on the environment that may be irreversible, at least over the timescale of many human generations.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities"">{{citation
column7: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-2.html Sec.19.2 Criteria for selecting 'key' vulnerabilities: Persistence and reversibility]
column8: chapter=Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column13: url-status=live}}</ref> These include the large-scale singularities such as the melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, and changes to the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities"" /> In biological systems, the extinction of species would be an irreversible impact.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities"" /> In social systems, unique [[culture]]s may be lost<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities"" /> or the survival of endangered languages may be exacerbated due to climate change.<ref name=""climate and language"">{{cite journal
column24: title=Impact Assessment of Storm Surge and Climate Change-Enhanced Sea Level Rise on Atoll Nations: A Case Study of the Tarawa Atoll, Kiribati
column30: date=10 November 2021}}</ref> For example, humans living on [[atoll]] islands face risks due to sea level rise, sea surface warming, and increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.<ref>{{cite journal
column46: s2cid=55644531}} This paper was published in 2001 as [http://www.tyndall.ac.uk/sites/default/files/wp9.pdf Tyndall Centre Working Paper 9] {{Webarchive

column1: == Impacts on health, food security and water security ==

column2: Effects of climate change on human health

column1: === Food security, agriculture and marine food production ===

column2: Effects of climate change on agriculture
column3: Effects of climate change on fisheries}}

column1: Climate change will impact agriculture and food production around the world due to the effects of elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere; higher temperatures; altered precipitation and [[transpiration]] regimes; increased frequency of extreme events; and modified [[weed]], [[pest (organism)
column9: chapter=Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column14: url-status=live}}</ref> Droughts result in crop failures and the loss of pasture for livestock.<ref>{{Cite journal
column22: title=Measuring economic impacts of drought: A review and discussion
column32: access-date=14 July 2019}}</ref> The rate of [[soil erosion]] is 10–20 times higher than the rate of soil accumulation in agricultural areas that use [[no-till farming]]. In areas with [[Tilling (agriculture)
column33: tilling]] it is 100 times higher. Climate change makes this type of land degradation and desertification worse.{{sfn

column1: Climate change is projected to negatively affect all four pillars of food security: not only how much food is available, but also how easy food is to access (prices), food quality and how stable the [[food system]] is.<ref>{{Cite book

column2: fisheries]] have already seen their catch decrease because of global warming and changes in [[Biogeochemical cycle
column3: biochemical cycles]]. In combination with [[overfishing]], warming waters decrease the maximum catch potential.<ref>{{Cite book
column12: IPCC SROCC DRAFT Summary for Policymakers
column20: url-status=live}}</ref> Global catch potential is projected to reduce further in 2050 by less than 4% if emissions are reduced strongly, and by about 8% for very high future emissions, with growth in the [[Arctic Ocean]].<ref>{{Cite book
column44: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities

column1: Between 1.5 and 2.5 billion people live in areas with regular [[water security]] issues. If global warming would reach {{val
column3: u=degC}}, water insecurity would affect about twice as many people.<ref name=""IPCC2022_FAQ4.1"">{{cite book
column6: title=Climate Change 2022: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability
column10: series=Contribution of Working Group II to the [[IPCC Sixth Assessment Report
column11: Sixth Assessment Report]] of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
column15: chapter-url=https://report.ipcc.ch/ar6wg2/pdf/IPCC_AR6_WGII_FinalDraft_Chapter04.pdf}}</ref> Water resources are projected to decrease in most dry subtropical regions and [[mid-latitudes]], but increase in high latitudes. However, as streamflow becomes more variable, even regions with increased water resources can experience additional short-term [[Water scarcity
column44: url-status=live}}</ref> The arid regions of India, China, the US and Africa are already seeing dry spells and drought impact water availability.<ref name=""IPCC2022_FAQ4.1"" />

column1: [[Water resources]] can be affected by climate change in various ways. The total amount of [[freshwater]] available can change, for instance due to [[dry spell]]s or droughts. Heavy rainfall and flooding can have an impact on water quality: pollutants can be transported into water bodies by the increased [[surface runoff]]. In coastal regions, more salt may find its way into water resources due to higher sea levels and more intense storms. Higher temperatures also directly degrade water quality: warm water contains less oxygen.<ref name=""IPCC2022_FAQ4.1"" />{{excerpt
column2: Water security#Changes in the future environment (climate change)

column1: The effects of climate change on humans are far reaching. Climate change impacts [[Effects of climate change on human health
column2: health]], the availability of drinking water and food, [[Economic inequality
column3: inequality]] and economic growth. The effects of climate change are often interlinked and can exacerbate each other as well as existing vulnerabilities.<ref>{{cite journal
column9: title=Double exposure: assessing the impacts of climate change within the context of economic globalization
column24: title=Climate change and shifts in cropping systems together exacerbate China's water scarcity
column56: title=Climate change and interconnected risks to sustainable development in the Mediterranean
column74: last12=Snoussi}}</ref> The impacts are often exacerbated by related environmental disruptions and pressures such as [[environmental pollution
column76: title=MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the 2021 UN Climate Change Conference in Glasgow, UK (COP26)
column84: reason=The current source is insufficiently reliable ([[WP:NOTRS]]).
column85: date=March 2022}} Some areas may become too hot for humans to live in<ref>{{cite news
column89: title=One billion people will live in insufferable heat within 50 years – study
column105: title=Future of the human climate niche
column106: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
column113: doi-access=free}}</ref> while people in some areas may experience [[Internally displaced person
column114: internal]] or long-distance displacement (and thus become [[climate refugees]]) triggered by climate change related changes or disasters.

column1: The effects of climate change, in combination with the sustained increases in greenhouse gas emissions, have led scientists to characterize it as a ""climate emergency"" or ""[[climate crisis]]"".<ref>{{Cite journal
column13: title=World Scientists' Warning of a Climate Emergency
column25: url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="":7"">World Scientists' Warning of a Climate Emergency, William J Ripple, Christopher Wolf, Thomas M Newsome, Phoebe Barnard, William R Moomaw.  BioScience, biz088, https://doi.org/10.1093/biosci/biz088.  A correction has been published: [https://academic.oup.com/bioscience/advance-article/doi/10.1093/biosci/biz152/5670749 BioScience, biz152] {{Webarchive
column29: date=28 February 2020 }}</ref><ref>[https://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/scientists-around-world-declare-climate-emergency-180973462/ Scientists Around the World Declare 'Climate Emergency'] {{Webarchive
column31: date=16 December 2019 }}, Smithsonian Magazine, 5 November 2019</ref> Some climate researchers<ref>[https://edition.cnn.com/2019/06/04/health/climate-change-existential-threat-report-intl/index.html Climate change could pose 'existential threat' by 2050: report] {{Webarchive
column33: date=27 January 2020 }}, CNN, 5 June 2019.</ref><ref>[https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-019-03595-0 Climate tipping points — too risky to bet against] {{Webarchive
column35: date=5 February 2020 }}, Nature, 27 November 2019.</ref> and activists<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2019/sep/25/greta-thunberg-showed-the-world-what-it-means-to-lead Greta Thunberg showed the world what it means to lead] {{Webarchive
column37: date=2021-10-29 }}, ''The Guardian,'' 25 September 2019</ref> have called it an ""existential threat to civilization"".

column4: Business activities affected by climate changed as found in the [[European Investment Bank]] Investment Survey 2020 ]]

column1: Economic forecasts of the impact of global warming vary considerably. Researchers have warned that current economic modelling may seriously underestimate the impact of potentially catastrophic climate change, and point to the need for new models that give a more accurate picture of potential damages. Nevertheless, one 2018 study found that potential global economic gains if countries implement mitigation strategies to comply with the 2 °C target set at the Paris Agreement are in the vicinity of US$17 trillion per year up to 2100 compared to a very high emission scenario.<ref>{{Cite journal
column9: title=The Effects of Climate Change on GDP by Country and the Global Economic Gains From Complying With the Paris Climate Accord

column1: Global losses reveal rapidly rising costs due to extreme weather events since the 1970s.<ref name="":12"">{{citation
column3: title=Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 2007
column4: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-8-5.html Sec. 1.3.8.5 Summary of disasters and hazards]
column5: chapter=Chapter 1: Assessment of observed changes and responses in natural and managed systems
column14: Socio-economic]] factors have contributed to the observed trend of global losses, such as population growth and increased [[wealth]].<ref>{{Citation
column17: title=Observed and Projected Impacts from Extreme Weather Events: Implications for Loss and Damage
column19: work=Loss and Damage from Climate Change: Concepts, Methods and Policy Options
column23: series=Climate Risk Management, Policy and Governance
column34: doi-access=free}}</ref> Part of the growth is also related to regional climatic factors, e.g., changes in precipitation and flooding events. It is difficult to quantify the relative impact of socio-economic factors and climate change on the observed trend.<ref name=""disaster losses"">{{citation
column44: 2001}}.</ref> The trend does, however, suggest increasing vulnerability of social systems to climate change.<ref name=""disaster losses"" />

column1: Climate change has contributed towards global economic inequality. Wealthy countries in colder regions have either felt little overall economic impact from climate change, or possibly benefited, whereas poor hotter countries very likely grew less than if global warming had not occurred.<ref>{{Cite journal
column7: title=Global warming has increased global economic inequality
column8: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
column19: title=Climate Change 2022: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability
column23: series=Contribution of Working Group II to the [[IPCC Sixth Assessment Report
column24: Sixth Assessment Report]] of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
column25: chapter=Chapter 1: Point of Departure and Key Concept

column1: The total economic impacts from climate change are difficult to estimate, but increase for higher temperature changes.<ref>*{{Cite book
column10: IPCC AR5 WG2 Summary for Policymakers
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> For instance, total damages are estimated to be 90% less if global warming is limited to 1.5 °C compared to 3.66 °C, a warming level chosen to represent no mitigation.<ref name="":9"">{{Cite book
column41: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5 ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column68: url-status=live}}</ref> One study found a 3.5% reduction in global [[GDP]] by the end of the century if warming is limited to 3 °C, excluding the potential effect of tipping points. Another study noted that global economic impact is underestimated by a factor of two to eight when tipping points are excluded from consideration.<ref name="":9"" /> In the Oxford Economics high emission scenario, a temperature rise of 2 degrees by 2050 would reduce global GDP by 2.5% – 7.5%. By the year 2100 in this case, the temperature would rise by 4 degrees, which could reduce the global GDP by 30% in the worst case.<ref>{{cite web
column71: title=Global GDP will suffer at least a 3% hit by 2050 from unchecked climate change, say economists

column1: ==== Most affected sectors apart from agriculture and fisheries ====

[[Thermal power station]]s (fossil fuel plants and [[nuclear power plants]]) depend on water to cool them. Not only is there increased demand for fresh water, but climate change can increase the likelihood of [[drought]] and [[Water shortage
column2: fresh water shortages]]. Another impact for thermal power plants, is that increasing the temperatures in which they operate reduces their efficiency and hence their output.<ref name=""ODI1"">Dr. Frauke Urban and Dr. Tom Mitchell 2011. [https://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.825.4966&rep=rep1&type=pdf Climate change, disasters and electricity generation] {{webarchive
column4: date=20 September 2012}}. London: [[Overseas Development Institute]] and [[Institute of Development Studies]]</ref> Changes in the amount of river flow correlate with the amount of energy produced by a dam. The result of diminished river flow can be a power shortage in areas that depend heavily on [[hydroelectric power]]. [[Brazil]] in particular, is vulnerable due to its having reliance on hydroelectricity as increasing temperatures, lower water flow, and alterations in the rainfall regime, could reduce total energy production by 7% annually by the end of the century.<ref name=""ODI1"" />

column1: Oil and natural gas infrastructure is affected by the effects of climate change and the increased risk of disasters such as [[storm]], [[cyclone]]s, [[flooding]] and [[Sea level rise
column7: title=40% of Oil and Gas Reserves Threatened by Climate Change
column14: New Orleans submerged after Hurricane Katrina]]

column1: [[Insurance]] is an important tool to manage risks, but often unavailable to poorer households. Due to climate change, premiums are going up for certain types of insurance, such as [[flood insurance]]. Poor adaptation to climate change further widens the gap between what people can afford and the costs of insurance, as risks increase.<ref>{{Cite journal
column9: title=How insurance can support climate resilience
column18: issn=1758-6798}}</ref> In 2019, Munich Re noted that climate change could cause [[home insurance]] to become unaffordable for households at or below average incomes.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Climate change could make insurance too expensive for most people – report

column1: Roads, airport runways, railway lines and pipelines, (including [[oil pipeline]]s, [[sanitary sewer
column2: sewer]]s, [[water main]]s etc.) may require increased maintenance and renewal as they become subject to greater temperature variation. Regions already adversely affected include areas of [[permafrost]], which are subject to high levels of [[subsidence]], resulting in buckling roads, sunken foundations, and severely cracked runways.<ref>[http://www.airportbusiness.com/article/article.jsp?id=2258&siteSection=4 Studies Show Climate Change Melting Permafrost Under Runways in Western Arctic] {{Webarchive
column4: date=27 September 2011 }} ''Weber, Bob Airportbusiness.com'' October 2007</ref>{{Better source needed
column5: reason=The current source is insufficiently reliable ([[WP:NOTRS]]).

column1: Climate change affects displacement of people in several ways. Firstly, involuntary displacement may increase through the increased number and severity of weather-related disasters which destroy homes and habitats. Effects of climate change such as [[desertification]] and [[rising sea levels]] gradually erode livelihood and force communities to abandon traditional homelands for more accommodating environments. On the other hand, some households may fall (further) into poverty due to climate change, limiting their ability to move to areas less affected.<ref>{{Cite journal
column7: title=The impact of climate change on migration: a synthesis of recent empirical insights

column1: According to the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre in 2020 approximately 30 million people were displaced by extreme weather events while approximately 10 million by violence and wars and climate change significantly contributed to this.<ref>{{cite book
column2: title=GRID Internal displacement in a changing climate
column10: title=Extreme Weather Displaces Record Numbers of People as Temperatures Rise
column14: date=21 May 2021}}</ref> The United Nations says there are already 64 million migrants in the world fleeing wars, hunger, persecution and the effects of global warming.<ref>Environmental Migrants: Up To 1 Billion By 2050, Centro Euro-Mediterraneo sui Cambiamenti Climactici (CMCC)</ref> In 2018, the World Bank estimated that climate change will cause [[internal migration]] of between 31 and 143 million people as they escape crop failures, water scarcity, and sea level rise. The study only included Sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia, and Latin America.<ref>[https://www.nationalgeographic.com/news/2018/03/climate-migrants-report-world-bank-spd/ 143 Million People May Soon Become Climate Migrants] {{Webarchive
column16: date=19 December 2019}}, National Geographic, 19 March 2018</ref><ref>{{Cite book
column20: title=Groundswell: preparing for internal climate migration
column35: [[Sea level rise]] at the [[Marshall Islands]], reaching the edge of a village (from the documentary ''One Word'')]]Asia and the Pacific is the global area most prone to natural disasters, both in terms of the absolute number of disasters and of populations affected. It is highly exposed to climate impacts, and is home to highly vulnerable population groups, who are disproportionately poor and marginalized. A 2015 Asian Development Bank report highlights ""environmental hot spots"" that are particular risk of flooding, [[cyclones]], [[typhoons]], and water stress.<ref name=""beta.adb.org"">{{cite web
column37: title=Addressing Climate Change and Migration in Asia and the Pacific: Final Report

column1: Gradual but pervasive environmental change and sudden natural disasters both influence the nature and extent of human migration but in different ways. [[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]] stated that climate change increases mass displacement, in many regions, including [[Sahel]], East Africa, South Asia, the ""drought corridor"" in Latin America. 90% of refugees comes from ""climate vulnerable hotspots"".<ref name=""UNHCR"">{{cite web
column4: title=Climate change fuels violence and mass displacement in Cameroon

column1: Some Pacific Ocean island nations, such as [[Tuvalu]], [[Kiribati]], and the [[Maldives]],<ref>{{cite web
column9: website=Science News}}</ref> are considering the eventual possibility of evacuation, as flood defense may become economically unrealistic.

column1: Governments have considered various approaches to reduce migration compelled by environmental conditions in at-risk communities, including programs of social protection, livelihoods development, basic urban infrastructure development, and disaster risk management.  Some experts support migration as an appropriate way for people to cope with environmental changes.  However, this is controversial because migrants – particularly low-skilled ones – are among the most vulnerable people in society and are often denied basic protections and access to services.<ref name=""beta.adb.org""/>

Slow-onset disasters and gradual environmental erosion such as desertification, reduction of soil fertility, coastal erosion and sea-level rise are likely to induce long-term migration.<ref>[https://www.climateforesight.eu/migrations/environmental-migrants-up-to-1-billion-by-2050/ Environmental Migrants: Up To 1 Billion By 2050] {{Webarchive
column3: date=19 December 2019}}, Centro Euro-Mediterraneo sui Cambiamenti Climactici (CMCC)</ref> Migration related to desertification and reduced soil fertility is likely to be predominantly from [[Rural area
column4: rural areas]] in [[developing countries]] to towns and cities.<ref name=""wdr migration"">{{citation
column6: title=Managing social risks: Empower communities to protect themselves
column8: chapter=Part One: Chapter 2: Reducing Human Vulnerability: Helping People Help Themselves

column1: Climate change can worsen conflicts by exacerbating tensions over limited resources like [[drinking water]] (in the case of [[Water conflict
column2: water conflicts]]). Climate change also has the potential to cause large population dislocations and migration, which can also lead to increased tensions.<ref>{{cite journal
column17: title=Exploring the Climate Change, Migration and Conflict Nexus
column18: journal=International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health
column26: doi-access=free}}</ref> However, factors other than climate change are judged to be substantially more important in affecting conflict. These factors include intergroup [[Social inequality
column27: inequality]] and low socio-economic development.<ref>{{Cite journal
column51: title=Climate as a risk factor for armed conflict
column65: s2cid=186207310}}</ref> In some cases, climate change can even lead to more peaceful relationships between groups, as environmental problems requires common policy to be developed.<ref name="":15"">{{cite book
column68: title=Climate Change 2022: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability
column74: series=Contribution of Working Group II to the [[IPCC Sixth Assessment Report
column75: Sixth Assessment Report]] of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
column78: chapter=Chapter 8: Poverty, Livelihoods and Sustainable Developmen

column1: Global warming has been described as a ""threat multiplier"".<ref>{{cite journal
column9: journal=Proceedings of the United States Naval Institute
column15: access-date=23 November 2015}}</ref> Certain conditions make it more likely that climate change impacts conflict: ethnic exclusion, an economy dependent on agriculture, insufficient infrastructure, poor local governance, and low levels of development.<ref name="":15"" /> A spike in wheat prices following crop losses from a period of drought may have contributed to the onset of the ""[[Arab Spring]]"" protests and revolutions in 2010.<ref>{{cite news
column19: title=Climate Change and Rising Food Prices Heightened Arab Spring
column20: work=Republished with permission by Scientific American

column1: The impacts of climate change on humans are not distributed uniformly within communities. Individual and social factors such as gender, age, education, ethnicity, geography and language lead to differential [[vulnerability]] and capacity to adapt to the effects of climate change. The following more vulnerable groups have been identified:

column2: People living in poverty]]: Climate change disproportionally affects poor people in low-income communities and [[Developing country
column3: developing countries]] around the world. Those in poverty have a higher chance of experiencing the ill-effects of climate change due to the increased exposure and vulnerability.<ref name=""Rayner"">{{cite journal
column7: title=Climate Change, Poverty, and Intragernerational Equity: The National Leve
column8: journal=International Journal of Global Environmental Issues
column13: doi=10.1504/IJGENVI.2001.000977}}</ref> A 2020 World Bank paper estimated that between 32 million to 132 million additional people will be pushed into [[extreme poverty]] by 2030 due to climate change.<ref>{{Cite web
column17: title=Revised Estimates of the Impact of Climate Change on Extreme Poverty by 2030

column2: Women]]: Climate change increases [[gender inequality]],<ref name="":16"">{{Cite journal
column6: title=Climate change and gender equality in developing states
column14: issn=0305-750X}}</ref> reduces women's ability to be financially independent,<ref name="":03"">{{Cite journal
column22: title=Where are We Standing and Where Should We Be Going? Gender and Climate Change Adaptation Behavior
column23: journal=Journal of Agricultural and Environmental Ethics
column30: s2cid=216404045}}</ref> and has an overall negative impact on the social and political [[rights of women]], especially in economies that are heavily based on agriculture.<ref name="":16"" />

column2: Indigenous peoples]]: Indigenous communities geographically tend to be located in regions more [[Climate change vulnerability
column3: vulnerable to climate change]] such as native [[Rainforest
column4: rainforests]], the [[Arctic]], and coastal areas.<ref>{{Cite journal
column19: doi-access=free}}</ref> Indigenous communities across the globe generally have economic disadvantages that are not as prevalent in non-indigenous communities due to the ongoing oppression they have experienced. These disadvantages include lower education levels and higher rates of poverty and unemployment, which add to their vulnerability to climate change.<ref name="":82"">{{Cite journal
