column2: small=yes}} [[Image:Risks and Impacts of Global Warming.png
column5: Graphical description of risks and impacts of climate change by IPCC (2001). A revision of this figure by Smith ''et al.'' (2009) shows increased risks.<ref>{{cite doi
column6: 10.1073/pnas.0812355106}}</ref>]] This article is about the '''effects of [[global warming]]''' and [[climate change]]. The effects, or impacts, of climate change may be physical, ecological, social or economic. Evidence of observed climate change includes the instrumental temperature record, rising [[Current sea level rise
column7: sea level]]s, and decreased snow cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]].<ref name=ar4wg1>{{cite book
column13: 2007}} }} </ref> According to the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC, 2007a:10), ""[most] of the observed increase in global average temperatures since the mid-20th century is ''very likely'' due to the observed increase in [human [[greenhouse gas]]] concentrations"". It is predicted that future climate changes will include further global warming (i.e., an upward [[trend estimation
column14: trend]] in global mean temperature), sea level rise, and a probable increase in the frequency of some [[extreme weather
column15: extreme weather events]]. Signatories of the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] have agreed to implement policies designed to reduce their emissions of greenhouse gases. ==Definition of climate change== {{See also
column16: Attribution of recent climate change}} This article refers to reports produced by the IPCC. In their usage, ""climate change"" refers to a change in the state of the climate that can be identified by changes in the mean and/or variability of its properties, and that persists for extended periods, typically decades or longer (IPCC, 2007d:30). <ref name=ar4syn>{{cite web
column18: title=Climate Change 2007: Synthesis Report. Contribution of Working Groups I, II and III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (Core Writing Team ''et al.'' (eds.))
column22: accessdate=2009-05-20}} </ref> The climate change referred to may be due to natural causes or the result of human activity. ==Temperature changes== [[Image:Instrumental Temperature Record (NASA).svg
column25: Global mean surface temperature difference from the average for 1880–2009]] This article breaks down some of the impacts of climate change according to different levels of future global warming. This way of describing impacts has, for instance, been used in the IPCC's Assessment Reports on climate change.<ref name=tab191>{{cite book
column28: series=Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column35: accessdate=2011-05-04}} </ref> The instrumental [[temperature record]] shows global warming of around 0.6°C over the entire 20<sup>th</sup> century.<ref name=synspm1/> The future level of global warming is uncertain, but a wide range of estimates (projections) have been made.<ref>{{cite book
column38: title= Issues related to mitigation in the long term context
column39: series=Climate Change 2007: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
column42: location = Cambrige, UK & New York, NY, USA; CH
column45: accessdate=2011-05-04}} </ref> The IPCC's ""[[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column46: SRES]]"" scenarios have been frequently used to make [[Global climate model#Projections of future climate change
column47: projections of future climate change]].<ref>{{cite book
column56: accessdate=2011-05-04}} </ref> Climate models using the six SRES ""marker"" scenarios suggest future warming of 1.1 to 6.4°C by the end of the 21<sup>st</sup> century (above average global temperatures over the 1980 to 1999 time period).<ref name=synthim/> The range in temperature projections partly reflects different projections of future social and economic development (e.g., [[economic growth]], [[population projection
column57: population level]]), which in turn affects projections of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. The range also reflects uncertainty in the response of the climate system to past and future GHG emissions (measured by the [[climate sensitivity]]). The projected rate of warming under these [[climate change scenario
column58: scenarios]] would very likely be without precedent during at least the last 10,000 years (see [[Effects of global warming#Footnotes
column60: IPCC, 2001]]. [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/vol4/english/005.htm SPM Question 3]</ref> The most recent warm period comparable to these projections was the mid-[[Pliocene]], around 3 million years ago.<ref>{{cite journal
column74: accessdate=2011-05-04}}</ref> At that time, models suggest that mean global temperatures were about 2–3°C warmer than pre-industrial temperatures.<ref>{{cite book
column76: contribution=6.3.2 What Does the Record of the Mid-Pliocene Show?
column85: Physical impacts of climate change}} [[Image:Changes in climate indicators that show global warming.png
column88: Key climate indicators that show global warming.<ref name=statecl/>{{Rp
column89: 2-3}}]] Working Group I's contribution to the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]], published in 2007, concluded that warming of the climate system was ""unequivocal.""<ref name=wg1obs>{{cite book
column91: contribution=Direct Observations of Recent Climate Change
column97: 2007}} }} </ref> This was based on the consistency of evidence across a range of observed changes, including increases in global average air and [[ocean]] temperatures, widespread melting of [[cryosphere
column98: snow and ice]], and [[Current sea level rise
column99: rising]] global average sea level.<ref>{{cite book
column108: 2007}} }}</ref> The report of IPCC Working Group II pointed to substantial evidence of physical and [[Climate change and ecosystems
column109: biological systems]] having been affected by regional changes in climate.<ref>{{cite book
column111: contribution=TS.2 Current knowledge about observed impacts on natural and managed systems
column119: accessdate=2011-05-08}} </ref> Human activities have contributed to a number of the observed changes in climate.<ref name=hegerl>{{cite book
column122: series=Chapter 9: Understanding and Attributing Climate Change
column128: 2007}} }} </ref> This contribution has principally been through the burning of [[fossil fuel]]s, which has led to an increase in the concentration of GHGs in the atmosphere.<ref>{{cite book
column130: contribution=Human and Natural Drivers of Climate Change
column136: 2007}} }} </ref> This increase in GHG concentrations has caused a [[radiative forcing]] of the climate in the direction of warming. Human-induced forcing of the climate has likely to contributed to a number of observed changes, including sea level rise, changes in climate [[extreme weather event
column137: extremes]] (such as warm and cold days), declines in [[Arctic sea ice]] extent, and to [[Retreat of glaciers since 1850
column138: glacier retreat]].<ref name=hegerl/> Human-induced warming could potentially lead to some impacts that are [[Effects of global warming#Abrupt or irreversible changes
column142: contribution=3. Projected climate change and its impacts
column148: title=New Study Shows Climate Change Largely Irreversible
column154: date=May 2011}}</ref> The probability of warming having unforeseen consequences increases with the rate, magnitude, and duration of climate change.<ref>{{cite web
column160: publisher=[[United States National Academy of Sciences]]
column162: year=2002}}</ref> With medium confidence (see [[Effects of global warming#Footnotes
column163: footnote 2]]), IPCC (2007b:17) concluded that with a global average temperature increase of 1–4°C, (relative to 1990–2000) partial deglaciation of the [[Greenland ice sheet]] would occur over a period of centuries to millennia.<ref name=magnitude>{{cite book
column172: accessdate=2011-05-08}} </ref> Including the possible contribution of partial deglaciation of the [[West Antarctic Ice Sheet]], sea level would rise by 4–6 [[metre]]s or more. === Effects on weather === Observations show that there have been changes in weather.<ref>{{cite book
column174: contribution=FAQ 1.2 What is the Relationship between Climate Change and Weather?
column181: 2007}} }}</ref> As climate changes, the [[probabilities]] of certain types of weather events are affected. Changes have been observed in the amount, intensity, frequency, and type of [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column190: 2009}} }}</ref> Widespread increases in heavy precipitation have occurred, even in places where total rain amounts have decreased. IPCC (2007d) concluded that human influences had, more likely than not (greater than 50% probability, based on expert judgement), contributed to an increase in the frequency of heavy precipitation events.<ref>{{citation
column195: title = SPM 2. Causes of change}}.</ref> Projections of future changes in precipitation show overall increases in the global average, but with substantial shifts in where and how precipitation falls.<ref name = karl24>{{cite book
column203: 2009}} }}</ref> Evidence suggests that, since the 1970s, there have been substantial increases in the intensity and duration of [[tropical storm]]s and hurricanes.<ref>{{cite book
column205: contribution=FAQ 3.3 Has there been a Change in Extreme Events like Heat Waves, Droughts, Floods and Hurricanes?
column206: series=Observations: Surface and Atmospheric Climate Change
column212: 2007}} }}</ref> Models project a general tendency for more intense but fewer storms outside the [[tropics]].<ref name=karl24/> [[Image:NOAAaccumulatedcycloneenergyindex.jpg
column215: [[Accumulated cyclone energy]] in the [[Atlantic Ocean]] and the sea surface temperature difference which influences such, measured by the U.S. [[NOAA]].]] ==== Extreme weather ==== {{See also
column218: List of Atlantic hurricane records}} Since the late 20<sup>th</sup> century, changes have been observed in the trends of some extreme weather and climate events, e.g., [[heat wave]]s.<ref>{{cite book
column226: 2007}} }}</ref> Human activities have, with varying degrees of confidence, contributed to some of these observed trends. Projections for the 21<sup>st</sup> century suggest continuing changes in trends for some extreme events. Solomon ''et al.'' (2007), for example, projected the following likely (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement) changes: *an increase in the areas affected by [[drought]]; *increased tropical cyclone activity; *and increased incidence of extreme high [[Current sea level rise
column227: sea level]] (excluding [[tsunami]]s) Projected changes in extreme events will have predominantly adverse impacts on ecosystems and human society.<ref>[[Effects of global warming#Further reading
column228: IPCC, 2001]]. [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/vol4/english/005.htm SPM Question 4].</ref><ref>[[Effects of global warming#Further reading
column229: IPCC, 2007d]]. [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains5-2.html SYR 5.2 Key vulnerabilities, impacts and risks – long-term perspectives]</ref> ==== Local climate change ==== {{Main
column230: Regional effects of global warming}} [[Image:Global Warming Map.jpg
column233: Mean surface temperature change for 1999–2008 relative to the average temperatures from 1940 to 1980]] Regional effects of global warming vary in nature. Some are the result of a generalised global change, such as rising temperature, resulting in local effects, such as melting ice. In other cases, a change may be related to a change in a particular ocean current or weather system. In such cases, the regional effect may be disproportionate and will not necessarily follow the global trend. There are three major ways in which global warming will make changes to regional climate: melting or forming ice, changing the [[hydrological cycle]] (of [[evaporation]] and [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column235: currents in the ocean]]s and air flows in the atmosphere. The coast can also be considered a region, and will suffer severe impacts from [[sea level rise]]. The human influence on the climate can be seen in the geographical pattern of observed warming, with greater temperature increases over land and in [[polar region]]s rather than over the oceans.<ref>{{cite book
column239: page=6}}</ref> Using models, it is possible to identify the human ""signal"" of global warming over both land and ocean areas. Projections of future climate changes at the regional scale do not hold as high a level of scientific confidence as projections made at the global scale.<ref>{{cite book
column243: page=9}} </ref> It is, however, expected that future warming will follow a similar geographical pattern to that seen already, with greatest warming over land and high northern [[latitude]]s, and least over the [[Southern Ocean]] and parts of the [[North Atlantic Ocean]].<ref>{{cite book
column245: contribution=Projections of Future Changes in Climate
column253: climate change feedback}} Climate change may have an effect on the carbon cycle in an interactive {{q
column254: feedback}} process. A feedback exists where an initial process triggers changes in a second process that in turn influences the initial process. A positive feedback intensifies the original process, and a negative feedback reduces it (IPCC, 2007d:78).<ref name = ar4syn /> Models suggest that the interaction of the climate system and the carbon cycle is one where the feedback effect is positive (Schneider ''et al.'', 2007:792).<ref name=schneider>{{cite book
column256: chapter=Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column263: p=781}} }}</ref> Using the A2 SRES emissions scenario, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007:789) found that this effect led to additional warming by 2100, relative to the 1990–2000 period, of 0.1–1.5°C. This estimate was made with high confidence. The climate projections made in the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report of 1.1–6.4°C account for this feedback effect. On the other hand, with medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007) commented that additional releases of GHGs were possible from permafrost, peat lands, wetlands, and large stores of marine hydrates at high latitudes. ===Glacier retreat and disappearance=== {{Main
column264: Retreat of glaciers since 1850}} [[Image:Glacier Mass Balance Map.png
column268: A map of the change in thickness of mountain glaciers since 1970. Thinning in orange and red, thickening in blue.]] IPCC (2007a:5) found that, on average, mountain glaciers and snow cover had decreased in both the northern and southern hemispheres.<ref name=wg1obs/> This widespread decrease in glaciers and ice caps had contributed to observed sea level rise. With very high or high confidence, IPCC (2007b<ref>{{cite book
column281: contribution=Table SPM.2, in: 3. Projected climate change and its impacts
column287: accessdate=2011-06-04}} </ref> made a number of projections relating to future changes in glaciers: *Mountainous areas in [[Europe]] will face glacier retreat *In [[Polar region]]s, there will be reductions in glacier extent and the thickness of glaciers. *More than one-sixth of the world's population are supplied by meltwater from major mountain ranges. Changes in glaciers and snow cover are expected to reduce water availability for these populations. *In [[Latin America]], changes in precipitation patterns and the disappearance of glaciers will significantly affect water availability for human consumption, agriculture, and energy production. ===Oceans=== The role of the oceans in global warming is a complex one. The oceans serve as a sink for carbon dioxide, taking up much that would otherwise remain in the atmosphere, but increased levels of {{chem
column289: 2}} have led to [[ocean acidification]]. Furthermore, as the temperature of the oceans increases, they become less able to absorb excess {{chem
column291: 2}}. The ocean have also acted as a sink in absorbing extra heat from the atmosphere. This extra heat has been added to the climate system due to the build-up of GHGs. More than 90 percent of warming that occurred over 1960–2009 is estimated to have gone into the oceans.<ref name=statecl> {{cite book
column294: publisher = Website of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration: National Climatic Data Center
column295: title = State of the Climate in 2009, as appearing in the July 2010 issue (Vol. 91) of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society (BAMS). Supplemental and Summary Materials: Report at a Glance: Highlights
column298: 4}} Global warming is projected to have a number of effects on the oceans. Ongoing effects include rising sea levels due to thermal expansion and melting of glaciers and ice sheets, and warming of the ocean surface, leading to increased temperature stratification. Other possible effects include large-scale changes in ocean circulation. ====Acidification==== {{Main
column299: Ocean acidification}} About one-third of the carbon dioxide emitted by human activity has already been taken up by the oceans.<ref name=nrcacid> {{cite book
column302: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column304: location = 500 Fifth Street, NW Washington, DC 20001, USA
column305: author = Commitee on Ecological Impacts of Climate Change, US National Research Council
column309: accessdate = 2011-06-11}} </ref> As carbon dioxide dissolves in [[sea water]], [[carbonic acid]] is formed, which has the effect of acidifying the ocean, measured as a change in [[pH]]. The uptake of human carbon emissions since the year 1750 has led to an average decrease in pH of 0.1 units.<ref name=ipccacid> {{cite book
column316: accessdate = 2011-06-11}} </ref> Projections using the SRES emissions scenarios suggest a further reduction in average global surface ocean pH of between 0.14 and 0.35 units over the 21<sup>st</sup> century. The effects of ocean acidification on the marine [[biosphere]] have yet to be documented.<ref name=ipccacid/> Laboratory experiments suggest beneficial effects for a few species, with potentially highly detrimental effects for a substantial number of species.<ref name=nrcacid/> With medium confidence, Fischlin ''et al.'' (2007) projected that future ocean acidification would impair a wide range of [[plankton]]ic and shallow [[benthos
column317: benthic]] marine organisms that use [[aragonite]] to make their shells or skeletons, such as [[coral]]s and marine [[snail]]s ([[pteropoda
column318: pteropods]]), with significant impacts particularly in the Southern Ocean.<ref>{{cite book
column321: series = Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods, and services
column328: accessdate = 2011-06-11}} </ref> ====Oxygen depletion==== The amount of oxygen dissolved in the oceans may decline, with adverse consequences for ocean life.<ref>{{cite doi
column337: caption1=Sea level rise during the Holocene.
column338: caption2=Sea level has been rising {{#expr: 20/120 round 1}} cm/yr, based on measurements of [[sea level rise]] from 23 long [[tide gauge]] records in geologically stable environments.}} There is strong evidence that global sea level rose gradually over the 20<sup>th</sup> century.<ref name=faq51> {{cite book
column341: series=Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column348: accessdate=2011-06-17}} </ref> With high confidence, Bindoff ''et al.'' (2007) concluded that between the mid-19<sup>th</sup> and mid-20<sup>th</sup> centuries, the rate of sea level rise increased.<ref> {{cite book
column351: series=Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column358: accessdate=2011-06-17}} </ref> The IPCC (2007d, p. 5) reported that between 1961 and 2003, global average sea level rose at an average rate of 1.8 [[millimetre
column359: mm]] per year (mm/yr), with an [[uncertainty quantification
column360: uncertainty range]] of 1.3–2.3 mm/yr.<ref name=synspm1> {{cite book
column363: contribution=1. Observed changes in climate and their effects
column369: accessdate=2011-06-17}} </ref> Between 1993 and 2003, the rate increased above the previous period to 3.1 mm/yr (uncertainty range of 2.4–3.8 mm/yr). The IPCC (2007d) was uncertain whether the increase in rate from 1993 to 2003 was due to [[climate change#Internal forcing mechanisms
column370: natural variations]] in sea level over the time period, or whether it reflected an increase in the underlying long-term trend. There are two main factors that have contributed to observed sea level rise.<ref name=faq51/> The first is [[thermal expansion]]: as ocean water warms, it expands.<ref> {{cite book
column372: contribution=Box 2: What causes sea level to change?
column378: accessdate=2011-06-14}} </ref> The second is from the contribution of land-based ice due to increased melting. The major store of water on land is found in glaciers and ice sheets. There is a widespread consensus that substantial long-term sea level rise will continue for centuries to come.<ref> {{cite book
column380: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column385: accessdate=2011-06-17}} </ref> The IPCC (2007d) projected sea level rise to the end of the 21<sup>st</sup> century using the SRES emissions scenarios.<ref> {{cite book
column386: contribution=Table SPM.1, in (section): 3. Projected climate change and its impacts
column392: accessdate=2011-06-17}} </ref> Across the six SRES marker scenarios, sea level was projected to rise by 18 to 59 [[centimetre
column394: in]]). This projection is for the time period 2090–99, with the increase in level relative to average global sea level over the 1980–99 period. Thermal expansion is the largest component in these projections, contributing 70-75% of the central estimate for all scenarios.<ref> {{cite book
column396: contribution=Section on sea level in: Executive summary
column402: accessdate=2011-06-17}} </ref> Due to a lack of scientific understanding, this sea level rise estimate does not include all of the possible contributions of ice sheets (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Abrupt or irreversible changes
column403: abrupt or irreversible changes]]). A literature assessment published in 2010 by the [[US National Research Council]] described the above IPCC projections as ""conservative,"" and summarized the results of more recent studies.<ref> {{cite book
column405: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column410: accessdate=2011-06-17}} </ref> Cited studies suggested a great deal of uncertainty in projections. A range of projections suggested possible sea level rise by the end of the 21<sup>st</sup> century of between 0.56 and 2 m. These projections are based on the same measurement range as IPCC (2007d), with the increase in sea level by 2090-99 measured against average global sea level over the 1980–99 time period. ====Temperature rise==== From 1961 to 2003, the global ocean temperature has risen by 0.10°C from the surface to a depth of 700 m. There is variability both year-to-year and over longer time scales, with global ocean heat content observations showing high rates of warming for 1991–2003, but some cooling from 2003 to 2007.<ref>{{cite book
column411: author=Bindoff, NL, J Willebrand, V Artale, A, Cazenave, J Gregory, S Gulev, K Hanawa, C Le Quéré, S Levitus, Y Nojiri, CK Shum, LD Talley and A Unnikrishnan
column414: chapter=5 Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column419: format=PDF}} </ref> The temperature of the Antarctic [[Southern Ocean]] rose by 0.17°C (0.31 °F) between the 1950s and the 1980s, nearly twice the rate for the world's oceans as a whole.<ref>{{cite journal
column421: title=Warming of the Southern Ocean Since the 1950s
column431: issue= 5558}}</ref> As well as having effects on ecosystems (e.g. by melting sea ice, affecting algae that grow on its underside), warming reduces the ocean's ability to absorb {{chem
column435: Effects of climate change on humans
column436: Climate change, industry and society}} The impacts of climate change can be thought of in terms of sensitivity and vulnerability. ""Sensitivity"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be affected, positively or negatively, by climate change and/or [[climate change#Causes
column437: climate variability]]. ""Vulnerability"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be adversely affected by climate change.<ref> {{cite book
column444: accessdate=2011-06-20}} </ref> The sensitivity of human society to climate change varies. Sectors sensitive to climate change include water resources, coastal zones, human settlements, and human health. Industries sensitive to climate change include [[climate change and agriculture
column449: contribution=2.4. Many Human Systems are Sensitive to Climate Change, and Some are Vulnerable
column458: series=Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column467: 2007–2008 world food price crisis}} Climate change will impact agriculture and food production around the world due to: the effects of elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere, higher temperatures, altered precipitation and [[transpiration]] regimes, increased frequency of extreme events, and modified [[weed]], [[pest (organism)
column471: series=Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column477: accessdate=2011-06-25}} </ref> In general, low-latitude areas are at most risk of having decreased crop yields (Schneider ''et al.'', 2007).<ref name=schagric/> So far, the effects of regional climate change on agriculture have been relatively limited.<ref name=rosen> {{cite book
column480: series=Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column485: accessdate=2011-06-25}} </ref> Changes in crop [[phenology]] provide important evidence of the response to recent regional climate change.<ref> {{cite book
column488: series=Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column493: accessdate=2011-06-25}} </ref> Phenology is the study of natural phenomena that recur periodically, and how these phenomena relate to climate and seasonal changes.<ref> {{cite book
column500: accessdate=2011-06-25}} </ref> A significant advance in phenology has been observed for agriculture and forestry in large parts of the Northern Hemisphere.<ref name=rosen/> ====Projections==== With low to medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007) projected that for about a 1 to 3 °C increase in global mean temperature (by 2100, relative to the 1990–2000 average level), there would be productivity decreases for some [[cereal]]s in low latitudes, and productivity increases in high latitudes. With medium confidence, global production potential was projected to:<ref name=tab191/> *increase up to around 3 °C, *very likely decrease above about 3 °C. Most of the studies on global agriculture assessed by Schneider ''et al.'' (2007) had not incorporated a number of critical factors, including changes in extreme events, or the spread of pests and diseases. Studies had also not considered the development of specific practices or technologies to aid [[adaptation to global warming#Agricultural production
column504: series=Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column510: accessdate=2011-06-25}} </ref> =====Food security===== Easterling ''et al.'' (2007) assessed studies that made quantitative projections of climate change impacts on [[food security]].<ref> {{cite book
column513: series=Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column518: accessdate=2011-06-25}} </ref> It was noted that these projections were highly uncertain and had limitations. However, the assessed studies suggested a number of fairly robust findings. The first was that climate change would likely increase the number of people at risk of [[hunger]] compared with reference scenarios with no climate change. Climate change impacts depended strongly on projected future social and economic development. Additionally, the magnitude of climate change impacts was projected to be smaller compared to the impact of social and economic development. According to Easterling ''et al.'' (2007), [[sub-Saharan Africa]] will likely surpass [[Asia]] as the most food-insecure region. This projection was largely independent of climate change and mostly the result of projected social and economic development. Easterling ''et al.'' (2007) pointed to the large potential benefits of [[climate change mitigation]] (i.e., reducing GHG emissions) on the agriculture sector. It was suggested that these benefits might only become apparent in the second half of the 21<sup>st</sup> century. ===Health=== Human beings are exposed to climate change through changing weather patterns (temperature, precipitation, sea-level rise and more frequent extreme events) and indirectly through changes in water, air and food quality and changes in ecosystems, agriculture, industry and settlements and the economy (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007:393).<ref>{{cite book
column527: pp=391–431}} }}</ref> According to a literature assessment by Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007:393), the effects of climate change to date have been small, but are projected to progressively increase in all countries and regions. With high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007:393) concluded that climate change had altered the seasonal distribution of some allergenic pollen species. With medium confidence, they concluded that climate change had: *altered the distribution of some infectious disease vectors *increased heatwave-related deaths With high confidence, IPCC (2007d:48) projected that:<ref name=ar4syn/> *the health status of millions of people would be affected through, for example, increases in [[malnutrition]]; increased deaths, diseases and injury due to extreme weather events; increased burden of [[Diarrhea
column528: diarrhoeal disease]]s; increased frequency of cardio-respiratory diseases due to high concentrations of ground-level ozone in urban areas related to climate change; and altered spatial distribution of some infectious diseases. *climate change would bring some benefits in temperate areas, such as fewer deaths from cold exposure, and some mixed effects such as changes in range and transmission potential of [[malaria]] in Africa. Overall, IPCC (2007d:48) expected that benefits would be outweighed by negative health effects of rising temperatures, especially in developing countries. With very high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007:393) concluded that economic development was an important component of possible adaptation to climate change. Economic growth on its own, however, was not judged to be sufficient to insulate the world's population from disease and injury due to climate change. The manner in which economic growth occurs was judged to be important, along with how the benefits of growth are distributed in society. Examples of other important factors in determining the health of populations were listed as: education, health care, and public-health infrastructure. ====Specific health impacts==== {{POV-section
column532: date=May 2010}} '''Malnutrition''' With high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) projected that malnutrition would increase due to climate change.<ref name=wg2c8es>{{cite book
column534: author=Confalonieri, U., B. Menne, R. Akhtar, K.L. Ebi, M. Hauengue, R.S. Kovats, B. Revich and A. Woodward
column535: title=Executive summary. In (book chapter): Human health. In: Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (M.L. Parry, O.F. Canziani, J.P. Palutikof, P.J. van der Linden and C.E. Hanson, Eds.)
column537: publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. This version: IPCC website
column539: accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref> This link is associated with climate variability and change (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref name=wg2s823>Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-3.html ""8.2.3 Drought, nutrition and food security""]</ref> Drought reduces variety in [[diet (nutrition)
column541: consumption]]. This can lead to [[micronutrient]] deficiencies. The [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) (referred to by Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007)<ref name=wg2s8411>Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-4-1-1.html ""8.4.1.1 Global burden of disease study""]</ref> conducted a regional and global assessment to quantify the amount of premature [[morbidity]] and [[death
column542: mortality]] due to a range of factors, including climate change. Projections were made over future climate change impacts. Limited adjustments for adaptation were included in the estimates based on these projections. Projected relative risks attributable to climate change in 2030 varied by health outcome and region. Risks were largely negative, with most of the projected disease burden due to increases in diarrhoeal disease and malnutrition. These increases were primarily in low-income populations already experiencing a large burden of disease. '''Extreme events''' With high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) projected that climate change would increase the number of people suffering from death, disease and injury from [[heatwave]]s, [[flood]]s, [[storm]]s, [[fire]]s and [[drought]]s.<ref name=wg2c8es/> ''Floods and weather disasters'' Floods are low-probability, high-impact events that can overwhelm physical infrastructure and human communities (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref>{{cite book
column544: author=Confalonieri, U., B. Menne, R. Akhtar, K.L. Ebi, M. Hauengue, R.S. Kovats, B. Revich and A. Woodward
column545: title=8.2.2 Wind, storms and floods. In (book chapter): Human health. In: Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (M.L. Parry, O.F. Canziani, J.P. Palutikof, P.J. van der Linden and C.E. Hanson, Eds.)
column547: publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. This version: IPCC website
column549: accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref> Major storm and flood disasters have occurred in the last two decades. The impacts of weather disasters is considerable and unequally distributed. For example, natural disasters have been shown to result in increased domestic violence against - and [[posttraumatic stress disorder
column550: post-traumatic stress disorders]] in – [[women]]. In terms of deaths and populations affected, floods and tropical cyclones have the greatest impact in South Asia and Latin America. Vulnerability to weather disasters depends on the attributes of the person at risk, including where they live and their age, as well as other social and environmental factors. High-density populations in low-lying coastal regions experience a high health burden from weather disasters. ''Heatwaves'' Hot days, hot nights and heatwaves have become more frequent (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref>Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-1-1.html ""8.2.1.1 Heatwaves""]</ref> Heatwaves are associated with marked short-term increases in mortality. For example, in August 2003, a heatwave in Europe resulted in excess mortality in the range of 35,000 total deaths. Heat-related morbidity and mortality is projected to increase (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref name=wg2s8413>Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-4-1-3.html ""8.4.1.3 Heat- and cold-related mortality""]</ref> The health burden could be relatively small for moderate heatwaves in temperate regions, because deaths occur primarily in susceptible persons. ''Drought'' The effects of drought on health include deaths, malnutrition, [[infectious disease]]s and [[respiratory disease]]s (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref name=wg2s823/> Countries within the ""[[Meningitis]] Belt"" in semi-arid sub-Saharan Africa experience the highest [[endemic (epidemiology)
column552: meningococcal]] meningitis in Africa, although other areas in the Rift Valley, the Great Lakes, and southern Africa are also affected (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref>Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-3-1.html ""8.2.3.1 Drought and infectious disease""]</ref> The spatial distribution, intensity, and seasonality of meningococcal (epidemic) meningitis appear to be strongly linked to climate and environmental factors, particularly drought. The cause of this link is not fully understood. ''Fires'' In some regions, changes in temperature and precipitation are projected to increase the frequency and severity of fire events (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref>Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-6-3.html ""8.2.6.3 Air pollutants from forest fires""]</ref> Forest and bush fires cause burns, damage from smoke inhalation and other injuries. '''Infectious disease vectors''' With high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) projected that climate change would continue to change the range of some [[infectious disease]] vectors.<ref name=wg2c8es/> [[Vector (epidemiology)
column553: Vector-borne diseases]] (VBD) are infections transmitted by the bite of infected [[arthropod]] species, such as [[mosquito]]es, [[tick]]s, [[triatominae
column558: author=Confalonieri, U., B. Menne, R. Akhtar, K.L. Ebi, M. Hauengue, R.S. Kovats, B. Revich and A. Woodward
column559: title=8.2.8 Vector-borne, rodent-borne and other infectious diseases. In (book chapter): Human health. In: Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (M.L. Parry, O.F. Canziani, J.P. Palutikof, P.J. van der Linden and C.E. Hanson, Eds.)
column561: publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. This version: IPCC website
column563: accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref> There is some evidence of climate-change-related shifts in the distribution of tick vectors of disease, of some (non-malarial) mosquito vectors in Europe and North America. Climate change has also been implicated in changes in the breeding and migration dates of several bird species. Several species of wild bird can act as carriers of human [[pathogen]]s as well as of vectors of infectious agents. ''Dengue'' It is possible<sup>d</sup> that climate change will increase the number of people at risk of dengue (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref name=wg2c8es/> Based on the expert judgement of Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007), this projection had about a two-in-ten chance of being correct. [[dengue fever
column564: Dengue]] is the world's most important vector-borne viral disease (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref>{{cite book
column566: author=Confalonieri, U., B. Menne, R. Akhtar, K.L. Ebi, M. Hauengue, R.S. Kovats, B. Revich and A. Woodward
column567: title=8.2.8.1 Dengue. In (book chapter): Human health. In: Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (M.L. Parry, O.F. Canziani, J.P. Palutikof, P.J. van der Linden and C.E. Hanson, Eds.)
column569: publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. This version: IPCC website
column571: accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref> Several studies have reported associations between dengue and climate, however, these associations are not entirely consistent. [[Image:Malaria mortality past century.jpg
column575: Observed malaria mortality: Although showing such over the past century of global warming, there are [[Malaria#Prevention
column576: also other factors impacting the past and future of malaria]].]] ''Malaria'' The spatial distribution, intensity of transmission, and seasonalty of [[malaria]] is influenced by climate in [[Sub-saharan Africa]] (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref>{{cite book
column578: author=Confalonieri, U., B. Menne, R. Akhtar, K.L. Ebi, M. Hauengue, R.S. Kovats, B. Revich and A. Woodward
column579: title=8.2.8.2 Malaria. In (book chapter): Human health. In: Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (M.L. Parry, O.F. Canziani, J.P. Palutikof, P.J. van der Linden and C.E. Hanson, Eds.)
column581: publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. This version: IPCC website
column583: accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref> Rainfall can be a limiting factor for mosquito populations and there is some evidence of reductions in transmission associated with decadal decreases in rainfall. The effects of observed climate change on the geographical distribution of malaria and its transmission intensity in highland regions remains controversial. There is no clear evidence that malaria has been affected by climate change in South America or in continental regions of the Russian Federation. There is still much uncertainty about the potential impact of climate change on malaria at local and global scales. {{Undue
column585: date=May 2010}} A paper by researchers from the [[University of Oxford]] and the [[University of Florida]] published in [[Nature (journal)
column586: Nature]] in May 2010 concluded that claims that a warming climate has led to more widespread disease and death due to malaria are largely at odds with the evidence, and that ""''predictions of an intensification of malaria in a warmer world, based on extrapolated empirical relationships or biological mechanisms, must be set against a context of a century of warming that has seen marked global declines in the disease and a substantial weakening of the global correlation between malaria endemicity and climate.''""<ref>{{cite journal
column589: title=Climate change and the global malaria recession
column590: author=Peter W. Gething, David L. Smith, Anand P. Patil, Andrew J. Tatem, Robert W. Snow & Simon I. Hay
column601: title=Don’t sweat it: Development and public-health initiatives will matter much more to malaria than the climate will
column604: accessdate=2010-05-25}}</ref> ''Other infectious diseases'' There is good evidence that diseases transmitted by [[rodent]]s sometimes increase during heavy rainfall and flooding because of altered patterns of human-pathogen-rodent contact (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref>{{cite book
column606: author=Confalonieri, U., B. Menne, R. Akhtar, K.L. Ebi, M. Hauengue, R.S. Kovats, B. Revich and A. Woodward
column607: title=8.2.8.3 Other infectious diseases. In (book chapter): Human health. In: Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (M.L. Parry, O.F. Canziani, J.P. Palutikof, P.J. van der Linden and C.E. Hanson, Eds.)
column609: publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. This version: IPCC website
column611: accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref> ''Projections'' With very high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) concluded that climate change would have mixed effects on malaria.<ref name=wg2c8es/> Malaria is a complex disease to model and all of the published models assessed by Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) had limited parameterization of some key factors.<ref>{{cite book
column613: author=Confalonieri, U., B. Menne, R. Akhtar, K.L. Ebi, M. Hauengue, R.S. Kovats, B. Revich and A. Woodward
column614: title=8.4.1.2 Malaria, dengue and other infectious diseases. In (book chapter): Human health. In: Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (M.L. Parry, O.F. Canziani, J.P. Palutikof, P.J. van der Linden and C.E. Hanson, Eds.)
column616: publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. This version: IPCC website
column618: accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref> Parametrization is used in [[climate model]]s because the resolution of models is insufficient to resolve some physical processes (Randall ''et al.'', 2007).<ref>{{cite book
column620: author= Randall, D.A., R.A. Wood, S. Bony, R. Colman, T. Fichefet, J. Fyfe, V. Kattsov, A. Pitman, J. Shukla, J. Srinivasan, R.J. Stouffer, A. Sumi and K.E. Taylor
column621: title= 8.2.1.3 Parametrizations. In (book chapter): Climate Models and Their Evaluation. In: Climate Change 2007: The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of Working Group I to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (Solomon, S., D. Qin, M. Manning, Z. Chen, M. Marquis, K.B. Averyt, M.Tignor and H.L. Miller (eds.))
column623: publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. This version: IPCC website
column625: accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref> Given this limitation, models assessed by Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) projected that, particularly in Africa, climate change would be associated with geographical expansions of the areas suitable for ''Plasmodium falciparum'' malaria in some regions, and contractions in other regions. Projections also suggested that some regions would experience a longer season of transmission. Projections suggested expansions in vector species that carry dengue for parts of Australia and New Zealand. '''Diarrhoeal diseases''' With medium confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) concluded that climate change would increase the burden of diarrhoeal diseases.<ref name=wg2c8es/> Childhood mortality due to diarrhoea in low-income countries, especially in Sub-Saharan Africa, remains high (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref>Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-5.html ""8.2.5 Water and disease""]</ref> This is despite improvements in care. Several studies have shown that transmission of [[intestine
column626: enteric]] pathogens is higher during the rainy season. Some studies have found that higher temperature was strongly associated with increased episodes of diarrhoeal disease in adults and children in Peru. The WHO study, referred to earlier, projected that climate change would increase the burden of diarrhoeal diseases in low-income regions by approximately 2 to 5% in 2020 (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref name=wg2s8411/> '''Ground-level ozone''' With high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) projected that climate change would increase cardio-respiratory morbidity and mortality associated with ground-level [[ozone]].<ref name=wg2c8es/> Ground-level ozone is both naturally occurring and is the primary constituent of urban [[smog]] (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref>Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-6.html ""8.2.6 Air quality and disease""]</ref> Ozone in smog is formed through chemical reactions involving [[nitrogen oxide]]s and other compounds. The reaction is a [[photochemical reaction]], meaning that it involves [[electromagnetic radiation]], and occurs in the presence of bright sunshine and high temperatures. Exposure to elevated concentrations of ozone is associated with increased hospital admissions for [[pneumonia]], [[chronic obstructive pulmonary disease]], [[asthma]], allergic [[rhinitis]] and other respiratory diseases, and with premature mortality. Background levels of ground-level ozone have risen since pre-industrial times because of increasing emissions of methane, [[carbon monoxide]] and nitrogen oxides (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref>Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-4-1-4.html ""8.4.1.4 Urban air quality""]</ref> This trend is expected to continue into the mid-21<sup>st</sup> century. '''Cold-waves''' It is expected that<sup>b</sup> climate change will bring some health benefits (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref name=wg2c8es/> It is expected that these benefits will be outweighed by negative climate change effects. [[cold wave
column627: Cold-waves]] continue to be a problem in northern latitudes, where very low temperatures can be reached in a few hours and extend over long periods (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref>Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-1-2.html ""8.2.1.2 Cold-waves""]</ref> Reductions in cold-deaths due to climate change are projected to be greater than increases in heat-related deaths in the UK (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007).<ref name=wg2s8413/> [[Image:NOAAprecipitationtrend.jpg
column630: Precipitation during the 20th century and up through 2008 during global warming, the [[NOAA]] estimating an observed trend over that period of 1.87% global precipitation increase per century.]] ===Water resources=== {{See also
column631: Water crisis}} In a literature assessment, Kundzewicz ''et al.'' (2007:175) concluded, with high confidence, that:<ref>{{cite book
column640: pp=173–210}} }}</ref> *the negative impacts of climate change on freshwater systems outweigh the benefits. All of the regions assessed in the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report (Africa, Asia, Australia and New Zealand, Europe, Latin America, North America, Polar regions (Arctic and Antarctic), and small islands) showed an overall net negative impact of climate change on water resources and freshwater ecosystems. *Semi-arid and arid areas are particularly exposed to the impacts of climate change on freshwater. With very high confidence, it was judged that many of these areas, e.g., the Mediterranean basin, western USA, southern Africa, and north-eastern Brazil, would suffer a decrease in water resources due to climate change. ===Migration and conflict=== An argument can be made that rising ethnic conflicts may be linked to competition over natural resources that are increasingly scarce as a result of climate change (Wilbanks ''et al.'', 2007:365).<ref>{{cite book
column649: pp=357–90}} }}</ref> According to a literature assessment by Wilbanks ''et al.'' (2007:365), other factors need to be taken into account. It was suggested that major environmentally influenced conflicts in Africa have more to do with the relative abundance of resources, e.g., oil and diamonds, than with resource scarcity. On this basis, Wilbanks ''et al.'' (2007:365) suggested that predictions of future conflicts due climate change should be viewed with caution. With high confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007:787) predicted that stresses such as increased drought, water shortages, and riverine and coastal flooding would affect many local and regional populations.<ref name = schneider /> With medium confidence, it was predicted that these stresses would lead, in some cases, to relocation within or between countries. This might have the effect of exacerbating conflicts, and possibly impose migration pressures. Zhang ''et al.'' also concluded that climate change drives conflict.<ref>{{cite doi
column651: Economic impacts of climate change}} Aggregating impacts adds up the total impact of climate change across sectors and/or regions (IPCC, 2007d:76).<ref name= ar4syn /> The impacts of climate change across world population will not be distributed evenly (Smith ''et al.'', 2001:957).<ref>{{cite book
column653: chapter=Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis.
column654: title=Climate Change 2001: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Third Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
column660: accessdate= 2010-01-10}}</ref> IPCC (2007b:17) found that for increases in global mean temperature of less than 1–3°C above 1990 levels, some impacts were projected to produce benefits in some places and sectors, and produce costs in other places and sectors.<ref name=magnitude/> For some low-latitude and polar regions, net costs were projected for small increases in temperature. According to the IPCC (2007b:17), a temperature increase of greater than about 2–3°C would very likely result in all regions either experiencing reductions in net benefits or increases in net costs. ==Regions== Some regions are likely to be especially affected by climate change (IPCC, 2007d:9):<ref name=ar4syn/> *The Arctic, because of high rates of projected warming. *Africa, especially in the sub-Saharan region. This is due to the continent's low capacity to adapt to climate change and projected impacts. *Small islands, due to high exposure of population and infrastructure at risk to sea-level rise and increased storm surge. *Asian megadeltas, due to large populations and high exposure to sea-level rise, storm surge and river flooding. Within other areas, some people are particularly at risk, such as the poor, young children and the elderly. ==Biological systems== {{Main
column663: Effect of climate change on plant biodiversity
column664: Effects of climate change on terrestrial animals
column665: Effects of climate change on marine mammals}} With very high confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007:792) concluded that regional temperature trends were already affecting species and ecosystems around the world.<ref name=schneider/> In a literature assessment, Rosenzweig ''et al.'' (2007:81) concluded that over the last three decades, human-induced warming had likely had a discernable influence on many physical and biological systems.<ref>{{cite book
column667: chapter=Assessment of observed changes and responses in natural and managed systems
column674: pp=79–131}} }}</ref> Schneider ''et al.'' (2007:792) concluded, with high confidence, that climate change would result in the extinction of many species and a reduction in the diversity of ecosystems. * '''Terrestrial ecosystems and biodiversity''': with a warming of 3°C, relative to 1990 levels, it is likely that global terrestrial vegetation would become a net source of carbon (Schneider ''et al.'', 2007:792). With high confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007:788) concluded that a global mean temperature increase of around 4°C (above the 1990–2000 level) by 2100 would lead to major extinctions around the globe. * '''Marine ecosystems and biodiversity''': with very high confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007:792) concluded that a warming of 2°C above 1990 levels would result in mass mortality of coral reefs globally. * '''Freshwater ecosystems''': above about a 4°C increase in global mean temperature by 2100 (relative to 1990–2000), Schneider ''et al.'' (2007:789) concluded, with high confidence, that many freshwater species would become extinct. ==Abrupt or irreversible changes== ===Abrupt climate change=== [[Abrupt climate change]] is defined as a large-scale change in the climate system that takes place over a few decades or less, persists (or is anticipated to persist) for at least a few decades, and causes substantial disruptions in human and natural systems (CCSP, 2008a).<ref>{{cite book
column677: title=Abrupt Climate Change: Summary and Findings (Brochure). A report by the US Climate Change Science Program and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column678: authors = Clark, PU, AJ Weaver (coordinating lead authors), E Brook, ER Cook, TL Delworth, and K. Steffen (chapter lead authors))
column683: accessdate=2010-08-20}}</ref> There is the possibility of a rapid change in glaciers, ice sheets, and hence sea level. Predictions of such a change are highly uncertain due to a lack of scientific understanding. Modeling of the processes associated with a rapid ice sheet and glacier change could potentially increase future projections of sea level rise. ===The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation=== {{See also
column684: Shutdown of thermohaline circulation}} The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is an important component of the Earth's climate system, characterized by a northward flow of warm, salty water in the upper layers of the Atlantic and a southward flow of colder water in the deep Atlantic (CCSP, 2008b, p. 5).<ref>{{cite book
column687: title=Abrupt Climate Change. A report by the US Climate Change Science Program and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column688: authors = Clark, PU, AJ Weaver (coordinating lead authors), E Brook, ER Cook, TL Delworth, and K Steffen (chapter lead authors))
column692: accessdate= 2010-08-20}}</ref> Potential impacts associated with MOC changes include reduced warming or (in the case of abrupt change) absolute cooling of northern high-latitude areas near Greenland and north-western Europe, an increased warming of Southern Hemisphere high-latitudes, tropical drying, as well as changes to marine ecosystems, terrestrial vegetation, oceanic CO<sub>2</sub> uptake, oceanic oxygen concentrations, and shifts in fisheries (Schneider ''et al.'', 2007).<ref>{{citation
column697: chapter = 19.3.5.3 Possible changes in the North Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (MOC)
column699: Parry ''et al.'', 2007]]}}.</ref> According to a assessment by the US [[Climate Change Science Program]] (CCSP, 2008b, p. 5), it is very likely that the strength of the AMOC will decrease over the course of the 21<sup>st</sup> century. Warming is still expected to occur over most of the European region downstream of the North Atlantic Current in response to increasing greenhouse gases, as well as over North America. Although it is very unlikely that the AMOC will collapse in the 21<sup>st</sup> century, the potential consequences of such a collapse could be severe. ===Irreversibilities=== An irreversible change is one where that change, once set in motion, cannot be reversed, at least over some specified timescale, e.g., centuries to millennia (Goldemberg ''et al.'', 1996, p. 22).<ref>{{cite book
column703: title=Climate Change 1995: Economic and Social Dimensions of Climate Change. Contribution of Working Group III to the Second Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
column706: location = Cambridge, UK, and New York, NY, USA; CH
column710: doi = 10.2277/0521568544}}</ref> Climate change is likely to lead to some irreversible impacts (IPCC, 2007d).<ref>{{citation
column715: chapter = 3.4 Risk of abrupt or irreversible changes}}.</ref> One example of a potentially irreversible impact of climate change is damage to ecosystems. ==Footnotes== <sup>1</sup> this statement applies to the SRES temperature projections made in the [[IPCC Third Assessment Report]] (TAR). The projected range in the TAR (1.4–5.8°C over 1990–2100) is slightly different to that given here (1.1–6.4°C by the end of the 21<sup>st</sup> century, above temperatures averaged over the 1980 to 1999 time period), but the two sets of projections are broadly comparable in size. <sup>2</sup> The IPCC report that is referred to in this article uses specific and quantitative language to describe uncertainty (Ahmad ''et al.'', 2001).<ref>{{cite book
column717: author=Ahmad, QK and RA Warrick. Lead Authors: TE Downing, S Nishioka, KS Parikh, C Parmesan, SH Schneider, F Toth, G Yohe. Contributing Authors: AU Ahmed, P Ayton, BB Fitzharris, JE Hay, RN Jones, G Morgan, R Moss, W North, G Petschel-Held, R Richels. Review Editors: I Burton and R Kates
column718: title =2.6. Characterizing Uncertainty and ""Levels of Confidence"" in Climate Assessment. In: Chapter 2. Methods and Tools. In: Climate Change 2001: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Third Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (JJ McCarthy, OF Canziani, NA Leary, DJ Dokken, and KS White, eds.)
column721: location = Cambridge, UK & New York, NY, USA; NO
column723: accessdate= 2010-05-31}}</ref> This language is intended to provide an indication of the level of confidence that IPCC authors have about a particular finding. The qualitative language used to describe uncertainty has a quantitative scale associated with it. The quantitative values for qualitative terms are intended to ensure that confidence levels are interpreted correctly. The is because qualitative statements, e.g., using the word ""likely,"" can be interpreted differently in quantitative terms (Moss and Schneider, 2000, p. 44).<ref>{{cite book
column727: title= Uncertainties. In: IPCC supporting material: guidance papers on the cross cutting issues of the Third Assessment Report of the IPCC (R Pachuari, T Taniguchi and K Tanaka, eds.)
column730: publisher=Global Industrial and Social Progress Research Institute (GISPRI)
column733: accessdate=2010-05-31}}</ref> Quantitative values for confidence statements made in the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report are listed below (IPCC, 2007).<ref>{{cite book
column736: title= F. Communication of uncertainty in the Working Group II Fourth Assessment. In: Foreword, Preface, and Introduction. In: Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (ML Parry, OF Canziani, JP Palutikof, PJ van der Linden and CE Hanson, eds.)
column741: accessdate=2010-05-31}}</ref> These quantitative values are subjective probabilities (Ahmad ''et al.'', 2001, section 2.6.2) that reflect the expert judgement of IPCC authors: *<sup>a</sup> Very high confidence: At least 9 out of 10 chance of being correct *<sup>b</sup> High confidence: About 8 out of 10 chance *<sup>c</sup> Medium confidence: About 5 out of 10 chance *<sup>d</sup> Low confidence: About 2 out of 10 chance *<sup>e</sup> Very low confidence: Less than a 1 out of 10 chance == See also == {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ; General * [[Anthropocene]] * [[Runaway climate change]] * [[Risks to civilization, humans and planet Earth]] * [[Indigenous Peoples Climate Change Assessment Initiative]] * [[Environmental sociology]] ; Regional * [[Arctic Climate Impact Assessment]] * [[Effects of global warming on Australia]] * [[Effects of global warming on India]] * [[Kivalina v. ExxonMobil Corp., Et al.]] * [[Climate Change Science Program#Impacts and adaptation
column742: Bush Administration assessments of impacts and adaptation]] (United States) {{Col-break}} {{Portal
column743: Global warming}} ; Science * [[Biological pump]] * [[Climate Vulnerability Monitor]] (CVM) * [[Oceanic anoxic event]] * [[PRECIS (Providing Regional Climates for Impacts Studies)]] * [[Solubility pump]] {{Col-end}} {{Clear}} == Notes == {{Reflist

column834: accessdate=2011-04-28}} ==External links== ===Physical impacts=== *[http://www.wmo.int/pages/themes/climate/main_climate_change.php ""Climate Change""]. [[World Meteorological Organization]]. *[http://www.ipcc-wg1.unibe.ch/ The IPCC Working Group I (WG I)]. This body assesses the physical scientific aspects of the climate system and climate change. ===Social, economic and ecological impacts=== *[http://www.un.org/esa/dsd/dsd_aofw_cc/cc_index.shtml Climate change] on the United Nations Economic and Social Development (UNESD) Division for Sustainable Development website. *[http://www.ipcc-wg2.gov/ The IPCC Working Group II (WG II) website] – This body assesses the vulnerability of socio-economic and natural systems to climate change, negative and positive consequences of climate change, and options for adapting to it. ===General=== *[http://esa.un.org/subindex/pgViewSites.asp?termCode=QB.25 List of United Nations Functional Commissions and Expert Bodies related to climate change] *[[IRIN]], the humanitarian news and analysis service of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs: [http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=79563 ""What climate change does""], [http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=79508 ""How climate change works""], and [http://www.irinnews.org/IndepthMain.aspx?IndepthId=73&ReportId=78246 ""Gathering Storm - the humanitarian impact of climate change""] *Videos: **[http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=4119472365452589212 ""Educational Forum: Arctic Climate Impact""]. Panel discussion with James J. McCarthy, Professor at Harvard University, and Author; Paul R. Epstein, M.D., instructor in medicine at Harvard Medical School; and Ross Gelbspan, Pulitzer-prize winning journalist and author. Massachusetts School of Law. **[http://climateprogress.org/2010/02/05/videos-humans-are-changing-the-climate-global-warming-threat-chris-field/#more-18551 ""How we know humans are changing the climate and Why climate change is a clear and present danger""]. Interviews with Christopher Field and Michael MacCracken. Christopher Field is the director of the Department of Global Ecology at the Carnegie Institution of Washington, professor of biology and environmental earth system science at Stanford University, and the Working Group II Co-Chair for the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Michael MacCracken is the chief scientist for Climate Change Programs at the Climate Institute and a co-author and contributing author for various chapters in the IPCC assessment reports. Climate Progress website, February 5, 2010. {{Global warming}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Effects Of Global Warming}} [[Category:Climate change]] [[Category:Effects of global warming

column5: small=yes}} [[File:Risks and Impacts of Global Warming.png
column8: The various effects of climate change pose risks that increase with global warming (i.e., increases in the Earth's global mean temperature).<ref name=""burning embers description""> {{citation
column20: 2001}}. </ref> The IPCC<ref name=""burning embers description""/><ref name=""ar4 reasons for concern""> {{citation
column24: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains5-2.html Sec. 5.2 Key vulnerabilities, impacts and risks – long-term perspectives] }}, in {{harvnb
column26: 2007}}. </ref> has organized many of these risks into five ""[[reasons for concern]]:"" threats to endangered species and unique systems, damages from extreme climate events, effects that fall most heavily on developing countries and the poor within countries, global aggregate impacts (i.e., various measurements of total social, economic and ecological impacts),<ref name=""ar4 reasons for concern""/><ref> {{citation
column28: chapter= Chapter 19. Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column32: 2001}}. </ref> and large-scale high-impact events. The above ""burning embers"" diagram was produced by the IPCC in 2001. A later revision of the diagram, published in 2009, but not approved by the IPCC, shows increased risks.<ref> {{Cite journal
column50: coauthors = Corfee-Merlot, J.; Magadza, C.H.D.; Füssel, H.; Pittock, A.B.; Rahman, A.; Suarez, A.; and van Ypersele, J. -->
column51: title = Assessing dangerous climate change through an update of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) ""reasons for concern""
column52: journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
column64: ref = harv }} </ref> ]] The '''effects of [[global warming]]''' are the ecological and social changes caused by the rise in global temperatures. Evidence of [[climate change]] includes the instrumental temperature record, rising [[Current sea level rise
column65: sea level]]s, and decreased snow cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]].<ref name=""direct observations of recent climate change""> {{citation
column69: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-direct-observations.html Direct Observations of Recent Climate Change] }}, in {{harvnb
column71: 2007}}. </ref> Most of the observed increase in global average temperatures since the mid-20th century is very likely due to the observed increase in human [[greenhouse gas]] concentrations<ref> {{citation
column75: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-understanding-and.html Understanding and Attributing Climate Change] }}, in {{harvnb
column77: 2007}}. </ref>. Projections of future climate change suggest further global warming, sea level rise, and an increase in the frequency of some [[extreme weather
column82: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains6-2.html Sec. 6.2 Drivers and projections of future climate changes and their impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column84: 2007}}. </ref> Parties to the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] (UNFCCC) have agreed to implement policies designed to reduce their emissions of greenhouse gases to [[Avoiding dangerous climate change
column85: avoid dangerous climate change]]. ==Definitions== In this article, the phrase “[[climate change]]” is used to describe a change in the climate, measured in terms of its statistical properties, e.g., the global [[mean]] surface [[temperature]].<ref> {{citation
column87: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/annex1sglossary-a-d.html Glossary A-D] ""Climate"" and ""climate change"" }}, in {{harvnb
column89: 2007}} </ref> In this context, “[[climate]]” is taken to mean the average weather. Climate can change over period of time ranging from months to thousands or millions of years. The classical time period is 30 years, as defined by the [[World Meteorological Organization]]. The climate change referred to may be due to natural causes, e.g., changes in the sun's output, or due to human activities, e.g., changing the composition of the atmosphere.<ref> {{citation
column93: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/011.htm Box 1: What drives changes in climate?] }}, in {{harvnb
column95: 2001}} </ref> Any human-induced changes in climate will occur against the “background” of natural climatic variations (see [[attribution of recent climate change]] for more information). In this article, the phrase “global warming” refers to the change in the Earth's global average surface temperature.<ref> {{citation
column98: title= Understanding and Responding to Climate Change
column99: publisher= [http://dels.nas.edu/basc Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate], US National Academy of Sciences
column100: url=http://dels.nas.edu/resources/static-assets/materials-based-on-reports/booklets/climate_change_2008_final.pdf }}, page 4. </ref> Measurements show a global temperature increase of 1.4 °F (0.78 °C) between the years 1900 and 2005. Global warming is closely associated with a broad spectrum of other climate changes, such as increases in the frequency of intense [[rainfall]], decreases in [[snow]] cover and [[sea ice]], more frequent and intense [[heat wave]]s, rising [[current sea level rise
column103: author= America's Climate Choices: Panel on Advancing the Science of Climate Change; National Research Council
column104: contribution= What we know about climate change
column105: title= Advancing the Science of Climate Change (pre-publication edition)
column108: url=http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12782&page=2 }}, page 2. </ref> Also, the term ""anthropogenic forcing"" refers to the influence exerted on a habitat or chemical environment by humans, as opposed to a natural process.<ref>http://www.chemistry-dictionary.com/definition/anthropogenic+forcing.php{{cn
column109: date=June 2012}}</ref> <!-- An anonymous web-site is not a reliable source. Better to go to the article linked to and cite that. -JJ --> ==Temperature changes== [[File:Instrumental Temperature Record (NASA).svg
column112: Global mean surface temperature difference from the average for 1880–2009]] This article breaks down some of the impacts of climate change according to different levels of future global warming. This way of describing impacts has, for instance, been used in the IPCC's Assessment Reports on climate change.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""> {{citation
column114: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column116: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-1.html Sec. 19.3.1 Introduction to Table 19.1] }}, in {{harvnb
column118: 2007}}. </ref> The instrumental [[temperature record]] shows global warming of around 0.6 °C over the entire 20th century.<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""/> ===SRES emissions scenarios=== The future level of global warming is uncertain, but a wide range of estimates (projections) have been made.<ref name=""Overview of GHG emissions scenarios""> {{citation
column120: chapter= Chapter 3: Issues related to mitigation in the long-term context
column124: 2007}} </ref> The IPCC's ""[[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column125: SRES]]"" scenarios have been frequently used to make [[Global climate model#Projections of future climate change
column126: projections of future climate change]].<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column127: 22-24}} The SRES scenarios are ""[[Economics of climate change mitigation#Baselines
column128: baseline]]"" (or ""reference"") scenarios, which means that they do not take into account any current or future measures to limit GHG emissions (e.g., the UNFCCC's [[Kyoto Protocol]] and the [[2010 United Nations Climate Change Conference
column131: chapter= Chapter 2, Greenhouse Gas Emission Mitigation Scenarios and Implications
column133: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/080.htm Sec. 2.5.1.1 IPCC Emissions Scenarios and the SRES Process] }}, in {{harvnb
column135: 2001}}. </ref> Emissions projections of the SRES scenarios are broadly comparable in range to the baseline emissions scenarios that have been developed by the scientific community.<ref> {{citation
column141: 2007}}. </ref><ref name=""Overview of GHG emissions scenarios""/> In the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]], changes in future global mean temperature were projected using the six SRES ""marker"" emissions scenarios.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""> {{citation
column145: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html#table-spm-1 Sec. 1 3. Projected climate change and its impacts: Table SPM.1] }}, in {{harvnb
column147: 2007}}. </ref> Emissions projections for the six SRES ""marker"" scenarios are representative of the full set of forty SRES scenarios.<ref> {{citation
column149: chapter= Chapter 2, Greenhouse Gas Emission Mitigation Scenarios and Implications
column151: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/081.htm#2514 Sec. 2.5.1.4 Emissions and Other Results of the SRES Scenarios] }}, in {{harvnb
column153: 2001}}. </ref> For the lowest emissions SRES marker scenario (""B1"" - see the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column154: SRES]] article for details on this scenario), the best estimate for global mean temperature is an increase of {{convert
column158: 1}}<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> by the end of the 21st century. This projection is relative to global temperatures at the end of the 20th century.<ref>Temperature change in years 2090-2099 relative to years 1980-1999</ref> The ""likely"" range (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> for the SRES B1 marker scenario is {{convert
column164: 1}}.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> For the highest emissions SRES marker scenario (A1FI), the best estimate for global mean temperature increase is {{convert
column174: 1}}.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> The range in temperature projections partly reflects the different choice of emissions scenario.<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column175: 22-24}} Different scenarios make different assumptions of future social and economic development (e.g., [[economic growth]], [[population projection
column177: energy policies]]), which in turn affects projections of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column178: 22-24}} The range also reflects uncertainty in the response of the climate system to past and future GHG emissions (measured by the [[climate sensitivity]]).<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column179: 22-24}} The projected rate of warming under these [[climate change scenario
column180: scenarios]] would very likely be without precedent during at least the last 10,000 years (see [[Effects of global warming#Footnotes
column187: 2001}}. </ref> The most recent warm period comparable to these projections was the mid-[[Pliocene]], around 3 million years ago.<ref> {{cite journal
column191: title= The Economics of Climate Change
column194: journal= American Economic Review: Papers & Proceedings
column202: ref=harv }} </ref> At that time, models suggest that mean global temperatures were about 2–3 °C warmer than pre-industrial temperatures.<ref> {{citation
column206: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch6s6-3-2.html Sec. 6.3.2 What Does the Record of the Mid-Pliocene Show?] }}, in {{harvnb
column209: Physical impacts of climate change}} [[File:Changes in climate indicators that show global warming.png
column212: Key climate indicators that show global warming.<ref name=statecl/>{{Rp
column213: 2-3}}]] Working Group I's contribution to the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]], published in 2007, concluded that warming of the climate system was ""unequivocal.""<ref name=""direct observations of recent climate change""/> This was based on the consistency of evidence across a range of observed changes, including increases in global average air and [[ocean]] temperatures, widespread melting of [[cryosphere
column214: snow and ice]], and [[Current sea level rise
column219: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-3-4.html TS.3.4 Consistency Among Observations] }}, in {{harvnb
column221: 2007}}. </ref> Human activities have contributed to a number of the observed changes in climate.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""> {{citation
column223: chapter= Chapter 9: Understanding and Attributing Climate Change
column227: 2007}}. </ref> This contribution has principally been through the burning of [[fossil fuel]]s, which has led to an increase in the concentration of GHGs in the atmosphere.<ref> {{citation
column231: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-human-and.html Human and Natural Drivers of Climate Change ] }}, in {{harvnb
column233: 2007}}. </ref> Another human influence on the climate are [[sulfur dioxide]] emissions, which are a precursor to the formation of [[sulfate aerosols]] in the atmosphere.<ref> {{cite book
column235: author=Committee on the Science of Climate Change, US National Research Council
column237: title=Climate Change Science: An Analysis of Some Key Questions
column242: isbn=0-309-07574-2 }} </ref> Human-induced warming could potentially lead to some impacts that are abrupt or irreversible (see the section on [[Effects of global warming#Abrupt or irreversible changes
column247: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html Sec. 3. Projected climate change and its impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column250: title=New Study Shows Climate Change Largely Irreversible
column255: date=June 2012}} <!-- A press release is NEVER an acceptable source re scientic study. --></ref> The probability of warming having unforeseen consequences increases with the rate, magnitude, and duration of climate change.<ref> {{cite book
column261: publisher=[[United States National Academy of Sciences]]
column263: year=2002 }}</ref> ===Radiative forcing=== The effect of human activities on the climate system can be measured by [[radiative forcing]]: [[Energy]] is constantly flowing into the atmosphere in the form of [[sunlight]] that always shines on half of the Earth's surface.<ref> {{cite web
