column267: publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) News Office
column268: url=http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2010/explained-radforce-0309.html }}</ref> Some of this sunlight is reflected back to space and the rest is absorbed by the planet. Some energy from the Earth is also radiated back out into space as invisible [[infrared]] light. Radiative forcing is a measure of the energy flowing into the Earth-atmosphere system, minus the energy flowing out. A positive radiative forcing will tend to warm the climate, while a negative forcing will tend to cool the climate.<ref name=""forster radiative forcing""> {{citation
column270: chapter= Chapter 2: Changes in Atmospheric Constituents and in Radiative Forcing
column272: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-2-1.html FAQ 2.1, Box 1: What is Radiative Forcing?] }}, in {{harvnb
column274: 2007}}. </ref> Anthopogenic forcing (i.e., the radiative forcing due to human activities) was estimated to have been positive (i.e., an overall warming effect) in the year 2005.<ref name=""forster radiative forcing""/> This is relative to the estimated forcings at the start of the industrial era, taken as the year 1750. Anthropogenic forcing of the climate has likely contributed to a number of observed changes, including sea level rise, changes in climate [[extreme weather event
column275: extremes]] (such as warm and cold days), declines in [[Arctic sea ice]] extent, and to [[Retreat of glaciers since 1850
column276: glacier retreat]].<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> === Effects on weather === Observations show that there have been changes in weather.<ref> {{citation
column278: chapter= Chapter 1: Historical Overview of Climate Change Science
column280: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-1-2.html FAQ 1.2 What is the Relationship between Climate Change and Weather?] }}, in {{harvnb
column282: 2007}}. </ref> As climate changes, the [[probabilities]] of certain types of weather events are affected. Changes have been observed in the amount, intensity, frequency, and type of [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column289: 18}} Widespread increases in heavy precipitation have occurred, even in places where total rain amounts have decreased. Authors of the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]] concluded that human influences had, more likely than not (greater than 50% probability, based on expert judgement),<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""> {{citation
column293: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-2.html Box TS.1: Treatment of Uncertainties in the Working Group I Assessment] }}, in {{harvnb
column295: 2007}}. </ref> led to an increase in the frequency of heavy precipitation events.<ref name=""ipcc 2007 causes of climate change""/> Projections of future changes in precipitation show overall increases in the global average, but with substantial shifts in where and how precipitation falls. Also, increased extremes of summer dryness and winter wetness are projected for much of the globe, meaning a generally greater risk of droughts and floods.<ref name = ""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column297: Climate model]]s tend to project increasing precipitation at high latitudes and in the [[tropics]] (e.g., the south-east [[monsoon]] region and over the tropical [[Pacific]]) and decreasing precipitation in the [[subtropics
column298: sub-tropics]] (e.g., over much of [[North Africa]] and the northern [[Sahara]]).<ref> {{citation
column300: chapter= Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column302: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch3s3-3-1.html 3.3.1 Climatic drivers - Projections for the future] }}, in {{harvnb
column304: 2007}}. </ref> Using the [[Palmer Drought Severity Index]], a 2010 study by the [[National Center for Atmospheric Research]] projects increasingly dry conditions across much of the globe in the next 30 years, possibly reaching a scale in some regions by the end of the century that has rarely, if ever, been observed in modern times.<ref>{{cite web
column305: title=Climate change: Drought may threaten much of globe within decades
column308: accessdate=23 March 2012}}</ref> Evidence suggests that, since the 1970s, there have been substantial increases in the intensity and duration of [[tropical storm]]s and hurricanes.<ref> {{citation
column310: chapter= Chapter 3: Observations: Surface and Atmospheric Climate Change
column312: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-3-3.html FAQ 3.3 Has there been a Change in Extreme Events like Heat Waves, Droughts, Floods and Hurricanes?] }}, in {{harvnb
column314: 2007}}. </ref> Models project a general tendency for more intense but fewer storms outside the [[tropics]].<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column318: [[Accumulated cyclone energy]] in the [[Atlantic Ocean]] and the sea surface temperature difference which influences such, measured by the U.S. [[NOAA]].]] ==== Extreme weather ==== {{See also
column321: List of Atlantic hurricane records}} Since the late 20th century, changes have been observed in the trends of some extreme weather and climate events, e.g., [[heat wave]]s.<ref name=""solomon extreme events""> {{citation
column327: 2007}}. </ref> Human activities have, with varying degrees of confidence, contributed to some of these observed trends. Projections for the 21st century suggest continuing changes in trends for some extreme events. Solomon ''et al.'' (2007),<ref name=""solomon extreme events""/> for example, projected the following likely (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> changes: *an increase in the areas affected by [[drought]]; *increased tropical cyclone activity; *and increased incidence of extreme high [[Current sea level rise
column328: sea level]] (excluding [[tsunami]]s). Projected changes in extreme events will have predominantly adverse impacts on ecosystems and human society.<ref> {{citation
column336: chapter= Synthesis Report, Topic 5: The long-term perspective
column338: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains5-2.html Sec. 5.2 Key vulnerabilities, impacts and risks – long-term perspectives] }}, pp.64–65, in {{harvnb
column341: Retreat of glaciers since 1850}} [[File:Glacier Mass Balance Map.png
column345: A map of the change in thickness of mountain glaciers since 1970. Thinning in orange and red, thickening in blue.]] Authors of the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report (AR4) found that, on average, mountain glaciers and snow cover had decreased in both the northern and southern hemispheres.<ref name=""direct observations of recent climate change""/> This widespread decrease in glaciers and ice caps had contributed to observed sea level rise. With very high or high confidence (see [[Effects of global warming#Footnotes
column346: footnote 2]]), authors of the IPCC Working Group II Assessment {{Harv
column352: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/spmsspm-c-1-freshwater-resources.html Freshwater resources and their management] }}, in {{harvnb
column358: chapter= Summary for Policymakers, Sec. 3. Projected climate change and its impacts
column362: 2007}}. </ref> made a number of projections relating to future changes in glaciers: *Mountainous areas in [[Europe]] will face glacier retreat *In [[Polar region]]s, there will be reductions in glacier extent and the thickness of glaciers. *More than one-sixth of the world's population are supplied by meltwater from major mountain ranges. Changes in glaciers and snow cover are expected to reduce water availability for these populations. *In [[Latin America]], changes in precipitation patterns and the disappearance of glaciers will significantly affect water availability for human consumption, agriculture, and energy production. ===Geology=== ====Volcanoes==== {{see also
column363: Post-glacial rebound}} The retreat of glaciers and ice caps can cause increased [[volcanism]]. Reduction in ice cover reduces the [[confining pressure]] exerted on the volcano, increasing [[deviatoric stress]]es and potentially causing the volcano to erupt. This reduction of pressure can also cause [[Magma#Partial melting
column364: decompression melting]] of material in the mantle, resulting in the generation of more magma.<ref>{{cite journal
column366: title=Will present day glacier retreat increase volcanic activity? Stress induced by recent glacier retreat and its effect on magmatism at the Vatnajökull ice cap, Iceland
column376: issue=9}}</ref> Researchers in Iceland have shown that the rate of volcanic rock production there following deglaciation (10,000 to 4500 years [[before present]]) was 20–30 times greater than that observed after 2900 years before present.<ref>{{cite journal
column378: title=Effect of glacier loading/deloading on volcanism: postglacial volcanic production rate of the Dyngjufj�ll area, central Iceland
column390: issue=5}}</ref> While the original study addresses the first reason for increased volcanism (reduced confining pressure), scientists have more recently shown that these lavas have unusually high [[trace element]] concentrations, indicative of increased melting in the mantle.<ref>{{cite journal
column392: title=Deglaciation effects on mantle melting under Iceland: results from the northern volcanic zone
column405: bibcode=1998E&PSL.164..151S}}</ref> This work in Iceland has been corroborated by a study in California, in which scientists found a strong correlation between volcanism and periods of global deglaciation.<ref>{{cite journal
column407: title=Did melting glaciers cause volcanic eruptions in eastern California? Probing the mechanics of dike formation
column414: bibcode=2004JGRB..10909206J}}</ref> The effects of [[current sea level rise]] could include increased [[crust (geology)
column415: crustal]] stress at the base of coastal volcanoes from a rise in the volcano's [[water table]] (and the associated [[saltwater intrusion]]), while the mass from extra water could activate dormant [[seismic fault]]s around volcanoes. In addition, the wide-scale displacement of water from melting in places such as [[West Antarctica]] is likely to slightly alter the Earth's [[rotational period]] and may shift its [[axial tilt]] on the scale of hundreds of metres, inducing further crustal stress changes.<ref>{{cite book
column418: title=Raging planet: earthquakes, volcanoes, and the tectonic threat to life on earth
column426: title=Collapse Of Antarctic Ice Sheet Would Likely Put Washington, D.C. Largely Underwater
column431: date=February 6, 2009}}</ref> Current melting of ice is predicted to increase the size and frequency of volcanic eruptions.<ref name=""rs_volc"">{{cite journal
column434: title=How will melting of ice affect volcanic hazards in the twenty-first century?
column435: journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
column442: bibcode = 2010RSPTA.368.2535T }}</ref> In particular, lateral collapse events at [[stratovolcano]]es are likely to increase,<ref name=""rs_volc""/><ref>{{cite journal
column449: title=Climate forcing of volcano lateral collapse: evidence from Mount Etna, Sicily
column450: journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
column457: bibcode = 2010RSPTA.368.2559D }}</ref> and there are potential positive feedbacks between the removal of ice and magmatism.<ref name=""rs_volc""/> ====Earthquakes==== A [[numerical model]]ing study has demonstrated that [[seismicity]] increases during unloading, such as that due to the removal of ice.<ref>{{cite journal
column464: title=Response of faults to climate-driven changes in ice and water volumes on Earth's surface
column465: journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
column472: bibcode = 2010RSPTA.368.2501H }}</ref> ===Oceans=== The role of the oceans in global warming is a complex one. The oceans serve as a sink for carbon dioxide, taking up much that would otherwise remain in the atmosphere, but increased levels of {{chem
column474: 2}} have led to [[ocean acidification]]. Furthermore, as the temperature of the oceans increases, they become less able to absorb excess {{chem
column476: 2}}. The ocean have also acted as a sink in absorbing extra heat from the atmosphere. This extra heat has been added to the climate system due to the build-up of GHGs. More than 90 percent of warming that occurred over 1960–2009 is estimated to have gone into the oceans.<ref name=statecl> {{cite book
column479: publisher = Website of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration: National Climatic Data Center
column480: title = State of the Climate in 2009, as appearing in the July 2010 issue (Vol. 91) of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society (BAMS). Supplemental and Summary Materials: Report at a Glance: Highlights
column483: 4}} Global warming is projected to have a number of effects on the oceans. Ongoing effects include rising sea levels due to thermal expansion and melting of glaciers and ice sheets, and warming of the ocean surface, leading to increased temperature stratification. Other possible effects include large-scale changes in ocean circulation. ====Acidification==== {{Main
column484: Ocean acidification}} About one-third of the carbon dioxide emitted by human activity has already been taken up by the oceans.<ref name=""nrc 2008b ocean acidification""> {{cite book
column486: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column490: 2008b}} </ref> As carbon dioxide dissolves in [[sea water]], [[carbonic acid]] is formed, which has the effect of acidifying the ocean, measured as a change in [[pH]]. The uptake of human carbon emissions since the year 1750 has led to an average decrease in pH of 0.1 units.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 ocean acidification""> {{citation
column496: 2007}}. </ref> Projections using the SRES emissions scenarios suggest a further reduction in average global surface ocean pH of between 0.14 and 0.35 units over the 21st century. The effects of ocean acidification on the marine [[biosphere]] have yet to be documented.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 ocean acidification""/> Laboratory experiments suggest beneficial effects for a few species, with potentially highly detrimental effects for a substantial number of species.<ref name=""nrc 2008b ocean acidification""/> With medium confidence, Fischlin ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column498: chapter = Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods, and services
column502: 2007}}. </ref> projected that future ocean acidification and climate change would impair a wide range of [[plankton]]ic and shallow [[benthos
column503: benthic]] marine organisms that use [[aragonite]] to make their shells or skeletons, such as [[coral]]s and marine [[snail]]s ([[pteropoda
column504: pteropods]]), with significant impacts particularly in the Southern Ocean. ====Oxygen depletion==== The amount of oxygen dissolved in the oceans may decline, with adverse consequences for ocean life.<ref>{{cite doi
column513: caption1=Sea level rise during the Holocene.
column514: caption2=Sea level has been rising {{#expr: 20/120 round 1}} cm/yr, based on measurements of [[sea level rise]] from 23 long [[tide gauge]] records in geologically stable environments. }} There is strong evidence that global sea level rose gradually over the 20th century.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""> {{citation
column516: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column518: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-5-1.html FAQ 5.1 Is Sea Level Rising?] }}, in {{harvnb
column522: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column526: 2007}}. </ref> concluded that between the mid-19th and mid-20th centuries, the rate of sea level rise increased. Authors of the IPCC Fourth Assessment Synthesis Report (IPCC AR4 SYR, 2007)<ref name= ""Observed changes in climate and their effects""> {{citation
column530: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms1.html Sec. 1. Observed changes in climate and their effects] }}, p. 5, in {{harvnb
column532: 2007}}. </ref> reported that between the years 1961 and 2003, global average sea level rose at an average rate of 1.8 mm per year (mm/yr), with a range of 1.3–2.3 mm/yr. Between 1993 and 2003, the rate increased above the previous period to 3.1 mm/yr (range of 2.4–3.8 mm/yr). Authors of IPCC AR4 SYR (2007)<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""/> were uncertain whether the increase in rate from 1993 to 2003 was due to [[climate change#Internal forcing mechanisms
column533: natural variations]] in sea level over the time period, or whether it reflected an increase in the underlying long-term trend. There are two main factors that have contributed to observed sea level rise.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""/> The first is [[thermal expansion]]: as ocean water warms, it expands.<ref> {{citation
column537: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/013.htm#b4 Box 2: What causes sea level to change?] }}, in {{harvnb
column539: 2007}}. </ref> The second is from the contribution of land-based ice due to increased melting. The major store of water on land is found in glaciers and ice sheets. Anthropogenic forcing very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> contributed to sea level rise during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> There is a widespread consensus that substantial long-term sea level rise will continue for centuries to come.<ref> {{citation
column540: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column543: 2010}}. <!-- XX Citation needs checking and expanding. --> </ref> In the Fourth Annual Review the IPCC<ref> {{citation
column545: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column549: 2007}}. </ref> projected sea level rise to the end of the 21st century using the SRES emissions scenarios. Across the six SRES marker scenarios, sea level was projected to rise by 18 to 59 cm (7.1 to 23.2 in), relative to sea level at the end of the 20th century.<ref>change in sea level by 2090–99, relative to 1980–99</ref> Thermal expansion is the largest component in these projections, contributing 70-75% of the central estimate for all scenarios.<ref> {{citation
column555: 2007}}. </ref> Due to a lack of scientific understanding, this sea level rise estimate does not include all of the possible contributions of ice sheets (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Abrupt or irreversible changes
column556: abrupt or irreversible changes]]). An assessment of the [[scientific literature]] on climate change was published in 2010 by the [[US National Research Council]] (NRC, 2010).<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""> {{citation
column558: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column561: 2010}}. </ref> NRC (2010)<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> described the projections in AR4 (i.e., those cited in the above paragraph) as ""conservative,"" and summarized the results of more recent studies. Cited studies suggested a great deal of uncertainty in projections.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> A range of projections suggested possible sea level rise by the end of the 21st century of between 0.56 and 2 m, relative to sea levels at the end of the 20th century.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> ====Ocean temperature rise==== From 1961 to 2003, the global ocean temperature has risen by 0.10 °C from the surface to a depth of 700 m. There is variability both year-to-year and over longer time scales, with global ocean heat content observations showing high rates of warming for 1991–2003, but some cooling from 2003 to 2007.<ref> {{citation
column563: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column567: 2007}}.{{full}} </ref> The temperature of the Antarctic [[Southern Ocean]] rose by 0.17 °C (0.31 °F) between the 1950s and the 1980s, nearly twice the rate for the world's oceans as a whole.<ref> {{cite journal
column571: title= Warming of the Southern Ocean Since the 1950s
column581: ref=harv }}</ref> As well as having effects on ecosystems (e.g. by melting sea ice, affecting algae that grow on its underside), warming reduces the ocean's ability to absorb {{chem
column584: date=June 2008}} It is likely (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> that anthropogenic forcing contributed to the general warming observed in the upper several hundred metres of the ocean during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> ==Regions== {{Main
column585: Regional effects of global warming}} [[Image:Global Warming Map.jpg
column588: Mean surface temperature change for 1999–2008 relative to the average temperatures from 1940 to 1980]] Regional effects of global warming vary in nature. Some are the result of a generalised global change, such as rising temperature, resulting in local effects, such as melting ice. In other cases, a change may be related to a change in a particular ocean current or weather system. In such cases, the regional effect may be disproportionate and will not necessarily follow the global trend. There are three major ways in which global warming will make changes to regional climate: melting or forming ice, changing the [[hydrological cycle]] (of [[evaporation]] and [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column590: currents in the ocean]]s and air flows in the atmosphere. The coast can also be considered a region, and will suffer severe impacts from [[sea level rise]]. ===Observed impacts=== With very high confidence, Rosenzweig ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> concluded that physical and biological systems on all continents and in most oceans had been affected by recent climate changes, particularly regional temperature increases. Impacts include earlier leafing of [[tree]]s and [[plant]]s over many regions; movements of species to higher latitudes and altitudes in the Northern Hemisphere; changes in [[bird migration]]s in Europe, North America and Australia; and shifting of the oceans' [[plankton]] and [[fish]] from cold- to warm-adapted communities.<ref name=""nasa briefs""/> The human influence on the climate can be seen in the geographical pattern of observed warming, with greater temperature increases over land and in [[polar region]]s rather than over the oceans.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""> {{cite book
column592: title=Understanding and Responding to Climate Change. A brochure prepared by the US National Research Council (US NRC)
column593: publisher=[http://dels.nas.edu/basc Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate], National Academy of Sciences
column597: 6}} Using models, it is possible to identify the human ""signal"" of global warming over both land and ocean areas.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""/>{{Rp
column598: 6}} ===Projected impacts=== Projections of future climate changes at the regional scale do not hold as high a level of scientific confidence as projections made at the global scale.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""/>{{Rp
column599: 9}} It is, however, expected that future warming will follow a similar geographical pattern to that seen already, with greatest warming over land and high northern [[latitude]]s, and least over the [[Southern Ocean]] and parts of the [[North Atlantic Ocean]].<ref> {{citation
column603: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-projections-of.html Projections of Future Changes in Climate] }}, in {{harvnb
column605: 2007}}. </ref> Nearly all land areas will very likely warm more than the global average.<ref name=""tar table of robust findings""> {{citation
column612: megadelta]]s are regions that are likely to be especially affected by climate change.<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions""> {{citation
column616: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-3.html Sec. 3.3.3 Especially affected systems, sectors and regions] }}, in {{harvnb
column618: 2007}}. </ref> Adverse impacts of climate change are expected to fall disproportionately upon developing countries.<ref name=""tar table of robust findings""/> Within other areas, even those with high incomes, some people can be particularly at risk from climate change, such as the poor, young [[children]] and the [[elderly]].<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions""/> ==Social systems== {{Main
column619: Effects of climate change on humans
column620: Climate change, industry and society}} The impacts of climate change can be thought of in terms of sensitivity and vulnerability. ""Sensitivity"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be affected, positively or negatively, by climate change and/or [[climate change#Causes
column621: climate variability]]. ""Vulnerability"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be adversely affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
column625: 2007}}. </ref> The sensitivity of human society to climate change varies. Sectors sensitive to climate change include water resources, coastal zones, human settlements, and human health. Industries sensitive to climate change include [[climate change and agriculture
column632: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/008.htm#24 Sec. 2.4. Many Human Systems are Sensitive to Climate Change, and Some are Vulnerable] }}, in {{harvnb
column636: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column644: 2007–2008 world food price crisis}} Climate change will impact agriculture and food production around the world due to: the effects of elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere, higher temperatures, altered precipitation and [[transpiration]] regimes, increased frequency of extreme events, and modified [[weed]], [[pest (organism)
column647: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column649: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch5s5-4.html#5-4-1 5.4.1 Primary effects and interactions] }}, in {{harvnb
column652: p=282}}. </ref> In general, low-latitude areas are at most risk of having decreased crop yields.<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> So far, the effects of regional climate change on agriculture have been relatively limited.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""> {{citation
column654: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column658: 2007}}. </ref> Changes in crop [[phenology]] provide important evidence of the response to recent regional climate change.<ref> {{citation
column660: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column662: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-6-1.html Sec. 1.3.6.1 Crops and livestock] }}, in {{harvnb
column664: 2007}}. </ref> Phenology is the study of natural phenomena that recur periodically, and how these phenomena relate to climate and seasonal changes.<ref> {{citation
column668: 2007}}. </ref> A significant advance in phenology has been observed for agriculture and forestry in large parts of the Northern Hemisphere.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> ====Projections==== With low to medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> projected that for about a 1 to 3 °C increase in global mean temperature (by the years 2090-2100, relative to temperature in the years 1990–2000), there would be productivity decreases for some [[cereal]]s in low latitudes, and productivity increases in high latitudes. With medium confidence, global production potential was projected to:<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> *increase up to around 3 °C, *very likely decrease above about 3 °C. Most of the studies on global agriculture assessed by Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> had not incorporated a number of critical factors, including changes in extreme events, or the spread of pests and diseases. Studies had also not considered the development of specific practices or technologies to aid [[adaptation to global warming#Agricultural production
column669: adaptation to climate change]].<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""> {{citation
column671: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column678: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column680: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch5s5-6-5.html Sec. 5.6.5 Food security and vulnerability] }}, in {{harvnb
column682: 2007}}. </ref> assessed studies that made quantitative projections of climate change impacts on [[food security]]. It was noted that these projections were highly uncertain and had limitations. However, the assessed studies suggested a number of fairly robust findings. The first was that climate change would likely increase the number of people at risk of [[hunger]] compared with reference scenarios with no climate change. Climate change impacts depended strongly on projected future social and economic development. Additionally, the magnitude of climate change impacts was projected to be smaller compared to the impact of social and economic development. In 2006, the global estimate for the number of people [[malnutrition
column688: accessdate=2011-07-07 }} </ref> Under the SRES A1, B1, and B2 scenarios (see the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios#Scenario families
column689: SRES article]] for information on each scenario group), projections for the year 2080 showed a reduction in the number of people undernourished of about 560-700 million people, with a global total of undernourished people of 100-240 million in 2080. By contrast, the SRES A2 scenario showed only a small decrease in the risk of hunger from 2006 levels. The smaller reduction under A2 was attributed to the higher projected future population level in this scenario. ===Health=== Human beings are exposed to climate change through changing weather patterns (temperature, precipitation, sea-level rise and more frequent extreme events) and indirectly through changes in water, air and food quality and changes in ecosystems, agriculture, industry and settlements and the economy (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007:393).<ref name=""health summary""/> According to an assessment of the scientific literature by Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007:393),<ref name=""health summary""/> the effects of climate change to date have been small, but are projected to progressively increase in all countries and regions. A study by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO, 2009)<ref> {{cite book
column692: title= Global health risks: mortality and burden of disease attributable to selected major risks
column700: url= http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/global_health_risks/en/index.html }} </ref> estimated the effect of climate change on human health. Not all of the effects of climate change were included in their estimates, for example, the effects of more frequent and extreme storms were excluded. Climate change was estimated to have been responsible for 3% of [[diarrhoea]], 3% of [[malaria]], and 3.8% of [[dengue fever]] deaths worldwide in 2004. Total attributable mortality was about 0.2% of deaths in 2004; of these, 85% were child deaths. ====Projections==== With high confidence, authors of the IPCC AR4 Synthesis report<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report""/>{{Rp
column701: 48}} projected that climate change would bring some benefits in temperate areas, such as fewer deaths from cold exposure, and some mixed effects such as changes in range and transmission potential of [[malaria]] in [[Africa]]. Benefits were projected to be outweighed by negative health effects of rising temperatures, especially in developing countries. With very high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/>{{Rp
column702: 393}} concluded that economic development was an important component of possible adaptation to climate change. Economic growth on its own, however, was not judged to be sufficient to insulate the world's population from disease and injury due to climate change. Future vulnerability to climate change will depend not only on the extent of social and economic change, but also on how the benefits and costs of change are distributed in society.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""> {{citation
column706: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-3-2.html Sec. 8.3.2 Future vulnerability to climate change] }}, in {{harvnb
column708: 2007}}. </ref> For example, in the 19th century, rapid [[urbanization]] in [[western Europe]] lead to a plummeting in population health.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""/> Other factors important in determining the health of populations include [[education]], the availability of health services, and [[public health
column712: date=May 2010}} =====Malnutrition===== With high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) projected that malnutrition would increase due to climate change.<ref name=""health summary""> {{citation
column718: 2007}}. </ref> This link is associated with climate variability and change.<ref name=""drought nutrition"">{{citation
column722: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-3.html Sec. 8.2.3 Drought, nutrition and food security] }}, in {{harvnb
column726: consumption]]. This can lead to [[micronutrient]] deficiencies. The WHO (referred to by Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007)<ref name=""who projections""> {{citation
column730: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-4-1-1.html Sec. 8.4.1.1 Global burden of disease study] }}, in {{harvnb
column732: 2007}}. </ref> conducted a regional and global assessment to quantify the amount of premature [[morbidity]] and [[death
column733: mortality]] due to a range of factors, including climate change. Projections were made over future climate change impacts. Limited adjustments for adaptation were included in the estimates based on these projections. Projected relative risks attributable to climate change in 2030 varied by health outcome and region. Risks were largely negative, with most of the projected disease burden due to increases in diarrhoeal disease and malnutrition. These increases were primarily in low-income populations already experiencing a large burden of disease. =====Extreme events===== With high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) projected that climate change would increase the number of people suffering from death, disease and injury from [[heatwave]]s, [[flood]]s, [[storm]]s, [[fire]]s and [[drought]]s.<ref name=""health summary""/> ;Floods and weather disasters Floods are low-probability, high-impact events that can overwhelm physical infrastructure and human communities.<ref name=""Health impacts of wind, storms and floods""> {{citation
column737: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-2.html Sec. 8.2.2 Wind, storms and floods] }}, in {{harvnb
column739: 2007}}. </ref> Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) reported that major storm and flood disasters have occurred in the last two decades. The impacts of weather disasters is considerable and unequally distributed.<ref name=""Health impacts of wind, storms and floods""/> For example, natural disasters have been shown to result in increased domestic violence against - and [[posttraumatic stress disorder
column740: post-traumatic stress disorders]] in – [[women]]. In terms of deaths and populations affected, floods and tropical cyclones have the greatest impact in South Asia and Latin America. Vulnerability to weather disasters depends on the attributes of the person at risk, including where they live and their age, as well as other social and environmental factors. High-density populations in low-lying coastal regions experience a high health burden from weather disasters. ;Heatwaves Hot days, hot nights and heatwaves have become more frequent.<ref> {{citation
column746: 2007}}. </ref> Heatwaves are associated with marked short-term increases in mortality. For example, in August 2003, a heatwave in Europe resulted in excess mortality in the range of 35,000 total deaths. Heat-related morbidity and mortality is projected to increase.<ref name=""heat and cold related mortality""> {{citation
column750: at = [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-4-1-3.html Sec. 8.4.1.3 Heat- and cold-related mortality] }}, in {{harvnb
column752: 2007}}. </ref> The health burden could be relatively small for moderate heatwaves in temperate regions, because deaths occur primarily in susceptible persons. ;Drought The effects of drought on health include deaths, malnutrition, [[infectious disease]]s and [[respiratory disease]]s.<ref name=""drought nutrition""/> Countries within the ""[[Meningitis]] Belt"" in semi-arid sub-Saharan Africa experience the highest [[endemic (epidemiology)
column754: meningococcal]] meningitis in Africa, although other areas in the Rift Valley, the Great Lakes, and southern Africa are also affected.<ref> {{citation
column758: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-3-1.html Sec. 8.2.3.1 Drought and infectious disease] }}, in {{harvnb
column760: 2007}}. </ref> The spatial distribution, intensity, and seasonality of meningococcal (epidemic) meningitis appear to be strongly linked to climate and environmental factors, particularly drought. The cause of this link is not fully understood. ;Fires In some regions, changes in temperature and precipitation are projected to increase the frequency and severity of fire events.<ref> {{citation
column764: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-6-3.html Sec. 8.2.6.3 Air pollutants from forest fires] }}, in {{harvnb
column766: 2007}}. </ref> Forest and bush fires cause burns, damage from smoke inhalation and other injuries. =====Infectious disease vectors===== With high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/> projected that climate change would continue to change the range of some [[infectious disease]] vectors. [[Vector (epidemiology)
column767: Vector-borne diseases]] (VBD) are infections transmitted by the bite of infected [[arthropod]] species, such as [[mosquito]]es, [[tick]]s, [[triatominae
column774: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-8.html Sec. 8.2.8 Vector-borne, rodent-borne and other infectious diseases] }}, in {{harvnb
column776: 2007}}. </ref> There is some evidence of climate-change-related shifts in the distribution of tick vectors of disease, of some (non-malarial) mosquito vectors in Europe and North America. Climate change has also been implicated in changes in the breeding and migration dates of several bird species. Several species of wild bird can act as carriers of human [[pathogen]]s as well as of vectors of infectious agents. ======Dengue====== With low confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) concluded that climate change would increase the number of people at risk of dengue.<ref name=""health summary""/> [[dengue fever
column777: Dengue]] is the world's most important vector-borne viral disease.<ref> {{citation
column783: 2007}}. </ref> Several studies have reported associations between dengue and climate, however, these associations are not entirely consistent. [[File:Malaria mortality past century.jpg
column787: Observed malaria mortality: Although showing such over the past century of global warming, there are [[Malaria#Prevention
column788: also other factors impacting the past and future of malaria]].]] ======Malaria====== The spatial distribution, intensity of transmission, and seasonalty of [[malaria]] is influenced by climate in [[Sub-saharan Africa]].<ref> {{citation
column794: 2007}}. </ref> Rainfall can be a limiting factor for mosquito populations and there is some evidence of reductions in transmission associated with decadal decreases in rainfall. The effects of observed climate change on the geographical distribution of malaria and its transmission intensity in highland regions remains controversial. There is no clear evidence that malaria has been affected by climate change in South America or in continental regions of the Russian Federation. There is still much uncertainty about the potential impact of climate change on malaria at local and global scales. {{Undue
column796: date=May 2010}} A paper by researchers from the [[University of Oxford]] and the [[University of Florida]] published in [[Nature (journal)
column797: Nature]] in May 2010 concluded that claims that a warming climate has led to more widespread disease and death due to malaria are largely at odds with the evidence, and that ""''predictions of an intensification of malaria in a warmer world, based on extrapolated empirical relationships or biological mechanisms, must be set against a context of a century of warming that has seen marked global declines in the disease and a substantial weakening of the global correlation between malaria endemicity and climate.''""<ref> {{cite journal
column798: author= Peter W. Gething, David L. Smith, Anand P. Patil, Andrew J. Tatem, Robert W. Snow & Simon I. Hay
column799: title= Climate change and the global malaria recession
column812: title=Don’t sweat it: Development and public-health initiatives will matter much more to malaria than the climate will
column815: accessdate=2010-05-25 }}</ref> ======Other infectious diseases====== There is good evidence that diseases transmitted by [[rodent]]s sometimes increase during heavy rainfall and flooding because of altered patterns of human-pathogen-rodent contact.<ref> {{citation
column819: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-8-3.html Sec. 8.2.8.3 Other infectious diseases] }}, in {{harvnb
column821: 2007}}. </ref> ======Projections====== With very high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/> concluded that climate change would have mixed effects on malaria. Malaria is a complex disease to model and all of the published models assessed by Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) had limited [[Parametrization (climate)
column826: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-4-1-2.html Sec. 8.4.1.2 Malaria, dengue and other infectious diseases] }}, in {{harvnb
column828: 2007}}. </ref> Parametrization is used in [[climate model]]s because the resolution of models is insufficient to resolve some physical processes.<ref> {{citation
column830: chapter= Chapter 8: Climate Models and their Evaluation
column834: 2007}}. </ref> Given this limitation, models assessed by Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) projected that, particularly in Africa, climate change would be associated with geographical expansions of the areas suitable for ''Plasmodium falciparum'' malaria in some regions, and contractions in other regions. Projections also suggested that some regions would experience a longer season of transmission. Projections suggested expansions in vector species that carry dengue for parts of Australia and New Zealand. =====Diarrhoeal diseases===== With medium confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/> concluded that climate change would increase the burden of diarrhoeal diseases. Childhood mortality due to diarrhoea in low-income countries, especially in Sub-Saharan Africa, remains high.<ref> {{citation
column838: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-5.html Sec.8.2.5 Water and disease] }}, in {{harvnb
column840: 2007}}. </ref> This is despite improvements in care. Several studies have shown that transmission of [[intestine
column841: enteric]] pathogens is higher during the rainy season. Some studies have found that higher temperature was strongly associated with increased episodes of diarrhoeal disease in adults and children in Peru. The WHO study, referred to earlier, projected that climate change would increase the burden of diarrhoeal diseases in low-income regions by approximately 2 to 5% in 2020.<ref name=""who projections""/> =====Ground-level ozone===== With high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/> projected that climate change would increase cardio-respiratory morbidity and mortality associated with ground-level [[ozone]]. Ground-level ozone is both naturally occurring and is the primary constituent of urban [[smog]].<ref> {{citation
column845: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-6.html Sec. 8.2.6 Air quality and disease] }}, in {{harvnb
column847: 2007}}. </ref> Ozone in smog is formed through chemical reactions involving [[nitrogen oxide]]s and other compounds. The reaction is a [[photochemical reaction]], meaning that it involves [[electromagnetic radiation]], and occurs in the presence of bright sunshine and high temperatures. Exposure to elevated concentrations of ozone is associated with increased hospital admissions for [[pneumonia]], [[chronic obstructive pulmonary disease]], [[asthma]], allergic [[rhinitis]] and other respiratory diseases, and with premature mortality. Background levels of ground-level ozone have risen since pre-industrial times because of increasing emissions of methane, [[carbon monoxide]] and nitrogen oxides.<ref> {{citation
column851: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-4-1-4.html Sec. 8.4.1.4 Urban air quality] }}, in {{harvnb
column853: 2007}}. </ref> This trend is expected to continue into the mid-21st century. =====Cold-waves===== [[cold wave
column854: Cold-waves]] continue to be a problem in northern latitudes, where very low temperatures can be reached in a few hours and extend over long periods.<ref> {{citation
column860: 2007}}. </ref> Reductions in cold-deaths due to climate change are projected to be greater than increases in heat-related deaths in the UK.<ref name=""heat and cold related mortality""/> [[File:NOAAprecipitationtrend.jpg
column863: Precipitation during the 20th century and up through 2008 during global warming, the [[NOAA]] estimating an observed trend over that period of 1.87% global precipitation increase per century.]] ===Water resources=== {{See also
column864: Water crisis}} A number of climate-related trends have been observed that affect [[water resources]]. These include changes in precipitation, the crysosphere and [[surface water]]s (e.g., changes in [[river flows]]).<ref> {{citation
column866: chapter = Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column870: 2007}}. </ref> Observed and projected impacts of climate change on [[freshwater]] systems and their management are mainly due to changes in temperature, sea level and precipitation variability.<ref name=""freshwater impacts""> {{citation
column872: chapter= Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column874: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch3s3-es.html Sec. 3.3 Executive summary] }}, p. 175, in {{harvnb
column876: 2007}}. </ref> Sea level rise will extend areas of [[salinization]] of [[groundwater]] and [[estuary
column877: estuaries]], resulting in a decrease in freshwater availability for humans and ecosystems in coastal areas. In an assessment of the [[scientific literature]], Kundzewicz ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""freshwater impacts""/> concluded, with high confidence, that: *the negative impacts of climate change on freshwater systems outweigh the benefits. All of the regions assessed in the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]] ([[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], [[Europe]], [[Latin America]], [[North America]], [[Polar region]]s ([[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]]), and small islands) showed an overall net negative impact of climate change on water resources and freshwater ecosystems. *[[semi-arid climate
column878: Semi-arid]] and [[arid]] areas are particularly exposed to the impacts of climate change on freshwater. With very high confidence, it was judged that many of these areas, e.g., the [[Mediterranean basin]], [[Western United States]], [[Southern Africa]], and north-eastern [[Brazil]], would suffer a decrease in water resources due to climate change. ===Migration and conflict=== {{See also
column880: General circulation model]]s project that the future climate change will bring wetter coasts, drier mid-continent areas, and further sea level rise.<ref name=""sar migration""> {{citation
column882: chapter= Chapter 12: Human settlements in a changing climate: impacts and adaptation
column883: at= Sec. 12.3.1 Population Migration }}, pp. 406—407, in {{harvnb
column885: 1996}}. </ref> Such changes could result in the gravest effects of climate change through sudden [[human migration]]. Millions might be displaced by [[shoreline erosion]]s, river and coastal [[flood]]ing, or severe [[drought]]. Migration related to climate change is likely to be predominantly from [[rural area]]s in [[developing countries]] to towns and [[cities]].<ref name=""sar migration""/>{{Rp
column888: title = Managing social risks: Empower communities to protect themselves
column889: chapter = Part One: Chapter 2: Reducing Human Vulnerability: Helping People Help Themselves
column892: 2010}}. </ref> In the short term climate stress is likely to add incrementally to existing migration patterns rather than generating entirely new flows of people.<ref name=""wdr migration""/>{{Rp
column893: 110}} It has been argued that environmental degradation, loss of access to resources (e.g., water resources),<ref> {{citation
column899: 2001}}. </ref> and resulting human migration could become a source of political and even [[military conflict]].<ref name=""tar migration""> {{citation
column901: chapter= Chapter 7: Human Settlements, Energy, and Industry
column905: 2001}}. </ref> Factors other than climate change may, however, be more important in affecting conflict. For example, Wilbanks ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column907: chapter = Chapter 7: Industry, settlement and society
column909: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-1.html Sec. 7.4.1 General effects: Box 7.2. Environmental migration] }}, in {{harvnb
column911: 2007}}. </ref> suggested that major environmentally influenced conflicts in Africa were more to do with the relative abundance of resources, e.g., [[oil]] and [[diamond]]s, than with resource scarcity. Scott ''et al.'' (2001) placed only low confidence in predictions of increased conflict due to climate change.<ref name=""tar migration""/> ===Aggregate impacts=== {{Main
column912: Economic impacts of climate change}} [[Aggregate data
column913: Aggregating]] impacts adds up the total impact of climate change across sectors and/or regions. <ref> {{citation
column915: chapter-url= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/annexessglossary-a-d.html Glossary A-D]: ""Aggregate impacts"" }}, p. 76, in {{harvnb
column917: 2007}}. </ref> Examples of aggregate measures include [[Economic impacts of climate change#Distribution of impacts
column918: economic cost]] (e.g., changes in [[gross domestic product]] (GDP) and the [[Economic impacts of climate change#Marginal impacts
column919: social cost of carbon]]), changes in ecosystems (e.g., changes over land area from one type of vegetation to another),<ref> {{citation
column921: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column923: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/677.htm Sec. 19.5.3 Insights and Lessons: Vulnerability over Time: Table 19-5] }}, in {{harvnb
column925: 2001}}. </ref> human health impacts, and the number of people affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
column927: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column929: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/676.htm Sec. 19.5.2. Insights and Lessons: The Static Picture] }}, in {{harvnb
column931: 2001}}. </ref> Aggregate measures such as economic cost require researchers to make [[value judgement]]s over the importance of impacts occurring in different regions and at different times. ====Observed impacts==== Global losses reveal rapidly rising costs due to extreme weather-related events since the 1970s.<ref> {{citation
column933: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of observed changes and responses in natural and managed systems
column935: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-8-5.html Sec. 1.3.8.5 Summary of disasters and hazards] }}, in {{harvnb
column938: Socio-economic]] factors have contributed to the observed trend of global losses, e.g., population growth, increased [[wealth]].<ref name=""disaster losses""> {{citation
column944: 2001}}. </ref> Part of the growth is also related to regional climatic factors, e.g., changes in precipitation and flooding events. It is difficult to quantify the relative impact of socio-economic factors and climate change on the observed trend.<ref name=""disaster losses""/> The trend does, however, suggest increasing vulnerability of social systems to climate change.<ref name=""disaster losses""/> ====Projected impacts==== The total economic impacts from climate change are highly uncertain.<ref> {{citation
column946: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column948: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-2-3.html Sec. 19.3.2.3 Aggregate market impacts] }}, p. 790, in {{harvnb
column950: 2007}}. </ref> With medium confidence, Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""> {{citation
column952: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column956: 2001}}. </ref> concluded that world GDP would change by plus or minus a few percent for a small increase in global mean temperature (up to around 2 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level). Most studies assessed by Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""/> projected losses in world GDP for a medium increase in global mean temperature (above 2-3 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level), with increasing losses for greater temperature increases. This assessment is consistent with the findings of more recent studies, as reviewed by Hitz and Smith (2004).<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""> {{citation
column958: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column960: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Sec. 19.3.7 Update on ‘Reasons for Concern’] }}, p. 796, in {{harvnb
column962: 2007}}. </ref> Economic impacts are expected to vary regionally.<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/><ref> {{citation
column964: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column966: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/675.htm Sec. 19.4.3. Distribution of Total Impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column968: 2001}}. </ref> For a medium increase in global mean temperature (2-3 °C of warming, relative to the average temperature between 1990–2000), market sectors in low-latitude and less-developed areas might experience net costs due to climate change.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> On the other hand, market sectors in high-latitude and developed regions might experience net benefits for this level of warming. A global mean temperature increase above about 2-3 °C (relative to 1990-2000) would very likely result in market sectors across all regions experiencing either declines in net benefits or rises in net costs.<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> Aggregate impacts have also been quantified in non-economic terms. For example, climate change over the 21st century is likely to adversely affect hundreds of millions of people through increased coastal flooding, reductions in water supplies, increased malnutrition and increased health impacts.<ref name=""ar4 synthesis reasons for concern""/> ==Biological systems== {{Main
column971: Effect of climate change on plant biodiversity
column972: Effects of climate change on terrestrial animals
column973: Effects of climate change on marine mammals}} ===Observed impacts on biological systems=== [[File:A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming (low-res).png
column976: A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming.<ref name=""nasa briefs""> {{cite web
column980: title=Science Briefs: Warming Climate is Changing Life on Global Scale
column981: publisher=Website of the US National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Goddard Institute for Space Studies
column983: accessdate=2011-07-08}} </ref>]] With very high confidence, Rosenzweig ''et al.'' (2007) concluded that recent warming had strongly affected natural biological systems.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> Hundreds of studies have documented responses of [[ecosystem]]s, [[plant]]s, and [[animal]]s to the climate changes that have already occurred.<ref> {{cite book
column985: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column990: page = 14 }} </ref> For example, in the Northern Hemisphere, species are almost uniformly moving their ranges northward and up in elevation in search of cooler temperatures.<ref name=""nrc 2008b observed ecosystem impacts""> {{cite book
column992: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column997: page = 16 }} </ref> Humans are very likely causing changes in regional temperatures to which plants and animals are responding.<ref name=""nrc 2008b observed ecosystem impacts""/> ===Projected impacts on biological systems=== By the year 2100, ecosystems will be exposed to atmospheric {{chem
column999: 2}} levels substantially higher than in the past 650,000 years, and global temperatures at least among the highest of those experienced in the past 740,000 years.<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""> {{citation
column1001: chapter= Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column1005: 2007}}. </ref> Significant disruptions of ecosystems are projected to increase with future climate change.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""> {{citation
column1011: 2001}}. </ref> Examples of disruptions include disturbances such as fire, drought, pest [[infestation]], invasion of species, storms, and [[coral bleaching]] events. The stresses caused by climate change, added to other stresses on ecological systems (e.g., land conversion, [[land degradation]], [[harvest]]ing, and [[pollution]]), threaten substantial damage to or complete loss of some unique ecosystems, and [[extinction]] of some critically endangered species.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""/> Climate change has been estimated to be a major driver of [[biodiversity]] loss in cool [[conifer]] forests, [[savanna]]s, [[mediterranean climate
column1012: mediterranean-climate]] systems, [[tropical forest]]s, in the [[Arctic tundra]], and in [[coral reef]]s.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""> {{citation
column1014: chapter= Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column1016: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch4s4-4-11.html Sec. 4.4.11 Global synthesis including impacts on biodiversity] }}, in {{harvnb
column1019: land-use]] change may be a stronger driver of biodiversity loss at least in the near-term.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> Beyond the year 2050, climate change may be the major driver for biodiversity loss globally.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> A literature assessment by Fischlin ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""/> included a quantitative estimate of the number of the number of species at increased risk of extinction due to climate change. With medium confidence, it was projected that approximately 20 to 30% of plant and animal species assessed so far (in an unbiased [[Sampling (statistics)
column1020: sample]]) would likely be at increasingly high risk of extinction should global mean temperatures exceed a warming of 2 to 3 °C above pre-industrial temperature levels.<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""/> The uncertainties in this estimate, however, are large: for a rise of about 2 °C the percentage may be as low as 10%, or for about 3 °C, as high as 40%, and depending on [[Biota (ecology)
column1021: biota]] (all living [[organism]]s of an area, the [[flora]] and [[fauna]] considered as a unit)<ref> {{citation
column1025: 2007}}. </ref> the range is between 1% and 80%.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> As global average temperature exceeds 4 °C above pre-industrial levels, model projections suggested that there could be significant extinctions (40-70% of species that were assessed) around the globe.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> Assessing whether future changes in ecosystems will be beneficial or detrimental is largely based on how ecosystems are valued by human society.<ref> {{citation
column1028: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column1032: 2008b}}. </ref> For increases in global average temperature exceeding 1.5 to 2.5 °C (relative to global temperatures over the years 1980-1999)<ref> {{citation
column1034: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column1036: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3.html Sec. 3.3 Impacts of future climate changes] }}, in {{harvnb
column1040: 2}} concentrations, projected changes in ecosystems will have predominantly negative consequences for biodiversity and ecosystems goods and [[ecosystem services
column1041: services]], e.g., water and food supply.<ref> {{citation
column1043: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column1045: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-1.html Sec. 3.3.1 Impacts on systems and sectors: Ecosystems] }}, in {{harvnb
column1047: 2007}}. </ref> ==Abrupt or irreversible changes== Physical, ecological and social systems may respond in an abrupt, [[non-linear]] or irregular way to climate change.<ref name=""singularities""> {{citation
column1049: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1051: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/679.htm Sec. 19.6.1. The Irregular Face of Climate Change] }}, in {{harvnb
column1053: 2001}}. </ref> This is as opposed to a smooth or regular response. A quantitative entity behaves ""irregularly"" when its [[system dynamics
column1055: discontinuous]] (i.e., not smooth), nondifferentiable, unbounded, wildly varying, or otherwise ill-defined.<ref name=""singularities""/> Such behaviour is often termed ""[[Mathematical singularity
column1056: singular]]."" Irregular behaviour in Earth systems may give rise to certain thresholds, which, when crossed, may lead to a large change in the system. Some singularities could potentially lead to severe impacts at regional or global scales.<ref name=""white et al singularities""> {{citation
column1060: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/052.htm Sec. 7.2.5, Large-Scale Singular Events] }}, in {{harvnb
column1062: 2001}}. </ref> Examples of ""large-scale"" singularities are discussed in the articles on [[abrupt climate change]], [[climate change feedback]] and [[runaway climate change]]. It is possible that human-induced climate change could trigger large-scale singularities, but the probabilities of triggering such events are, for the most part,<ref> ""[F]or the most part"" refers to improved scientific understanding of singularities since the assessment by White ''et al.'' (2001). See: {{citation
column1064: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1066: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Sec. 19.3.7 Update on ‘Reasons for Concern’] }}, in {{harvnb
column1068: 2007}}. </ref> poorly understood.<ref name=""white et al singularities""/> With low to medium confidence, Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""singularities""> {{citation
column1070: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1074: 2001}}. </ref> concluded that a rapid warming of more than 3 °C above 1990 levels would exceed thresholds that would lead to large-scale discontinuities in the climate system. Since the assessment by Smith ''et al.'' (2001), improved scientific understanding provides more guidance for two large-scale singularities: the role of [[carbon cycle]] feedbacks in future climate change (discussed below in the section on biogeochemical cycles) and the melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column1075: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s.<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/> ===Biogeochemical cycles=== {{See also
column1076: climate change feedback}} Climate change may have an effect on the [[carbon cycle]] in an interactive ""feedback"" process. A feedback exists where an initial process triggers changes in a second process that in turn influences the initial process. A positive feedback intensifies the original process, and a negative feedback reduces it.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report""> {{citation
column1081: 78}} Models suggest that the interaction of the climate system and the carbon cycle is one where the feedback effect is positive.<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""> {{citation
column1083: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1088: 792}} Using the A2 SRES emissions scenario, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""/>{{Rp
column1089: 789}} found that this effect led to additional warming by the years 2090-2100 (relative to the 1990–2000) of 0.1–1.5 °C. This estimate was made with high confidence. The climate projections made in the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report summarized earlier of 1.1–6.4 °C account for this feedback effect. On the other hand, with medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""/>{{Rp
column1090: 789}} commented that additional releases of GHGs were possible from permafrost, peat lands, wetlands, and large stores of marine hydrates at high latitudes. ===Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets=== With medium confidence, authors of AR4<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""> {{citation
column1096: 2007}}. </ref> concluded that with a global average temperature increase of 1–4 °C (relative to temperatures over the years 1990–2000), at least a partial deglaciation of the [[Greenland ice sheet]], and possibly the [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s would occur. The estimated timescale for partial deglaciation was centuries to millennia, and would contribute {{convert
column1100: m}} or more to sea level rise over this period. ===The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation=== {{See also
column1102: This map shows the general location and direction of the warm surface (red) and cold deep water (blue) currents of the [[thermohaline circulation]]. [[Salinity]] is represented by color in units of the Practical Salinity Scale. Low values (blue) are less saline, while high values (orange) are more saline.<ref> {{cite web
column1104: author=Riebeek, H.. design by R. Simmon
column1105: title=Paleoclimatology: Explaining the Evidence: Explaining Rapid Climate Change: Tales from the Ice
column1111: right]] The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is an important component of the Earth's climate system, characterized by a northward flow of warm, salty water in the upper layers of the [[Atlantic ocean
column1112: Atlantic]] and a southward flow of colder water in the deep Atlantic.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""> {{cite book
column1115: title= Abrupt Climate Change. A report by the US Climate Change Science Program (CCSP) and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column1119: 5}} The AMOC is equivalently known as the [[thermohaline circulation]] (THC).<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/> Potential impacts associated with MOC changes include reduced warming or (in the case of abrupt change) absolute cooling of northern high-latitude areas near [[Greenland]] and north-western Europe, an increased warming of [[Southern Hemisphere]] high-latitudes, tropical drying, as well as changes to [[marine ecosystem]]s, terrestrial vegetation, oceanic {{chem
column1121: 2}} uptake, oceanic oxygen concentrations, and shifts in fisheries.<ref> {{citation
column1123: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1125: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-5-3.html Sec. 19.3.5.3 Possible changes in the North Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (MOC)] }}, in {{harvnb
column1127: 2007}}. </ref> According to an assessment by the US [[Climate Change Science Program]] (CCSP, 2008b),<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1128: 5}} it is very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1129: 12}} that the strength of the AMOC will decrease over the course of the 21st century. Warming is still expected to occur over most of the European region downstream of the [[North Atlantic Current]] in response to increasing GHGs, as well as over [[North America]]. Although it is very unlikely (less than 10% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1130: 12}} that the AMOC will collapse in the 21st century, the potential consequences of such a collapse could be severe.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1131: 5}} ===Irreversibilities=== ====Commitment to radiative forcing==== Emissions of GHGs are a potentially irreversible commitment to sustained [[radiative forcing]] in the future.<ref name=""albritton irreversible radiative forcing""> {{citation
column1135: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc%5Ftar/wg1/016.htm Sec. C.1 Observed Changes in Globally Well-Mixed Greenhouse Gas Concentrations and Radiative Forcing] }}, p. 38, in {{harvnb
column1137: 2001}}. </ref> The contribution of a GHG to radiative forcing depends on the gas's ability to trap [[infrared]] (heat) radiation, the concentration of the gas in the atmosphere, and the length of time the gas resides in the atmosphere.<ref name=""albritton irreversible radiative forcing""/> {{chem
column1139: 2}} is the most important anthropogenic GHG.<ref name=""ipcc 2007 causes of climate change""> {{citation
column1143: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms2.html Sec. 2. Causes of change] }}, p. 5, in {{harvnb
column1145: 2007}}. </ref> While more than half of the {{chem
column1147: 2}} emitted is currently removed from the atmosphere within a century, some fraction (about 20%) of emitted {{chem
column1149: 2}} remains in the atmosphere for many thousands of years.<ref> {{cite book
column1153: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-10-3.html Frequently Asked Question 10.3: If Emissions of Greenhouse Gases are Reduced, How Quickly do Their Concentrations in the Atmosphere Decrease?] }}, in {{harvnb
column1157: 2}} emitted today is potentially an irreversible commitment to sustained radiative forcing over thousands of years. It should be noted that this commitment may not be truly irreversible should techniques be developed to remove {{chem
column1159: 2}} or other GHGs directly from the atmosphere, or to block sunlight to induce cooling.<ref> {{cite journal
column1162: title=Irreversible climate change due to carbon dioxide emissions
column1163: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (PNAS)
column1173: bibcode = 2009PNAS..106.1704S }}</ref> Techniques of this sort are referred to as [[geoengineering]]. Little is known about the effectiveness, costs or potential [[Unintended consequences
column1174: side-effect]]s of geoengineering options.<ref name=""barker geoengineering""> {{citation
column1176: chapter= Chapter 11: Mitigation from a cross-sectoral perspective
column1178: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/ch11s11-es.html Executive summary - Unconventional options] }} , in {{harvnb
column1180: 2007}}. </ref> Some geoengineering options, such as blocking sunlight, would not prevent further [[ocean acidification]].<ref name=""barker geoengineering""/> ====Irreversible impacts==== Human-induced climate change may lead to irreversible impacts on physical, biological, and social systems.<ref> {{citation
column1186: 2001}}. <!-- XX Needs checking. --> </ref> There are a number of examples of climate change impacts that may be irreversible, at least over the timescale of many human generations.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""> {{citation
column1188: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1190: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-2.html Sec.19.2 Criteria for selecting ‘key’ vulnerabilities: Persistence and reversibility] }}, in {{harvnb
column1192: 2007}}. </ref> These include the large-scale singularities described above - changes in carbon cycle feedbacks, the melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, and changes to the AMOC.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In biological systems, the extinction of species would be an irreversible impact.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In social systems, unique [[culture]]s may be lost due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> For example, humans living on [[atoll]] islands face risks due to sea-level rise, sea-surface warming, and increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.<ref> {{cite journal
column1200: url=http://www.uea.ac.uk/env/people/adgerwn/ClimChange2003Barnett.pdf }} This paper was published in 2001 as [http://www.tyndall.ac.uk/sites/default/files/wp9.pdf Tyndall Centre Working Paper 9] </ref> == See also == {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ; General * [[Anthropocene]] * [[Risks to civilization, humans and planet Earth]] * [[Indigenous Peoples Climate Change Assessment Initiative]] * [[Environmental sociology]] ; Regional * [[Arctic Climate Impact Assessment]] * [[Effects of global warming on Australia]] * [[Effects of global warming on India]] * [[Kivalina v. ExxonMobil Corp., Et al.]] * [[Climate Change Science Program#Impacts and adaptation
column1201: Bush Administration assessments of impacts and adaptation]] (United States) {{Col-break}} {{Portalbox
column1204: Environment}} * [[Biological pump]] * [[Climate Vulnerability Monitor]] (CVM) * [[Oceanic anoxic event]] * [[PRECIS (Providing Regional Climates for Impacts Studies)]] * [[Solubility pump]] {{Col-end}} {{Clear}} ==Footnotes== <sup>1</sup> this statement applies to the SRES global mean temperature projections given in the [[IPCC Third Assessment Report]] (TAR) using all of the SRES scenarios.<ref name=""Global warming projections in the TAR""> {{citation
column1206: chapter= Chapter 9. Projections of Future Climate Change
column1210: 2001}}. </ref> This is a range of 1.4–5.8 °C between the years 1990–2100.<ref name=""Global warming projections in the TAR""/> The projected temperature range in the TAR is slightly different to the ""likely"" range given in the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report (AR4). This is warming of 1.1 °C (by the end of the 21st century, relative to global mean temperature averaged over the 1980 to 1999 time period) for the lowest emissions SRES ""marker"" scenario and 6.4 °C for the highest emissions SRES ""marker"" scenario.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> However, the two sets of temperature projections are broadly comparable in size. <sup>2</sup> The TAR<ref name=""Uncertainty in the TAR""> {{citation
column1216: 2001}}. </ref> and AR4<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> that are referred to in this article use specific and quantitative language to describe uncertainty. This language is intended to provide an indication of the level of confidence that IPCC authors have about a particular finding. The qualitative language used to describe uncertainty has a quantitative scale associated with it. The quantitative values for qualitative terms are intended to ensure that confidence levels are interpreted correctly. The is because qualitative statements, e.g., using the word ""likely,"" can be interpreted differently in quantitative terms.<ref> {{citation
column1223: title= IPCC supporting material: guidance papers on the cross cutting issues of the Third Assessment Report of the IPCC
column1224: editor= R. Pachuari, T. Taniguchi and K. Tanaka, (eds.)
column1226: publisher= Global Industrial and Social Progress Research Institute (GISPRI)
column1229: 44}} Quantitative values for confidence statements made in AR4 are listed below:<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> *Very high confidence: At least 9 out of 10 chance of being correct *High confidence: About 8 out of 10 chance "" "" "" *Medium confidence: About 5 out of 10 chance "" "" "" *Low confidence: About 2 out of 10 chance "" "" "" *Very low confidence: Less than a 1 out of 10 chance "" "" "" A slightly different set of confidence levels are used in the TAR:<ref> {{citation
column1233: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/023.htm#14 Box 2. Confidence Levels and State of Knowledge] }}, in {{harvnb
column1235: 2001}}. </ref> *Very High = 95% or greater *High = 67-95% *Medium = 33-67% *Low = 5-33% *Very Low = 5% or less The quantitative values used by IPCC authors are ""subjective"" probabilities,<ref> {{citation
column1239: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/106.htm Sec. 2.6.2. ""Objective"" and ""Subjective"" Probabilities are not Always Explicitly Distinguished] }}, in {{harvnb
column1241: 2001}}. </ref><ref name=""Uncertainty in the TAR""/><ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> also known as ""personalist"" or ""[[Bayesian probability
column1242: Bayesian]]"" probabilities,<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""> {{cite book
column1244: author= Granger Morgan, M. (Lead Author), H. Dowlatabadi, M. Henrion, D. Keith, R. Lempert, S. McBride, M. Small and T. Wilbanks (Contributing Authors)
column1245: title= Synthesis and Assessment Product 5.2: Best practice approaches for characterizing, communicating, and incorporating scientific uncertainty in decisionmaking. A Report by the U.S. [[Climate Change Science Program]] and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column1246: publisher= National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
column1249: url= http://www.globalchange.gov/publications/reports/scientific-assessments/saps/311 }} Tables 2.1 and 2.2 on pages 27-28 show two quantitative scales of uncertainty which are used in the TAR and AR4.</ref> and reflect the expert judgement of IPCC authors.
