In this formulation, probability is not only a function of an event, but also the state of information that is available to the person making the assessment.<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""/> In this framework, assigned probabilities may change as more or different information becomes available.<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""/> The IPCC also uses another scale to describe the likelihood of a particular event occurring.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> This is different from the confidence scales described above, and it is possible to assign confidence values to statements of likelihood. For example, the judgement that an event is improbable (e.g., rolling a [[dice]] twice and getting a six both times) may be assigned a high level of scientific confidence.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> Also, the probability that an event has an even chance of occurring (e.g., a tossed [[coin]] coming up heads) may also be assigned a high level of confidence.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> == Notes == {{Reflist

column1371: ref=CITEREFWDR2010 }} ==External links== ;Physical impacts *[http://www.wmo.int/pages/themes/climate/main_climate_change.php ""Climate Change""]. [[World Meteorological Organization]]. *[http://www.ipcc-wg1.unibe.ch/ The IPCC Working Group I (WG I)]. This body assesses the physical scientific aspects of the climate system and climate change. ;Social, economic and ecological impacts *[http://www.un.org/esa/dsd/dsd_aofw_cc/cc_index.shtml Climate change] on the United Nations Economic and Social Development (UNESD) Division for Sustainable Development website. *[http://www.ipcc-wg2.gov/ The IPCC Working Group II (WG II) website] – This body assesses the vulnerability of socio-economic and natural systems to climate change, negative and positive consequences of climate change, and options for adapting to it. ;General *[http://esa.un.org/subindex/pgViewSites.asp?termCode=QB.25 List of United Nations Functional Commissions and Expert Bodies related to climate change] *[[IRIN]], the humanitarian news and analysis service of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs: [http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=79563 ""What climate change does""], [http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=79508 ""How climate change works""], and [http://www.irinnews.org/IndepthMain.aspx?IndepthId=73&ReportId=78246 ""Gathering Storm - the humanitarian impact of climate change""] *Videos: **[http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=4119472365452589212 ""Educational Forum: Arctic Climate Impact""]. Panel discussion with James J. McCarthy, Professor at Harvard University, and Author; Paul R. Epstein, M.D., instructor in medicine at Harvard Medical School; and Ross Gelbspan, Pulitzer-prize winning journalist and author. Massachusetts School of Law. **[http://climateprogress.org/2010/02/05/videos-humans-are-changing-the-climate-global-warming-threat-chris-field/#more-18551 ""How we know humans are changing the climate and Why climate change is a clear and present danger""]. Interviews with Christopher Field and Michael MacCracken. Christopher Field is the director of the Department of Global Ecology at the Carnegie Institution of Washington, professor of biology and environmental earth system science at Stanford University, and the Working Group II Co-Chair for the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Michael MacCracken is the chief scientist for Climate Change Programs at the Climate Institute and a co-author and contributing author for various chapters in the IPCC assessment reports. Climate Progress website, February 5, 2010. {{Global warming}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Effects Of Global Warming}} [[Category:Effects of global warming

column5: small=yes}} [[File:Effects of global warming, plotted against changes in global mean temperature.png
column8: alt=Refer to caption and image description
column9: Summary of climate change impacts.]] The '''effects of [[global warming]]''' are the ecological and social changes caused by the rise in global temperatures. There is a [[scientific opinion on climate change
column10: scientific consensus]] that climate change is occurring, and that human activities are the primary driver.<ref> {{citation
column11: author=Joint-statement by leaders of 18 scientific organizations: American Association for the Advancement of Science, American Chemical Society, American Geophysical Union, American Institute of Biological Sciences, American Meteorological Society, American Society of Agronomy, American Society of Plant Biologists, American Statistical Association, Association of Ecosystem Research Centers, Botanical Society of America, Crop Science Society of America, Ecological Society of America, Natural Science Collections, Alliance Organization of Biological Field Stations, Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, [[Society of Systematic Biologists]], Soil Science Society of America, University Corporation for Atmospheric Research
column13: title=Joint-statement on climate change by leaders of 18 scientific organizations
column16: publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science
column17: location=Washington DC, USA }} </ref> Evidence of [[climate change]] includes the instrumental temperature record, rising [[Current sea level rise
column18: sea level]]s, and decreased snow cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]].<ref name=""direct observations of recent climate change""> {{citation
column22: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-direct-observations.html Direct Observations of Recent Climate Change] }}, in {{harvnb
column24: 2007}}. </ref> According to the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC), most of the observed increase in global average temperatures since the mid-20th century is very likely due to the observed increase in human [[greenhouse gas]] concentrations.<ref> {{citation
column28: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-understanding-and.html Understanding and Attributing Climate Change] }}, in {{harvnb
column30: 2007}}. </ref> Projections of future climate change suggest further global warming, [[current sea level rise
column31: sea level rise]], and an increase in the frequency and severity of some [[extreme weather
column36: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains6-2.html Sec. 6.2 Drivers and projections of future climate changes and their impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column38: 2007}}. </ref> Parties to the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] (UNFCCC) have agreed to ""stabilize greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent [[Avoiding dangerous climate change
column39: dangerous anthropogenic interference]] with the climate system.""<ref> {{citation
column41: work = The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
column44: attribution of recent climate change}} In this article, ""[[climate change]]"" means a change in climate that persists over a sustained period of time.<ref name=""ipcc definition of climate change""> {{citation
column46: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/annex1sglossary-a-d.html Glossary A-D] ""Climate"" and ""climate change"" }}, in {{harvnb
column51: at=Click on the image to open a pop-up that explains the differences between climate change and global warming.
column54: publisher=US EPA }} </ref> The [[World Meteorological Organization]] defines this time period as 30 years.<ref name=""ipcc definition of climate change""/> Examples of climate change include increases in global surface temperature (global warming), changes in [[rainfall]] patterns, and changes in the frequency of [[extreme weather]] events. Changes in climate may be due to natural causes, e.g., changes in the [[sun]]'s output, or due to human activities, e.g., changing the composition of the atmosphere.<ref name=""albritton climate change""/> Any human-induced changes in climate will occur against the ""background"" of natural climatic variations.<ref name=""albritton climate change""> {{citation
column58: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/011.htm Box 1: What drives changes in climate?] }}, in {{harvnb
column60: 2001}} </ref> Also, the term ""anthropogenic forcing"" refers to the influence exerted on a habitat or chemical environment by humans, as opposed to a natural process.<ref> {{cite web
column62: title=Definition of Anthropogenic Forcing – Chemistry Dictionary and Glossary }} </ref> ==Temperature changes== {{Multiple image
column66: alt1=The NASA instrumental temperature record shows a long-term trend of global warming between 1880 and 2009
column67: image2= Projected global warming over the 21st century using three SRES greenhouse gas emissions scenarios. Data from CMIP3 (2007).png
column70: caption1=Global mean surface temperature difference from the average for 1880–2009.
column71: caption2=The graph above shows the average of a set of temperature simulations for the 20th century (black line), followed by projected temperatures for the 21st century based on three greenhouse gas emissions scenarios (colored lines).<ref name=""herring temperature projections""> {{cite web
column76: url= http://www.climatewatch.noaa.gov/article/2012/global-temperature-projections }} </ref> }} This article breaks down some of the impacts of climate change according to different levels of future global warming. This way of describing impacts has, for instance, been used in the IPCC's Assessment Reports on climate change.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""> {{citation
column78: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column80: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-1.html Sec. 19.3.1 Introduction to Table 19.1] }}, in {{harvnb
column82: 2007}}. </ref> The instrumental [[temperature record]] shows global warming of around 0.6 °C over the entire 20th century.<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""/> ===SRES emissions scenarios=== The future level of global warming is uncertain, but a wide range of estimates (projections) have been made.<ref name=""Overview of GHG emissions scenarios""> {{citation
column84: chapter= Chapter 3: Issues related to mitigation in the long-term context
column88: 2007}} </ref> The IPCC's ""[[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column89: SRES]]"" scenarios have been frequently used to make [[Global climate model#Projections of future climate change
column90: projections of future climate change]].<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column92: date=November 2012}} The SRES scenarios are ""[[Economics of climate change mitigation#Baselines
column93: baseline]]"" (or ""reference"") scenarios, which means that they do not take into account any current or future measures to limit GHG emissions (e.g., the UNFCCC's [[Kyoto Protocol]] and the [[2010 United Nations Climate Change Conference
column96: chapter= Chapter 2, Greenhouse Gas Emission Mitigation Scenarios and Implications
column98: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/080.htm Sec. 2.5.1.1 IPCC Emissions Scenarios and the SRES Process] }}, in {{harvnb
column100: 2001}}. </ref> Emissions projections of the SRES scenarios are broadly comparable in range to the baseline emissions scenarios that have been developed by the scientific community.<ref name=""Overview of GHG emissions scenarios""/><ref> {{citation
column106: 2007}}. </ref> In the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]], changes in future global mean temperature were projected using the six SRES ""marker"" emissions scenarios.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""> {{citation
column110: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html#table-spm-1 Sec. 1 3. Projected climate change and its impacts: Table SPM.1] }}, in {{harvnb
column112: 2007}}. </ref> Emissions projections for the six SRES ""marker"" scenarios are representative of the full set of forty SRES scenarios.<ref> {{citation
column114: chapter= Chapter 2, Greenhouse Gas Emission Mitigation Scenarios and Implications
column116: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/081.htm#2514 Sec. 2.5.1.4 Emissions and Other Results of the SRES Scenarios] }}, in {{harvnb
column118: 2001}}. </ref> For the lowest emissions SRES marker scenario (""B1"" - see the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column119: SRES]] article for details on this scenario), the best estimate for global mean temperature is an increase of {{convert
column123: 1}}<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> by the end of the 21st century. This projection is relative to global temperatures at the end of the 20th century.<ref>Temperature change in years 2090-2099 relative to years 1980-1999</ref> The ""likely"" range (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> for the SRES B1 marker scenario is {{convert
column129: 1}}.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> For the highest emissions SRES marker scenario (A1FI), the best estimate for global mean temperature increase is {{convert
column139: 1}}.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> The range in temperature projections partly reflects (1) the choice of [[economics of global warming#Emissions scenarios
column140: emissions scenario]], and (2) the ""[[climate sensitivity]]"".<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column142: date=November 2012}} For (1), different scenarios make different assumptions of future social and economic development (e.g., [[economic growth]], [[population projection
column144: energy policies]]), which in turn affects projections of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column146: date=November 2012}} The projected magnitude of warming by 2100 is closely related to the level of cumulative emissions over the 21st century (i.e. total emissions between 2000-2100).<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions""> {{citation
column149: chapter=Ch 2: Which emissions pathways are consistent with a {{val
column153: u=°C}} temperature limit?: Sec 2.2 What determines long-term temperature?
column154: title=The Emissions Gap Report: Are the Copenhagen Accord pledges sufficient to limit global warming to {{val
column161: publisher=UNEP }}, p.28. This publication is also available in [http://www.unep.org/publications/ebooks/emissionsgapreport/ e-book format] </ref> The higher the cumulative emissions over this time period, the greater the level of warming is projected to occur.<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions""/> (2) reflects uncertainty in the response of the climate system to past and future GHG emissions, which is measured by the [[climate sensitivity]]).<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column163: date=November 2012}} Higher estimates of climate sensitivity lead to greater projected warming, while lower estimates of climate sensitivity lead to less projected warming.<ref> {{citation
column164: chapter=Box 8.1 Likelihood of exceeding a temperature increase at equilibrium, in: Ch 8: The Challenge of Stabilisation
column168: p=195}} </ref> Over the next several millennia, projections suggest that global warming could be irreversible.<ref name=""solomon irreversible climate change""/> Even if emissions were drastically reduced, global temperatures would remain close to their highest level for at least 1,000 years (see the later section on [[effects of global warming#Irreversibilities
column175: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-7-2.html Sec 10.7.2 Climate Change Commitment to Year 3000 and Beyond to Equilibrium]
column185: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column186: Two millennia of mean surface temperatures according to different reconstructions from [[Proxy (climate)
column187: climate proxies]], each smoothed on a decadal scale, with the [[instrumental temperature record]] overlaid in black.]]
column188: [[File:Global temperature relative to peak Holocene temperature, based on ocean cores (NASA).png
column192: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column193: Global surface temperature for the past 5.3 million years as inferred from cores of ocean [[sediment]]s taken all around the global ocean. The last 800,000 years are expanded in the lower half of the figure (image credit: [[NASA]]).<ref name=""hansen climate history""/>]]
column194: } Scientists have used various ""proxy"" data to assess past changes in Earth's climate ([[paleoclimate]]).<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""> {{citation
column196: title=NOAA Paleoclimatology Global Warming - The Story: Proxy Data
column199: publisher=NOAA Paleoclimatology Program - NCDC Paleoclimatology Branch }} </ref> Sources of proxy data include historical records (such as [[farmer]]s' logs), [[tree ring]]s, [[coral]]s, [[fossil pollen]], [[ice core]]s, and ocean and lake [[sediment]]s.<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""/> Analysis of these data suggest that recent warming is unusual in the past 400 years, possibly longer.<ref> {{citation
column202: title=Surface Temperature Reconstructions for the Last 2,000 Years
column205: author=Committee on Surface Temperature Reconstructions for the Last 2,000 Years, US National Research Council
column207: isbn=0-309-66144-7 }}, p.3 </ref> By the end of the 21st century, temperatures may increase to a level not experienced since the mid-[[Pliocene]], around 3 million years ago.<ref name=""jansen pliocene""> {{citation
column211: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch6s6-3-2.html Sec. 6.3.2 What Does the Record of the Mid-Pliocene Show?] }}, in {{harvnb
column213: 2007}}. </ref> At that time, models suggest that mean global temperatures were about 2–3 °C warmer than pre-industrial temperatures.<ref name=""jansen pliocene""/> Even a 2 °C rise above the pre-industrial level would be outside the range of temperatures experienced by human [[civilization]].<ref> {{citation
column214: at=[http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/686.htm Footnote 4, in Sec 19.8.2. What does Each Reason for Concern Indicate?]
column215: chapter=Ch 19. Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column222: title=NASA GISS: Science Briefs: Earth's Climate History: Implications for Tomorrow
column224: location=New York City, New York, USA
column228: [[File:Diagram showing ten indicators of global warming.png
column232: alt=Refer to caption and adjacent text
column233: Seven of these indicators would be expected to increase in a warming world and observations show that they are, in fact, increasing. Three would be expected to decrease and they are, in fact, decreasing.<ref> {{harvnb
column237: } [[File:Changes in climate indicators that show global warming.png
column242: This set of graphs show changes in climate indicators over several decades. Each of the different colored lines in each panel represents an independently analyzed set of data. The data come from many different technologies including [[weather station]]s, [[satellite]]s, [[weather balloons]], [[ship]]s and [[buoy]]s.<ref> {{harvnb
column245: p=3}} </ref>]] A broad range of evidence shows that the climate system has warmed.<ref> {{citation
column249: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-3-4.html TS.3.4 Consistency Among Observations] }}, in {{harvnb
column251: 2007}}. </ref> Evidence of global warming is shown in the graphs opposite. Some of the graphs show a positive [[trend estimation
column252: trend]], e.g., increasing temperature over land and the ocean, and [[current sea level rise
column253: sea level rise]]. Other graphs show a negative trend, e.g., decreased [[snow]] cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]], and declining [[Arctic sea ice]] extent. Evidence of warming is also apparent in living [[Effects of global warming#Observed impacts on biological systems
column254: (biological) systems]].<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> Human activities have contributed to a number of the observed changes in climate.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""> {{citation
column256: chapter= Chapter 9: Understanding and Attributing Climate Change
column260: 2007}}. </ref> This contribution has principally been through the burning of [[fossil fuel]]s, which has led to an increase in the concentration of GHGs in the atmosphere.<ref> {{citation
column264: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-human-and.html Human and Natural Drivers of Climate Change ] }}, in {{harvnb
column266: 2007}}. </ref> Another human influence on the climate are [[sulfur dioxide]] emissions, which are a precursor to the formation of [[sulfate aerosols]] in the atmosphere.<ref> {{cite book
column268: author=Committee on the Science of Climate Change, US National Research Council
column270: title=Climate Change Science: An Analysis of Some Key Questions
column275: isbn=0-309-07574-2 }} </ref> Human-induced warming could lead to [[Effects of global warming#Abrupt or irreversible changes
column276: large-scale, irreversible, and/or abrupt changes]] in physical systems.<ref> {{citation
column280: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html Sec. 3. Projected climate change and its impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column283: title=ESRL News: New Study Shows Climate Change Largely Irreversible
column286: publisher=US Department of Commerce, NOAA, Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL)
column287: date=26 January 2009 }}</ref> An example of this is the melting of [[ice sheet]]s, which contributes to sea level rise.<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> The probability of warming having unforeseen consequences increases with the rate, magnitude, and duration of climate change.<ref> {{cite book
column292: publisher=[[United States National Academy of Sciences]]
column295: date=December 2012}}</ref> ===Radiative forcing=== The effect of human activities on the climate system can be measured by [[radiative forcing]].<ref> {{cite web
column299: publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) News Office
column300: url=http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2010/explained-radforce-0309.html }}</ref> A positive radiative forcing will tend to warm the climate, while a negative forcing will tend to cool the climate.<ref name=""forster radiative forcing""> {{citation
column302: chapter= Chapter 2: Changes in Atmospheric Constituents and in Radiative Forcing
column304: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-2-1.html FAQ 2.1, Box 1: What is Radiative Forcing?] }}, in {{harvnb
column306: 2007}}. </ref> Anthopogenic forcing (i.e. the radiative forcing due to human activities) was estimated to have been positive (i.e. an overall warming effect) in the year 2005.<ref name=""forster radiative forcing""/> This is relative to the estimated forcings at the start of the industrial era, taken as the year 1750. Anthropogenic forcing of the climate has likely contributed to a number of observed changes, including sea level rise, changes in climate [[extreme weather event
column307: extremes]] (such as warm and cold days), declines in [[Arctic sea ice]] extent, and to [[Retreat of glaciers since 1850
column308: glacier retreat]].<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> === Effects on weather === Observations show that there have been changes in weather.<ref> {{citation
column310: chapter= Chapter 1: Historical Overview of Climate Change Science
column312: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-1-2.html FAQ 1.2 What is the Relationship between Climate Change and Weather?] }}, in {{harvnb
column314: 2007}}. </ref> As climate changes, the [[probabilities]] of certain types of weather events are affected. [[File:Projected change in annual average precipitation for the 21st century, based on the SRES A1B emissions scenario, and simulated by the GFDL CM2.1 model.png
column318: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column319: Projected change in annual average precipitation by the end of the 21st century, based on a medium emissions scenario ([[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column320: SRES]] A1B) (Credit: NOAA [[Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory]]).<ref> {{citation
column324: title= GFDL Climate Modeling Research Highlights: Will the Wet Get Wetter and the Dry Drier
column329: title=Will the wet get wetter and the dry drier?
column333: publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory (GFDL)
column334: location=Princeton, NJ, USA }}. Revision 10/15/2008, 4:47:16 PM. </ref>]] Changes have been observed in the amount, intensity, frequency, and type of [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column342: date=November 2012}} Widespread increases in heavy precipitation have occurred, even in places where total rain amounts have decreased. With medium confidence (see [[Effects of global warming#Footnotes
column348: p=8}} </ref> concluded that human influences had contributed to an increase in heavy precipitation events at the global scale. Projections of future changes in precipitation show overall increases in the global average, but with substantial shifts in where and how precipitation falls.<ref name = ""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column350: date=November 2012}} Projections suggest a reduction in rainfall in the [[subtropics]], and an increase in precipitation in subpolar latitudes and some [[equatorial region]]s.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> In other words, regions which are dry at present will in general become even drier, while regions that are currently wet will in general become even wetter.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> This projection does not apply to every locale, and in some cases can be modified by local conditions.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> ==== Extreme weather ==== {{See also
column352: Tropical cyclone#Global warming}} Since the 1950s, it is very likely that the number of cold days and nights have decreased globally.<ref name=""srex extreme weather spm p6""> {{citation
column357: p=6}} </ref> There have been other changes in climate extremes, e.g., [[flood]]s and [[tropical cyclone]]s, but these changes are more difficult to identify.<ref name=""srex extreme weather spm p6""/> As previously stated, human influences appear to have contributed to some of the observed changes.<ref> {{citation
column362: p=7}} </ref> Future climate change will very likely be associated with more very hot days and fewer very cold days.<ref name=""srex extreme weather spm p11""> {{citation
column367: p=11}} </ref> The frequency, length and intensity of [[heat wave]]s will very likely increase over most land areas.<ref name=""srex extreme weather spm p11""/> It's likely that the average maximum [[wind speed]] of [[tropical cyclone]]s will increase, though there may also be fewer cyclones.<ref name=""srex extreme weather spm p11""/> A number of regions may experience more intense [[drought]]s, including [[southern Europe]] and the [[Mediterranean basin
column368: Mediterranean region]], [[central Europe]], central [[North America]], [[Central America]] and [[Mexico]], Northwest [[Brazil]], and [[southern Africa]].<ref name=""srex extreme weather spm p11""/> Increases in [[heavy rain]]fall might contribute to increases in local [[flood]]ing in some [[drainage basin
column369: catchment]]s or regions. In [[coast]]al regions, sea level rise will very likely contribute to extremes in sea level. The impacts of extreme events on the environment and human society will vary. Some impacts will be beneficial -- e.g., fewer cold extremes will probably lead to fewer cold deaths.<ref name=""health summary""/> Overall, however, impacts will probably be mostly negative.<ref> {{citation
column377: chapter= Synthesis Report, Topic 5: The long-term perspective
column379: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains5-2.html Sec. 5.2 Key vulnerabilities, impacts and risks – long-term perspectives] }}, pp.64–65, in {{harvnb
column382: Retreat of glaciers since 1850}} [[File:Glacier Mass Balance Map.png
column386: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column387: A map of the change in thickness of mountain glaciers since 1970. Thinning in orange and red, thickening in blue.]] [[File:SeaIce-Sept162012 HR.jpg
column392: A map that shows ice concentration on 16 September 2012, along with the extent of the previous record low (yellow line) and the mid-September median extent (black line) setting a new record low that was 18 percent smaller than the previous record and nearly 50 percent smaller than the long-term (1979-2000) average.]] The [[cryosphere]] is made up of areas of the Earth which are covered by snow or ice.<ref> [http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/glossary.html#C ""Cryosphere""], in {{harvnb
column394: 2012}} </ref> Observed changes in the cryosphere include declines in [[Arctic sea ice]] extent,<ref> {{citation
column399: title=Mass Balance of Mountain Glaciers in 2011
column402: 2012}} </ref> and reduced snow cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]].<ref> {{citation
column403: title=2011 Snow Cover in Northern Hemisphere
column406: 2012}} </ref> Solomon ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""ar4 arctic sea ice""> {{citation
column410: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-5-2.html TS.5.2 Large-Scale Projections for the 21st Century] }}, in {{harvnb
column412: 2007}} </ref> assessed the potential impacts of climate change on [[summer]]time Arctic sea ice extent. Assuming high growth in greenhouse gas emissions ([[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column413: SRES A2]]), some models projected that Arctic sea ice in the summer could largely disappear by the end of the 21st century.<ref name=""ar4 arctic sea ice""/> More recent projections suggest that the Arctic summers could be ice-free (defined as ice extent less than 1 million square km) as early as 2025-2030.<ref> {{citation
column422: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-4.html Box 10.1: Future Abrupt Climate Change, ‘Climate Surprises’, and Irreversible Changes: Glaciers and ice caps] }}, in {{harvnb
column425: p=776}} </ref> and snow cover are projected to continue their widespread retreat.<ref> {{citation
column429: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-3-2.html Sec 10.3.3.2 Changes in Snow Cover and Frozen Ground] }}, in {{harvnb
column432: pp=770, 772}} </ref> In the western mountains of [[North America]], increasing temperatures and changes in precipitation are projected to lead to reduced [[snowpack]].<ref> {{citation
column436: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch14s14-4.html#14-4-1 Sec 14.4.1 Freshwater resources: Surface water] }}, in {{harvnb
column439: p=627}} </ref> Snowpack is the seasonal accumulation of slow-melting snow.<ref> [http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/glossary.html#S ""Snowpack""], in {{harvnb
column441: 2012}} </ref> The melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column442: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s could contribute to sea level rise, especially over long time-scales (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets
column443: Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets]]).<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> Changes in the cryosphere are projected to have social impacts.<ref> Some of these impacts are included in table SPM.2: {{citation
column444: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html#spm2 3 Projected climate change and its impacts: Table SPM.2]
column449: pp=11-12}} </ref> For example, in some regions, glacier retreat could increase the risk of reductions in seasonal water availability.<ref> {{citation
column451: chapter=Ch 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column458: title=Potential impacts of a warming climate on water availability in snow-dominated regions: Abstract
column463: doi=10.1038/nature04141 }} </ref> estimated that more than one-sixth of the [[world's population]] rely on glaciers and snowpack for their water supply. ===Geology=== ====Volcanoes==== {{see also
column464: Post-glacial rebound}} The retreat of glaciers and ice caps can cause increased [[volcanism]]. Reduction in ice cover reduces the [[confining pressure]] exerted on the volcano, increasing [[deviatoric stress]]es and potentially causing the volcano to erupt. This reduction of pressure can also cause [[Magma#Partial melting
column465: decompression melting]] of material in the mantle, resulting in the generation of more magma.<ref>{{cite journal
column467: title=Will present day glacier retreat increase volcanic activity? Stress induced by recent glacier retreat and its effect on magmatism at the Vatnajökull ice cap, Iceland
column477: issue=9}}</ref> Researchers in Iceland have shown that the rate of volcanic rock production there following deglaciation (10,000 to 4500 years [[before present]]) was 20–30 times greater than that observed after 2900 years before present.<ref>{{cite journal
column479: title=Effect of glacier loading/deloading on volcanism: postglacial volcanic production rate of the Dyngjufj�ll area, central Iceland
column491: issue=5}}</ref> While the original study addresses the first reason for increased volcanism (reduced confining pressure), scientists have more recently shown that these lavas have unusually high [[trace element]] concentrations, indicative of increased melting in the mantle.<ref>{{cite journal
column493: title=Deglaciation effects on mantle melting under Iceland: results from the northern volcanic zone
column506: bibcode=1998E&PSL.164..151S}}</ref> This work in Iceland has been corroborated by a study in California, in which scientists found a strong correlation between volcanism and periods of global deglaciation.<ref>{{cite journal
column508: title=Did melting glaciers cause volcanic eruptions in eastern California? Probing the mechanics of dike formation
column515: bibcode=2004JGRB..10909206J}}</ref> The effects of [[current sea level rise]] could include increased [[crust (geology)
column516: crustal]] stress at the base of coastal volcanoes from a rise in the volcano's [[water table]] (and the associated [[saltwater intrusion]]), while the mass from extra water could activate dormant [[seismic fault]]s around volcanoes. In addition, the wide-scale displacement of water from melting in places such as [[West Antarctica]] is likely to slightly alter the Earth's [[rotational period]] and may shift its [[axial tilt]] on the scale of hundreds of metres, inducing further crustal stress changes.<ref>{{cite book
column519: title=Raging planet: earthquakes, volcanoes, and the tectonic threat to life on earth
column527: title=Collapse Of Antarctic Ice Sheet Would Likely Put Washington, D.C. Largely Underwater
column532: date=February 6, 2009}}</ref> Current melting of ice is predicted to increase the size and frequency of volcanic eruptions.<ref name=""rs_volc"">{{cite journal
column535: title=How will melting of ice affect volcanic hazards in the twenty-first century?
column536: journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
column544: url=http://rsta.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/368/1919/2535.full }}</ref> In particular, lateral collapse events at [[stratovolcano]]es are likely to increase,<ref name=""rs_volc""/><ref>{{cite journal
column551: title=Climate forcing of volcano lateral collapse: evidence from Mount Etna, Sicily
column552: journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
column559: bibcode = 2010RSPTA.368.2559D }}</ref> and there are potential positive feedbacks between the removal of ice and magmatism.<ref name=""rs_volc""/> ====Earthquakes==== A [[numerical model]]ing study has demonstrated that [[seismicity]] increases during unloading, such as that due to the removal of ice.<ref>{{cite journal
column566: title=Response of faults to climate-driven changes in ice and water volumes on Earth's surface
column567: journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
column574: bibcode = 2010RSPTA.368.2501H }}</ref> ===Oceans=== The role of the oceans in global warming is a complex one. The oceans serve as a sink for carbon dioxide, taking up much that would otherwise remain in the atmosphere, but increased levels of {{chem
column576: 2}} have led to [[ocean acidification]]. Furthermore, as the temperature of the oceans increases, they become less able to absorb excess {{chem
column578: 2}}. The ocean have also acted as a sink in absorbing extra heat from the atmosphere.<ref name=statecl> {{cite book
column581: publisher = Website of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration: National Climatic Data Center
column582: title = State of the Climate in 2009, as appearing in the July 2010 issue (Vol. 91) of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society (BAMS). Supplemental and Summary Materials: Report at a Glance: Highlights
column586: date=November 2012}} The increase in ocean [[heat content]] is much larger than any other store of [[energy]] in the Earth’s heat balance over the two periods 1961 to 2003 and 1993 to 2003, and accounts for more than 90% of the possible increase in heat content of the Earth system during these periods.<ref> {{citation
column587: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch5s5-2-2-3.html Sec 5.2.2.3 Implications for Earth’s Heat Balance]
column588: chapter=Ch. 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column593: title=Climate Graphics by Skeptical Science: Global Warming Components:
column594: at=Components of global warming for the period 1993 to 2003 calculated from IPCC AR4 5.2.2.3
column596: publisher=Skeptical Science }} </ref> Global warming is projected to have a number of effects on the oceans. Ongoing effects include rising sea levels due to thermal expansion and melting of glaciers and ice sheets, and warming of the ocean surface, leading to increased temperature stratification. Other possible effects include large-scale changes in ocean circulation. ====Acidification==== {{Main
column597: Ocean acidification}} [[File:Changes in aragonite saturation of the world's oceans, 1880-2012 (US EPA).png
column601: alt=refer to caption and image description
column602: This map shows changes in the amount of [[aragonite]] dissolved in [[ocean]] surface waters between the 1880s and the most recent decade (2003-2012).<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/> Historical modeling suggests that since the 1880s, increased {{CO2}} has led to lower [[aragonite]] saturation levels (less availability of minerals) in the oceans around the world.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""> {{Include-USGov
column605: title=Climate Change Indicators in the United States, 2012, 2nd ed: Ocean Acidity: Figure 2. Changes in Aragonite Saturation of the World's Oceans, 1880-2012
column607: url=http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/science/indicators/oceans/acidity.html#fragment-2 }} }} </ref> The largest decreases in aragonite saturation have occurred in [[tropical]] waters.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/> However, decreases in cold areas may be of greater concern because colder waters typically have lower aragonite levels to begin with.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/>]] About one-third of the carbon dioxide emitted by human activity has already been taken up by the oceans.<ref name=""nrc 2008b ocean acidification""> {{cite book
column609: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column613: 2008b}} </ref> As carbon dioxide dissolves in [[sea water]], [[carbonic acid]] is formed, which has the effect of acidifying the ocean, measured as a change in [[pH]]. The uptake of human carbon emissions since the year 1750 has led to an average decrease in pH of 0.1 units.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 ocean acidification""> {{citation
column619: 2007}}. </ref> Projections using the SRES emissions scenarios suggest a further reduction in average global surface ocean pH of between 0.14 and 0.35 units over the 21st century. The effects of ocean acidification on the marine [[biosphere]] have yet to be documented.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 ocean acidification""/> Laboratory experiments suggest beneficial effects for a few species, with potentially highly detrimental effects for a substantial number of species.<ref name=""nrc 2008b ocean acidification""/> With medium confidence, Fischlin ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column621: chapter = Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods, and services
column625: 2007}}. </ref> projected that future ocean acidification and climate change would impair a wide range of [[plankton]]ic and shallow [[benthos
column626: benthic]] marine organisms that use [[aragonite]] to make their shells or skeletons, such as [[coral]]s and marine [[snail]]s ([[pteropoda
column627: pteropods]]), with significant impacts particularly in the Southern Ocean. ====Oxygen depletion==== The amount of oxygen dissolved in the oceans may decline, with adverse consequences for ocean life.<ref>{{cite doi
column630: Current sea level rise}} [[File:Trends in global average absolute sea level, 1870-2008 (US EPA).png
column634: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column635: Trends in global average absolute sea level, 1870-2008.<ref> {{cite web
column637: title= Sea Level: Climate Change: US EPA
column640: year=2010 }} </ref>]] There is strong evidence that global sea level rose gradually over the 20th century.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""> {{citation
column642: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column644: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-5-1.html FAQ 5.1 Is Sea Level Rising?] }}, in {{harvnb
column648: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column652: 2007}}. </ref> concluded that between the mid-19th and mid-20th centuries, the rate of sea level rise increased. Authors of the IPCC Fourth Assessment Synthesis Report (IPCC AR4 SYR, 2007)<ref name= ""Observed changes in climate and their effects""> {{citation
column656: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms1.html Sec. 1. Observed changes in climate and their effects] }}, p. 5, in {{harvnb
column658: 2007}}. </ref> reported that between the years 1961 and 2003, global average sea level rose at an average rate of 1.8 mm per year (mm/yr), with a range of 1.3–2.3 mm/yr. Between 1993 and 2003, the rate increased above the previous period to 3.1 mm/yr (range of 2.4–3.8 mm/yr). Authors of IPCC AR4 SYR (2007)<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""/> were uncertain whether the increase in rate from 1993 to 2003 was due to [[climate change#Internal forcing mechanisms
column659: natural variations]] in sea level over the time period, or whether it reflected an increase in the underlying long-term trend. There are two main factors that have contributed to observed sea level rise.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""/> The first is [[thermal expansion]]: as ocean water warms, it expands.<ref> {{citation
column663: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/013.htm#b4 Box 2: What causes sea level to change?] }}, in {{harvnb
column665: 2007}}. </ref> The second is from the contribution of land-based ice due to increased melting. The major store of water on land is found in glaciers and ice sheets. Anthropogenic forcing very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""> {{citation
column669: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-2.html Box TS.1: Treatment of Uncertainties in the Working Group I Assessment] }}, in {{harvnb
column671: 2007}}. </ref> contributed to sea level rise during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> There is a widespread consensus that substantial long-term sea level rise will continue for centuries to come.<ref> {{citation
column672: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column676: p=245}}. </ref> In their Fourth Assessment Report, the IPCC<ref> {{citation
column678: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column682: 2007}}. </ref> projected sea level rise to the end of the 21st century using the SRES emissions scenarios. Across the six SRES marker scenarios, sea level was projected to rise by 18 to 59 cm (7.1 to 23.2 in), relative to sea level at the end of the 20th century.<ref>change in sea level by 2090–99, relative to 1980–99</ref> Thermal expansion is the largest component in these projections, contributing 70-75% of the central estimate for all scenarios.<ref> {{citation
column688: 2007}}. </ref> Due to a lack of scientific understanding, this sea level rise estimate does not include all of the possible contributions of ice sheets (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets
column689: Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets]]). An assessment of the [[scientific literature]] on climate change was published in 2010 by the [[US National Research Council]] (NRC, 2010).<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""> {{citation
column691: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column694: 2010}}. </ref> NRC (2010)<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> described the projections in AR4 (i.e. those cited in the above paragraph) as ""conservative"", and summarized the results of more recent studies. Cited studies suggested a great deal of uncertainty in projections.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> A range of projections suggested possible sea level rise by the end of the 21st century of between 0.56 and 2 m, relative to sea levels at the end of the 20th century.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> ====Ocean temperature rise==== [[File:Heat content700m2000myr.png
column699: Global ocean heat content from 1955-2012]] From 1961 to 2003, the global ocean temperature has risen by 0.10 °C from the surface to a depth of 700 m. There is variability both year-to-year and over longer time scales, with global ocean heat content observations showing high rates of warming for 1991–2003, but some cooling from 2003 to 2007.<ref> {{citation
column701: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column706: date=November 2012}} </ref> The temperature of the Antarctic [[Southern Ocean]] rose by 0.17 °C (0.31 °F) between the 1950s and the 1980s, nearly twice the rate for the world's oceans as a whole.<ref> {{cite journal
column710: title= Warming of the Southern Ocean Since the 1950s
column720: ref=harv }}</ref> As well as having effects on ecosystems (e.g. by melting sea ice, affecting algae that grow on its underside), warming reduces the ocean's ability to absorb {{chem
column723: date=June 2008}} It is likely (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> that anthropogenic forcing contributed to the general warming observed in the upper several hundred metres of the ocean during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> ==Regions== {{Main
column724: Regional effects of global warming}} {{Multiple image
column727: image1=Temperatures across the world in the 1880s (left) and the 1980s (right), as compared to average temperatures from 1951 to 1980 (US EPA).jpg
column728: alt1=Temperatures in most parts of the world were warmer in the 1980s compared to the 1880s
column729: image2= Map of projected global warming across the globe by the 2050s. Projections based on three SRES greenhouse gas emissions scenarios. Data from CMIP3 (2007).jpg
column730: alt2=Future warming across the globe varies according to different projections of greenhouse gas emissions
column732: caption1=Temperatures across the world in the 1880s (left) and the 1980s (right), as compared to average temperatures from 1951 to 1980.<ref> {{cite web
column735: title=Science: Climate Change: US EPA (Climate Change Science Overview)
column738: caption2=Projected changes in average temperatures across the world in the 2050s under three greenhouse gas (GHG) [[Economics of global warming#Emissions scenarios
column739: emissions scenarios]].<ref name=""herring temperature projections""/> }} Regional effects of global warming vary in nature. Some are the result of a generalised global change, such as rising temperature, resulting in local effects, such as melting ice. In other cases, a change may be related to a change in a particular ocean current or weather system. In such cases, the regional effect may be disproportionate and will not necessarily follow the global trend. There are three major ways in which global warming will make changes to regional climate: melting or forming ice, changing the [[hydrological cycle]] (of [[evaporation]] and [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column741: currents in the ocean]]s and air flows in the atmosphere. The coast can also be considered a region, and will suffer severe impacts from [[sea level rise]]. ===Observed impacts=== With very high confidence, Rosenzweig ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> concluded that physical and biological systems on all continents and in most oceans had been affected by recent climate changes, particularly regional temperature increases. Impacts include earlier leafing of [[tree]]s and [[plant]]s over many regions; movements of species to higher latitudes and altitudes in the Northern Hemisphere; changes in [[bird migration]]s in Europe, North America and Australia; and shifting of the oceans' [[plankton]] and [[fish]] from cold- to warm-adapted communities.<ref name=""nasa briefs""/> The human influence on the climate can be seen in the geographical pattern of observed warming, with greater temperature increases over land and in [[polar region]]s rather than over the oceans.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""> {{cite book
column743: title=Understanding and Responding to Climate Change. A brochure prepared by the US National Research Council (US NRC)
column744: publisher=[http://dels.nas.edu/basc Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate], National Academy of Sciences
column749: date=November 2012}} Using models, it is possible to identify the human ""signal"" of global warming over both land and ocean areas.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""/>{{Rp
column751: date=November 2012}} ===Projected impacts=== Projections of future climate changes at the regional scale do not hold as high a level of scientific confidence as projections made at the global scale.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""/>{{Rp
column753: date=November 2012}} It is, however, expected that future warming will follow a similar geographical pattern to that seen already, with greatest warming over land and high northern [[latitude]]s, and least over the [[Southern Ocean]] and parts of the [[North Atlantic Ocean]].<ref> {{citation
column757: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-projections-of.html Projections of Future Changes in Climate] }}, in {{harvnb
column759: 2007}}. </ref> Nearly all land areas will very likely warm more than the global average.<ref name=""tar table of robust findings""> {{citation
column766: megadelta]]s are regions that are likely to be especially affected by climate change.<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions""> {{citation
column770: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-3.html Sec. 3.3.3 Especially affected systems, sectors and regions] }}, in {{harvnb
column772: 2007}}. </ref> Adverse impacts of climate change are expected to fall disproportionately upon developing countries.<ref name=""tar table of robust findings""/> Within other areas, even those with high incomes, some people can be particularly at risk from climate change, such as the poor, young [[children]] and the [[elderly]].<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions""/> ==Social systems== {{Main
column773: Effects of climate change on humans
column774: Climate change, industry and society}} The impacts of climate change can be thought of in terms of sensitivity and vulnerability. ""Sensitivity"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be affected, positively or negatively, by climate change and/or [[climate change#Causes
column775: climate variability]]. ""Vulnerability"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be adversely affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
column779: 2007}}. </ref> The sensitivity of human society to climate change varies. Sectors sensitive to climate change include water resources, coastal zones, human settlements, and human health. Industries sensitive to climate change include [[climate change and agriculture
column786: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/008.htm#24 Sec. 2.4. Many Human Systems are Sensitive to Climate Change, and Some are Vulnerable] }}, in {{harvnb
column790: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column798: 2007–2008 world food price crisis}} Climate change will impact agriculture and food production around the world due to: the effects of elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere, higher temperatures, altered precipitation and [[transpiration]] regimes, increased frequency of extreme events, and modified [[weed]], [[pest (organism)
column801: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column803: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch5s5-4.html#5-4-1 5.4.1 Primary effects and interactions] }}, in {{harvnb
column806: p=282}}. </ref> In general, low-latitude areas are at most risk of having decreased crop yields.<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> So far, the effects of regional climate change on agriculture have been relatively limited.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""> {{citation
column808: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column812: 2007}}. </ref> Changes in crop [[phenology]] provide important evidence of the response to recent regional climate change.<ref> {{citation
column814: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column816: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-6-1.html Sec. 1.3.6.1 Crops and livestock] }}, in {{harvnb
column818: 2007}}. </ref> Phenology is the study of natural phenomena that recur periodically, and how these phenomena relate to climate and seasonal changes.<ref> {{citation
column822: 2007}}. </ref> A significant advance in phenology has been observed for agriculture and forestry in large parts of the Northern Hemisphere.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> ====Projections==== With low to medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> projected that for about a 1 to 3 °C increase in global mean temperature (by the years 2090-2100, relative to temperature in the years 1990–2000), there would be productivity decreases for some [[cereal]]s in low latitudes, and productivity increases in high latitudes. With medium confidence, global production potential was projected to:<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> *increase up to around 3 °C, *very likely decrease above about 3 °C. Most of the studies on global agriculture assessed by Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> had not incorporated a number of critical factors, including changes in extreme events, or the spread of pests and diseases. Studies had also not considered the development of specific practices or technologies to aid [[adaptation to global warming#Agricultural production
column823: adaptation to climate change]].<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""> {{citation
column825: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column832: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column834: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch5s5-6-5.html Sec. 5.6.5 Food security and vulnerability] }}, in {{harvnb
column836: 2007}}. </ref> assessed studies that made quantitative projections of climate change impacts on [[food security]]. It was noted that these projections were highly uncertain and had limitations. However, the assessed studies suggested a number of fairly robust findings. The first was that climate change would likely increase the number of people at risk of [[hunger]] compared with reference scenarios with no climate change. Climate change impacts depended strongly on projected future social and economic development. Additionally, the magnitude of climate change impacts was projected to be smaller compared to the impact of social and economic development. In 2006, the global estimate for the number of people [[malnutrition
column842: accessdate=2011-07-07 }} </ref> Under the SRES A1, B1, and B2 scenarios (see the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios#Scenario families
column843: SRES article]] for information on each scenario group), projections for the year 2080 showed a reduction in the number of people undernourished of about 560-700 million people, with a global total of undernourished people of 100-240 million in 2080. By contrast, the SRES A2 scenario showed only a small decrease in the risk of hunger from 2006 levels. The smaller reduction under A2 was attributed to the higher projected future population level in this scenario. ====Agriculture==== Droughts have been occurring more frequently because of global warming and they are expected to become more frequent and intense in Africa, southern Europe, the Middle East, most of the Americas, Australia, and Southeast Asia.<ref>[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/wcc.81/abstract ""Drought under global warming: a review""] ''Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Climate Change'', October 19, 2010</ref> Their impacts are aggravated because of increased water demand, population growth, urban expansion, and environmental protection efforts in many areas.<ref>[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022169411002393 ""Drought modeling – A review""] ''Journal of Hydrology'', 6 June 2011</ref> Droughts result in crop failures and the loss of pasture grazing land for livestock.<ref>[http://www.emeraldinsight.com/journals.htm?articleid=1949627&show=abstract ""Measuring economic impacts of drought: a review and discussion""] ''Disaster Prevention and Management'', 2011</ref> ===Health=== {{Main
column844: Effects of global warming on human health}} Human beings are exposed to climate change through changing weather patterns (temperature, precipitation, sea-level rise and more frequent extreme events) and indirectly through changes in water, air and food quality and changes in ecosystems, agriculture, industry and settlements and the economy (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007:393).<ref name=""health summary""/> According to an assessment of the scientific literature by Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007:393),<ref name=""health summary""/> the effects of climate change to date have been small, but are projected to progressively increase in all countries and regions. A study by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO, 2009)<ref> {{cite book
column847: title= Global health risks: mortality and burden of disease attributable to selected major risks
column855: url= http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/global_health_risks/en/index.html }} </ref> estimated the effect of climate change on human health. Not all of the effects of climate change were included in their estimates, for example, the effects of more frequent and extreme storms were excluded. Climate change was estimated to have been responsible for 3% of [[diarrhoea]], 3% of [[malaria]], and 3.8% of [[dengue fever]] deaths worldwide in 2004. Total attributable mortality was about 0.2% of deaths in 2004; of these, 85% were child deaths. ====Projections==== With high confidence, authors of the IPCC AR4 Synthesis report<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report""/>{{Rp
column857: date=November 2012}} projected that climate change would bring some benefits in temperate areas, such as fewer deaths from cold exposure, and some mixed effects such as changes in range and transmission potential of [[malaria]] in [[Africa]]. Benefits were projected to be outweighed by negative health effects of rising temperatures, especially in developing countries. With very high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/>{{Rp
column859: date=November 2012}} concluded that economic development was an important component of possible adaptation to climate change. Economic growth on its own, however, was not judged to be sufficient to insulate the world's population from disease and injury due to climate change. Future vulnerability to climate change will depend not only on the extent of social and economic change, but also on how the benefits and costs of change are distributed in society.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""> {{citation
column863: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-3-2.html Sec. 8.3.2 Future vulnerability to climate change] }}, in {{harvnb
column865: 2007}}. </ref> For example, in the 19th century, rapid [[urbanization]] in [[western Europe]] lead to a plummeting in population health.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""/> Other factors important in determining the health of populations include [[education]], the availability of health services, and [[public health
column870: date=May 2010}} =====Malnutrition===== With high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) projected that malnutrition would increase due to climate change.<ref name=""health summary""> {{citation
column876: 2007}}. </ref> This link is associated with climate variability and change.<ref name=""drought nutrition"">{{citation
column880: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-3.html Sec. 8.2.3 Drought, nutrition and food security] }}, in {{harvnb
column884: consumption]]. This can lead to [[micronutrient]] deficiencies. The [[World Health Organization]] (Campbell-Lendrum ''et al.'', 2003)<ref name=""who projections""> {{citation
column885: title= How much disease could climate change cause? Climate Change and Human Health: Risks and Responses
column889: publisher=World Health Organization (WHO) / World Meteorological Organization (WMO) / United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP)
column892: at = [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-4-1-1.html 8.4.1.1 Global burden of disease study]
column895: 2007}} </ref> conducted a regional and global assessment to quantify the amount of premature [[morbidity]] and [[death
column896: mortality]] due to a range of factors, including climate change. Projections were made over future climate change impacts. Limited adjustments for adaptation were included in the estimates based on these projections. Projected relative risks attributable to climate change in 2030 varied by health outcome and region. Risks were largely negative, with most of the projected disease burden due to increases in diarrhoeal disease and malnutrition. These increases were primarily in low-income populations already experiencing a large burden of disease. =====Extreme events===== With high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) projected that climate change would increase the number of people suffering from death, disease and injury from [[heatwave]]s, [[flood]]s, [[storm]]s, [[fire]]s and [[drought]]s.<ref name=""health summary""/> ;Floods and weather disasters Floods are low-probability, high-impact events that can overwhelm physical infrastructure and human communities.<ref name=""Health impacts of wind, storms and floods""> {{citation
column900: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-2.html Sec. 8.2.2 Wind, storms and floods] }}, in {{harvnb
column902: 2007}}. </ref> Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) reported that major storm and flood disasters have occurred in the last two decades. The impacts of weather disasters is considerable and unequally distributed.<ref name=""Health impacts of wind, storms and floods""/> For example, natural disasters have been shown to result in increased domestic violence against - and [[posttraumatic stress disorder
column903: post-traumatic stress disorders]] in – [[women]]. In terms of deaths and populations affected, floods and tropical cyclones have the greatest impact in South Asia and Latin America. Vulnerability to weather disasters depends on the attributes of the person at risk, including where they live and their age, as well as other social and environmental factors. High-density populations in low-lying coastal regions experience a high health burden from weather disasters. ;Heatwaves Hot days, hot nights and heatwaves have become more frequent.<ref> {{citation
column909: 2007}}. </ref> Heatwaves are associated with marked short-term increases in mortality. For example, in August 2003, a heatwave in Europe resulted in excess mortality in the range of 35,000 total deaths. Heat-related morbidity and mortality is projected to increase.<ref name=""heat and cold related mortality""> {{citation
column913: at = [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-4-1-3.html Sec. 8.4.1.3 Heat- and cold-related mortality] }}, in {{harvnb
column915: 2007}}. </ref> The health burden could be relatively small for moderate heatwaves in temperate regions, because deaths occur primarily in susceptible persons. ;Drought The effects of drought on health include deaths, malnutrition, [[infectious disease]]s and [[respiratory disease]]s.<ref name=""drought nutrition""/> Countries within the ""[[Meningitis]] Belt"" in semi-arid sub-Saharan Africa experience the highest [[endemic (epidemiology)
column917: meningococcal]] meningitis in Africa, although other areas in the Rift Valley, the Great Lakes, and southern Africa are also affected.<ref> {{citation
column921: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-3-1.html Sec. 8.2.3.1 Drought and infectious disease] }}, in {{harvnb
column923: 2007}}. </ref> The spatial distribution, intensity, and seasonality of meningococcal (epidemic) meningitis appear to be strongly linked to climate and environmental factors, particularly drought. The cause of this link is not fully understood. ;Fires In some regions, changes in temperature and precipitation are projected to increase the frequency and severity of fire events.<ref> {{citation
column927: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-6-3.html Sec. 8.2.6.3 Air pollutants from forest fires] }}, in {{harvnb
column929: 2007}}. </ref> Forest and bush fires cause burns, damage from smoke inhalation and other injuries. =====Infectious disease vectors===== With high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/> projected that climate change would continue to change the range of some [[infectious disease]] vectors. [[Vector (epidemiology)
column930: Vector-borne diseases]] (VBD) are infections transmitted by the bite of infected [[arthropod]] species, such as [[mosquito]]es, [[tick]]s, [[triatominae
column937: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-8.html Sec. 8.2.8 Vector-borne, rodent-borne and other infectious diseases] }}, in {{harvnb
column939: 2007}}. </ref> There is some evidence of climate-change-related shifts in the distribution of tick vectors of disease, of some (non-malarial) mosquito vectors in Europe and North America. Climate change has also been implicated in changes in the breeding and migration dates of several bird species. Several species of wild bird can act as carriers of human [[pathogen]]s as well as of vectors of infectious agents. ======Dengue====== With low confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) concluded that climate change would increase the number of people at risk of dengue.<ref name=""health summary""/> [[dengue fever
column940: Dengue]] is the world's most important vector-borne viral disease.<ref> {{citation
column946: 2007}}. </ref> Several studies have reported associations between dengue and climate, however, these associations are not entirely consistent. [[File:Malaria mortality past century.jpg
column949: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column951: Observed malaria mortality: Although showing such over the past century of global warming, there are [[Malaria#Prevention
column952: also other factors impacting the past and future of malaria]].]] ======Malaria====== The spatial distribution, intensity of transmission, and seasonalty of [[malaria]] is influenced by climate in [[Sub-saharan Africa]].<ref> {{citation
column958: 2007}}. </ref> Rainfall can be a limiting factor for mosquito populations and there is some evidence of reductions in transmission associated with decadal decreases in rainfall. The effects of observed climate change on the geographical distribution of malaria and its transmission intensity in highland regions remains controversial. There is no clear evidence that malaria has been affected by climate change in South America or in continental regions of the Russian Federation. There is still much uncertainty about the potential impact of climate change on malaria at local and global scales. {{Undue
column960: date=May 2010}} A paper by researchers from the [[University of Oxford]] and the [[University of Florida]] published in [[Nature (journal)
column961: Nature]] in May 2010 concluded that claims that a warming climate has led to more widespread disease and death due to malaria are largely at odds with the evidence, and that ""''predictions of an intensification of malaria in a warmer world, based on extrapolated empirical relationships or biological mechanisms, must be set against a context of a century of warming that has seen marked global declines in the disease and a substantial weakening of the global correlation between malaria endemicity and climate.''""<ref> {{cite journal
column962: author= Peter W. Gething, David L. Smith, Anand P. Patil, Andrew J. Tatem, Robert W. Snow & Simon I. Hay
column963: title= Climate change and the global malaria recession
column976: title=Don’t sweat it: Development and public-health initiatives will matter much more to malaria than the climate will
column979: accessdate=2010-05-25 }}</ref> ======Other infectious diseases====== There is good evidence that diseases transmitted by [[rodent]]s sometimes increase during heavy rainfall and flooding because of altered patterns of human-pathogen-rodent contact.<ref> {{citation
column983: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-8-3.html Sec. 8.2.8.3 Other infectious diseases] }}, in {{harvnb
column985: 2007}}. </ref> ======Projections====== With very high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/> concluded that climate change would have mixed effects on malaria. Malaria is a complex disease to model and all of the published models assessed by Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) had limited [[Parametrization (climate)
column990: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-4-1-2.html Sec. 8.4.1.2 Malaria, dengue and other infectious diseases] }}, in {{harvnb
column992: 2007}}. </ref> Parametrization is used in [[climate model]]s because the resolution of models is insufficient to resolve some physical processes.<ref> {{citation
column994: chapter= Chapter 8: Climate Models and their Evaluation
column998: 2007}}. </ref> Given this limitation, models assessed by Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007) projected that, particularly in Africa, climate change would be associated with geographical expansions of the areas suitable for ''Plasmodium falciparum'' malaria in some regions, and contractions in other regions. Projections also suggested that some regions would experience a longer season of transmission. Projections suggested expansions in vector species that carry dengue for parts of Australia and New Zealand. =====Diarrhoeal diseases===== With medium confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/> concluded that climate change would increase the burden of diarrhoeal diseases. Childhood mortality due to diarrhoea in low-income countries, especially in Sub-Saharan Africa, remains high.<ref> {{citation
column1002: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-5.html Sec.8.2.5 Water and disease] }}, in {{harvnb
column1004: 2007}}. </ref> This is despite improvements in care. Several studies have shown that transmission of [[intestine
column1005: enteric]] pathogens is higher during the rainy season. Some studies have found that higher temperature was strongly associated with increased episodes of diarrhoeal disease in adults and children in Peru. Campbell-Lendrum ''et al.'' (2003)<ref name=""who projections""/> projected that climate change would increase the burden of diarrhoeal diseases in low-income regions by approximately 2 to 5% in 2020. =====Ground-level ozone===== With high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/> projected that climate change would increase cardio-respiratory morbidity and mortality associated with ground-level [[ozone]]. Ground-level ozone is both naturally occurring and is the primary constituent of urban [[smog]].<ref> {{citation
column1009: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-2-6.html Sec. 8.2.6 Air quality and disease] }}, in {{harvnb
column1011: 2007}}. </ref> Ozone in smog is formed through chemical reactions involving [[nitrogen oxide]]s and other compounds. The reaction is a [[photochemical reaction]], meaning that it involves [[electromagnetic radiation]], and occurs in the presence of bright sunshine and high temperatures. Exposure to elevated concentrations of ozone is associated with increased hospital admissions for [[pneumonia]], [[chronic obstructive pulmonary disease]], [[asthma]], allergic [[rhinitis]] and other respiratory diseases, and with premature mortality. Background levels of ground-level ozone have risen since pre-industrial times because of increasing emissions of methane, [[carbon monoxide]] and nitrogen oxides.<ref> {{citation
column1015: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-4-1-4.html Sec. 8.4.1.4 Urban air quality] }}, in {{harvnb
column1017: 2007}}. </ref> This trend is expected to continue into the mid-21st century. =====Cold-waves===== [[cold wave
column1018: Cold-waves]] continue to be a problem in northern latitudes, where very low temperatures can be reached in a few hours and extend over long periods.<ref> {{citation
column1024: 2007}}. </ref> Reductions in cold-deaths due to climate change are projected to be greater than increases in heat-related deaths in the UK.<ref name=""heat and cold related mortality""/> [[File:NOAAprecipitationtrend.jpg
column1028: Precipitation during the 20th century and up through 2008 during global warming, the [[NOAA]] estimating an observed trend over that period of 1.87% global precipitation increase per century.]] ===Water resources=== {{See also
column1029: Water crisis}} A number of climate-related trends have been observed that affect [[water resources]]. These include changes in precipitation, the crysosphere and [[surface water]]s (e.g., changes in [[river flows]]).<ref> {{citation
column1031: chapter = Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column1035: 2007}}. </ref> Observed and projected impacts of climate change on [[freshwater]] systems and their management are mainly due to changes in temperature, sea level and precipitation variability.<ref name=""freshwater impacts""> {{citation
column1037: chapter= Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column1039: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch3s3-es.html Sec. 3.3 Executive summary] }}, p. 175, in {{harvnb
column1041: 2007}}. </ref> Sea level rise will extend areas of [[salinization]] of [[groundwater]] and [[estuary
column1042: estuaries]], resulting in a decrease in freshwater availability for humans and ecosystems in coastal areas. In an assessment of the [[scientific literature]], Kundzewicz ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""freshwater impacts""/> concluded, with high confidence, that: *the negative impacts of climate change on freshwater systems outweigh the benefits. All of the regions assessed in the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]] ([[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], [[Europe]], [[Latin America]], [[North America]], [[Polar region]]s ([[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]]), and small islands) showed an overall net negative impact of climate change on water resources and freshwater ecosystems. *[[semi-arid climate
column1043: Semi-arid]] and [[arid]] areas are particularly exposed to the impacts of climate change on freshwater. With very high confidence, it was judged that many of these areas, e.g., the [[Mediterranean basin]], [[Western United States]], [[Southern Africa]], and north-eastern [[Brazil]], would suffer a decrease in water resources due to climate change. ===Migration and conflict=== {{See also
column1045: General circulation model]]s project that the future climate change will bring wetter coasts, drier mid-continent areas, and further sea level rise.<ref name=""sar migration""> {{citation
column1047: chapter= Chapter 12: Human settlements in a changing climate: impacts and adaptation
column1048: at= Sec. 12.3.1 Population Migration }}, pp. 406—407, in {{harvnb
column1050: 1996}}. </ref> Such changes could result in the gravest effects of climate change through sudden [[human migration]]. Millions might be displaced by [[shoreline erosion]]s, river and coastal [[flood]]ing, or severe [[drought]]. Migration related to climate change is likely to be predominantly from [[rural area]]s in [[developing countries]] to towns and [[cities]].<ref name=""sar migration""/>{{Rp
column1054: title = Managing social risks: Empower communities to protect themselves
column1055: chapter = Part One: Chapter 2: Reducing Human Vulnerability: Helping People Help Themselves
column1058: 2010}}. </ref> In the short term climate stress is likely to add incrementally to existing migration patterns rather than generating entirely new flows of people.<ref name=""wdr migration""/>{{Rp
column1060: date=November 2012}} It has been argued that environmental degradation, loss of access to resources (e.g., water resources),<ref> {{citation
column1066: 2001}}. </ref> and resulting human migration could become a source of political and even [[military conflict]].<ref name=""tar migration""> {{citation
column1068: chapter= Chapter 7: Human Settlements, Energy, and Industry
column1072: 2001}}. </ref> Factors other than climate change may, however, be more important in affecting conflict. For example, Wilbanks ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column1074: chapter = Chapter 7: Industry, settlement and society
column1076: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-1.html Sec. 7.4.1 General effects: Box 7.2. Environmental migration] }}, in {{harvnb
column1078: 2007}}. </ref> suggested that major environmentally influenced conflicts in Africa were more to do with the relative abundance of resources, e.g., [[oil]] and [[diamond]]s, than with resource scarcity. Scott ''et al.'' (2001) placed only low confidence in predictions of increased conflict due to climate change.<ref name=""tar migration""/> ===Aggregate impacts=== {{Main
column1079: Economic impacts of climate change}} [[Aggregate data
column1080: Aggregating]] impacts adds up the total impact of climate change across sectors and/or regions. <ref> {{citation
