column1082: chapter-url= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/annexessglossary-a-d.html Glossary A-D]: ""Aggregate impacts"" }}, p. 76, in {{harvnb
column1084: 2007}}. </ref> Examples of aggregate measures include [[Economic impacts of climate change#Distribution of impacts
column1085: economic cost]] (e.g., changes in [[gross domestic product]] (GDP) and the [[Economic impacts of climate change#Marginal impacts
column1086: social cost of carbon]]), changes in ecosystems (e.g., changes over land area from one type of vegetation to another),<ref> {{citation
column1088: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1090: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/677.htm Sec. 19.5.3 Insights and Lessons: Vulnerability over Time: Table 19-5] }}, in {{harvnb
column1092: 2001}}. </ref> human health impacts, and the number of people affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
column1094: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1096: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/676.htm Sec. 19.5.2. Insights and Lessons: The Static Picture] }}, in {{harvnb
column1098: 2001}}. </ref> Aggregate measures such as economic cost require researchers to make [[value judgement]]s over the importance of impacts occurring in different regions and at different times. ====Observed impacts==== Global losses reveal rapidly rising costs due to extreme weather-related events since the 1970s.<ref> {{citation
column1100: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of observed changes and responses in natural and managed systems
column1102: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-8-5.html Sec. 1.3.8.5 Summary of disasters and hazards] }}, in {{harvnb
column1105: Socio-economic]] factors have contributed to the observed trend of global losses, e.g., population growth, increased [[wealth]].<ref name=""disaster losses""> {{citation
column1111: 2001}}. </ref> Part of the growth is also related to regional climatic factors, e.g., changes in precipitation and flooding events. It is difficult to quantify the relative impact of socio-economic factors and climate change on the observed trend.<ref name=""disaster losses""/> The trend does, however, suggest increasing vulnerability of social systems to climate change.<ref name=""disaster losses""/> ====Projected impacts==== The total economic impacts from climate change are highly uncertain.<ref> {{citation
column1113: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1115: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-2-3.html Sec. 19.3.2.3 Aggregate market impacts] }}, p. 790, in {{harvnb
column1117: 2007}}. </ref> With medium confidence, Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""> {{citation
column1119: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1123: 2001}}. </ref> concluded that world GDP would change by plus or minus a few percent for a small increase in global mean temperature (up to around 2 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level). Most studies assessed by Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""/> projected losses in world GDP for a medium increase in global mean temperature (above 2-3 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level), with increasing losses for greater temperature increases. This assessment is consistent with the findings of more recent studies, as reviewed by Hitz and Smith (2004).<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""> {{citation
column1125: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1127: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Sec. 19.3.7 Update on ‘Reasons for Concern’] }}, p. 796, in {{harvnb
column1129: 2007}}. </ref> Economic impacts are expected to vary regionally.<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/><ref> {{citation
column1131: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1133: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/675.htm Sec. 19.4.3. Distribution of Total Impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column1135: 2001}}. </ref> For a medium increase in global mean temperature (2-3 °C of warming, relative to the average temperature between 1990–2000), market sectors in low-latitude and less-developed areas might experience net costs due to climate change.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> On the other hand, market sectors in high-latitude and developed regions might experience net benefits for this level of warming. A global mean temperature increase above about 2-3 °C (relative to 1990-2000) would very likely result in market sectors across all regions experiencing either declines in net benefits or rises in net costs.<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> Aggregate impacts have also been quantified in non-economic terms. For example, climate change over the 21st century is likely to adversely affect hundreds of millions of people through increased coastal flooding, reductions in water supplies, increased malnutrition and increased health impacts.<ref name=""ar4 synthesis reasons for concern""/> ==Biological systems== {{Main
column1138: Effect of climate change on plant biodiversity
column1139: Effects of climate change on terrestrial animals
column1140: Effects of climate change on marine mammals}} ===Observed impacts on biological systems=== [[File:A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming (low-res).png
column1144: A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming.<ref name=""nasa briefs""> {{cite web
column1148: title=Science Briefs: Warming Climate is Changing Life on Global Scale
column1149: publisher=Website of the US National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Goddard Institute for Space Studies
column1151: accessdate=2011-07-08}} </ref>]] With very high confidence, Rosenzweig ''et al.'' (2007) concluded that recent warming had strongly affected natural biological systems.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> Hundreds of studies have documented responses of [[ecosystem]]s, [[plant]]s, and [[animal]]s to the climate changes that have already occurred.<ref> {{cite book
column1153: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column1158: page = 14 }} </ref> For example, in the Northern Hemisphere, species are almost uniformly moving their ranges northward and up in elevation in search of cooler temperatures.<ref name=""nrc 2008b observed ecosystem impacts""> {{cite book
column1160: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column1165: page = 16 }} </ref> Humans are very likely causing changes in regional temperatures to which plants and animals are responding.<ref name=""nrc 2008b observed ecosystem impacts""/> ===Projected impacts on biological systems=== By the year 2100, ecosystems will be exposed to atmospheric {{chem
column1167: 2}} levels substantially higher than in the past 650,000 years, and global temperatures at least among the highest of those experienced in the past 740,000 years.<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""> {{citation
column1169: chapter= Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column1173: 2007}}. </ref> Significant disruptions of ecosystems are projected to increase with future climate change.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""> {{citation
column1179: 2001}}. </ref> Examples of disruptions include disturbances such as fire, drought, pest [[infestation]], invasion of species, storms, and [[coral bleaching]] events. The stresses caused by climate change, added to other stresses on ecological systems (e.g., land conversion, [[land degradation]], [[harvest]]ing, and [[pollution]]), threaten substantial damage to or complete loss of some unique ecosystems, and [[extinction]] of some critically endangered species.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""/> Climate change has been estimated to be a major driver of [[biodiversity]] loss in cool [[conifer]] forests, [[savanna]]s, [[mediterranean climate
column1180: mediterranean-climate]] systems, [[tropical forest]]s, in the [[Arctic tundra]], and in [[coral reef]]s.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""> {{citation
column1182: chapter= Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column1184: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch4s4-4-11.html Sec. 4.4.11 Global synthesis including impacts on biodiversity] }}, in {{harvnb
column1187: land-use]] change may be a stronger driver of biodiversity loss at least in the near-term.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> Beyond the year 2050, climate change may be the major driver for biodiversity loss globally.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> A literature assessment by Fischlin ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""/> included a quantitative estimate of the number of the number of species at increased risk of extinction due to climate change. With medium confidence, it was projected that approximately 20 to 30% of plant and animal species assessed so far (in an unbiased [[Sampling (statistics)
column1188: sample]]) would likely be at increasingly high risk of extinction should global mean temperatures exceed a warming of 2 to 3 °C above pre-industrial temperature levels.<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""/> The uncertainties in this estimate, however, are large: for a rise of about 2 °C the percentage may be as low as 10%, or for about 3 °C, as high as 40%, and depending on [[Biota (ecology)
column1189: biota]] (all living [[organism]]s of an area, the [[flora]] and [[fauna]] considered as a unit)<ref> {{citation
column1193: 2007}}. </ref> the range is between 1% and 80%.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> As global average temperature exceeds 4 °C above pre-industrial levels, model projections suggested that there could be significant extinctions (40-70% of species that were assessed) around the globe.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> Assessing whether future changes in ecosystems will be beneficial or detrimental is largely based on how ecosystems are valued by human society.<ref> {{citation
column1196: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column1200: 2008b}}. </ref> For increases in global average temperature exceeding 1.5 to 2.5 °C (relative to global temperatures over the years 1980-1999)<ref> {{citation
column1202: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column1204: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3.html Sec. 3.3 Impacts of future climate changes] }}, in {{harvnb
column1208: 2}} concentrations, projected changes in ecosystems will have predominantly negative consequences for biodiversity and ecosystems goods and [[ecosystem services
column1209: services]], e.g., water and food supply.<ref> {{citation
column1211: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column1213: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-1.html Sec. 3.3.1 Impacts on systems and sectors: Ecosystems] }}, in {{harvnb
column1215: 2007}}. </ref> ==Abrupt or irreversible changes== Physical, ecological and social systems may respond in an abrupt, [[non-linear]] or irregular way to climate change.<ref name=""singularities""> {{citation
column1217: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1219: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/679.htm Sec. 19.6.1. The Irregular Face of Climate Change] }}, in {{harvnb
column1221: 2001}}. </ref> This is as opposed to a smooth or regular response. A quantitative entity behaves ""irregularly"" when its [[system dynamics
column1223: discontinuous]] (i.e., not smooth), nondifferentiable, unbounded, wildly varying, or otherwise ill-defined.<ref name=""singularities""/> Such behaviour is often termed ""[[Mathematical singularity
column1224: singular]]"". Irregular behaviour in Earth systems may give rise to certain thresholds, which, when crossed, may lead to a large change in the system. Some singularities could potentially lead to severe impacts at regional or global scales.<ref name=""white et al singularities""> {{citation
column1228: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/052.htm Sec. 7.2.5, Large-Scale Singular Events] }}, in {{harvnb
column1230: 2001}}. </ref> Examples of ""large-scale"" singularities are discussed in the articles on [[abrupt climate change]], [[climate change feedback]] and [[runaway climate change]]. It is possible that human-induced climate change could trigger large-scale singularities, but the probabilities of triggering such events are, for the most part,<ref> ""[F]or the most part"" refers to improved scientific understanding of singularities since the assessment by White ''et al.'' (2001). See: {{citation
column1232: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1234: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Sec. 19.3.7 Update on ‘Reasons for Concern’] }}, in {{harvnb
column1236: 2007}}. </ref> poorly understood.<ref name=""white et al singularities""/> With low to medium confidence, Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""singularities""> {{citation
column1238: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1242: 2001}}. </ref> concluded that a rapid warming of more than 3 °C above 1990 levels would exceed thresholds that would lead to large-scale discontinuities in the climate system. Since the assessment by Smith ''et al.'' (2001), improved scientific understanding provides more guidance for two large-scale singularities: the role of [[carbon cycle]] feedbacks in future climate change (discussed below in the section on biogeochemical cycles) and the melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column1243: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s.<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/> ===Biogeochemical cycles=== {{See also
column1244: climate change feedback}} Climate change may have an effect on the [[carbon cycle]] in an interactive ""feedback"" process. A feedback exists where an initial process triggers changes in a second process that in turn influences the initial process. A positive feedback intensifies the original process, and a negative feedback reduces it.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report""> {{citation
column1250: date=November 2012}} Models suggest that the interaction of the climate system and the carbon cycle is one where the feedback effect is positive.<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""> {{citation
column1252: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1258: date=November 2012}} Using the A2 SRES emissions scenario, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""/>{{Rp
column1260: date=November 2012}} found that this effect led to additional warming by the years 2090-2100 (relative to the 1990–2000) of 0.1–1.5 °C. This estimate was made with high confidence. The climate projections made in the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report summarized earlier of 1.1–6.4 °C account for this feedback effect. On the other hand, with medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""/>{{Rp
column1262: date=November 2012}} commented that additional releases of GHGs were possible from permafrost, peat lands, wetlands, and large stores of marine hydrates at high latitudes. ===Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets=== With medium confidence, authors of AR4<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""> {{citation
column1268: 2007}}. </ref> concluded that with a global average temperature increase of 1–4 °C (relative to temperatures over the years 1990–2000), at least a partial deglaciation of the [[Greenland ice sheet]], and possibly the [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s would occur. The estimated timescale for partial deglaciation was centuries to millennia, and would contribute {{convert
column1272: m}} or more to sea level rise over this period. ===The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation=== {{See also
column1275: This map shows the general location and direction of the warm surface (red) and cold deep water (blue) currents of the [[thermohaline circulation]]. [[Salinity]] is represented by color in units of the Practical Salinity Scale. Low values (blue) are less saline, while high values (orange) are more saline.<ref> {{cite web
column1277: author=Riebeek, H.. design by R. Simmon
column1278: title=Paleoclimatology: Explaining the Evidence: Explaining Rapid Climate Change: Tales from the Ice
column1284: right]] The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is an important component of the Earth's climate system, characterized by a northward flow of warm, salty water in the upper layers of the [[Atlantic ocean
column1285: Atlantic]] and a southward flow of colder water in the deep Atlantic.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""> {{cite book
column1288: title= Abrupt Climate Change. A report by the US Climate Change Science Program (CCSP) and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column1293: date=November 2012}} The AMOC is equivalently known as the [[thermohaline circulation]] (THC).<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/> Potential impacts associated with MOC changes include reduced warming or (in the case of abrupt change) absolute cooling of northern high-latitude areas near [[Greenland]] and north-western Europe, an increased warming of [[Southern Hemisphere]] high-latitudes, tropical drying, as well as changes to [[marine ecosystem]]s, terrestrial vegetation, oceanic {{chem
column1295: 2}} uptake, oceanic oxygen concentrations, and shifts in fisheries.<ref> {{citation
column1297: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1299: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-5-3.html Sec. 19.3.5.3 Possible changes in the North Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (MOC)] }}, in {{harvnb
column1301: 2007}}. </ref> According to an assessment by the US [[Climate Change Science Program]] (CCSP, 2008b),<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1303: date=November 2012}} it is very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1305: date=November 2012}} that the strength of the AMOC will decrease over the course of the 21st century. Warming is still expected to occur over most of the European region downstream of the [[North Atlantic Current]] in response to increasing GHGs, as well as over [[North America]]. Although it is very unlikely (less than 10% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1307: date=November 2012}} that the AMOC will collapse in the 21st century, the potential consequences of such a collapse could be severe.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1309: date=November 2012}} ===Irreversibilities=== ====Commitment to radiative forcing==== Emissions of GHGs are a potentially irreversible commitment to sustained [[radiative forcing]] in the future.<ref name=""albritton irreversible radiative forcing""> {{citation
column1313: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc%5Ftar/wg1/016.htm Sec. C.1 Observed Changes in Globally Well-Mixed Greenhouse Gas Concentrations and Radiative Forcing] }}, p. 38, in {{harvnb
column1315: 2001}}. </ref> The contribution of a GHG to radiative forcing depends on the gas's ability to trap [[infrared]] (heat) radiation, the concentration of the gas in the atmosphere, and the length of time the gas resides in the atmosphere.<ref name=""albritton irreversible radiative forcing""/> {{chem
column1317: 2}} is the most important anthropogenic GHG.<ref name=""ipcc 2007 causes of climate change""> {{citation
column1321: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms2.html Sec. 2. Causes of change] }}, p. 5, in {{harvnb
column1323: 2007}}. </ref> While more than half of the {{chem
column1325: 2}} emitted is currently removed from the atmosphere within a century, some fraction (about 20%) of emitted {{chem
column1327: 2}} remains in the atmosphere for many thousands of years.<ref> {{cite book
column1331: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-10-3.html Frequently Asked Question 10.3: If Emissions of Greenhouse Gases are Reduced, How Quickly do Their Concentrations in the Atmosphere Decrease?] }}, in {{harvnb
column1335: 2}} emitted today is potentially an irreversible commitment to sustained radiative forcing over thousands of years. This commitment may not be truly irreversible should techniques be developed to remove {{chem
column1337: 2}} or other GHGs directly from the atmosphere, or to block sunlight to induce cooling.<ref name=""solomon irreversible climate change""> {{cite journal
column1340: title=Irreversible climate change due to carbon dioxide emissions
column1341: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (PNAS)
column1350: bibcode = 2009PNAS..106.1704S }}</ref> Techniques of this sort are referred to as [[geoengineering]]. Little is known about the effectiveness, costs or potential [[Unintended consequences
column1351: side-effect]]s of geoengineering options.<ref name=""barker geoengineering""> {{citation
column1353: chapter= Chapter 11: Mitigation from a cross-sectoral perspective
column1355: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/ch11s11-es.html Executive summary - Unconventional options] }} , in {{harvnb
column1357: 2007}}. </ref> Some geoengineering options, such as blocking sunlight, would not prevent further [[ocean acidification]].<ref name=""barker geoengineering""/> ====Irreversible impacts==== Human-induced climate change may lead to irreversible impacts on physical, biological, and social systems.<ref> {{citation
column1363: 2001}}. <!-- XX Needs checking. --> </ref> There are a number of examples of climate change impacts that may be irreversible, at least over the timescale of many human generations.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""> {{citation
column1365: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1367: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-2.html Sec.19.2 Criteria for selecting ‘key’ vulnerabilities: Persistence and reversibility] }}, in {{harvnb
column1369: 2007}}. </ref> These include the large-scale singularities described above - changes in carbon cycle feedbacks, the melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, and changes to the AMOC.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In biological systems, the extinction of species would be an irreversible impact.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In social systems, unique [[culture]]s may be lost due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> For example, humans living on [[atoll]] islands face risks due to sea-level rise, sea-surface warming, and increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.<ref> {{cite journal
column1377: url=http://www.uea.ac.uk/env/people/adgerwn/ClimChange2003Barnett.pdf }} This paper was published in 2001 as [http://www.tyndall.ac.uk/sites/default/files/wp9.pdf Tyndall Centre Working Paper 9] </ref> == See also == {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ; General * [[Anthropocene]] * [[Risks to civilization, humans and planet Earth]] * [[Indigenous Peoples Climate Change Assessment Initiative]] * [[Environmental sociology]] ; Regional * [[Arctic Climate Impact Assessment]] * [[Effects of global warming on Australia]] * [[Effects of global warming on India]] * [[Kivalina v. ExxonMobil Corporation]] * [[Climate Change Science Program#Impacts and adaptation
column1378: Bush Administration assessments of impacts and adaptation]] (United States) {{Col-break}} {{Portal
column1381: Environment}} * [[Biological pump]] * [[Climate Vulnerability Monitor]] (CVM) * [[Oceanic anoxic event]] * [[PRECIS (Providing Regional Climates for Impacts Studies)]] * [[Solubility pump]] {{Col-end}} {{Clear}} ==Footnotes== <sup>1</sup> The TAR<ref name=""Uncertainty in the TAR""> {{citation
column1387: 2001}}. </ref> and AR4<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> that are referred to in this article use specific and quantitative language to describe uncertainty. This language is intended to provide an indication of the level of confidence that IPCC authors have about a particular finding. The qualitative language used to describe uncertainty has a quantitative scale associated with it. The quantitative values for qualitative terms are intended to ensure that confidence levels are interpreted correctly. The is because qualitative statements, e.g., using the word ""likely"", can be interpreted differently in quantitative terms.<ref> {{citation
column1394: title= IPCC supporting material: guidance papers on the cross cutting issues of the Third Assessment Report of the IPCC
column1395: editor= R. Pachuari, T. Taniguchi and K. Tanaka, (eds.)
column1397: publisher= Global Industrial and Social Progress Research Institute (GISPRI)
column1401: date=November 2012}} Confidence levels used in the TAR:<ref> {{citation
column1405: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/023.htm#14 Box 2. Confidence Levels and State of Knowledge] }}, in {{harvnb
column1407: 2001}}. </ref> *Very High = 95% or greater *High = 67-95% *Medium = 33-67% *Low = 5-33% *Very Low = 5% or less Confidence statements made in AR4 are listed below:<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> *Very high confidence: At least 9 out of 10 chance of being correct *High confidence: About 8 out of 10 chance "" "" "" *Medium confidence: About 5 out of 10 chance "" "" "" *Low confidence: About 2 out of 10 chance "" "" "" *Very low confidence: Less than a 1 out of 10 chance "" "" "" IPCC (2012)<ref> {{citation
column1412: p=19}} </ref> uses the following terms: ""very low"", ""low"", ""medium"", ""high"", and ""very high confidence"". Unlike the TAR and AR4, the scale is qualitative rather than quantitative. The quantitative values used by IPCC authors are ""subjective"" probabilities,<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/><ref name=""Uncertainty in the TAR""/><ref> {{citation
column1416: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/106.htm Sec. 2.6.2. ""Objective"" and ""Subjective"" Probabilities are not Always Explicitly Distinguished] }}, in {{harvnb
column1419: Bayesian]]"" probabilities,<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""> {{cite book
column1421: author= Granger Morgan, M. (Lead Author), H. Dowlatabadi, M. Henrion, D. Keith, R. Lempert, S. McBride, M. Small and T. Wilbanks (Contributing Authors)
column1422: title= Synthesis and Assessment Product 5.2: Best practice approaches for characterizing, communicating, and incorporating scientific uncertainty in decisionmaking. A Report by the U.S. [[Climate Change Science Program]] and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column1423: publisher= National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
column1426: url= http://www.globalchange.gov/publications/reports/scientific-assessments/saps/311 }} Tables 2.1 and 2.2 on pages 27-28 show two quantitative scales of uncertainty which are used in the TAR and AR4.</ref> and reflect the expert judgement of IPCC authors. In this formulation, probability is not only a function of an event, but also the state of information that is available to the person making the assessment.<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""/> In this framework, assigned probabilities may change as more or different information becomes available.<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""/> The IPCC also uses another scale to describe the likelihood of a particular event occurring.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> This is different from the confidence scales described above, and it is possible to assign confidence values to statements of likelihood. For example, the judgement that an event is improbable (e.g., rolling a [[dice]] twice and getting a six both times) may be assigned a high level of scientific confidence.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> Also, the probability that an event has an even chance of occurring (e.g., a tossed [[coin]] coming up heads) may also be assigned a high level of confidence.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> == Notes == {{Reflist

This body assesses the physical scientific aspects of the climate system and climate change. ;Social, economic and ecological impacts *[http://www.un.org/esa/dsd/dsd_aofw_cc/cc_index.shtml Climate change] on the United Nations Economic and Social Development (UNESD) Division for Sustainable Development website. *[http://www.ipcc-wg2.gov/ The IPCC Working Group II (WG II) website] – This body assesses the vulnerability of socio-economic and natural systems to climate change, negative and positive consequences of climate change, and options for adapting to it. ;General *[http://esa.un.org/subindex/pgViewSites.asp?termCode=QB.25 List of United Nations Functional Commissions and Expert Bodies related to climate change] *[[IRIN]], the humanitarian news and analysis service of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs: [http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=79563 ""What climate change does""], [http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=79508 ""How climate change works""], and [http://www.irinnews.org/IndepthMain.aspx?IndepthId=73&ReportId=78246 ""Gathering Storm - the humanitarian impact of climate change""] *Videos: **[http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=4119472365452589212 ""Educational Forum: Arctic Climate Impact""]. Panel discussion with James J. McCarthy, Professor at Harvard University, and Author; Paul R. Epstein, M.D., instructor in medicine at Harvard Medical School; and Ross Gelbspan, Pulitzer-prize winning journalist and author. Massachusetts School of Law. **[http://climateprogress.org/2010/02/05/videos-humans-are-changing-the-climate-global-warming-threat-chris-field/#more-18551 ""How we know humans are changing the climate and Why climate change is a clear and present danger""]. Interviews with Christopher Field and Michael MacCracken. Christopher Field is the director of the Department of Global Ecology at the Carnegie Institution of Washington, professor of biology and environmental earth system science at Stanford University, and the Working Group II Co-Chair for the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Michael MacCracken is the chief scientist for Climate Change Programs at the Climate Institute and a co-author and contributing author for various chapters in the IPCC assessment reports. Climate Progress website, February 5, 2010. {{Global warming}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Effects Of Global Warming}} [[Category:Effects of global warming

column2: This article is primarily about effects during the 21st century. For longer-term effects, see [[Long-term effects of global warming]].}} {{Pp-semi-protected
column3: small=yes}} [[File:Effects of global warming, plotted against changes in global mean temperature.png
column6: alt=Refer to caption and image description
column7: Summary of climate change impacts.]] The '''effects of [[global warming]]''' are the environmental and social changes caused (directly or indirectly) by human emissions of [[greenhouse gas]]es. There is a [[scientific opinion on climate change
column8: scientific consensus]] that climate change is occurring, and that human activities are the primary driver.<ref> {{citation
column9: author=Joint-statement by leaders of 18 scientific organizations: American Association for the Advancement of Science, American Chemical Society, American Geophysical Union, American Institute of Biological Sciences, American Meteorological Society, American Society of Agronomy, American Society of Plant Biologists, American Statistical Association, Association of Ecosystem Research Centers, Botanical Society of America, Crop Science Society of America, Ecological Society of America, Natural Science Collections, Alliance Organization of Biological Field Stations, Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, [[Society of Systematic Biologists]], Soil Science Society of America, University Corporation for Atmospheric Research
column11: title=Joint-statement on climate change by leaders of 18 scientific organizations
column14: publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science
column15: location=Washington DC, USA }} </ref> Evidence of [[climate change]] includes the instrumental temperature record, rising [[Current sea level rise
column16: sea levels]], and decreased snow cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]].<ref name=""direct observations of recent climate change""> {{citation
column20: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-direct-observations.html Direct Observations of Recent Climate Change] }}, in {{harvnb
column22: 2007}}. </ref> According to the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC), most of the observed increase in global average temperatures since the mid-20th century is very likely due to the observed increase in human [[greenhouse gas]] concentrations.<ref> {{citation
column26: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-understanding-and.html Understanding and Attributing Climate Change] }}, in {{harvnb
column28: 2007}}. </ref> Projections of future climate change suggest further global warming, [[current sea level rise
column29: sea level rise]], and an increase in the frequency and severity of some [[extreme weather
column34: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains6-2.html Sec. 6.2 Drivers and projections of future climate changes and their impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column36: 2007}}. </ref> Parties to the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] (UNFCCC) have agreed to ""stabilize greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent [[Avoiding dangerous climate change
column37: dangerous anthropogenic interference]] with the climate system.""<ref> {{citation
column39: work = The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
column42: attribution of recent climate change}} In this article, ""[[climate change]]"" means a change in climate that persists over a sustained period of time.<ref name=""ipcc definition of climate change""> {{citation
column50: at=Click on the image to open a pop-up that explains the differences between climate change and global warming.
column53: publisher=US EPA }} </ref> The [[World Meteorological Organization]] defines this time period as 30 years.<ref name=""ipcc definition of climate change""/> Examples of climate change include increases in global surface temperature (global warming), changes in [[rainfall]] patterns, and changes in the frequency of [[extreme weather]] events. Changes in climate may be due to natural causes, e.g., changes in the [[sun]]'s output, or due to human activities, e.g., changing the composition of the atmosphere.<ref name=""albritton climate change""/> Any human-induced changes in climate will occur against the ""background"" of natural climatic variations.<ref name=""albritton climate change""> {{citation
column57: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/011.htm Box 1: What drives changes in climate?] }}, in {{harvnb
column59: 2001}} </ref> Also, the term ""anthropogenic forcing"" refers to the influence exerted on a habitat or chemical environment by humans, as opposed to a natural process.<ref> {{cite web
column61: title=Definition of Anthropogenic Forcing – Chemistry Dictionary and Glossary }} </ref> ==Temperature changes== {{Multiple image
column65: alt1=The NASA instrumental temperature record shows a long-term trend of global warming between 1880 and 2009
column66: image2= Projected global warming over the 21st century using three SRES greenhouse gas emissions scenarios. Data from CMIP3 (2007).png
column69: caption1=Global mean surface temperature difference from the average for 1880–2009.
column70: caption2=The graph above shows the average of a set of temperature simulations for the 20th century (black line), followed by projected temperatures for the 21st century based on three greenhouse gas emissions scenarios (colored lines).<ref name=""herring temperature projections""> {{cite web
column75: url= http://www.climatewatch.noaa.gov/article/2012/global-temperature-projections }} </ref> }} This article breaks down some of the impacts of climate change according to different levels of future global warming. This way of describing impacts has, for instance, been used in the IPCC's Assessment Reports on climate change.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""> {{citation
column77: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column79: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-1.html Sec. 19.3.1 Introduction to Table 19.1] }}, in {{harvnb
column81: 2007}}. </ref> The instrumental [[temperature record]] shows global warming of around 0.6 °C over the entire 20th century.<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""/> ===SRES emissions scenarios=== The future level of global warming is uncertain, but a wide range of estimates (projections) have been made.<ref name=""Overview of GHG emissions scenarios""> {{citation
column83: chapter= Chapter 3: Issues related to mitigation in the long-term context
column87: 2007}} </ref> The IPCC's ""[[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column88: SRES]]"" scenarios have been frequently used to make [[Global climate model#Projections of future climate change
column89: projections of future climate change]].<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column91: date=November 2012}} The SRES scenarios are ""[[Economics of climate change mitigation#Baselines
column92: baseline]]"" (or ""reference"") scenarios, which means that they do not take into account any current or future measures to limit GHG emissions (e.g., the UNFCCC's [[Kyoto Protocol]] and the [[2010 United Nations Climate Change Conference
column95: chapter= Chapter 2, Greenhouse Gas Emission Mitigation Scenarios and Implications
column97: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/080.htm Sec. 2.5.1.1 IPCC Emissions Scenarios and the SRES Process] }}, in {{harvnb
column99: 2001}}. </ref> Emissions projections of the SRES scenarios are broadly comparable in range to the baseline emissions scenarios that have been developed by the scientific community.<ref name=""Overview of GHG emissions scenarios""/><ref> {{citation
column105: 2007}}. </ref> In the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]], changes in future global mean temperature were projected using the six SRES ""marker"" emissions scenarios.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""> {{citation
column109: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html#table-spm-1 Sec. 1 3. Projected climate change and its impacts: Table SPM.1] }}, in {{harvnb
column111: 2007}}. </ref> Emissions projections for the six SRES ""marker"" scenarios are representative of the full set of forty SRES scenarios.<ref> {{citation
column113: chapter= Chapter 2, Greenhouse Gas Emission Mitigation Scenarios and Implications
column115: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/081.htm#2514 Sec. 2.5.1.4 Emissions and Other Results of the SRES Scenarios] }}, in {{harvnb
column117: 2001}}. </ref> For the lowest emissions SRES marker scenario (""B1"" - see the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column118: SRES]] article for details on this scenario), the best estimate for global mean temperature is an increase of {{convert
column122: 1}}<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> by the end of the 21st century. This projection is relative to global temperatures at the end of the 20th century.<ref>Temperature change in years 2090-2099 relative to years 1980-1999</ref> The ""likely"" range (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> for the SRES B1 marker scenario is {{convert
column128: 1}}.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> For the highest emissions SRES marker scenario (A1FI), the best estimate for global mean temperature increase is {{convert
column138: 1}}.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> The range in temperature projections partly reflects (1) the choice of [[economics of global warming#Emissions scenarios
column139: emissions scenario]], and (2) the ""[[climate sensitivity]]"".<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column141: date=November 2012}} For (1), different scenarios make different assumptions of future social and economic development (e.g., [[economic growth]], [[population projection
column143: energy policies]]), which in turn affects projections of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column145: date=November 2012}} The projected magnitude of warming by 2100 is closely related to the level of cumulative emissions over the 21st century (i.e. total emissions between 2000-2100).<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions""> {{citation
column148: chapter=Ch 2: Which emissions pathways are consistent with a {{val
column152: u=°C}} temperature limit?: Sec 2.2 What determines long-term temperature?
column153: title=The Emissions Gap Report: Are the Copenhagen Accord pledges sufficient to limit global warming to {{val
column160: publisher=UNEP }}, p.28. This publication is also available in [http://www.unep.org/publications/ebooks/emissionsgapreport/ e-book format] </ref> The higher the cumulative emissions over this time period, the greater the level of warming is projected to occur.<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions""/> (2) reflects uncertainty in the response of the climate system to past and future GHG emissions, which is measured by the [[climate sensitivity]]).<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column162: date=November 2012}} Higher estimates of climate sensitivity lead to greater projected warming, while lower estimates of climate sensitivity lead to less projected warming.<ref> {{citation
column163: chapter=Box 8.1 Likelihood of exceeding a temperature increase at equilibrium, in: Ch 8: The Challenge of Stabilisation
column167: p=195}} </ref> Over the next several millennia, projections suggest that global warming could be irreversible.<ref name=""solomon irreversible climate change""/> Even if emissions were drastically reduced, global temperatures would remain close to their highest level for at least 1,000 years (see the later section on [[effects of global warming#Irreversibilities
column174: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-7-2.html Sec 10.7.2 Climate Change Commitment to Year 3000 and Beyond to Equilibrium]
column184: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column185: Two millennia of mean surface temperatures according to different reconstructions from [[Proxy (climate)
column186: climate proxies]], each smoothed on a decadal scale, with the [[instrumental temperature record]] overlaid in black.]]
column187: [[File:Global temperature relative to peak Holocene temperature, based on ocean cores (NASA).png
column191: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column192: Global surface temperature for the past 5.3 million years as inferred from cores of ocean [[sediment]]s taken all around the global ocean. The last 800,000 years are expanded in the lower half of the figure (image credit: [[NASA]]).<ref name=""hansen climate history""/>]]
column193: } Scientists have used various ""proxy"" data to assess past changes in Earth's climate ([[paleoclimate]]).<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""> {{citation
column195: title=NOAA Paleoclimatology Global Warming - The Story: Proxy Data
column198: publisher=NOAA Paleoclimatology Program - NCDC Paleoclimatology Branch }} </ref> Sources of proxy data include historical records (such as [[farmer]]s' logs), [[tree ring]]s, [[coral]]s, [[fossil pollen]], [[ice core]]s, and ocean and lake [[sediment]]s.<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""/> Analysis of these data suggest that recent warming is unusual in the past 400 years, possibly longer.<ref> {{citation
column201: title=Surface Temperature Reconstructions for the Last 2,000 Years
column204: author=Committee on Surface Temperature Reconstructions for the Last 2,000 Years, US National Research Council
column206: isbn=0-309-66144-7 }}, p.3 </ref> By the end of the 21st century, temperatures may increase to a level not experienced since the mid-[[Pliocene]], around 3 million years ago.<ref name=""jansen pliocene""> {{citation
column210: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch6s6-3-2.html Sec. 6.3.2 What Does the Record of the Mid-Pliocene Show?] }}, in {{harvnb
column212: 2007}}. </ref> At that time, models suggest that mean global temperatures were about 2–3 °C warmer than pre-industrial temperatures.<ref name=""jansen pliocene""/> Even a 2 °C rise above the pre-industrial level would be outside the range of temperatures experienced by human [[civilization]].<ref name=""hansen climate history""> {{citation
column215: title=NASA GISS: Science Briefs: Earth's Climate History: Implications for Tomorrow
column217: location=New York City, New York, USA
column219: at=[http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/686.htm Footnote 4, in Sec 19.8.2. What does Each Reason for Concern Indicate?]
column220: chapter=Ch 19. Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column227: [[File:Diagram showing ten indicators of global warming.png
column231: alt=Refer to caption and adjacent text
column232: Seven of these indicators would be expected to increase in a warming world and observations show that they are, in fact, increasing. Three would be expected to decrease and they are, in fact, decreasing.<ref> {{harvnb
column236: } [[File:Changes in climate indicators that show global warming.png
column241: This set of graphs show changes in climate indicators over several decades. Each of the different colored lines in each panel represents an independently analyzed set of data. The data come from many different technologies including [[weather station]]s, [[satellite]]s, [[weather balloons]], [[ship]]s and [[buoy]]s.<ref> {{harvnb
column244: p=3}} </ref>]] A broad range of evidence shows that the climate system has warmed.<ref> {{citation
column248: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-3-4.html TS.3.4 Consistency Among Observations] }}, in {{harvnb
column250: 2007}}. </ref> Evidence of global warming is shown in the graphs opposite. Some of the graphs show a positive [[trend estimation
column251: trend]], e.g., increasing temperature over land and the ocean, and [[current sea level rise
column252: sea level rise]]. Other graphs show a negative trend, e.g., decreased [[snow]] cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]], and declining [[Arctic sea ice]] extent. Evidence of warming is also apparent in living [[Effects of global warming#Observed impacts on biological systems
column253: (biological) systems]].<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> Human activities have contributed to a number of the observed changes in climate.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""> {{citation
column255: chapter= Chapter 9: Understanding and Attributing Climate Change
column259: 2007}}. </ref> This contribution has principally been through the burning of [[fossil fuel]]s, which has led to an increase in the concentration of GHGs in the atmosphere.<ref> {{citation
column263: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-human-and.html Human and Natural Drivers of Climate Change ] }}, in {{harvnb
column265: 2007}}. </ref> Another human influence on the climate are [[sulfur dioxide]] emissions, which are a precursor to the formation of [[sulfate aerosols]] in the atmosphere.<ref> {{cite book
column267: author=Committee on the Science of Climate Change, US National Research Council
column269: title=Climate Change Science: An Analysis of Some Key Questions
column274: isbn=0-309-07574-2 }} </ref> Human-induced warming could lead to [[Effects of global warming#Abrupt or irreversible changes
column275: large-scale, irreversible, and/or abrupt changes]] in physical systems.<ref> {{citation
column279: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html Sec. 3. Projected climate change and its impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column282: title=ESRL News: New Study Shows Climate Change Largely Irreversible
column285: publisher=US Department of Commerce, NOAA, Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL)
column286: date=26 January 2009 }}</ref> An example of this is the melting of [[ice sheet]]s, which contributes to sea level rise.<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> The probability of warming having unforeseen consequences increases with the rate, magnitude, and duration of climate change.<ref> {{cite book
column291: publisher=[[United States National Academy of Sciences]]
column293: date=December 2012}}</ref> ===Radiative forcing=== The effect of human activities on the climate system can be measured by [[radiative forcing]].<ref> {{cite web
column297: publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) News Office
column298: url=http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2010/explained-radforce-0309.html }}</ref> A positive radiative forcing will tend to warm the climate, while a negative forcing will tend to cool the climate.<ref name=""forster radiative forcing""> {{citation
column300: chapter= Chapter 2: Changes in Atmospheric Constituents and in Radiative Forcing
column302: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-2-1.html FAQ 2.1, Box 1: What is Radiative Forcing?] }}, in {{harvnb
column304: 2007}}. </ref> Anthopogenic forcing (i.e. the radiative forcing due to human activities) was estimated to have been positive (i.e. an overall warming effect) in the year 2005.<ref name=""forster radiative forcing""/> This is relative to the estimated forcings at the start of the industrial era, taken as the year 1750. Anthropogenic forcing of the climate has likely contributed to a number of observed changes, including sea level rise, changes in climate [[extreme weather event
column305: extremes]] (such as warm and cold days), declines in [[Arctic sea ice]] extent, and to [[Retreat of glaciers since 1850
column306: glacier retreat]].<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> === Effects on weather === Observations show that there have been changes in weather.<ref> {{citation
column308: chapter= Chapter 1: Historical Overview of Climate Change Science
column310: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-1-2.html FAQ 1.2 What is the Relationship between Climate Change and Weather?] }}, in {{harvnb
column312: 2007}}. </ref> As climate changes, the [[probabilities]] of certain types of weather events are affected. [[File:Projected change in annual average precipitation for the 21st century, based on the SRES A1B emissions scenario, and simulated by the GFDL CM2.1 model.png
column316: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column317: Projected change in annual average precipitation by the end of the 21st century, based on a medium emissions scenario ([[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column318: SRES]] A1B) (Credit: NOAA [[Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory]]).<ref> {{citation
column322: title= GFDL Climate Modeling Research Highlights: Will the Wet Get Wetter and the Dry Drier
column327: title=Will the wet get wetter and the dry drier?
column331: publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory (GFDL)
column332: location=Princeton, NJ, USA }}. Revision 10/15/2008, 4:47:16 PM. </ref>]] Changes have been observed in the amount, intensity, frequency, and type of [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column340: date=November 2012}} Widespread increases in heavy precipitation have occurred, even in places where total rain amounts have decreased. With medium confidence (see [[Effects of global warming#Footnotes
column346: p=8}} </ref> concluded that human influences had contributed to an increase in heavy precipitation events at the global scale. Projections of future changes in precipitation show overall increases in the global average, but with substantial shifts in where and how precipitation falls.<ref name = ""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column348: date=November 2012}} Projections suggest a reduction in rainfall in the [[subtropics]], and an increase in precipitation in subpolar latitudes and some [[equatorial region]]s.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> In other words, regions which are dry at present will in general become even drier, while regions that are currently wet will in general become even wetter.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> This projection does not apply to every locale, and in some cases can be modified by local conditions.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> ==== Extreme weather ==== {{See also
column350: Tropical cyclone#Global warming}} Over most land areas since the 1950s, it is very likely that there have been fewer and/or warmer cold days and nights.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""> IPCC (2013), Table SPM.1, in [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf Summary for Policymakers, p.5] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140226155600/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column352: 2013}} </ref> Hot days and nights have also very likely become warmer and/or more frequent.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Human activities have very likely contributed to these trends.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> There may have been changes in other climate extremes (e.g., [[flood]]s, [[drought]]s and [[tropical cyclone]]s) but these changes are more difficult to identify.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Projections suggest changes in the frequency and intensity of some extreme weather events.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Confidence in projections varies over time.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> ; Near-term projections (2016-2035) Some changes (e.g., more frequent hot days) will probably be evident in the near-term, while other near-term changes (e.g., more intense droughts and tropical cyclones) are more uncertain.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> ; Long-term projections (2081-2100) Future climate change will be associated with more very hot days and fewer very cold days.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> The frequency, length and intensity of [[heat wave]]s will very likely increase over most land areas.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Higher growth in anthropogenic GHG emissions will be associated with larger increases in the frequency and severity of temperature extremes.<ref> Stocker, T.F., ''et al.'' (2013), Temperature Extremes, Heat Waves and Warm Spells, in: TFE.9, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf Technical Summary, p.111] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221070705/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column354: 2013}} </ref> Assuming high growth in GHG emissions (IPCC scenario [[Representative Concentration Pathways
column355: RCP8.5]]), presently dry regions may be affected by an increase in the risk of drought and reductions in [[soil moisture]].<ref> Stocker, T.F., ''et al.'' (2013), Floods and Droughts, in: TFE.9, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf Technical Summary, p.112] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221070705/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column357: 2013}} </ref> Over most of the mid-latitude land masses and wet tropical regions, extreme precipitation events will very likely become more intense and frequent.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> ; Tropical cyclones At the global scale, the frequency of tropical cyclones will probably decrease or be unchanged.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""> Christensen, J.H.,''et al.'' (2013), Cyclones, in: Executive Summary, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf Chapter 14: Climate Phenomena and their Relevance for Future Regional Climate Change, p.1220] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221075046/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column359: 2013}} </ref> Global mean tropical cyclone maximum wind speed and precipitation rates will likely increase.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""/> Changes in tropical cyclones will probably vary by region, but these variations are uncertain.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""/> ; Effects of climate extremes The impacts of extreme events on the environment and human society will vary. Some impacts will be beneficial—e.g., fewer cold extremes will probably lead to fewer cold deaths.<ref name=""health summary""/> Overall, however, impacts will probably be mostly negative.<ref> {{citation
column367: chapter= Synthesis Report, Topic 5: The long-term perspective
column369: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains5-2.html Sec. 5.2 Key vulnerabilities, impacts and risks – long-term perspectives] }}, pp.64–65, in {{harvnb
column372: Retreat of glaciers since 1850}} [[File:Glacier Mass Balance Map.png
column376: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column377: A map of the change in thickness of mountain glaciers since 1970. Thinning in orange and red, thickening in blue.]] [[File:SeaIce-Sept162012 HR.jpg
column382: A map that shows ice concentration on 16 September 2012, along with the extent of the previous record low (yellow line) and the mid-September median extent (black line) setting a new record low that was 18 percent smaller than the previous record and nearly 50 percent smaller than the long-term (1979-2000) average.]] The [[cryosphere]] is made up of areas of the Earth which are covered by snow or ice.<ref> [http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/glossary.html#C ""Cryosphere""], in {{harvnb
column384: 2012}} </ref> Observed changes in the cryosphere include declines in [[Arctic sea ice]] extent,<ref> {{citation
column389: title=Mass Balance of Mountain Glaciers in 2011
column392: 2012}} </ref> and reduced snow cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]].<ref> {{citation
column393: title=2011 Snow Cover in Northern Hemisphere
column396: 2012}} </ref> Solomon ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""ar4 arctic sea ice""> {{citation
column400: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-5-2.html TS.5.2 Large-Scale Projections for the 21st Century] }}, in {{harvnb
column402: 2007}} </ref> assessed the potential impacts of climate change on [[summer]]time Arctic sea ice extent. Assuming high growth in greenhouse gas emissions ([[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column403: SRES A2]]), some models projected that Arctic sea ice in the summer could largely disappear by the end of the 21st century.<ref name=""ar4 arctic sea ice""/> More recent projections suggest that the Arctic summers could be ice-free (defined as ice extent less than 1 million square km) as early as 2025-2030.<ref> {{citation
column412: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-4.html Box 10.1: Future Abrupt Climate Change, ‘Climate Surprises’, and Irreversible Changes: Glaciers and ice caps] }}, in {{harvnb
column415: p=776}} </ref> and snow cover are projected to continue their widespread retreat.<ref> {{citation
column419: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-3-2.html Sec 10.3.3.2 Changes in Snow Cover and Frozen Ground] }}, in {{harvnb
column422: pp=770, 772}} </ref> In the western mountains of [[North America]], increasing temperatures and changes in precipitation are projected to lead to reduced [[snowpack]].<ref> {{citation
column426: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch14s14-4.html#14-4-1 Sec 14.4.1 Freshwater resources: Surface water] }}, in {{harvnb
column429: p=627}} </ref> Snowpack is the seasonal accumulation of slow-melting snow.<ref> [http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/glossary.html#S ""Snowpack""], in {{harvnb
column431: 2012}} </ref> The melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column432: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s could contribute to sea level rise, especially over long time-scales (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets
column433: Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets]]).<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> Changes in the cryosphere are projected to have social impacts.<ref> Some of these impacts are included in table SPM.2: {{citation
column434: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html#spm2 3 Projected climate change and its impacts: Table SPM.2]
column439: pp=11–12}} </ref> For example, in some regions, glacier retreat could increase the risk of reductions in seasonal water availability.<ref> {{citation
column441: chapter=Ch 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column448: title=Potential impacts of a warming climate on water availability in snow-dominated regions: Abstract
column455: pmid=16292301}} </ref> estimated that more than one-sixth of the [[world's population]] rely on glaciers and snowpack for their water supply. ===Oceans=== The role of the oceans in global warming is complex. The oceans serve as a sink for carbon dioxide, taking up much that would otherwise remain in the atmosphere, but increased levels of {{chem
column457: 2}} have led to [[ocean acidification]]. Furthermore, as the temperature of the oceans increases, they become less able to absorb excess {{chem
column459: 2}}. The ocean have also acted as a sink in absorbing extra heat from the atmosphere.<ref name=statecl> {{cite book
column461: publisher = Website of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration: National Climatic Data Center
column462: title = State of the Climate in 2009, as appearing in the July 2010 issue (Vol. 91) of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society (BAMS). Supplemental and Summary Materials: Report at a Glance: Highlights
column466: date=November 2012}} The increase in ocean [[heat content]] is much larger than any other store of [[energy]] in the Earth’s heat balance over the two periods 1961 to 2003 and 1993 to 2003, and accounts for more than 90% of the possible increase in heat content of the Earth system during these periods.<ref> {{citation
column467: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch5s5-2-2-3.html Sec 5.2.2.3 Implications for Earth’s Heat Balance]
column468: chapter=Ch. 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column473: title=Climate Graphics by Skeptical Science: Global Warming Components:
column474: at=Components of global warming for the period 1993 to 2003 calculated from IPCC AR4 5.2.2.3
column476: publisher=Skeptical Science }} </ref> Global warming is projected to have a number of effects on the oceans. Ongoing effects include rising sea levels due to thermal expansion and melting of glaciers and ice sheets, and warming of the ocean surface, leading to increased temperature stratification. Other possible effects include large-scale changes in ocean circulation. ====Acidification==== {{Main
column477: Ocean acidification}} [[File:Changes in aragonite saturation of the world's oceans, 1880-2012 (US EPA).png
column481: alt=refer to caption and image description
column482: This map shows changes in the amount of [[aragonite]] dissolved in [[ocean]] surface waters between the 1880s and the most recent decade (2003-2012).<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/> Historical modeling suggests that since the 1880s, increased {{CO2}} has led to lower [[aragonite]] saturation levels (less availability of minerals) in the oceans around the world.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""> {{Include-USGov
column485: title=Climate Change Indicators in the United States, 2012, 2nd ed: Ocean Acidity: Figure 2. Changes in Aragonite Saturation of the World's Oceans, 1880-2012
column487: url=http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/science/indicators/oceans/acidity.html#fragment-2 }} }} </ref> The largest decreases in aragonite saturation have occurred in [[tropical]] waters.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/> However, decreases in cold areas may be of greater concern because colder waters typically have lower aragonite levels to begin with.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/>]] About one-third of the carbon dioxide emitted by human activity has already been taken up by the oceans.<ref name=""nrc 2008b ocean acidification""> {{cite book
column489: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column493: 2008b}} </ref> As carbon dioxide dissolves in [[sea water]], [[carbonic acid]] is formed, which has the effect of acidifying the ocean, measured as a change in [[pH]]. The uptake of human carbon emissions since the year 1750 has led to an average decrease in pH of 0.1 units.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 ocean acidification""> {{citation
column499: 2007}}. </ref> Projections using the SRES emissions scenarios suggest a further reduction in average global surface ocean pH of between 0.14 and 0.35 units over the 21st century. The effects of ocean acidification on the marine [[biosphere]] have yet to be documented.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 ocean acidification""/> Laboratory experiments suggest beneficial effects for a few species, with potentially highly detrimental effects for a substantial number of species.<ref name=""nrc 2008b ocean acidification""/> With medium confidence, Fischlin ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column501: chapter = Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods, and services
column505: 2007}}. </ref> projected that future ocean acidification and climate change would impair a wide range of [[plankton]]ic and shallow [[benthos
column506: benthic]] marine organisms that use [[aragonite]] to make their shells or skeletons, such as [[coral]]s and marine [[snail]]s ([[pteropoda
column507: pteropods]]), with significant impacts particularly in the Southern Ocean. ====Oxygen depletion==== The amount of oxygen dissolved in the oceans may decline, with adverse consequences for ocean life.<ref>{{cite doi
column510: Current sea level rise}} [[File:Trends in global average absolute sea level, 1870-2008 (US EPA).png
column514: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column515: Trends in global average absolute sea level, 1870-2008.<ref> {{cite web
column517: title= Sea Level: Climate Change: US EPA
column520: year=2010 }} </ref>]] There is strong evidence that global sea level rose gradually over the 20th century.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""> {{citation
column522: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column524: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-5-1.html FAQ 5.1 Is Sea Level Rising?] }}, in {{harvnb
column528: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column532: 2007}}. </ref> concluded that between the mid-19th and mid-20th centuries, the rate of sea level rise increased. Authors of the IPCC Fourth Assessment Synthesis Report (IPCC AR4 SYR, 2007)<ref name= ""Observed changes in climate and their effects""> {{citation
column536: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms1.html Sec. 1. Observed changes in climate and their effects] }}, p. 5, in {{harvnb
column538: 2007}}. </ref> reported that between the years 1961 and 2003, global average sea level rose at an average rate of 1.8 mm per year (mm/yr), with a range of 1.3–2.3 mm/yr. Between 1993 and 2003, the rate increased above the previous period to 3.1 mm/yr (range of 2.4–3.8 mm/yr). Authors of IPCC AR4 SYR (2007)<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""/> were uncertain whether the increase in rate from 1993 to 2003 was due to [[climate change#Internal forcing mechanisms
column539: natural variations]] in sea level over the time period, or whether it reflected an increase in the underlying long-term trend. There are two main factors that have contributed to observed sea level rise.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""/> The first is [[thermal expansion]]: as ocean water warms, it expands.<ref> {{citation
column543: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/013.htm#b4 Box 2: What causes sea level to change?] }}, in {{harvnb
column545: 2007}}. </ref> The second is from the contribution of land-based ice due to increased melting. The major store of water on land is found in glaciers and ice sheets. Anthropogenic forcing very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""> {{citation
column549: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-2.html Box TS.1: Treatment of Uncertainties in the Working Group I Assessment] }}, in {{harvnb
column551: 2007}}. </ref> contributed to sea level rise during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> [[File:Global Sea Level Rise Risks.png
column553: This is a topographic map designed to emphasize regions near sea level that could potentially be vulnerable to sea level rise.This map is based on the SRTM30 PLUS digital elevation model. Like all space based elevation models, SRTM30 contains errors of several meters, especially in areas of complex terrain (Rodriguez et al. 2006). Hence, while broad qualitative features should be relatively reliable, one should not rely upon data such as these for small scale or precise details unless they have been confirmed by ground based observations.<ref>http://www.globalwarmingart.com/wiki/File:Global_Sea_Level_Rise_Risks_png</ref>]] There is a widespread consensus that substantial long-term sea level rise will continue for centuries to come.<ref> {{citation
column554: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column558: p=245}}. </ref> In their Fourth Assessment Report, the IPCC<ref> {{citation
column560: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column564: 2007}}. </ref> projected sea level rise to the end of the 21st century using the SRES emissions scenarios. Across the six SRES marker scenarios, sea level was projected to rise by 18 to 59 cm (7.1 to 23.2 in), relative to sea level at the end of the 20th century.<ref>change in sea level by 2090–99, relative to 1980–99</ref> Thermal expansion is the largest component in these projections, contributing 70-75% of the central estimate for all scenarios.<ref> {{citation
column570: 2007}}. </ref> Due to a lack of scientific understanding, this sea level rise estimate does not include all of the possible contributions of ice sheets (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets
column571: Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets]]). An assessment of the [[scientific literature]] on climate change was published in 2010 by the [[US National Research Council]] (US NRC, 2010).<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""> {{citation
column573: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column576: 2010}}. </ref> NRC (2010)<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> described the projections in AR4 (i.e. those cited in the above paragraph) as ""conservative"", and summarized the results of more recent studies. Cited studies suggested a great deal of uncertainty in projections.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> A range of projections suggested possible sea level rise by the end of the 21st century of between 0.56 and 2 m, relative to sea levels at the end of the 20th century.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> ====Ocean temperature rise==== [[File:Heat content700m2000myr.png
column581: Global ocean heat content from 1955-2012]] From 1961 to 2003, the global ocean temperature has risen by 0.10 °C from the surface to a depth of 700 m. There is variability both year-to-year and over longer time scales, with global ocean heat content observations showing high rates of warming for 1991–2003, but some cooling from 2003 to 2007.<ref> {{citation
column583: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column588: date=November 2012}} </ref> The temperature of the Antarctic [[Southern Ocean]] rose by 0.17 °C (0.31 °F) between the 1950s and the 1980s, nearly twice the rate for the world's oceans as a whole.<ref> {{cite journal
column592: title= Warming of the Southern Ocean Since the 1950s
column602: ref=harv }}</ref> As well as having effects on ecosystems (e.g. by melting sea ice, affecting algae that grow on its underside), warming reduces the ocean's ability to absorb {{chem
column605: date=June 2008}} It is likely (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> that anthropogenic forcing contributed to the general warming observed in the upper several hundred metres of the ocean during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> ==Regions== {{Main
column606: Regional effects of global warming}} {{Multiple image
column609: image1=Temperatures across the world in the 1880s (left) and the 1980s (right), as compared to average temperatures from 1951 to 1980 (US EPA).jpg
column610: alt1=Temperatures in most parts of the world were warmer in the 1980s compared to the 1880s
column611: image2= Map of projected global warming across the globe by the 2050s. Projections based on three SRES greenhouse gas emissions scenarios. Data from CMIP3 (2007).jpg
column612: alt2=Future warming across the globe varies according to different projections of greenhouse gas emissions
column614: caption1=Temperatures across the world in the 1880s (left) and the 1980s (right), as compared to average temperatures from 1951 to 1980.<ref> {{cite web
column617: title=Science: Climate Change: US EPA (Climate Change Science Overview)
column620: caption2=Projected changes in average temperatures across the world in the 2050s under three greenhouse gas (GHG) [[Economics of global warming#Emissions scenarios
column621: emissions scenarios]].<ref name=""herring temperature projections""/> }} Regional effects of global warming vary in nature. Some are the result of a generalised global change, such as rising temperature, resulting in local effects, such as melting ice. In other cases, a change may be related to a change in a particular ocean current or weather system. In such cases, the regional effect may be disproportionate and will not necessarily follow the global trend. There are three major ways in which global warming will make changes to regional climate: melting or forming ice, changing the [[hydrological cycle]] (of [[evaporation]] and [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column623: currents in the oceans]] and air flows in the atmosphere. The coast can also be considered a region, and will suffer severe impacts from [[sea level rise]]. ===Observed impacts=== With very high confidence, Rosenzweig ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> concluded that physical and biological systems on all continents and in most oceans had been affected by recent climate changes, particularly regional temperature increases. Impacts include earlier leafing of [[tree]]s and [[plant]]s over many regions; movements of species to higher latitudes and altitudes in the Northern Hemisphere; changes in [[bird migration]]s in Europe, North America and Australia; and shifting of the oceans' [[plankton]] and [[fish]] from cold- to warm-adapted communities.<ref name=""nasa briefs""/> The human influence on the climate can be seen in the geographical pattern of observed warming, with greater temperature increases over land and in [[polar region]]s rather than over the oceans.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""> {{cite book
column625: title=Understanding and Responding to Climate Change. A brochure prepared by the US National Research Council (US NRC)
column626: publisher=[http://dels.nas.edu/basc Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate], National Academy of Sciences
column631: date=November 2012}} Using models, it is possible to identify the human ""signal"" of global warming over both land and ocean areas.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""/>{{Rp
column633: date=November 2012}} ===Projected impacts=== Projections of future climate changes at the regional scale do not hold as high a level of scientific confidence as projections made at the global scale.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""/>{{Rp
column635: date=November 2012}} It is, however, expected that future warming will follow a similar geographical pattern to that seen already, with greatest warming over land and high northern [[latitude]]s, and least over the [[Southern Ocean]] and parts of the [[North Atlantic Ocean]].<ref> {{citation
column639: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-projections-of.html Projections of Future Changes in Climate] }}, in {{harvnb
column641: 2007}}. </ref> Nearly all land areas will very likely warm more than the global average.<ref name=""tar table of robust findings""> {{citation
column648: megadeltas]] are regions that are likely to be especially affected by climate change.<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions""> {{citation
column652: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-3.html Sec. 3.3.3 Especially affected systems, sectors and regions] }}, in {{harvnb
column656: less-developed]] areas are at most risk of experiencing negative impacts due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts""> {{citation
column658: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column660: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Distribution of Impacts, in: Sec 19.3.7 Update on 'Reasons for Concern'] }}, in {{harvnb
column663: p=796}} </ref> [[Developed countries]] are also vulnerable to climate change.<ref name=""schneider regional vulnerabilities""> {{citation
column665: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column670: p=792}} </ref> For example, developed countries will be negatively affected by increases in the severity and frequency of some [[extreme weather]] events, such as [[heat wave]]s.<ref name=""schneider regional vulnerabilities""/> In all regions, some people can be particularly at risk from climate change, such as the [[poverty
column671: poor]], young [[children]] and the [[elderly]].<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions""/><ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts""/><ref> {{citation
column675: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-2-5.html Sec 7.4.2.5 Social issues and Sec 7.4.3 Key vulnerabilities] }}, in {{harvnb
column679: Effects of climate change on humans
column680: Climate change, industry and society}} {{See also
column681: climate change and gender}} The impacts of climate change can be thought of in terms of sensitivity and vulnerability. ""Sensitivity"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be affected, positively or negatively, by climate change and/or [[climate change#Causes
column682: climate variability]]. ""Vulnerability"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be adversely affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
