column687: 2007}}. </ref> The sensitivity of human society to climate change varies. Sectors sensitive to climate change include water resources, coastal zones, human settlements, and human health. Industries sensitive to climate change include [[climate change and agriculture
column694: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/008.htm#24 Sec. 2.4. Many Human Systems are Sensitive to Climate Change, and Some are Vulnerable] }}, in {{harvnb
column698: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column706: 2007–2008 world food price crisis}} Climate change will impact agriculture and food production around the world due to: the effects of elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere, higher temperatures, altered precipitation and [[transpiration]] regimes, increased frequency of extreme events, and modified [[weed]], [[pest (organism)
column709: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column711: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch5s5-4.html#5-4-1 5.4.1 Primary effects and interactions] }}, in {{harvnb
column714: p=282}}. </ref> In general, low-latitude areas are at most risk of having decreased crop yields.<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> So far, the effects of regional climate change on agriculture have been small.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""> {{citation
column716: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column720: 2007}}. </ref> Changes in crop [[phenology]] provide important evidence of the response to recent regional climate change.<ref> {{citation
column722: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column724: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-6-1.html Sec. 1.3.6.1 Crops and livestock] }}, in {{harvnb
column726: 2007}}. </ref> Phenology is the study of natural phenomena that recur periodically, and how these phenomena relate to climate and seasonal changes.<ref> {{citation
column731: 2007}}. </ref> A significant advance in phenology has been observed for agriculture and forestry in large parts of the Northern Hemisphere.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> ====Projections==== [[File:Projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming.png
column736: Projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""> [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12877&page=161 Figure 5.1], p.161, in: Sec 5.1 FOOD PRODUCTION, PRICES, AND HUNGER, in: Ch 5: Impacts in the Next Few Decades and Coming Centuries, in: {{harvnb
column738: 2011}} </ref>]] [[File:Projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming.png
column743: Projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""/>]] With low to medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> projected that for about a 1 to 3 °C increase in global mean temperature (by the years 2090-2100, relative to average temperatures in the years 1990–2000), there would be productivity decreases for some [[cereal]]s in low latitudes, and productivity increases in high latitudes. With medium confidence, global production potential was projected to:<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> * increase up to around 3 °C, * very likely decrease above about 3 °C. Most of the studies on global agriculture assessed by Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> had not incorporated a number of critical factors, including changes in extreme events, or the spread of pests and diseases. Studies had also not considered the development of specific practices or technologies to aid [[adaptation to global warming#Agricultural production
column744: adaptation to climate change]].<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""> {{citation
column746: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column751: p=790}}. </ref> The graphs opposite show the projected effects of climate change on selected crop yields.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 text""> Sec 5.1 FOOD PRODUCTION, PRICES, AND HUNGER, [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12877&page=160 pp.160-162], in: Ch 5: Impacts in the Next Few Decades and Coming Centuries, in {{harvnb
column753: 2011}} </ref> Actual changes in yields may be above or below these central estimates.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 text""/> The projections above can be expressed relative to pre-industrial (1750) temperatures.<ref> {{citation
column755: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column757: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-1.html Box 19.2. Reference for temperature levels] }}, in {{harvnb
column760: p=783}}. </ref> 0.6 °C of warming is estimated to have occurred between 1750 and 1990-2000. Add 0.6 °C to the above projections to convert them from a 1990-2000 to pre-industrial baseline. =====Food security===== Easterling ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column762: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column764: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch5s5-6-5.html Sec. 5.6.5 Food security and vulnerability] }}, in {{harvnb
column766: 2007}}. </ref> assessed studies that made quantitative projections of climate change impacts on [[food security]]. It was noted that these projections were highly uncertain and had limitations. However, the assessed studies suggested a number of fairly robust findings. The first was that climate change would likely increase the number of people at risk of [[hunger]] compared with reference scenarios with no climate change. Climate change impacts depended strongly on projected future social and economic development. Additionally, the magnitude of climate change impacts was projected to be smaller compared to the impact of social and economic development. In 2006, the global estimate for the number of people [[malnutrition
column772: accessdate=2011-07-07 }} </ref> Under the SRES A1, B1, and B2 scenarios (see the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios#Scenario families
column773: SRES article]] for information on each scenario group), projections for the year 2080 showed a reduction in the number of people undernourished of about 560-700 million people, with a global total of undernourished people of 100-240 million in 2080. By contrast, the SRES A2 scenario showed only a small decrease in the risk of hunger from 2006 levels. The smaller reduction under A2 was attributed to the higher projected future population level in this scenario. ====Droughts and agriculture==== Some evidence suggests that droughts have been occurring more frequently because of global warming and they are expected to become more frequent and intense in Africa, southern Europe, the Middle East, most of the Americas, Australia, and Southeast Asia.<ref>{{cite doi
column774: 10.1002/wcc.81}}</ref> However, other research suggests that there has been little change in drought over the past 60 years.<ref>{{cite doi
column775: 10.1038/nature11575}}</ref> Their impacts are aggravated because of increased water demand, population growth, urban expansion, and environmental protection efforts in many areas.<ref>{{cite doi
column776: 10.1016/j.jhydrol.2011.03.049}}</ref> Droughts result in crop failures and the loss of pasture grazing land for livestock.<ref>{{cite doi
column778: Effects of global warming on human health}} Human beings are exposed to climate change through changing weather patterns (temperature, precipitation, sea-level rise and more frequent extreme events) and indirectly through changes in water, air and food quality and changes in ecosystems, agriculture, industry and settlements and the economy (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007:393).<ref name=""health summary""> {{citation
column784: 2007}}. </ref> According to an assessment of the scientific literature by Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007:393),<ref name=""health summary""/> the effects of climate change to date have been small, but are projected to progressively increase in all countries and regions. A study by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO, 2009)<ref> {{cite book
column787: title= Global health risks: mortality and burden of disease attributable to selected major risks
column795: url= http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/global_health_risks/en/index.html }} </ref> estimated the effect of climate change on human health. Not all of the effects of climate change were included in their estimates, for example, the effects of more frequent and extreme storms were excluded. Climate change was estimated to have been responsible for 3% of [[diarrhoea]], 3% of [[malaria]], and 3.8% of [[dengue fever]] deaths worldwide in 2004. Total attributable mortality was about 0.2% of deaths in 2004; of these, 85% were child deaths. ====Projections==== With high confidence, authors of the IPCC AR4 Synthesis report<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report""/>{{Rp
column797: date=November 2012}} projected that climate change would bring some benefits in temperate areas, such as fewer deaths from cold exposure, and some mixed effects such as changes in range and transmission potential of [[malaria]] in [[Africa]]. Benefits were projected to be outweighed by negative health effects of rising temperatures, especially in developing countries. With very high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/>{{Rp
column799: date=November 2012}} concluded that economic development was an important component of possible adaptation to climate change. Economic growth on its own, however, was not judged to be sufficient to insulate the world's population from disease and injury due to climate change. Future vulnerability to climate change will depend not only on the extent of social and economic change, but also on how the benefits and costs of change are distributed in society.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""> {{citation
column803: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-3-2.html Sec. 8.3.2 Future vulnerability to climate change] }}, in {{harvnb
column805: 2007}}. </ref> For example, in the 19th century, rapid [[urbanization]] in [[western Europe]] lead to a plummeting in population health.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""/> Other factors important in determining the health of populations include [[education]], the availability of health services, and [[public health
column813: Precipitation during the 20th century and up through 2008 during global warming, the [[NOAA]] estimating an observed trend over that period of 1.87% global precipitation increase per century.]] A number of climate-related trends have been observed that affect [[water resources]]. These include changes in precipitation, the crysosphere and [[surface water]]s (e.g., changes in [[river flows]]).<ref> {{citation
column815: chapter = Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column819: 2007}}. </ref> Observed and projected impacts of climate change on [[freshwater]] systems and their management are mainly due to changes in temperature, sea level and precipitation variability.<ref name=""freshwater impacts""> {{citation
column821: chapter= Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column823: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch3s3-es.html Sec. 3.3 Executive summary] }}, p. 175, in {{harvnb
column825: 2007}}. </ref> Sea level rise will extend areas of [[salinization]] of [[groundwater]] and [[estuary
column826: estuaries]], resulting in a decrease in freshwater availability for humans and ecosystems in coastal areas. In an assessment of the [[scientific literature]], Kundzewicz ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""freshwater impacts""/> concluded, with high confidence, that: * the negative impacts of climate change on freshwater systems outweigh the benefits. All of the regions assessed in the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]] ([[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], [[Europe]], [[Latin America]], [[North America]], [[Polar region]]s ([[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]]), and small islands) showed an overall net negative impact of climate change on water resources and freshwater ecosystems. * [[semi-arid climate
column827: Semi-arid]] and [[arid]] areas are particularly exposed to the impacts of climate change on freshwater. With very high confidence, it was judged that many of these areas, e.g., the [[Mediterranean basin]], [[Western United States]], [[Southern Africa]], and north-eastern [[Brazil]], would suffer a decrease in water resources due to climate change. ===Migration and conflict=== {{See also
column829: General circulation models]] project that the future climate change will bring wetter coasts, drier mid-continent areas, and further sea level rise.<ref name=""sar migration""> {{citation
column831: chapter= Chapter 12: Human settlements in a changing climate: impacts and adaptation
column832: at= Sec. 12.3.1 Population Migration }}, pp. 406—407, in {{harvnb
column834: 1996}}. </ref> Such changes could result in the gravest effects of climate change through sudden [[human migration]]. Millions might be displaced by [[shoreline erosion]]s, river and coastal [[flood]]ing, or severe [[drought]]. Migration related to climate change is likely to be predominantly from [[rural area]]s in [[developing countries]] to towns and [[cities]].<ref name=""sar migration""/>{{Rp
column838: title = Managing social risks: Empower communities to protect themselves
column839: chapter = Part One: Chapter 2: Reducing Human Vulnerability: Helping People Help Themselves
column842: 2010}}. </ref> In the short term climate stress is likely to add incrementally to existing migration patterns rather than generating entirely new flows of people.<ref name=""wdr migration""/>{{Rp
column844: date=November 2012}} It has been argued that environmental degradation, loss of access to resources (e.g., water resources),<ref> {{citation
column850: 2001}}. </ref> and resulting human migration could become a source of political and even [[military conflict]].<ref name=""tar migration""> {{citation
column852: chapter= Chapter 7: Human Settlements, Energy, and Industry
column856: 2001}}. </ref> Factors other than climate change may, however, be more important in affecting conflict. For example, Wilbanks ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column858: chapter = Chapter 7: Industry, settlement and society
column860: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-1.html Sec. 7.4.1 General effects: Box 7.2. Environmental migration] }}, in {{harvnb
column862: 2007}}. </ref> suggested that major environmentally influenced conflicts in Africa were more to do with the relative abundance of resources, e.g., [[oil]] and [[diamond]]s, than with resource scarcity. Scott ''et al.'' (2001) placed only low confidence in predictions of increased conflict due to climate change.<ref name=""tar migration""/> A 2013 study found that significant climatic changes were associated with a higher risk of conflict worldwide, and predicted that ""amplified rates of human conflict could represent a large and critical social impact of anthropogenic climate change in both low- and high-income countries.""<ref>{{cite journal
column863: author=Hsiang SM, Burke M, Miguel E
column864: title=Quantifying the influence of climate on human conflict
column872: url=}}</ref> Similarly, a 2014 study found that higher temperatures were associated with a greater likelihood of violent crime, and predicted that global warming would cause millions of such crimes in the United States alone during the 21st century. <ref>{{cite doi
column873: 10.1016/j.jeem.2013.11.008}}</ref> Military planners are concerned that global warming is a ""threat multiplier"". ""Whether it is poverty, food and water scarcity, diseases, economic instability, or threat of natural disasters, the broad range of changing climatic conditions may be far reaching. These challenges may threaten stability in much of the world"".<ref>{{cite journal
column878: journal =Proceedings of the US Naval Institute
column885: Economic impacts of climate change}} [[Aggregate data
column886: Aggregating]] impacts adds up the total impact of climate change across sectors and/or regions.<ref> [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/annexessglossary-a-d.html Glossary A-D: ""Aggregate impacts""], in {{harvnb
column889: p=76}} </ref> Examples of aggregate measures include [[Economic impacts of climate change#Distribution of impacts
column890: economic cost]] (e.g., changes in [[gross domestic product]] (GDP) and the [[Economic impacts of climate change#Marginal impacts
column891: social cost of carbon]]), changes in ecosystems (e.g., changes over land area from one type of vegetation to another),<ref> {{citation
column893: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column895: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/677.htm Sec. 19.5.3 Insights and Lessons: Vulnerability over Time: Table 19-5] }}, in {{harvnb
column897: 2001}}. </ref> human health impacts, and the number of people affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
column899: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column901: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/676.htm Sec. 19.5.2. Insights and Lessons: The Static Picture] }}, in {{harvnb
column903: 2001}}. </ref> Aggregate measures such as economic cost require researchers to make [[value judgement]]s over the importance of impacts occurring in different regions and at different times. ====Observed impacts==== Global losses reveal rapidly rising costs due to extreme weather-related events since the 1970s.<ref> {{citation
column905: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of observed changes and responses in natural and managed systems
column907: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-8-5.html Sec. 1.3.8.5 Summary of disasters and hazards] }}, in {{harvnb
column910: Socio-economic]] factors have contributed to the observed trend of global losses, e.g., population growth, increased [[wealth]].<ref name=""disaster losses""> {{citation
column916: 2001}}. </ref> Part of the growth is also related to regional climatic factors, e.g., changes in precipitation and flooding events. It is difficult to quantify the relative impact of socio-economic factors and climate change on the observed trend.<ref name=""disaster losses""/> The trend does, however, suggest increasing vulnerability of social systems to climate change.<ref name=""disaster losses""/> ====Projected impacts==== The total economic impacts from climate change are highly uncertain.<ref> {{citation
column918: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column920: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-2-3.html Sec. 19.3.2.3 Aggregate market impacts] }}, p. 790, in {{harvnb
column922: 2007}}. </ref> With medium confidence, Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""> {{citation
column924: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column928: 2001}}. </ref> concluded that world GDP would change by plus or minus a few percent for a small increase in global mean temperature (up to around 2 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level). Most studies assessed by Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""/> projected losses in world GDP for a medium increase in global mean temperature (above 2-3 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level), with increasing losses for greater temperature increases. This assessment is consistent with the findings of more recent studies, as reviewed by Hitz and Smith (2004).<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""> {{citation
column930: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column932: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Sec. 19.3.7 Update on ‘Reasons for Concern’] }}, p. 796, in {{harvnb
column934: 2007}}. </ref> Economic impacts are expected to vary regionally.<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/><ref> {{citation
column936: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column938: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/675.htm Sec. 19.4.3. Distribution of Total Impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column940: 2001}}. </ref> For a medium increase in global mean temperature (2-3 °C of warming, relative to the average temperature between 1990–2000), market sectors in low-latitude and less-developed areas might experience net costs due to climate change.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> On the other hand, market sectors in high-latitude and developed regions might experience net benefits for this level of warming. A global mean temperature increase above about 2-3 °C (relative to 1990-2000) would very likely result in market sectors across all regions experiencing either declines in net benefits or rises in net costs.<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> Aggregate impacts have also been quantified in non-economic terms. For example, climate change over the 21st century is likely to adversely affect hundreds of millions of people through increased coastal flooding, reductions in water supplies, increased malnutrition and increased health impacts.<ref name=""ar4 synthesis reasons for concern""/> ==Biological systems== {{Main
column943: Effect of climate change on plant biodiversity
column944: Effects of climate change on terrestrial animals
column945: Effects of climate change on marine mammals}} ===Observed impacts on biological systems=== [[File:A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming (low-res).png
column949: A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming.<ref name=""nasa briefs""> {{cite web
column952: title=Science Briefs: Warming Climate is Changing Life on Global Scale
column953: publisher=Website of the US National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Goddard Institute for Space Studies
column955: accessdate=2011-07-08}} </ref>]] With very high confidence, Rosenzweig ''et al.'' (2007) concluded that recent warming had strongly affected natural biological systems.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> Hundreds of studies have documented responses of [[ecosystem]]s, [[plant]]s, and [[animal]]s to the climate changes that have already occurred.<ref> {{cite book
column957: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column962: page = 14 }} </ref> For example, in the Northern Hemisphere, species are almost uniformly moving their ranges northward and up in elevation in search of cooler temperatures.<ref name=""nrc 2008b observed ecosystem impacts""> {{cite book
column964: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column969: page = 16 }} </ref> Humans are very likely causing changes in regional temperatures to which plants and animals are responding.<ref name=""nrc 2008b observed ecosystem impacts""/> ===Projected impacts on biological systems=== By the year 2100, ecosystems will be exposed to atmospheric {{chem
column971: 2}} levels substantially higher than in the past 650,000 years, and global temperatures at least among the highest of those experienced in the past 740,000 years.<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""> {{citation
column973: chapter= Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column977: 2007}}. </ref> Significant disruptions of ecosystems are projected to increase with future climate change.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""> {{citation
column983: 2001}}. </ref> Examples of disruptions include disturbances such as fire, drought, pest [[infestation]], invasion of species, storms, and [[coral bleaching]] events. The stresses caused by climate change, added to other stresses on ecological systems (e.g., land conversion, [[land degradation]], [[harvest]]ing, and [[pollution]]), threaten substantial damage to or complete loss of some unique ecosystems, and [[extinction]] of some critically endangered species.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""/> Climate change has been estimated to be a major driver of [[biodiversity]] loss in cool [[conifer]] forests, [[savanna]]s, [[mediterranean climate
column984: mediterranean-climate]] systems, [[tropical forest]]s, in the [[Arctic tundra]], and in [[coral reef]]s.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""> {{citation
column986: chapter= Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column988: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch4s4-4-11.html Sec. 4.4.11 Global synthesis including impacts on biodiversity] }}, in {{harvnb
column991: land-use]] change may be a stronger driver of biodiversity loss at least in the near-term.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> Beyond the year 2050, climate change may be the major driver for biodiversity loss globally.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> A literature assessment by Fischlin ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""/> included a quantitative estimate of the number of the number of species at increased risk of extinction due to climate change. With medium confidence, it was projected that approximately 20 to 30% of plant and animal species assessed so far (in an unbiased [[Sampling (statistics)
column992: sample]]) would likely be at increasingly high risk of extinction should global mean temperatures exceed a warming of 2 to 3 °C above pre-industrial temperature levels.<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""/> The uncertainties in this estimate, however, are large: for a rise of about 2 °C the percentage may be as low as 10%, or for about 3 °C, as high as 40%, and depending on [[Biota (ecology)
column993: biota]] (all living [[organism]]s of an area, the [[flora]] and [[fauna]] considered as a unit)<ref> {{citation
column998: 2007}}. </ref> the range is between 1% and 80%.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> As global average temperature exceeds 4 °C above pre-industrial levels, model projections suggested that there could be significant extinctions (40-70% of species that were assessed) around the globe.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> Assessing whether future changes in ecosystems will be beneficial or detrimental is largely based on how ecosystems are valued by human society.<ref> {{citation
column1001: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column1005: 2008b}}. </ref> For increases in global average temperature exceeding 1.5 to 2.5 °C (relative to global temperatures over the years 1980-1999)<ref> {{citation
column1007: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column1009: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3.html Sec. 3.3 Impacts of future climate changes] }}, in {{harvnb
column1013: 2}} concentrations, projected changes in ecosystems will have predominantly negative consequences for biodiversity and ecosystems goods and [[ecosystem services
column1014: services]], e.g., water and food supply.<ref> {{citation
column1016: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column1018: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-1.html Sec. 3.3.1 Impacts on systems and sectors: Ecosystems] }}, in {{harvnb
column1020: 2007}}. </ref> ==Abrupt or irreversible changes== Physical, ecological and social systems may respond in an abrupt, [[non-linear]] or irregular way to climate change.<ref name=""singularities""> {{citation
column1022: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1024: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/679.htm Sec. 19.6.1. The Irregular Face of Climate Change] }}, in {{harvnb
column1026: 2001}}. </ref> This is as opposed to a smooth or regular response. A quantitative entity behaves ""irregularly"" when its [[system dynamics
column1028: discontinuous]] (i.e., not smooth), nondifferentiable, unbounded, wildly varying, or otherwise ill-defined.<ref name=""singularities""/> Such behaviour is often termed ""[[Mathematical singularity
column1029: singular]]"". Irregular behaviour in Earth systems may give rise to certain thresholds, which, when crossed, may lead to a large change in the system. Some singularities could potentially lead to severe impacts at regional or global scales.<ref name=""white et al singularities""> {{citation
column1033: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/052.htm Sec. 7.2.5, Large-Scale Singular Events] }}, in {{harvnb
column1035: 2001}}. </ref> Examples of ""large-scale"" singularities are discussed in the articles on [[abrupt climate change]], [[climate change feedback]] and [[runaway climate change]]. It is possible that human-induced climate change could trigger large-scale singularities, but the probabilities of triggering such events are, for the most part,<ref> ""[F]or the most part"" refers to improved scientific understanding of singularities since the assessment by White ''et al.'' (2001). See: {{citation
column1037: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1039: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Sec. 19.3.7 Update on ‘Reasons for Concern’] }}, in {{harvnb
column1041: 2007}}. </ref> poorly understood.<ref name=""white et al singularities""/> With low to medium confidence, Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""singularities""> {{citation
column1043: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1047: 2001}}. </ref> concluded that a rapid warming of more than 3 °C above 1990 levels would exceed thresholds that would lead to large-scale discontinuities in the climate system. Since the assessment by Smith ''et al.'' (2001), improved scientific understanding provides more guidance for two large-scale singularities: the role of [[carbon cycle]] feedbacks in future climate change (discussed below in the section on biogeochemical cycles) and the melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column1048: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s.<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/> ===Biogeochemical cycles=== {{See also
column1049: climate change feedback}} Climate change may have an effect on the [[carbon cycle]] in an interactive ""feedback"" process. A feedback exists where an initial process triggers changes in a second process that in turn influences the initial process. A positive feedback intensifies the original process, and a negative feedback reduces it.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report""> {{harvnb
column1053: date=November 2012}} Models suggest that the interaction of the climate system and the carbon cycle is one where the feedback effect is positive.<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""> {{citation
column1055: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1061: date=November 2012}} Using the A2 SRES emissions scenario, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""/>{{Rp
column1063: date=November 2012}} found that this effect led to additional warming by the years 2090-2100 (relative to the 1990–2000) of 0.1–1.5 °C. This estimate was made with high confidence. The climate projections made in the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report summarized earlier of 1.1–6.4 °C account for this feedback effect. On the other hand, with medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""/>{{Rp
column1065: date=November 2012}} commented that additional releases of GHGs were possible from permafrost, peat lands, wetlands, and large stores of marine hydrates at high latitudes. ===Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets=== With medium confidence, authors of AR4<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""> {{citation
column1071: 2007}}. </ref> concluded that with a global average temperature increase of 1–4 °C (relative to temperatures over the years 1990–2000), at least a partial deglaciation of the [[Greenland ice sheet]], and possibly the [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s would occur. The estimated timescale for partial deglaciation was centuries to millennia, and would contribute {{convert
column1075: m}} or more to sea level rise over this period. ===The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation=== {{See also
column1078: This map shows the general location and direction of the warm surface (red) and cold deep water (blue) currents of the [[thermohaline circulation]]. [[Salinity]] is represented by color in units of the Practical Salinity Scale. Low values (blue) are less saline, while high values (orange) are more saline.<ref> {{cite web
column1080: author=Riebeek, H.. design by R. Simmon
column1081: title=Paleoclimatology: Explaining the Evidence: Explaining Rapid Climate Change: Tales from the Ice
column1087: right]] The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is an important component of the Earth's climate system, characterized by a northward flow of warm, salty water in the upper layers of the [[Atlantic ocean
column1088: Atlantic]] and a southward flow of colder water in the deep Atlantic.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""> {{cite book
column1091: title= Abrupt Climate Change. A report by the US Climate Change Science Program (CCSP) and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column1096: date=November 2012}} The AMOC is equivalently known as the [[thermohaline circulation]] (THC).<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/> Potential impacts associated with MOC changes include reduced warming or (in the case of abrupt change) absolute cooling of northern high-latitude areas near [[Greenland]] and north-western Europe, an increased warming of [[Southern Hemisphere]] high-latitudes, tropical drying, as well as changes to [[marine ecosystem]]s, terrestrial vegetation, oceanic {{chem
column1098: 2}} uptake, oceanic oxygen concentrations, and shifts in fisheries.<ref> {{citation
column1100: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1102: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-5-3.html Sec. 19.3.5.3 Possible changes in the North Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (MOC)] }}, in {{harvnb
column1104: 2007}}. </ref> According to an assessment by the US [[Climate Change Science Program]] (CCSP, 2008b),<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1106: date=November 2012}} it is very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1108: date=November 2012}} that the strength of the AMOC will decrease over the course of the 21st century. Warming is still expected to occur over most of the European region downstream of the [[North Atlantic Current]] in response to increasing GHGs, as well as over [[North America]]. Although it is very unlikely (less than 10% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1110: date=November 2012}} that the AMOC will collapse in the 21st century, the potential consequences of such a collapse could be severe.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1112: date=November 2012}} ===Irreversibilities=== ====Commitment to radiative forcing==== Emissions of GHGs are a potentially irreversible commitment to sustained [[radiative forcing]] in the future.<ref name=""albritton irreversible radiative forcing""> {{citation
column1116: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc%5Ftar/wg1/016.htm Sec. C.1 Observed Changes in Globally Well-Mixed Greenhouse Gas Concentrations and Radiative Forcing] }}, p. 38, in {{harvnb
column1118: 2001}}. </ref> The contribution of a GHG to radiative forcing depends on the gas's ability to trap [[infrared]] (heat) radiation, the concentration of the gas in the atmosphere, and the length of time the gas resides in the atmosphere.<ref name=""albritton irreversible radiative forcing""/> {{chem
column1120: 2}} is the most important anthropogenic GHG.<ref name=""ipcc 2007 causes of climate change""> {{citation
column1124: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms2.html Sec. 2. Causes of change] }}, p. 5, in {{harvnb
column1126: 2007}}. </ref> While more than half of the {{chem
column1128: 2}} emitted is currently removed from the atmosphere within a century, some fraction (about 20%) of emitted {{chem
column1130: 2}} remains in the atmosphere for many thousands of years.<ref> {{cite book
column1134: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-10-3.html Frequently Asked Question 10.3: If Emissions of Greenhouse Gases are Reduced, How Quickly do Their Concentrations in the Atmosphere Decrease?] }}, in {{harvnb
column1138: 2}} emitted today is potentially an irreversible commitment to sustained radiative forcing over thousands of years. This commitment may not be truly irreversible should techniques be developed to remove {{chem
column1140: 2}} or other GHGs directly from the atmosphere, or to block sunlight to induce cooling.<ref name=""solomon irreversible climate change""> {{cite journal
column1143: title=Irreversible climate change due to carbon dioxide emissions
column1144: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (PNAS)
column1153: bibcode = 2009PNAS..106.1704S }}</ref> Techniques of this sort are referred to as [[geoengineering]]. Little is known about the effectiveness, costs or potential [[Unintended consequences
column1154: side-effects]] of geoengineering options.<ref name=""barker geoengineering""> {{citation
column1156: chapter= Chapter 11: Mitigation from a cross-sectoral perspective
column1158: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/ch11s11-es.html Executive summary - Unconventional options] }} , in {{harvnb
column1160: 2007}}. </ref> Some geoengineering options, such as blocking sunlight, would not prevent further [[ocean acidification]].<ref name=""barker geoengineering""/> ====Irreversible impacts==== Human-induced climate change may lead to irreversible impacts on physical, biological, and social systems.<ref> {{citation
column1166: 2001}}. <!-- XX Needs checking. --> </ref> There are a number of examples of climate change impacts that may be irreversible, at least over the timescale of many human generations.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""> {{citation
column1168: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1170: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-2.html Sec.19.2 Criteria for selecting ‘key’ vulnerabilities: Persistence and reversibility] }}, in {{harvnb
column1172: 2007}}. </ref> These include the large-scale singularities described above - changes in carbon cycle feedbacks, the melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, and changes to the AMOC.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In biological systems, the extinction of species would be an irreversible impact.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In social systems, unique [[culture]]s may be lost due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> For example, humans living on [[atoll]] islands face risks due to sea-level rise, sea-surface warming, and increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.<ref> {{cite journal
column1181: doi=10.1023/b:clim.0000004559.08755.88 }} This paper was published in 2001 as [http://www.tyndall.ac.uk/sites/default/files/wp9.pdf Tyndall Centre Working Paper 9] </ref> ==Scientific opinion== The [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC) has published several major assessments on the effects of global warming.<ref> {{harvnb
column1184: pp=4-7}} </ref> Its most recent comprehensive impact assessment was published in 2014.<ref> {{harvnb
column1186: 2014}} </ref> Publications describing the effects of climate change have also been produced by the following organizations: *[[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] (AAAS)<ref> {{harvnb
column1189: n.d.}} </ref> *A report by the [[Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency]], the [[Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute]], and [[Wageningen University and Research Centre]]<ref> {{harvnb
column1197: 2013}} for other AVOID publications. </ref> *A report by the UK [[Royal Society]] and [[US National Academy of Sciences]]<ref> {{harvnb
column1200: 2014}} </ref> *[[University of New South Wales]] Climate Change Research Centre<ref> {{harvnb
column1207: 2011}} </ref> A report by Molina ''et al.'' (no date)<ref> {{harvnb
column1211:
p=3}} states:
The overwhelming evidence of human-caused climate change documents both current impacts with significant costs and extraordinary future risks to society and natural systems

ExxonMobil Corporation]] * [[Climate Change Science Program#Impacts and adaptation
column1212: Bush Administration assessments of impacts and adaptation]] (United States) {{Col-break}} {{Portal
column1215: Environment}} * [[Biological pump]] * [[Climate Vulnerability Monitor]] (CVM) * [[Oceanic anoxic event]] * [[PRECIS (Providing Regional Climates for Impacts Studies)]] * [[Solubility pump]] {{Col-end}} {{Clear}} ==Footnotes== <sup>1</sup> The TAR<ref name=""Uncertainty in the TAR""> {{citation
column1221: 2001}}. </ref> and AR4<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> that are referred to in this article use specific and quantitative language to describe uncertainty. This language is intended to provide an indication of the level of confidence that IPCC authors have about a particular finding. The qualitative language used to describe uncertainty has a quantitative scale associated with it. The quantitative values for qualitative terms are intended to ensure that confidence levels are interpreted correctly. The is because qualitative statements, e.g., using the word ""likely"", can be interpreted differently in quantitative terms.<ref> {{citation
column1228: title= IPCC supporting material: guidance papers on the cross cutting issues of the Third Assessment Report of the IPCC
column1229: editor= R. Pachuari, T. Taniguchi and K. Tanaka, (eds.)
column1231: publisher= Global Industrial and Social Progress Research Institute (GISPRI)
column1235: date=November 2012}} Confidence levels used in the TAR:<ref> {{citation
column1239: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/023.htm#14 Box 2. Confidence Levels and State of Knowledge] }}, in {{harvnb
column1241: 2001}}. </ref> * Very High = 95% or greater * High = 67-95% * Medium = 33-67% * Low = 5-33% * Very Low = 5% or less Confidence statements made in AR4 are listed below:<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> * Very high confidence: At least 9 out of 10 chance of being correct * High confidence: About 8 out of 10 chance "" "" "" * Medium confidence: About 5 out of 10 chance "" "" "" * Low confidence: About 2 out of 10 chance "" "" "" * Very low confidence: Less than a 1 out of 10 chance "" "" "" IPCC (2012)<ref> {{citation
column1246: p=19}} </ref> uses the following terms: ""very low"", ""low"", ""medium"", ""high"", and ""very high confidence"". Unlike the TAR and AR4, the scale is qualitative rather than quantitative. The quantitative values used by IPCC authors are ""subjective"" probabilities,<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/><ref name=""Uncertainty in the TAR""/><ref> {{citation
column1250: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/106.htm Sec. 2.6.2. ""Objective"" and ""Subjective"" Probabilities are not Always Explicitly Distinguished] }}, in {{harvnb
column1253: Bayesian]]"" probabilities,<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""> {{cite book
column1255: author= Granger Morgan, M. (Lead Author), H. Dowlatabadi, M. Henrion, D. Keith, R. Lempert, S. McBride, M. Small and T. Wilbanks (Contributing Authors)
column1256: title= Synthesis and Assessment Product 5.2: Best practice approaches for characterizing, communicating, and incorporating scientific uncertainty in decisionmaking. A Report by the U.S. Climate Change Science Program and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column1257: publisher= National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
column1260: url= http://www.globalchange.gov/publications/reports/scientific-assessments/saps/311 }} Tables 2.1 and 2.2 on pages 27-28 show two quantitative scales of uncertainty which are used in the TAR and AR4.</ref> and reflect the expert judgement of IPCC authors. In this formulation, probability is not only a function of an event, but also the state of information that is available to the person making the assessment.<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""/> In this framework, assigned probabilities may change as more or different information becomes available.<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""/> The IPCC also uses another scale to describe the likelihood of a particular event occurring.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> This is different from the confidence scales described above, and it is possible to assign confidence values to statements of likelihood. For example, the judgement that an event is improbable (e.g., rolling a [[dice]] twice and getting a six both times) may be assigned a high level of scientific confidence.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> Also, the probability that an event has an even chance of occurring (e.g., a tossed [[coin]] coming up heads) may also be assigned a high level of confidence.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> == Notes == {{Reflist

This body assesses the physical scientific aspects of the climate system and climate change. ;Social, economic and ecological impacts * [http://www.un.org/esa/dsd/dsd_aofw_cc/cc_index.shtml Climate change] on the United Nations Economic and Social Development (UNESD) Division for Sustainable Development website. * [http://www.ipcc-wg2.gov/ The IPCC Working Group II (WG II) website] – This body assesses the vulnerability of socio-economic and natural systems to climate change, negative and positive consequences of climate change, and options for adapting to it. ;General * [http://esa.un.org/subindex/pgViewSites.asp?termCode=QB.25 List of United Nations Functional Commissions and Expert Bodies related to climate change] * [[IRIN]], the humanitarian news and analysis service of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs: [http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=79563 ""What climate change does""], [http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=79508 ""How climate change works""], and [http://www.irinnews.org/IndepthMain.aspx?IndepthId=73&ReportId=78246 ""Gathering Storm - the humanitarian impact of climate change""] * Videos: ** [http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=4119472365452589212 ""Educational Forum: Arctic Climate Impact""]. Panel discussion with James J. McCarthy, Professor at Harvard University, and Author; Paul R. Epstein, M.D., instructor in medicine at Harvard Medical School; and Ross Gelbspan, Pulitzer-prize winning journalist and author. Massachusetts School of Law. ** [http://climateprogress.org/2010/02/05/videos-humans-are-changing-the-climate-global-warming-threat-chris-field/#more-18551 ""How we know humans are changing the climate and Why climate change is a clear and present danger""]. Interviews with Christopher Field and Michael MacCracken. Christopher Field is the director of the Department of Global Ecology at the Carnegie Institution of Washington, professor of biology and environmental earth system science at Stanford University, and the Working Group II Co-Chair for the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Michael MacCracken is the chief scientist for Climate Change Programs at the Climate Institute and a co-author and contributing author for various chapters in the IPCC assessment reports. column2: This article is primarily about effects during the 21st century. For longer-term effects, see [[Long-term effects of global warming]].}} {{Pp-semi-protected
column6: alt=Refer to caption and image description
column7: Summary of climate change impacts.]] [[File:Projected global warming in 2100 for a range of emission scenarios.png
column10: alt=Refer to caption and image description
column11: Projected global warming in 2100 for a range of emission scenarios.]] The '''effects of [[global warming]]''' are the environmental and social changes caused (directly or indirectly) by human emissions of [[greenhouse gas]]es. There is [[scientific opinion on climate change
column12: a scientific consensus that climate change is occurring]], and that human activities are the primary driver.<ref> {{citation
column13: author=Joint-statement by leaders of 18 scientific organizations: American Association for the Advancement of Science, American Chemical Society, American Geophysical Union, American Institute of Biological Sciences, American Meteorological Society, American Society of Agronomy, American Society of Plant Biologists, American Statistical Association, Association of Ecosystem Research Centers, Botanical Society of America, Crop Science Society of America, Ecological Society of America, Natural Science Collections, Alliance Organization of Biological Field Stations, Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, [[Society of Systematic Biologists]], Soil Science Society of America, University Corporation for Atmospheric Research
column15: title=Joint-statement on climate change by leaders of 18 scientific organizations
column18: publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science
column19: location=Washington DC, USA }}. Archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20140714124825/http://www.aaas.org/sites/default/files/content_files/1021climate_letter.pdf 14 July 2014]. </ref> Many impacts of climate change have already been observed, including [[Retreat of glaciers since 1850
column20: glacier retreat]],<ref name=""cramer observed effects"">Cramer, W., ''et al.'', Executive summary, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap18_FINAL.pdf Chapter 18: Detection and attribution of observed impacts] (archived [http://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap18_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), pp.982-984, in {{harvnb
column22: 2014}} </ref> changes in the timing of seasonal events<ref name=""cramer observed effects""/> (e.g., earlier flowering of plants),<ref>Settele, J., ''et al.'', Section 4.3.2.1: Phenology, in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap4_FINAL.pdf Chapter 4: Terrestrial and inland water systems] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap4_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), p.291, in {{harvnb
column24: 2014}} </ref> and changes in agricultural productivity.<ref name=""cramer observed effects""/> Future effects of climate change will vary depending on climate change policies<ref name=""adaptation and mitigation"">Oppenheimer, M., ''et al.'', ''Section 19.7.1: Relationship between Adaptation Efforts, Mitigation Efforts, and Residual Impacts,'' in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf Chapter 19: Emergent risks and key vulnerabilities] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1080-1085, in {{harvnb
column26: 2014}} </ref> and [[social development]].<ref>Oppenheimer, M., ''et al.'', ''Section 19.6.2.2. The Role of Adaptation and Alternative Development Pathways,'' in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf Chapter 19: Emergent risks and key vulnerabilities] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1072-1073, in {{harvnb
column28: 2014}} </ref> The two main policies to address climate change are reducing human greenhouse gas emissions ([[climate change mitigation]]) and [[climate change adaptation
column29: adapting]] to the impacts of climate change.<ref name=""climate change policy"">Denton, F., ''et al.'', ''Section 20.3. Contributions to Resilience through Climate Change Responses,'' in: [http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg2/WGIIAR5-Chap20_FINAL.pdf Chapter Climate-resilient pathways: adaptation, mitigation, and sustainable development] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap20_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1113-1118, in {{harvnb
column32: Geoengineering]] is another policy option.<ref name=""climate change policy""/> Near-term climate change policies could significantly affect long-term climate change impacts.<ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Section A-3. The Decision-making Context, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [http://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.55, in {{harvnb
column34: 2014}} </ref><ref name=""adaptation and mitigation""/> Stringent mitigation policies might be able to limit global warming (in 2100) to around 2 °C or below, relative to pre-industrial levels.<ref>SPM.4.1 Long‐term mitigation pathways, in: [http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf Summary for Policymakers], pp.11-15 (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20140702014732/http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf 2 July 2014)], in {{harvnb
column36: 2014}} </ref> Without mitigation, increased [[energy demand]] and extensive use of [[fossil fuel]]s<ref> Clarke, L., ''et al.'', Section 6.3.1.3 Baseline emissions projections from fossil fuels and industry (pp.17-18 of final draft), in: [http://report.mitigation2014.org/drafts/final-draft-postplenary/ipcc_wg3_ar5_final-draft_postplenary_chapter6.pdf Chapter 6: Assessing Transformation Pathways] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020021617/http://report.mitigation2014.org/drafts/final-draft-postplenary/ipcc_wg3_ar5_final-draft_postplenary_chapter6.pdf 20 October 2014]), in: {{harvnb
column38: 2014}} </ref> might lead to global warming of around 4 °C.<ref> Greenhouse Gas Concentrations and Climate Implications, p.14, in {{harvnb
column41: 2014}}. The range given by Prinn and Reilly is 3.3 to 5.5 °C, with a median of 3.9 °C. </ref><ref>SPM.3 Trends in stocks and flows of greenhouse gases and their drivers, in: [http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf Summary for Policymakers], p.8 (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20140702014732/http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf 2 July 2014)], in {{harvnb
column43: 2014}}. The range given by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change is 3.7 to 4.8 °C, relative to pre-industrial levels (2.5 to 7.8 °C including climate uncertainty). </ref> Higher magnitudes of global warming would be more difficult to adapt to,<ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Box TS.8: Adaptation Limits and Transformation, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [http://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.89, in {{harvnb
column45: 2014}} </ref> and would increase the risk of negative impacts.<ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Section B-1. Key Risks across Sectors and Regions, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [http://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.62, in {{harvnb
column48: attribution of recent climate change}} In this article, ""[[climate change]]"" means a change in climate that persists over a sustained period of time.<ref name=""ipcc definition of climate change""> {{citation
column56: at=Click on the image to open a pop-up that explains the differences between climate change and global warming.
column59: publisher=US EPA }} </ref> The [[World Meteorological Organization]] defines this time period as 30 years.<ref name=""ipcc definition of climate change""/> Examples of climate change include increases in global surface temperature (global warming), changes in [[rainfall]] patterns, and changes in the frequency of [[extreme weather]] events. Changes in climate may be due to natural causes, e.g., changes in the [[sun]]'s output, or due to human activities, e.g., changing the composition of the atmosphere.<ref name=""albritton climate change""/> Any human-induced changes in climate will occur against a background of natural climatic variations<ref name=""albritton climate change""> {{citation
column63: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/011.htm Box 1: What drives changes in climate?] }}, in {{harvnb
column65: 2001}} </ref> and of variations in human activity such as population growth on shores or in arid areas which increase or decrease climate vulnerability.<ref name='NatureTaboo'>{{cite journal
column66: title = Lifting the taboo on adaptation
column80: doi=10.1038/445597a}}</ref> Also, the term ""anthropogenic forcing"" refers to the influence exerted on a habitat or chemical environment by humans, as opposed to a natural process.<ref> {{cite web
column82: title=Definition of Anthropogenic Forcing – Chemistry Dictionary and Glossary }} </ref> ==Temperature changes== {{Multiple image
column86: alt1=Global mean surface temperature change since 1880, relative to the 1951–1980 mean, showing a long term warming trend.
column87: image2= Projected global warming over the 21st century using three SRES greenhouse gas emissions scenarios. Data from CMIP3 (2007).png
column90: caption1=Global mean surface temperature change since 1880, relative to the 1951–1980 mean. Source: [http://data.giss.nasa.gov/gistemp/ NASA GISS]
column91: caption2=The graph above shows the average of a set of temperature simulations for the 20th century (black line), followed by projected temperatures for the 21st century based on three greenhouse gas emissions scenarios (colored lines).<ref name=""herring temperature projections""> {{cite web
column96: url= http://www.climatewatch.noaa.gov/article/2012/global-temperature-projections }} </ref> }} This article breaks down some of the impacts of climate change according to different levels of future global warming. This way of describing impacts has, for instance, been used in the IPCC ([[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]]) Assessment Reports on climate change.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""> {{citation
column98: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column100: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-1.html Sec. 19.3.1 Introduction to Table 19.1] }}, in {{harvnb
column102: 2007}}. </ref> The instrumental [[temperature record]] shows global warming of around 0.6 °C during the 20th century.<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""/> ===SRES emissions scenarios=== The future level of global warming is uncertain, but a wide range of estimates (projections) have been made.<ref name=""Overview of GHG emissions scenarios""> {{citation
column104: chapter= Chapter 3: Issues related to mitigation in the long-term context
column108: 2007}} </ref> The IPCC's ""[[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column109: SRES]]"" scenarios have been frequently used to make [[Global climate model#Projections of future climate change
column110: projections of future climate change]].<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column112: date=November 2012}} The SRES scenarios are ""[[Economics of climate change mitigation#Baselines
column113: baseline]]"" (or ""reference"") scenarios, which means that they do not take into account any current or future measures to limit GHG emissions (e.g., the UNFCCC's [[Kyoto Protocol]] and the [[2010 United Nations Climate Change Conference
column116: chapter= Chapter 2, Greenhouse Gas Emission Mitigation Scenarios and Implications
column118: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/080.htm Sec. 2.5.1.1 IPCC Emissions Scenarios and the SRES Process] }}, in {{harvnb
column120: 2001}}. </ref> Emissions projections of the SRES scenarios are broadly comparable in range to the baseline emissions scenarios that have been developed by the scientific community.<ref name=""Overview of GHG emissions scenarios""/><ref> {{citation
column126: 2007}}. </ref> In the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]], changes in future global mean temperature were projected using the six SRES ""marker"" emissions scenarios.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""> {{citation
column130: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html#table-spm-1 Sec. 1 3. Projected climate change and its impacts: Table SPM.1] }}, in {{harvnb
column132: 2007}}. </ref> Emissions projections for the six SRES ""marker"" scenarios are representative of the full set of forty SRES scenarios.<ref> {{citation
column134: chapter= Chapter 2, Greenhouse Gas Emission Mitigation Scenarios and Implications
column136: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/081.htm#2514 Sec. 2.5.1.4 Emissions and Other Results of the SRES Scenarios] }}, in {{harvnb
column138: 2001}}. </ref> For the lowest emissions SRES marker scenario (""B1"" - see the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column139: SRES]] article for details on this scenario), the best estimate for global mean temperature is an increase of {{convert
column143: 1}}<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> by the end of the 21st century. This projection is relative to global temperatures at the end of the 20th century.<ref>Temperature change in years 2090-2099 relative to years 1980-1999</ref> The ""likely"" range (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> for the SRES B1 marker scenario is {{convert
column149: 1}}.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> For the highest emissions SRES marker scenario (A1FI), the best estimate for global mean temperature increase is {{convert
column159: 1}}.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> The range in temperature projections partly reflects (1) the choice of [[economics of global warming#Emissions scenarios
column160: emissions scenario]], and (2) the ""[[climate sensitivity]]"".<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column162: date=November 2012}} For (1), different scenarios make different assumptions of future social and economic development (e.g., [[economic growth]], [[population projection
column164: energy policies]]), which in turn affects projections of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column166: date=November 2012}} The projected magnitude of warming by 2100 is closely related to the level of cumulative emissions over the 21st century (i.e. total emissions between 2000-2100).<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions""> {{citation
column169: chapter=Ch 2: Which emissions pathways are consistent with a {{val
column173: u=°C}} temperature limit?: Sec 2.2 What determines long-term temperature?
column174: title=The Emissions Gap Report: Are the Copenhagen Accord pledges sufficient to limit global warming to {{val
column181: publisher=UNEP }}, p.28. This publication is also available in [http://www.unep.org/publications/ebooks/emissionsgapreport/ e-book format] </ref> The higher the cumulative emissions over this time period, the greater the level of warming is projected to occur.<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions""/> (2) reflects uncertainty in the response of the climate system to past and future GHG emissions, which is measured by the [[climate sensitivity]]).<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column183: date=November 2012}} Higher estimates of climate sensitivity lead to greater projected warming, while lower estimates of climate sensitivity lead to less projected warming.<ref> {{citation
column184: chapter=Box 8.1 Likelihood of exceeding a temperature increase at equilibrium, in: Ch 8: The Challenge of Stabilisation
column188: p=195}} </ref> Over the next several millennia, projections suggest that global warming could be irreversible.<ref name=""solomon irreversible climate change""/> Even if emissions were drastically reduced, global temperatures would remain close to their highest level for at least 1,000 years (see the later section on [[effects of global warming#Irreversibilities
column195: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-7-2.html Sec 10.7.2 Climate Change Commitment to Year 3000 and Beyond to Equilibrium]
column205: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column206: Two millennia of mean surface temperatures according to different reconstructions from [[Proxy (climate)
column207: climate proxies]], each smoothed on a decadal scale, with the [[instrumental temperature record]] overlaid in black.]]
column208: [[File:Global temperature relative to peak Holocene temperature, based on ocean cores (NASA).png
column212: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column213: Global surface temperature for the past 5.3 million years as inferred from cores of ocean [[sediment]]s taken all around the global ocean. The last 800,000 years are expanded in the lower half of the figure (image credit: [[NASA]]).<ref name=""hansen climate history""/>]]
column214: } Scientists have used various ""proxy"" data to assess past changes in Earth's climate ([[paleoclimate]]).<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""> {{citation
column216: title=NOAA Paleoclimatology Global Warming - The Story: Proxy Data
column219: publisher=NOAA Paleoclimatology Program - NCDC Paleoclimatology Branch }} </ref> Sources of proxy data include historical records (such as [[farmer]]s' logs), [[tree ring]]s, [[coral]]s, [[fossil pollen]], [[ice core]]s, and ocean and lake [[sediment]]s.<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""/> Analysis of these data suggest that recent warming is unusual in the past 400 years, possibly longer.<ref> {{citation
column222: title=Surface Temperature Reconstructions for the Last 2,000 Years
column225: author=Committee on Surface Temperature Reconstructions for the Last 2,000 Years, US National Research Council
column227: isbn=0-309-66144-7 }}, p.3 </ref> By the end of the 21st century, temperatures may increase to a level not experienced since the mid-[[Pliocene]], around 3 million years ago.<ref name=""jansen pliocene""> {{citation
column231: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch6s6-3-2.html Sec. 6.3.2 What Does the Record of the Mid-Pliocene Show?] }}, in {{harvnb
column233: 2007}}. </ref> At that time, models suggest that mean global temperatures were about 2–3 °C warmer than pre-industrial temperatures.<ref name=""jansen pliocene""/> Even a 2 °C rise above the pre-industrial level would be outside the range of temperatures experienced by human [[civilization]].<ref name=""hansen climate history""> {{citation
column236: title=NASA GISS: Science Briefs: Earth's Climate History: Implications for Tomorrow
column238: location=New York City, New York, USA
column240: at=[http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/686.htm Footnote 4, in Sec 19.8.2. What does Each Reason for Concern Indicate?]
column241: chapter=Ch 19. Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column248: [[File:Diagram showing ten indicators of global warming.png
column252: alt=Refer to caption and adjacent text
column253: Seven of these indicators would be expected to increase in a warming world and observations show that they are, in fact, increasing. Three would be expected to decrease and they are, in fact, decreasing.<ref> {{harvnb
column257: } [[File:Changes in climate indicators that show global warming.png
column262: This set of graphs show changes in climate indicators over several decades. Each of the different colored lines in each panel represents an independently analyzed set of data. The data come from many different technologies including [[weather station]]s, [[satellite]]s, [[weather balloons]], [[ship]]s and [[buoy]]s.<ref> {{harvnb
column265: p=3}} </ref>]] A broad range of evidence shows that the climate system has warmed.<ref> {{citation
column269: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-3-4.html TS.3.4 Consistency Among Observations] }}, in {{harvnb
column271: 2007}}. </ref> Evidence of global warming is shown in the graphs opposite. Some of the graphs show a positive [[trend estimation
column272: trend]], e.g., increasing temperature over land and the ocean, and [[current sea level rise
column273: sea level rise]]. Other graphs show a negative trend, e.g., decreased [[snow]] cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]], and declining [[Arctic sea ice]] extent. Evidence of warming is also apparent in living [[Effects of global warming#Observed impacts on biological systems
column274: (biological) systems]].<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> Human activities have contributed to a number of the observed changes in climate.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""> {{citation
column276: chapter= Chapter 9: Understanding and Attributing Climate Change
column280: 2007}}. </ref> This contribution has principally been through the burning of [[fossil fuel]]s, which has led to an increase in the concentration of GHGs in the atmosphere.<ref> {{citation
column284: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-human-and.html Human and Natural Drivers of Climate Change ] }}, in {{harvnb
column286: 2007}}. </ref> Another human influence on the climate are [[sulfur dioxide]] emissions, which are a precursor to the formation of [[sulfate aerosols]] in the atmosphere.<ref> {{cite book
column288: author=Committee on the Science of Climate Change, US National Research Council
column290: title=Climate Change Science: An Analysis of Some Key Questions
column295: isbn=0-309-07574-2 }} </ref> Human-induced warming could lead to [[Effects of global warming#Abrupt or irreversible changes
column296: large-scale, irreversible, and/or abrupt changes]] in physical systems.<ref> {{citation
column300: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html Sec. 3. Projected climate change and its impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column303: title=ESRL News: New Study Shows Climate Change Largely Irreversible
column306: publisher=US Department of Commerce, NOAA, Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL)
column307: date=26 January 2009 }}</ref> An example of this is the melting of [[ice sheet]]s, which contributes to sea level rise.<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> The probability of warming having unforeseen consequences increases with the rate, magnitude, and duration of climate change.<ref> {{cite book
column312: publisher=[[United States National Academy of Sciences]]
column314: date=December 2012}}</ref> === Effects on weather === Observations show that there have been changes in weather.<ref> {{citation
column316: chapter= Chapter 1: Historical Overview of Climate Change Science
column318: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-1-2.html FAQ 1.2 What is the Relationship between Climate Change and Weather?] }}, in {{harvnb
column320: 2007}}. </ref> As climate changes, the [[probabilities]] of certain types of weather events are affected. [[File:Projected change in annual average precipitation for the 21st century, based on the SRES A1B emissions scenario, and simulated by the GFDL CM2.1 model.png
column324: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column325: Projected change in annual average precipitation by the end of the 21st century, based on a medium emissions scenario ([[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column326: SRES]] A1B) (Credit: NOAA [[Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory]]).<ref> {{citation
column330: title= GFDL Climate Modeling Research Highlights: Will the Wet Get Wetter and the Dry Drier
column335: title=Will the wet get wetter and the dry drier?
column339: publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory (GFDL)
column340: location=Princeton, NJ, USA }}. Revision 10/15/2008, 4:47:16 PM. </ref>]] Changes have been observed in the amount, intensity, frequency, and type of [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column348: date=November 2012}} Widespread increases in heavy precipitation have occurred, even in places where total rain amounts have decreased. With medium confidence (see [[Effects of global warming#Footnotes
column354: p=8}} </ref> concluded that human influences had contributed to an increase in heavy precipitation events at the global scale. Projections of future changes in precipitation show overall increases in the global average, but with substantial shifts in where and how precipitation falls.<ref name = ""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column356: date=November 2012}} Projections suggest a reduction in rainfall in the [[subtropics]], and an increase in precipitation in subpolar latitudes and some [[equatorial region]]s.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> In other words, regions which are dry at present will in general become even drier, while regions that are currently wet will in general become even wetter.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> This projection does not apply to every locale, and in some cases can be modified by local conditions.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> ==== Extreme weather ==== {{See also
column358: Tropical cyclone#Global warming}} Over most land areas since the 1950s, it is very likely that there have been fewer or warmer cold days and nights.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""> IPCC (2013), Table SPM.1, in [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf Summary for Policymakers, p. 5] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140226155600/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column360: 2013}} </ref> Hot days and nights have also very likely become warmer or more frequent.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Human activities have very likely contributed to these trends.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> There may have been changes in other climate extremes (e.g., [[flood]]s, [[drought]]s and [[tropical cyclone]]s) but these changes are more difficult to identify.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Projections suggest changes in the frequency and intensity of some extreme weather events.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Confidence in projections varies over time.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> ; Near-term projections (2016–2035) Some changes (e.g., more frequent hot days) will probably be evident in the near term, while other near-term changes (e.g., more intense droughts and tropical cyclones) are more uncertain.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> ; Long-term projections (2081–2100) Future climate change will be associated with more very hot days and fewer very cold days.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> The frequency, length and intensity of [[heat wave]]s will very likely increase over most land areas.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Higher growth in anthropogenic GHG emissions will be associated with larger increases in the frequency and severity of temperature extremes.<ref>Stocker, T.F., ''et al.'' (2013), Temperature Extremes, Heat Waves and Warm Spells, in: TFE.9, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf Technical Summary, p. 111] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221070705/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column362: 2013}} </ref> Assuming high growth in GHG emissions (IPCC scenario [[Representative Concentration Pathways
column363: RCP8.5]]), presently dry regions may be affected by an increase in the risk of drought and reductions in [[soil moisture]].<ref>Stocker, T.F., ''et al.'' (2013), Floods and Droughts, in: TFE.9, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf Technical Summary, p. 112] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221070705/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column365: 2013}} </ref> Over most of the mid-latitude land masses and wet tropical regions, extreme precipitation events will very likely become more intense and frequent.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> ; Tropical cyclones At the global scale, the frequency of tropical cyclones will probably decrease or be unchanged.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""> Christensen, J.H.,''et al.'' (2013), Cyclones, in: Executive Summary, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf Chapter 14: Climate Phenomena and their Relevance for Future Regional Climate Change, p. 1220] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221075046/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column367: 2013}} </ref> Global mean tropical cyclone maximum wind speed and precipitation rates will likely increase.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""/> Changes in tropical cyclones will probably vary by region, but these variations are uncertain.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""/> ; Effects of climate extremes The impacts of extreme events on the environment and human society will vary. Some impacts will be beneficial—e.g., fewer cold extremes will probably lead to fewer cold deaths.<ref name=""health summary""/> Overall, however, impacts will probably be mostly negative.<ref> {{citation
column375: chapter= Synthesis Report, Topic 5: The long-term perspective
column377: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains5-2.html Sec. 5.2 Key vulnerabilities, impacts and risks – long-term perspectives] }}, pp. 64–65, in {{harvnb
column380: Retreat of glaciers since 1850}} [[File:Glacier Mass Balance Map.png
column384: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column385: A map of the change in thickness of mountain glaciers since 1970. Thinning in orange and red, thickening in blue.]] [[File:SeaIce-Sept162012 HR.jpg
column390: A map that shows ice concentration on 16 September 2012, along with the extent of the previous record low (yellow line) and the mid-September median extent (black line) setting a new record low that was 18 percent smaller than the previous record and nearly 50 percent smaller than the long-term (1979-2000) average.]] The [[cryosphere]] is made up of areas of the Earth which are covered by snow or ice.<ref> [http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/glossary.html#C ""Cryosphere""], in {{harvnb
column392: 2012}} </ref> Observed changes in the cryosphere include declines in [[Arctic sea ice]] extent,<ref> {{citation
column397: title=Mass Balance of Mountain Glaciers in 2011
column400: 2012}} </ref> and reduced snow cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]].<ref> {{citation
column401: title=2011 Snow Cover in Northern Hemisphere
column404: 2012}} </ref> Solomon ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""ar4 arctic sea ice""> {{citation
column408: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-5-2.html TS.5.2 Large-Scale Projections for the 21st Century] }}, in {{harvnb
