column410: 2007}} </ref> assessed the potential impacts of climate change on [[summer]]time Arctic sea ice extent. Assuming high growth in greenhouse gas emissions ([[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column411: SRES A2]]), some models projected that Arctic sea ice in the summer could largely disappear by the end of the 21st century.<ref name=""ar4 arctic sea ice""/> More recent projections suggest that the Arctic summers could be ice-free (defined as ice extent less than 1 million square km) as early as 2025-2030.<ref> {{citation
column420: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-4.html Box 10.1: Future Abrupt Climate Change, ‘Climate Surprises’, and Irreversible Changes: Glaciers and ice caps] }}, in {{harvnb
column423: p=776}} </ref> and snow cover are projected to continue their widespread retreat.<ref> {{citation
column427: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-3-2.html Sec 10.3.3.2 Changes in Snow Cover and Frozen Ground] }}, in {{harvnb
column430: pp=770, 772}} </ref> In the western mountains of [[North America]], increasing temperatures and changes in precipitation are projected to lead to reduced [[snowpack]].<ref> {{citation
column434: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch14s14-4.html#14-4-1 Sec 14.4.1 Freshwater resources: Surface water] }}, in {{harvnb
column437: p=627}} </ref> Snowpack is the seasonal accumulation of slow-melting snow.<ref> [http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/glossary.html#S ""Snowpack""], in {{harvnb
column439: 2012}} </ref> The melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column440: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s could contribute to sea level rise, especially over long time-scales (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets
column441: Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets]]).<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> Changes in the cryosphere are projected to have social impacts.<ref> Some of these impacts are included in table SPM.2: {{citation
column442: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html#spm2 3 Projected climate change and its impacts: Table SPM.2]
column447: pp=11–12}} </ref> For example, in some regions, glacier retreat could increase the risk of reductions in seasonal water availability.<ref> {{citation
column449: chapter=Ch 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column456: title=Potential impacts of a warming climate on water availability in snow-dominated regions: Abstract
column463: pmid=16292301}} </ref> estimated that more than one-sixth of the [[world's population]] rely on glaciers and snowpack for their water supply. ===Oceans=== {{Main
column464: Effects of global warming on oceans}} The role of the oceans in global warming is complex. The oceans serve as a sink for carbon dioxide, taking up much that would otherwise remain in the atmosphere, but increased levels of {{chem
column466: 2}} have led to [[ocean acidification]]. Furthermore, as the temperature of the oceans increases, they become less able to absorb excess {{chem
column468: 2}}. The ocean have also acted as a sink in absorbing extra heat from the atmosphere.<ref name=""statecl"">{{cite book
column470: publisher = Website of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration: National Climatic Data Center
column471: title = State of the Climate in 2009, as appearing in the July 2010 issue (Vol. 91) of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society (BAMS). Supplemental and Summary Materials: Report at a Glance: Highlights
column475: date=November 2012}} The increase in ocean [[heat content]] is much larger than any other store of [[energy]] in the Earth’s heat balance over the two periods 1961 to 2003 and 1993 to 2003, and accounts for more than 90% of the possible increase in heat content of the Earth system during these periods.<ref>{{citation
column476: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch5s5-2-2-3.html Sec 5.2.2.3 Implications for Earth’s Heat Balance]
column477: chapter=Ch. 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column482: title=Climate Graphics by Skeptical Science: Global Warming Components:
column483: at=Components of global warming for the period 1993 to 2003 calculated from IPCC AR4 5.2.2.3
column485: publisher=Skeptical Science }} </ref> Global warming is projected to have a number of effects on the oceans. Ongoing effects include rising sea levels due to thermal expansion and melting of glaciers and ice sheets, and warming of the ocean surface, leading to increased temperature stratification. Other possible effects include large-scale changes in ocean circulation. ====Acidification==== {{Main
column486: Ocean acidification}} [[File:Changes in aragonite saturation of the world's oceans, 1880-2012 (US EPA).png
column490: alt=refer to caption and image description
column491: This map shows changes in the amount of [[aragonite]] dissolved in [[ocean]] surface waters between the 1880s and the most recent decade (2003-2012).<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/> Historical modeling suggests that since the 1880s, increased {{CO2}} has led to lower [[aragonite]] saturation levels (less availability of minerals) in the oceans around the world.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""> {{Include-USGov
column494: title=Climate Change Indicators in the United States, 2012, 2nd ed: Ocean Acidity: Figure 2. Changes in Aragonite Saturation of the World's Oceans, 1880-2012
column496: url=http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/science/indicators/oceans/acidity.html#fragment-2 }} }} </ref> The largest decreases in aragonite saturation have occurred in [[tropical]] waters.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/> However, decreases in cold areas may be of greater concern because colder waters typically have lower aragonite levels to begin with.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/>]] About one-third of the carbon dioxide emitted by human activity has already been taken up by the oceans.<ref name=""nrc 2008b ocean acidification""> {{cite book
column498: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column502: 2008b}} </ref> As carbon dioxide dissolves in [[sea water]], [[carbonic acid]] is formed, which has the effect of acidifying the ocean, measured as a change in [[pH]]. The uptake of human carbon emissions since the year 1750 has led to an average decrease in pH of 0.1 units.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 ocean acidification""> {{citation
column508: 2007}}. </ref> Projections using the SRES emissions scenarios suggest a further reduction in average global surface ocean pH of between 0.14 and 0.35 units over the 21st century. The effects of ocean acidification on the marine [[biosphere]] have yet to be documented.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 ocean acidification""/> Laboratory experiments suggest beneficial effects for a few species, with potentially highly detrimental effects for a substantial number of species.<ref name=""nrc 2008b ocean acidification""/> With medium confidence, Fischlin ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column510: chapter = Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods, and services
column514: 2007}}. </ref> projected that future ocean acidification and climate change would impair a wide range of [[plankton]]ic and shallow [[benthos
column515: benthic]] marine organisms that use [[aragonite]] to make their shells or skeletons, such as [[coral]]s and marine [[snail]]s ([[pteropoda
column516: pteropods]]), with significant impacts particularly in the Southern Ocean. ====Oxygen depletion==== The amount of oxygen dissolved in the oceans may decline, with adverse consequences for ocean life.<ref>{{cite doi
column519: Current sea level rise}} [[File:Trends in global average absolute sea level, 1870-2008 (US EPA).png
column523: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column524: Trends in global average absolute sea level, 1870-2008.<ref> {{cite web
column526: title= Sea Level: Climate Change: US EPA
column529: year=2010 }} </ref>]] There is strong evidence that global sea level rose gradually over the 20th century.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""> {{citation
column531: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column533: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-5-1.html FAQ 5.1 Is Sea Level Rising?] }}, in {{harvnb
column537: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column541: 2007}}. </ref> concluded that between the mid-19th and mid-20th centuries, the rate of sea level rise increased. Authors of the IPCC Fourth Assessment Synthesis Report (IPCC AR4 SYR, 2007)<ref name= ""Observed changes in climate and their effects""> {{citation
column545: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms1.html Sec. 1. Observed changes in climate and their effects] }}, p. 5, in {{harvnb
column547: 2007}}. </ref> reported that between the years 1961 and 2003, global average sea level rose at an average rate of 1.8 mm per year (mm/yr), with a range of 1.3–2.3 mm/yr. Between 1993 and 2003, the rate increased above the previous period to 3.1 mm/yr (range of 2.4–3.8 mm/yr). Authors of IPCC AR4 SYR (2007)<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""/> were uncertain whether the increase in rate from 1993 to 2003 was due to [[climate change#Internal forcing mechanisms
column548: natural variations]] in sea level over the time period, or whether it reflected an increase in the underlying long-term trend. There are two main factors that have contributed to observed sea level rise.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""/> The first is [[thermal expansion]]: as ocean water warms, it expands.<ref> {{citation
column552: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/013.htm#b4 Box 2: What causes sea level to change?] }}, in {{harvnb
column554: 2007}}. </ref> The second is from the contribution of land-based ice due to increased melting. The major store of water on land is found in glaciers and ice sheets. Anthropogenic forces very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""> {{citation
column558: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-2.html Box TS.1: Treatment of Uncertainties in the Working Group I Assessment] }}, in {{harvnb
column560: 2007}}. </ref> contributed to sea level rise during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> There is a widespread consensus that substantial long-term sea level rise will continue for centuries to come.<ref> {{citation
column561: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column565: p=245}}. </ref> In their Fourth Assessment Report, the IPCC<ref> {{citation
column567: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column571: 2007}}. </ref> projected sea level rise to the end of the 21st century using the SRES emissions scenarios. Across the six SRES marker scenarios, sea level was projected to rise by 18 to 59 cm (7.1 to 23.2 in), relative to sea level at the end of the 20th century.<ref>change in sea level by 2090–99, relative to 1980–99</ref> Thermal expansion is the largest component in these projections, contributing 70-75% of the central estimate for all scenarios.<ref> {{citation
column577: 2007}}. </ref> Due to a lack of scientific understanding, this sea level rise estimate does not include all of the possible contributions of ice sheets (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets
column578: Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets]]). An assessment of the [[scientific literature]] on climate change was published in 2010 by the [[US National Research Council]] (US NRC, 2010).<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""> {{citation
column580: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column583: 2010}}. </ref> NRC (2010)<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> described the projections in AR4 (i.e. those cited in the above paragraph) as ""conservative"", and summarized the results of more recent studies. Cited studies suggested a great deal of uncertainty in projections.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> A range of projections suggested possible sea level rise by the end of the 21st century of between 0.56 and 2 m, relative to sea levels at the end of the 20th century.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> ====Ocean temperature rise==== [[File:Heat content700m2000myr.png
column588: Global ocean heat content from 1955-2012]] From 1961 to 2003, the global ocean temperature has risen by 0.10 °C from the surface to a depth of 700 m. There is variability both year-to-year and over longer time scales, with global ocean heat content observations showing high rates of warming for 1991–2003, but some cooling from 2003 to 2007.<ref> {{citation
column590: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column595: date=November 2012}} </ref> The temperature of the Antarctic [[Southern Ocean]] rose by 0.17 °C (0.31 °F) between the 1950s and the 1980s, nearly twice the rate for the world's oceans as a whole.<ref> {{cite journal
column599: title= Warming of the Southern Ocean Since the 1950s
column609: ref=harv }}</ref> As well as having effects on ecosystems (e.g. by melting sea ice, affecting algae that grow on its underside), warming reduces the ocean's ability to absorb {{chem
column612: date=June 2008}} It is likely (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> that anthropogenic forcing contributed to the general warming observed in the upper several hundred metres of the ocean during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> ==Regions== {{Main
column613: Regional effects of global warming}} {{Multiple image
column616: image1=Temperatures across the world in the 1880s (left) and the 1980s (right), as compared to average temperatures from 1951 to 1980 (US EPA).jpg
column617: alt1=Temperatures in most parts of the world were warmer in the 1980s compared to the 1880s
column618: image2= Map of projected global warming across the globe by the 2050s. Projections based on three SRES greenhouse gas emissions scenarios. Data from CMIP3 (2007).jpg
column619: alt2=Future warming across the globe varies according to different projections of greenhouse gas emissions
column621: caption1=Temperatures across the world in the 1880s (left) and the 1980s (right), as compared to average temperatures from 1951 to 1980.<ref> {{cite web
column624: title=Science: Climate Change: US EPA (Climate Change Science Overview)
column627: caption2=Projected changes in average temperatures across the world in the 2050s under three greenhouse gas (GHG) [[Economics of global warming#Emissions scenarios
column628: emissions scenarios]].<ref name=""herring temperature projections""/> }} Regional effects of global warming vary in nature. Some are the result of a generalised global change, such as rising temperature, resulting in local effects, such as melting ice. In other cases, a change may be related to a change in a particular ocean current or weather system. In such cases, the regional effect may be disproportionate and will not necessarily follow the global trend. There are three major ways in which global warming will make changes to regional climate: melting or forming ice, changing the [[hydrological cycle]] (of [[evaporation]] and [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column630: currents in the oceans]] and air flows in the atmosphere. The coast can also be considered a region, and will suffer severe impacts from [[sea level rise]]. ===Observed impacts=== With very high confidence, Rosenzweig ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> concluded that physical and biological systems on all continents and in most oceans had been affected by recent climate changes, particularly regional temperature increases. Impacts include earlier leafing of [[tree]]s and [[plant]]s over many regions; movements of species to higher latitudes and altitudes in the Northern Hemisphere; changes in [[bird migration]]s in Europe, North America and Australia; and shifting of the oceans' [[plankton]] and [[fish]] from cold- to warm-adapted communities.<ref name=""nasa briefs""/> The human influence on the climate can be seen in the geographical pattern of observed warming, with greater temperature increases over land and in [[polar region]]s rather than over the oceans.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""> {{cite book
column632: title=Understanding and Responding to Climate Change. A brochure prepared by the US National Research Council (US NRC)
column633: publisher=[http://dels.nas.edu/basc Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate], National Academy of Sciences
column638: date=November 2012}} Using models, it is possible to identify the human ""signal"" of global warming over both land and ocean areas.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""/>{{Rp
column640: date=November 2012}} ===Projected impacts=== Projections of future climate changes at the regional scale do not hold as high a level of scientific confidence as projections made at the global scale.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""/>{{Rp
column642: date=November 2012}} It is, however, expected that future warming will follow a similar geographical pattern to that seen already, with greatest warming over land and high northern [[latitude]]s, and least over the [[Southern Ocean]] and parts of the [[North Atlantic Ocean]].<ref> {{citation
column646: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-projections-of.html Projections of Future Changes in Climate] }}, in {{harvnb
column648: 2007}}. </ref> Nearly all land areas will very likely warm more than the global average.<ref name=""tar table of robust findings""> {{citation
column655: megadeltas]] are regions that are likely to be especially affected by climate change.<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions""> {{citation
column659: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-3.html Sec. 3.3.3 Especially affected systems, sectors and regions] }}, in {{harvnb
column663: less-developed]] areas are at most risk of experiencing negative impacts due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts""> {{citation
column665: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column667: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Distribution of Impacts, in: Sec 19.3.7 Update on 'Reasons for Concern'] }}, in {{harvnb
column670: p=796}} </ref> [[Developed countries]] are also vulnerable to climate change.<ref name=""schneider regional vulnerabilities""> {{citation
column672: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column677: p=792}} </ref> For example, developed countries will be negatively affected by increases in the severity and frequency of some [[extreme weather]] events, such as [[heat wave]]s.<ref name=""schneider regional vulnerabilities""/> In all regions, some people can be particularly at risk from climate change, such as the [[poverty
column678: poor]], young [[children]] and the [[elderly]].<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions""/><ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts""/><ref> {{citation
column682: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-2-5.html Sec 7.4.2.5 Social issues and Sec 7.4.3 Key vulnerabilities] }}, in {{harvnb
column686: Effects of climate change on humans
column687: Climate change, industry and society}} {{See also
column688: climate change and gender}} The impacts of climate change can be thought of in terms of sensitivity and vulnerability. ""Sensitivity"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be affected, positively or negatively, by climate change and/or [[climate change#Causes
column689: climate variability]]. ""Vulnerability"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be adversely affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
column694: 2007}}. </ref> The sensitivity of human society to climate change varies. Sectors sensitive to climate change include water resources, coastal zones, human settlements, and human health. Industries sensitive to climate change include [[climate change and agriculture
column701: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/008.htm#24 Sec. 2.4. Many Human Systems are Sensitive to Climate Change, and Some are Vulnerable] }}, in {{harvnb
column705: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column713: 2007–2008 world food price crisis}} Climate change will impact agriculture and food production around the world due to: the effects of elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere, higher temperatures, altered precipitation and [[transpiration]] regimes, increased frequency of extreme events, and modified [[weed]], [[pest (organism)
column716: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column718: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch5s5-4.html#5-4-1 5.4.1 Primary effects and interactions] }}, in {{harvnb
column721: p=282}}. </ref> In general, low-latitude areas are at most risk of having decreased crop yields.<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> As of 2007, the effects of regional climate change on agriculture have been small.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""> {{citation
column723: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column727: 2007}}. </ref> Changes in crop [[phenology]] provide important evidence of the response to recent regional climate change.<ref> {{citation
column729: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column731: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-6-1.html Sec. 1.3.6.1 Crops and livestock] }}, in {{harvnb
column733: 2007}}. </ref> Phenology is the study of natural phenomena that recur periodically, and how these phenomena relate to climate and seasonal changes.<ref> {{citation
column738: 2007}}. </ref> A significant advance in phenology has been observed for agriculture and forestry in large parts of the Northern Hemisphere.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> ====Projections==== [[File:Projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming.png
column743: Projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""> [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12877&page=161 Figure 5.1], p.161, in: Sec 5.1 FOOD PRODUCTION, PRICES, AND HUNGER, in: Ch 5: Impacts in the Next Few Decades and Coming Centuries, in: {{harvnb
column745: 2011}} </ref>]] [[File:Projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming.png
column750: Projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""/>]] With low to medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> projected that for about a 1 to 3 °C increase in global mean temperature (by the years 2090-2100, relative to average temperatures in the years 1990–2000), there would be productivity decreases for some [[cereal]]s in low latitudes, and productivity increases in high latitudes. With medium confidence, global production potential was projected to:<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> * increase up to around 3 °C, * very likely decrease above about 3 °C. Most of the studies on global agriculture assessed by Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> had not incorporated a number of critical factors, including changes in extreme events, or the spread of pests and diseases. Studies had also not considered the development of specific practices or technologies to aid [[adaptation to global warming#Agricultural production
column751: adaptation to climate change]].<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""> {{citation
column753: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column758: p=790}}. </ref> The graphs opposite show the projected effects of climate change on selected crop yields.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 text""> Sec 5.1 FOOD PRODUCTION, PRICES, AND HUNGER, [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12877&page=160 pp.160-162], in: Ch 5: Impacts in the Next Few Decades and Coming Centuries, in {{harvnb
column760: 2011}} </ref> Actual changes in yields may be above or below these central estimates.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 text""/> The projections above can be expressed relative to pre-industrial (1750) temperatures.<ref> {{citation
column762: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column764: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-1.html Box 19.2. Reference for temperature levels] }}, in {{harvnb
column767: p=783}}. </ref> 0.6 °C of warming is estimated to have occurred between 1750 and 1990-2000. Add 0.6 °C to the above projections to convert them from a 1990-2000 to pre-industrial baseline. =====Food security===== Easterling ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column769: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column771: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch5s5-6-5.html Sec. 5.6.5 Food security and vulnerability] }}, in {{harvnb
column773: 2007}}. </ref> assessed studies that made quantitative projections of climate change impacts on [[food security]]. It was noted that these projections were highly uncertain and had limitations. However, the assessed studies suggested a number of fairly robust findings. The first was that climate change would likely increase the number of people at risk of [[hunger]] compared with reference scenarios with no climate change. Climate change impacts depended strongly on projected future social and economic development. Additionally, the magnitude of climate change impacts was projected to be smaller compared to the impact of social and economic development. In 2006, the global estimate for the number of people [[malnutrition
column779: accessdate=2011-07-07 }} </ref> Under the SRES A1, B1, and B2 scenarios (see the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios#Scenario families
column780: SRES article]] for information on each scenario group), projections for the year 2080 showed a reduction in the number of people undernourished of about 560-700 million people, with a global total of undernourished people of 100-240 million in 2080. By contrast, the SRES A2 scenario showed only a small decrease in the risk of hunger from 2006 levels. The smaller reduction under A2 was attributed to the higher projected future population level in this scenario. ====Droughts and agriculture==== Some evidence suggests that droughts have been occurring more frequently because of global warming and they are expected to become more frequent and intense in Africa, southern Europe, the Middle East, most of the Americas, Australia, and Southeast Asia.<ref>{{cite doi
column781: 10.1002/wcc.81}}</ref> However, other research suggests that there has been little change in drought over the past 60 years.<ref>{{cite doi
column782: 10.1038/nature11575}}</ref> Their impacts are aggravated because of increased water demand, population growth, urban expansion, and environmental protection efforts in many areas.<ref>{{cite doi
column783: 10.1016/j.jhydrol.2011.03.049}}</ref> Droughts result in crop failures and the loss of pasture grazing land for livestock.<ref>{{cite doi
column785: Effects of global warming on human health}} Human beings are exposed to climate change through changing weather patterns (temperature, precipitation, sea-level rise and more frequent extreme events) and indirectly through changes in water, air and food quality and changes in ecosystems, agriculture, industry and settlements and the economy (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007:393).<ref name=""health summary""> {{citation
column791: 2007}}. </ref> According to an assessment of the scientific literature by Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007:393),<ref name=""health summary""/> the effects of climate change to date have been small, but are projected to progressively increase in all countries and regions. A study by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO, 2009)<ref> {{cite book
column794: title= Global health risks: mortality and burden of disease attributable to selected major risks
column802: url= http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/global_health_risks/en/index.html }} </ref> estimated the effect of climate change on human health. Not all of the effects of climate change were included in their estimates, for example, the effects of more frequent and extreme storms were excluded. Climate change was estimated to have been responsible for 3% of [[diarrhoea]], 3% of [[malaria]], and 3.8% of [[dengue fever]] deaths worldwide in 2004. Total attributable mortality was about 0.2% of deaths in 2004; of these, 85% were child deaths. ====Projections==== With high confidence, authors of the IPCC AR4 Synthesis report<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report""/>{{Rp
column804: date=November 2012}} projected that climate change would bring some benefits in temperate areas, such as fewer deaths from cold exposure, and some mixed effects such as changes in range and transmission potential of [[malaria]] in [[Africa]]. Benefits were projected to be outweighed by negative health effects of rising temperatures, especially in developing countries. With very high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/>{{Rp
column806: date=November 2012}} concluded that economic development was an important component of possible adaptation to climate change. Economic growth on its own, however, was not judged to be sufficient to insulate the world's population from disease and injury due to climate change. Future vulnerability to climate change will depend not only on the extent of social and economic change, but also on how the benefits and costs of change are distributed in society.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""> {{citation
column810: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-3-2.html Sec. 8.3.2 Future vulnerability to climate change] }}, in {{harvnb
column812: 2007}}. </ref> For example, in the 19th century, rapid [[urbanization]] in [[western Europe]] lead to a plummeting in population health.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""/> Other factors important in determining the health of populations include [[education]], the availability of health services, and [[public health
column820: Precipitation during the 20th century and up through 2008 during global warming, the [[NOAA]] estimating an observed trend over that period of 1.87% global precipitation increase per century.]] A number of climate-related trends have been observed that affect [[water resources]]. These include changes in precipitation, the crysosphere and [[surface water]]s (e.g., changes in [[river flows]]).<ref> {{citation
column822: chapter = Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column826: 2007}}. </ref> Observed and projected impacts of climate change on [[freshwater]] systems and their management are mainly due to changes in temperature, sea level and precipitation variability.<ref name=""freshwater impacts""> {{citation
column828: chapter= Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column830: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch3s3-es.html Sec. 3.3 Executive summary] }}, p. 175, in {{harvnb
column832: 2007}}. </ref> Sea level rise will extend areas of [[salinization]] of [[groundwater]] and [[estuary
column833: estuaries]], resulting in a decrease in freshwater availability for humans and ecosystems in coastal areas. In an assessment of the [[scientific literature]], Kundzewicz ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""freshwater impacts""/> concluded, with high confidence, that: * the negative impacts of climate change on freshwater systems outweigh the benefits. All of the regions assessed in the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]] ([[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], [[Europe]], [[Latin America]], [[North America]], [[Polar region]]s ([[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]]), and small islands) showed an overall net negative impact of climate change on water resources and freshwater ecosystems. * [[semi-arid climate
column834: Semi-arid]] and [[arid]] areas are particularly exposed to the impacts of climate change on freshwater. With very high confidence, it was judged that many of these areas, e.g., the [[Mediterranean basin]], [[Western United States]], [[Southern Africa]], and north-eastern [[Brazil]], would suffer a decrease in water resources due to climate change. ===Migration and conflict=== {{See also
column836: General circulation models]] project that the future climate change will bring wetter coasts, drier mid-continent areas, and further sea level rise.<ref name=""sar migration""> {{citation
column838: chapter= Chapter 12: Human settlements in a changing climate: impacts and adaptation
column839: at= Sec. 12.3.1 Population Migration }}, pp. 406—407, in {{harvnb
column841: 1996}}. </ref> Such changes could result in the gravest effects of climate change through sudden [[human migration]]. Millions might be displaced by [[shoreline erosion]]s, river and coastal [[flood]]ing, or severe [[drought]]. Migration related to climate change is likely to be predominantly from [[rural area]]s in [[developing countries]] to towns and [[cities]].<ref name=""sar migration""/>{{Rp
column845: title = Managing social risks: Empower communities to protect themselves
column846: chapter = Part One: Chapter 2: Reducing Human Vulnerability: Helping People Help Themselves
column849: 2010}}. </ref> In the short term climate stress is likely to add incrementally to existing migration patterns rather than generating entirely new flows of people.<ref name=""wdr migration""/>{{Rp
column851: date=November 2012}} It has been argued that environmental degradation, loss of access to resources (e.g., water resources),<ref> {{citation
column857: 2001}}. </ref> and resulting human migration could become a source of political and even [[military conflict]].<ref name=""tar migration""> {{citation
column859: chapter= Chapter 7: Human Settlements, Energy, and Industry
column863: 2001}}. </ref> Factors other than climate change may, however, be more important in affecting conflict. For example, Wilbanks ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column865: chapter = Chapter 7: Industry, settlement and society
column867: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-1.html Sec. 7.4.1 General effects: Box 7.2. Environmental migration] }}, in {{harvnb
column869: 2007}}. </ref> suggested that major environmentally influenced conflicts in Africa were more to do with the relative abundance of resources, e.g., [[oil]] and [[diamond]]s, than with resource scarcity. Scott ''et al.'' (2001) placed only low confidence in predictions of increased conflict due to climate change.<ref name=""tar migration""/> A 2013 study found that significant climatic changes were associated with a higher risk of conflict worldwide, and predicted that ""amplified rates of human conflict could represent a large and critical social impact of anthropogenic climate change in both low- and high-income countries.""<ref>{{cite journal
column870: author=Hsiang SM, Burke M, Miguel E
column871: title=Quantifying the influence of climate on human conflict
column879: url=}}</ref> Similarly, a 2014 study found that higher temperatures were associated with a greater likelihood of violent crime, and predicted that global warming would cause millions of such crimes in the United States alone during the 21st century. <ref>{{cite doi
column880: 10.1016/j.jeem.2013.11.008}}</ref> Military planners are concerned that global warming is a ""threat multiplier"". ""Whether it is poverty, food and water scarcity, diseases, economic instability, or threat of natural disasters, the broad range of changing climatic conditions may be far reaching. These challenges may threaten stability in much of the world"".<ref>{{cite journal
column885: journal =Proceedings of the US Naval Institute
column892: Economic impacts of climate change}} [[Aggregate data
column893: Aggregating]] impacts adds up the total impact of climate change across sectors and/or regions.<ref> [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/annexessglossary-a-d.html Glossary A-D: ""Aggregate impacts""], in {{harvnb
column896: p=76}} </ref> Examples of aggregate measures include [[Economic impacts of climate change#Distribution of impacts
column897: economic cost]] (e.g., changes in [[gross domestic product]] (GDP) and the [[Economic impacts of climate change#Marginal impacts
column898: social cost of carbon]]), changes in ecosystems (e.g., changes over land area from one type of vegetation to another),<ref> {{citation
column900: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column902: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/677.htm Sec. 19.5.3 Insights and Lessons: Vulnerability over Time: Table 19-5] }}, in {{harvnb
column904: 2001}}. </ref> human health impacts, and the number of people affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
column906: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column908: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/676.htm Sec. 19.5.2. Insights and Lessons: The Static Picture] }}, in {{harvnb
column910: 2001}}. </ref> Aggregate measures such as economic cost require researchers to make [[value judgement]]s over the importance of impacts occurring in different regions and at different times. ====Observed impacts==== Global losses reveal rapidly rising costs due to extreme weather-related events since the 1970s.<ref> {{citation
column912: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of observed changes and responses in natural and managed systems
column914: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-8-5.html Sec. 1.3.8.5 Summary of disasters and hazards] }}, in {{harvnb
column917: Socio-economic]] factors have contributed to the observed trend of global losses, e.g., population growth, increased [[wealth]].<ref name=""disaster losses""> {{citation
column923: 2001}}. </ref> Part of the growth is also related to regional climatic factors, e.g., changes in precipitation and flooding events. It is difficult to quantify the relative impact of socio-economic factors and climate change on the observed trend.<ref name=""disaster losses""/> The trend does, however, suggest increasing vulnerability of social systems to climate change.<ref name=""disaster losses""/><ref>[http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/billions Billion-Dollar Weather and Climate Disasters]</ref> ====Projected impacts==== The total economic impacts from climate change are highly uncertain.<ref> {{citation
column925: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column927: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-2-3.html Sec. 19.3.2.3 Aggregate market impacts] }}, p. 790, in {{harvnb
column929: 2007}}. </ref> With medium confidence, Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""> {{citation
column931: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column935: 2001}}. </ref> concluded that world GDP would change by plus or minus a few percent for a small increase in global mean temperature (up to around 2 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level). Most studies assessed by Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""/> projected losses in world GDP for a medium increase in global mean temperature (above 2-3 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level), with increasing losses for greater temperature increases. This assessment is consistent with the findings of more recent studies, as reviewed by Hitz and Smith (2004).<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""> {{citation
column937: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column939: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Sec. 19.3.7 Update on ‘Reasons for Concern’] }}, p. 796, in {{harvnb
column941: 2007}}. </ref> Economic impacts are expected to vary regionally.<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/><ref> {{citation
column943: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column945: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/675.htm Sec. 19.4.3. Distribution of Total Impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column947: 2001}}. </ref> For a medium increase in global mean temperature (2-3 °C of warming, relative to the average temperature between 1990–2000), market sectors in low-latitude and less-developed areas might experience net costs due to climate change.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> On the other hand, market sectors in high-latitude and developed regions might experience net benefits for this level of warming. A global mean temperature increase above about 2-3 °C (relative to 1990-2000) would very likely result in market sectors across all regions experiencing either declines in net benefits or rises in net costs.<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> Aggregate impacts have also been quantified in non-economic terms. For example, climate change over the 21st century is likely to adversely affect hundreds of millions of people through increased coastal flooding, reductions in water supplies, increased malnutrition and increased health impacts.<ref name=""ar4 synthesis reasons for concern""/> ==Biological systems== {{Main
column950: Effect of climate change on plant biodiversity
column951: Effects of climate change on terrestrial animals
column952: Effects of climate change on marine mammals}} ===Observed impacts on biological systems=== [[File:A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming (low-res).png
column956: A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming.<ref name=""nasa briefs""> {{cite web
column959: title=Science Briefs: Warming Climate is Changing Life on Global Scale
column960: publisher=Website of the US National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Goddard Institute for Space Studies
column962: accessdate=2011-07-08}} </ref>]] With very high confidence, Rosenzweig ''et al.'' (2007) concluded that recent warming had strongly affected natural biological systems.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> Hundreds of studies have documented responses of [[ecosystem]]s, [[plant]]s, and [[animal]]s to the climate changes that have already occurred.<ref> {{cite book
column964: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column969: page = 14 }} </ref> For example, in the Northern Hemisphere, species are almost uniformly moving their ranges northward and up in elevation in search of cooler temperatures.<ref name=""nrc 2008b observed ecosystem impacts""> {{cite book
column971: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column976: page = 16 }} </ref> Humans are very likely causing changes in regional temperatures to which plants and animals are responding.<ref name=""nrc 2008b observed ecosystem impacts""/> ===Projected impacts on biological systems=== By the year 2100, ecosystems will be exposed to atmospheric {{chem
column978: 2}} levels substantially higher than in the past 650,000 years, and global temperatures at least among the highest of those experienced in the past 740,000 years.<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""> {{citation
column980: chapter= Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column984: 2007}}. </ref> Significant disruptions of ecosystems are projected to increase with future climate change.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""> {{citation
column990: 2001}}. </ref> Examples of disruptions include disturbances such as fire, drought, pest [[infestation]], invasion of species, storms, and [[coral bleaching]] events. The stresses caused by climate change, added to other stresses on ecological systems (e.g., land conversion, [[land degradation]], [[harvest]]ing, and [[pollution]]), threaten substantial damage to or complete loss of some unique ecosystems, and [[extinction]] of some critically endangered species.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""/><ref>Van Riper, Charles. (2014) [http://purl.fdlp.gov/GPO/gpo50857 Projecting Climate Effects on Birds and Reptiles of the Southwestern United States.] Reston, Va.: [[United States Department of the Interior
column991: U.S. Department of the Interior]], [[United States Geological Survey
column992: U.S. Geological Survey]].</ref> Climate change has been estimated to be a major driver of [[biodiversity]] loss in cool [[conifer]] forests, [[savanna]]s, [[mediterranean climate
column993: mediterranean-climate]] systems, [[tropical forest]]s, in the [[Arctic tundra]], and in [[coral reef]]s.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""> {{citation
column995: chapter= Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column997: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch4s4-4-11.html Sec. 4.4.11 Global synthesis including impacts on biodiversity] }}, in {{harvnb
column1000: land-use]] change may be a stronger driver of biodiversity loss at least in the near-term.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> Beyond the year 2050, climate change may be the major driver for biodiversity loss globally.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> A literature assessment by Fischlin ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""/> included a quantitative estimate of the number of species at increased risk of extinction due to climate change. With medium confidence, it was projected that approximately 20 to 30% of plant and animal species assessed so far (in an unbiased [[Sampling (statistics)
column1001: sample]]) would likely be at increasingly high risk of extinction should global mean temperatures exceed a warming of 2 to 3 °C above pre-industrial temperature levels.<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""/> The uncertainties in this estimate, however, are large: for a rise of about 2 °C the percentage may be as low as 10%, or for about 3 °C, as high as 40%, and depending on [[Biota (ecology)
column1002: biota]] (all living [[organism]]s of an area, the [[flora]] and [[fauna]] considered as a unit)<ref> {{citation
column1007: 2007}}. </ref> the range is between 1% and 80%.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> As global average temperature exceeds [[4 Degrees and Beyond International Climate Conference
column1008: 4 °C]] above pre-industrial levels, model projections suggested that there could be significant extinctions (40-70% of species that were assessed) around the globe.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> Assessing whether future changes in ecosystems will be beneficial or detrimental is largely based on how ecosystems are valued by human society.<ref> {{citation
column1011: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column1015: 2008b}}. </ref> For increases in global average temperature exceeding 1.5 to 2.5 °C (relative to global temperatures over the years 1980-1999)<ref> {{citation
column1017: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column1019: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3.html Sec. 3.3 Impacts of future climate changes] }}, in {{harvnb
column1023: 2}} concentrations, projected changes in ecosystems will have predominantly negative consequences for biodiversity and ecosystems goods and [[ecosystem services
column1024: services]], e.g., water and food supply.<ref> {{citation
column1026: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column1028: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-1.html Sec. 3.3.1 Impacts on systems and sectors: Ecosystems] }}, in {{harvnb
column1030: 2007}}. </ref> ==Abrupt or irreversible changes== Physical, ecological and social systems may respond in an abrupt, [[non-linear]] or irregular way to climate change.<ref name=""singularities""> {{citation
column1032: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1034: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/679.htm Sec. 19.6.1. The Irregular Face of Climate Change] }}, in {{harvnb
column1036: 2001}}. </ref> This is as opposed to a smooth or regular response. A quantitative entity behaves ""irregularly"" when its [[system dynamics
column1038: discontinuous]] (i.e., not smooth), nondifferentiable, unbounded, wildly varying, or otherwise ill-defined.<ref name=""singularities""/> Such behaviour is often termed ""[[Mathematical singularity
column1039: singular]]"". Irregular behaviour in Earth systems may give rise to certain thresholds, which, when crossed, may lead to a large change in the system. Some singularities could potentially lead to severe impacts at regional or global scales.<ref name=""white et al singularities""> {{citation
column1043: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/052.htm Sec. 7.2.5, Large-Scale Singular Events] }}, in {{harvnb
column1045: 2001}}. </ref> Examples of ""large-scale"" singularities are discussed in the articles on [[abrupt climate change]], [[climate change feedback]] and [[runaway climate change]]. It is possible that human-induced climate change could trigger large-scale singularities, but the probabilities of triggering such events are, for the most part,<ref> ""[F]or the most part"" refers to improved scientific understanding of singularities since the assessment by White ''et al.'' (2001). See: {{citation
column1047: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1049: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Sec. 19.3.7 Update on ‘Reasons for Concern’] }}, in {{harvnb
column1051: 2007}}. </ref> poorly understood.<ref name=""white et al singularities""/> With low to medium confidence, Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""singularities""> {{citation
column1053: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1057: 2001}}. </ref> concluded that a rapid warming of more than 3 °C above 1990 levels would exceed thresholds that would lead to large-scale discontinuities in the climate system. Since the assessment by Smith ''et al.'' (2001), improved scientific understanding provides more guidance for two large-scale singularities: the role of [[carbon cycle]] feedbacks in future climate change (discussed below in the section on biogeochemical cycles) and the melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column1058: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s.<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/> ===Biogeochemical cycles=== {{See also
column1059: climate change feedback}} Climate change may have an effect on the [[carbon cycle]] in an interactive ""feedback"" process. A feedback exists where an initial process triggers changes in a second process that in turn influences the initial process. A positive feedback intensifies the original process, and a negative feedback reduces it.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report""> {{harvnb
column1063: date=November 2012}} Models suggest that the interaction of the climate system and the carbon cycle is one where the feedback effect is positive.<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""> {{citation
column1065: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1071: date=November 2012}} Using the A2 SRES emissions scenario, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""/>{{Rp
column1073: date=November 2012}} found that this effect led to additional warming by the years 2090-2100 (relative to the 1990–2000) of 0.1–1.5 °C. This estimate was made with high confidence. The climate projections made in the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report summarized earlier of 1.1–6.4 °C account for this feedback effect. On the other hand, with medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""/>{{Rp
column1075: date=November 2012}} commented that additional releases of GHGs were possible from permafrost, peat lands, wetlands, and large stores of marine hydrates at high latitudes. ===Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets=== With medium confidence, authors of AR4<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""> {{citation
column1081: 2007}}. </ref> concluded that with a global average temperature increase of 1–4 °C (relative to temperatures over the years 1990–2000), at least a partial deglaciation of the [[Greenland ice sheet]], and possibly the [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s would occur. The estimated timescale for partial deglaciation was centuries to millennia, and would contribute {{convert
column1085: m}} or more to sea level rise over this period. ===The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation=== {{See also
column1088: This map shows the general location and direction of the warm surface (red) and cold deep water (blue) currents of the [[thermohaline circulation]]. [[Salinity]] is represented by color in units of the Practical Salinity Scale. Low values (blue) are less saline, while high values (orange) are more saline.<ref> {{cite web
column1090: author=Riebeek, H.. design by R. Simmon
column1091: title=Paleoclimatology: Explaining the Evidence: Explaining Rapid Climate Change: Tales from the Ice
column1097: right]] The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is an important component of the Earth's climate system, characterized by a northward flow of warm, salty water in the upper layers of the [[Atlantic ocean
column1098: Atlantic]] and a southward flow of colder water in the deep Atlantic.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""> {{cite book
column1101: title= Abrupt Climate Change. A report by the US Climate Change Science Program (CCSP) and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column1106: date=November 2012}} The AMOC is equivalently known as the [[thermohaline circulation]] (THC).<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/> Potential impacts associated with MOC changes include reduced warming or (in the case of abrupt change) absolute cooling of northern high-latitude areas near [[Greenland]] and north-western Europe, an increased warming of [[Southern Hemisphere]] high-latitudes, tropical drying, as well as changes to [[marine ecosystem]]s, terrestrial vegetation, oceanic {{chem
column1108: 2}} uptake, oceanic oxygen concentrations, and shifts in fisheries.<ref> {{citation
column1110: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1112: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-5-3.html Sec. 19.3.5.3 Possible changes in the North Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (MOC)] }}, in {{harvnb
column1114: 2007}}. </ref> According to an assessment by the US [[Climate Change Science Program]] (CCSP, 2008b),<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1116: date=November 2012}} it is very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1118: date=November 2012}} that the strength of the AMOC will decrease over the course of the 21st century. Warming is still expected to occur over most of the European region downstream of the [[North Atlantic Current]] in response to increasing GHGs, as well as over [[North America]]. Although it is very unlikely (less than 10% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1120: date=November 2012}} that the AMOC will collapse in the 21st century, the potential consequences of such a collapse could be severe.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1122: date=November 2012}} ===Irreversibilities=== ====Commitment to radiative forcing==== Emissions of GHGs are a potentially irreversible commitment to sustained [[radiative forcing]] in the future.<ref name=""albritton irreversible radiative forcing""> {{citation
column1126: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc%5Ftar/wg1/016.htm Sec. C.1 Observed Changes in Globally Well-Mixed Greenhouse Gas Concentrations and Radiative Forcing] }}, p. 38, in {{harvnb
column1128: 2001}}. </ref> The contribution of a GHG to radiative forcing depends on the gas's ability to trap [[infrared]] (heat) radiation, the concentration of the gas in the atmosphere, and the length of time the gas resides in the atmosphere.<ref name=""albritton irreversible radiative forcing""/> {{chem
column1130: 2}} is the most important anthropogenic GHG.<ref name=""ipcc 2007 causes of climate change""> {{citation
column1134: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms2.html Sec. 2. Causes of change] }}, p. 5, in {{harvnb
column1136: 2007}}. </ref> While more than half of the {{chem
column1138: 2}} emitted is currently removed from the atmosphere within a century, some fraction (about 20%) of emitted {{chem
column1140: 2}} remains in the atmosphere for many thousands of years.<ref> {{cite book
column1144: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-10-3.html Frequently Asked Question 10.3: If Emissions of Greenhouse Gases are Reduced, How Quickly do Their Concentrations in the Atmosphere Decrease?]
column1149: 2}} emitted today is potentially an irreversible commitment to sustained radiative forcing over thousands of years. This commitment may not be truly irreversible should techniques be developed to remove {{chem
column1151: 2}} or other GHGs directly from the atmosphere, or to block sunlight to induce cooling.<ref name=""solomon irreversible climate change""> {{cite journal
column1154: title=Irreversible climate change due to carbon dioxide emissions
column1155: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (PNAS)
column1165: display-authors=etal}}</ref> Techniques of this sort are referred to as [[climate engineering
column1166: geoengineering]]. Little is known about the effectiveness, costs or potential [[Unintended consequences
column1167: side-effects]] of geoengineering options.<ref name=""barker geoengineering""> {{citation
column1169: chapter= Chapter 11: Mitigation from a cross-sectoral perspective
column1171: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/ch11s11-es.html Executive summary - Unconventional options] }} , in {{harvnb
column1173: 2007}}. </ref> Some geoengineering options, such as blocking sunlight, would not prevent further [[ocean acidification]].<ref name=""barker geoengineering""/> ====Irreversible impacts==== Human-induced climate change may lead to irreversible impacts on physical, biological, and social systems.<ref> {{citation
column1179: 2001}}. <!-- XX Needs checking. --> </ref> There are a number of examples of climate change impacts that may be irreversible, at least over the timescale of many human generations.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""> {{citation
column1181: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1183: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-2.html Sec.19.2 Criteria for selecting ‘key’ vulnerabilities: Persistence and reversibility] }}, in {{harvnb
column1185: 2007}}. </ref> These include the large-scale singularities described above – changes in carbon cycle feedbacks, the melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, and changes to the AMOC.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In biological systems, the extinction of species would be an irreversible impact.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In social systems, unique [[culture]]s may be lost due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> For example, humans living on [[atoll]] islands face risks due to sea-level rise, sea-surface warming, and increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.<ref> {{cite journal
column1194: doi=10.1023/b:clim.0000004559.08755.88 }} This paper was published in 2001 as [http://www.tyndall.ac.uk/sites/default/files/wp9.pdf Tyndall Centre Working Paper 9] </ref> ==Scientific opinion== The [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC) has published several major assessments on the effects of global warming.<ref> {{harvnb
column1197: pp=4-7}} </ref> Its most recent comprehensive impact assessment was published in 2014.<ref> {{harvnb
column1199: 2014}} </ref> Publications describing the effects of climate change have also been produced by the following organizations: *[[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] (AAAS)<ref> {{harvnb
column1202: n.d.}} </ref> *A report by the [[Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency]], the [[Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute]], and [[Wageningen University and Research Centre]]<ref> {{harvnb
column1210: 2013}} for other AVOID publications. </ref> *A report by the UK [[Royal Society]] and [[US National Academy of Sciences]]<ref> {{harvnb
column1213: 2014}} </ref> *[[University of New South Wales]] Climate Change Research Centre<ref> {{harvnb
column1220: 2011}} </ref> A report by Molina ''et al.'' (no date)<ref> {{harvnb
column1224:
p=3}} states:
The overwhelming evidence of human-caused climate change documents both current impacts with significant costs and extraordinary future risks to society and natural systems
===NASA data and tools=== NASA has released public data and tools to predict how temperature and rainfall patterns worldwide may change through to the year 2100 caused by increasing carbon dioxide in Earth’s atmosphere. The dataset, shows projected changes worldwide on a regional level simulated by 21 climate models. The data can be viewed on a daily timescale for individual cities and towns and may be used to conduct climate risk assessments to predict the local and global effects of weather dangers, for example droughts, floods, heat waves and declines in agriculture productivity, and help plan responses to global warming effects. {{Cite web
column1225: title = NASA Releases Detailed Global Climate Change Projections
column1227: accessdate = 2015-06-09}}</ref> == See also == {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ; General * [[4 Degrees and Beyond International Climate Conference]] * [[Anthropocene]] * [[Risks to civilization, humans and planet Earth]] * [[Indigenous Peoples Climate Change Assessment Initiative]] * [[Environmental sociology]] ; Regional * [[Arctic Climate Impact Assessment]] * [[Effects of global warming on Australia]] * [[Effects of global warming on India]] * [[Kivalina v. ExxonMobil Corporation]] * [[Climate Change Science Program#Impacts and adaptation
column1228: Bush Administration assessments of impacts and adaptation]] (United States) {{Col-break}} {{Portal
column1231: Environment}} * [[Biological pump]] * [[Climate Vulnerability Monitor]] (CVM) * [[Oceanic anoxic event]] * [[PRECIS (Providing Regional Climates for Impacts Studies)]] * [[Solubility pump]] {{Col-end}} {{Clear}} ==Footnotes== <sup>1</sup> The TAR<ref name=""Uncertainty in the TAR""> {{citation
column1237: 2001}}. </ref> and AR4<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> that are referred to in this article use specific and quantitative language to describe uncertainty. This language is intended to provide an indication of the level of confidence that IPCC authors have about a particular finding. The qualitative language used to describe uncertainty has a quantitative scale associated with it. The quantitative values for qualitative terms are intended to ensure that confidence levels are interpreted correctly. The is because qualitative statements, e.g., using the word ""likely"", can be interpreted differently in quantitative terms.<ref> {{citation
column1244: title= IPCC supporting material: guidance papers on the cross cutting issues of the Third Assessment Report of the IPCC
column1245: editor= R. Pachuari, T. Taniguchi and K. Tanaka, (eds.)
column1247: publisher= Global Industrial and Social Progress Research Institute (GISPRI)
column1251: date=November 2012}} Confidence levels used in the TAR:<ref> {{citation
column1255: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/023.htm#14 Box 2. Confidence Levels and State of Knowledge] }}, in {{harvnb
column1257: 2001}}. </ref> * Very High = 95% or greater * High = 67-95% * Medium = 33-67% * Low = 5-33% * Very Low = 5% or less Confidence statements made in AR4 are listed below:<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> * Very high confidence: At least 9 out of 10 chance of being correct * High confidence: About 8 out of 10 chance "" "" "" * Medium confidence: About 5 out of 10 chance "" "" "" * Low confidence: About 2 out of 10 chance "" "" "" * Very low confidence: Less than a 1 out of 10 chance "" "" "" IPCC (2012)<ref> {{citation
column1262: p=19}} </ref> uses the following terms: ""very low"", ""low"", ""medium"", ""high"", and ""very high confidence"". Unlike the TAR and AR4, the scale is qualitative rather than quantitative. The quantitative values used by IPCC authors are ""subjective"" probabilities,<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/><ref name=""Uncertainty in the TAR""/><ref> {{citation
column1266: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/106.htm Sec. 2.6.2. ""Objective"" and ""Subjective"" Probabilities are not Always Explicitly Distinguished] }}, in {{harvnb
column1269: Bayesian]]"" probabilities,<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""> {{cite book
column1271: author= Granger Morgan, M. (Lead Author), H. Dowlatabadi, M. Henrion, D. Keith, R. Lempert, S. McBride, M. Small and T. Wilbanks (Contributing Authors)
column1272: title= Synthesis and Assessment Product 5.2: Best practice approaches for characterizing, communicating, and incorporating scientific uncertainty in decisionmaking. A Report by the U.S. Climate Change Science Program and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column1273: publisher= National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
column1276: url= http://www.globalchange.gov/publications/reports/scientific-assessments/saps/311 }} Tables 2.1 and 2.2 on pages 27-28 show two quantitative scales of uncertainty which are used in the TAR and AR4.</ref> and reflect the expert judgement of IPCC authors. In this formulation, probability is not only a function of an event, but also the state of information that is available to the person making the assessment.<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""/> In this framework, assigned probabilities may change as more or different information becomes available.<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""/> The IPCC also uses another scale to describe the likelihood of a particular event occurring.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> This is different from the confidence scales described above, and it is possible to assign confidence values to statements of likelihood. For example, the judgement that an event is improbable (e.g., rolling a [[dice]] twice and getting a six both times) may be assigned a high level of scientific confidence.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> Also, the probability that an event has an even chance of occurring (e.g., a tossed [[coin]] coming up heads) may also be assigned a high level of confidence.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> == Notes == {{Reflist

column2: This article is primarily about effects during the 21st century. For longer-term effects, see [[Long-term effects of global warming]]. See also [[Effects of global warming on humans]].}} {{Pp-semi-protected
column6: alt=Refer to caption and image description
column7: Summary of climate change impacts.]] [[File:Projected global warming in 2100 for a range of emission scenarios.png
column10: alt=Refer to caption and image description
column11: Projected global warming in 2100 for a range of emission scenarios.]] The '''effects of [[global warming]]''' are the environmental and social changes caused (directly or indirectly) by human emissions of [[greenhouse gas]]es. There is [[scientific opinion on climate change
column12: a scientific consensus that climate change is occurring]], and that human activities are the primary driver.<ref> {{citation
column13: author=Joint-statement by leaders of 18 scientific organizations: American Association for the Advancement of Science, American Chemical Society, American Geophysical Union, American Institute of Biological Sciences, American Meteorological Society, American Society of Agronomy, American Society of Plant Biologists, American Statistical Association, Association of Ecosystem Research Centers, Botanical Society of America, Crop Science Society of America, Ecological Society of America, Natural Science Collections, Alliance Organization of Biological Field Stations, Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, [[Society of Systematic Biologists]], Soil Science Society of America, University Corporation for Atmospheric Research
column15: title=Joint-statement on climate change by leaders of 18 scientific organizations
column18: publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science
column19: location=Washington DC, USA }}. Archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20140714124825/http://www.aaas.org/sites/default/files/content_files/1021climate_letter.pdf 14 July 2014]. </ref> Many impacts of climate change have already been observed, including [[Retreat of glaciers since 1850
column20: glacier retreat]],<ref name=""cramer observed effects"">Cramer, W., ''et al.'', Executive summary, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap18_FINAL.pdf Chapter 18: Detection and attribution of observed impacts] (archived [http://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap18_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), pp.982-984, in {{harvnb
column22: 2014}} </ref> changes in the timing of seasonal events<ref name=""cramer observed effects""/> (e.g., earlier flowering of plants),<ref>Settele, J., ''et al.'', Section 4.3.2.1: Phenology, in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap4_FINAL.pdf Chapter 4: Terrestrial and inland water systems] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap4_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), p.291, in {{harvnb
column24: 2014}} </ref> and changes in agricultural productivity.<ref name=""cramer observed effects""/> Future effects of climate change will vary depending on [[Individual and political action on climate change
column25: climate change policies]]<ref name=""adaptation and mitigation"">Oppenheimer, M., ''et al.'', ''Section 19.7.1: Relationship between Adaptation Efforts, Mitigation Efforts, and Residual Impacts,'' in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf Chapter 19: Emergent risks and key vulnerabilities] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1080-1085, in {{harvnb
column27: 2014}} </ref> and [[social development]].<ref>Oppenheimer, M., ''et al.'', ''Section 19.6.2.2. The Role of Adaptation and Alternative Development Pathways,'' in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf Chapter 19: Emergent risks and key vulnerabilities] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1072-1073, in {{harvnb
column29: 2014}} </ref> The two main policies to address climate change are reducing human greenhouse gas emissions ([[climate change mitigation]]) and [[climate change adaptation
column30: adapting to the impacts]] of climate change.<ref name=""climate change policy"">Denton, F., ''et al.'', ''Section 20.3. Contributions to Resilience through Climate Change Responses,'' in: [http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg2/WGIIAR5-Chap20_FINAL.pdf Chapter Climate-resilient pathways: adaptation, mitigation, and sustainable development] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap20_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1113-1118, in {{harvnb
column33: Geoengineering]] is another policy option.<ref name=""climate change policy""/> Near-term climate change policies could significantly affect long-term climate change impacts.<ref name=""adaptation and mitigation""/><ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Section A-3. The Decision-making Context, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [http://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.55, in {{harvnb
column35: 2014}} </ref> Stringent mitigation policies might be able to limit global warming (in 2100) to around 2 [[°C]] or below, relative to pre-industrial levels.<ref>SPM.4.1 Long‐term mitigation pathways, in: [http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf Summary for Policymakers], pp.11-15 (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20140702014732/http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf 2 July 2014)], in {{harvnb
column37: 2014}} </ref> Without mitigation, increased [[energy demand]] and extensive use of [[fossil fuel]]s<ref> Clarke, L., ''et al.'', Section 6.3.1.3 Baseline emissions projections from fossil fuels and industry (pp.17-18 of final draft), in: [http://report.mitigation2014.org/drafts/final-draft-postplenary/ipcc_wg3_ar5_final-draft_postplenary_chapter6.pdf Chapter 6: Assessing Transformation Pathways] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020021617/http://report.mitigation2014.org/drafts/final-draft-postplenary/ipcc_wg3_ar5_final-draft_postplenary_chapter6.pdf 20 October 2014]), in: {{harvnb
column39: 2014}} </ref> might lead to global warming of around 4 °C.<ref> Greenhouse Gas Concentrations and Climate Implications, p.14, in {{harvnb
column42: 2014}}. The range given by Prinn and Reilly is 3.3 to 5.5 °C, with a median of 3.9 °C. </ref><ref>SPM.3 Trends in stocks and flows of greenhouse gases and their drivers, in: [http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf Summary for Policymakers], p.8 (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20140702014732/http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf 2 July 2014)], in {{harvnb
column44: 2014}}. The range given by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change is 3.7 to 4.8 °C, relative to pre-industrial levels (2.5 to 7.8 °C including climate uncertainty). </ref> Higher magnitudes of global warming would be more difficult to adapt to,<ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Box TS.8: Adaptation Limits and Transformation, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [http://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.89, in {{harvnb
column46: 2014}} </ref> and would increase the risk of negative impacts.<ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Section B-1. Key Risks across Sectors and Regions, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [http://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.62, in {{harvnb
column49: attribution of recent climate change}} In this article, ""[[climate change]]"" means a change in climate that persists over a sustained period of time.<ref name=""ipcc definition of climate change""> {{citation
column57: at=Click on the image to open a pop-up that explains the differences between climate change and global warming.
column60: publisher=US EPA }} </ref> The [[World Meteorological Organization]] defines this time period as 30 years.<ref name=""ipcc definition of climate change""/> Examples of climate change include increases in global surface temperature (global warming), changes in [[rainfall]] patterns, and changes in the frequency of [[extreme weather]] events. Changes in climate may be due to natural causes, e.g., changes in the [[sun]]'s output, or due to human activities, e.g., changing the composition of the atmosphere.<ref name=""albritton climate change""/> Any human-induced changes in climate will occur against a background of natural climatic variations<ref name=""albritton climate change""> {{citation
column65: title=Box 1: What drives changes in climate?
column68: 2001}} </ref> and of variations in human activity such as population growth on shores or in arid areas which increase or decrease climate vulnerability.<ref name='NatureTaboo'>{{cite journal
column69: title = Lifting the taboo on adaptation
column83: doi=10.1038/445597a}}</ref> Also, the term ""anthropogenic forcing"" refers to the influence exerted on a habitat or chemical environment by humans, as opposed to a natural process.<ref> {{cite web
column85: title=Definition of Anthropogenic Forcing – Chemistry Dictionary and Glossary }} </ref> ==Temperature changes== {{Multiple image
column89: alt1=Global mean surface temperature change since 1880, relative to the 1951–1980 mean, showing a long term warming trend.
column90: image2= Projected global warming over the 21st century using three SRES greenhouse gas emissions scenarios. Data from CMIP3 (2007).png
column93: caption1=Global mean surface temperature change since 1880, relative to the 1951–1980 mean. Source: [http://data.giss.nasa.gov/gistemp/ NASA GISS]
column94: caption2=The graph above shows the average of a set of temperature simulations for the 20th century (black line), followed by projected temperatures for the 21st century based on three greenhouse gas emissions scenarios (colored lines).<ref name=""herring temperature projections""> {{cite web
column99: url= http://www.climatewatch.noaa.gov/article/2012/global-temperature-projections }} </ref> }} This article breaks down some of the impacts of climate change according to different levels of future global warming. This way of describing impacts has, for instance, been used in the IPCC ([[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]]) Assessment Reports on climate change.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""> {{citation
column101: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column106: 2007}}. </ref> The instrumental [[temperature record]] shows global warming of around 0.6 °C during the 20th century.<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""/> ===SRES emissions scenarios=== The future level of global warming is uncertain, but a wide range of estimates (projections) have been made.<ref name=""Overview of GHG emissions scenarios""> {{citation
column108: chapter= Chapter 3: Issues related to mitigation in the long-term context
column113: 2007}} </ref> The IPCC's ""[[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column114: SRES]]"" scenarios have been frequently used to make [[Global climate model#Projections of future climate change
column115: projections of future climate change]].<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column117: date=November 2012}} The SRES scenarios are ""[[Economics of climate change mitigation#Baselines
column118: baseline]]"" (or ""reference"") scenarios, which means that they do not take into account any current or future measures to limit GHG emissions (e.g., the UNFCCC's [[Kyoto Protocol]] and the [[2010 United Nations Climate Change Conference
