column121: chapter= Chapter 2, Greenhouse Gas Emission Mitigation Scenarios and Implications
column123: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/080.htm Sec. 2.5.1.1 IPCC Emissions Scenarios and the SRES Process]
column126: 2001}}. </ref> Emissions projections of the SRES scenarios are broadly comparable in range to the baseline emissions scenarios that have been developed by the scientific community.<ref name=""Overview of GHG emissions scenarios""/><ref> {{citation
column132: 2007}}. </ref> In the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]], changes in future global mean temperature were projected using the six SRES ""marker"" emissions scenarios.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""> {{citation
column136: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html#table-spm-1 Sec. 1 3. Projected climate change and its impacts: Table SPM.1] }}, in {{harvnb
column138: 2007}}. </ref> Emissions projections for the six SRES ""marker"" scenarios are representative of the full set of forty SRES scenarios.<ref> {{citation
column140: chapter= Chapter 2, Greenhouse Gas Emission Mitigation Scenarios and Implications
column142: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/081.htm#2514 Sec. 2.5.1.4 Emissions and Other Results of the SRES Scenarios]
column145: 2001}}. </ref> For the lowest emissions SRES marker scenario (""B1"" - see the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column146: SRES]] article for details on this scenario), the best estimate for global mean temperature is an increase of {{convert
column150: 1}}<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> by the end of the 21st century. This projection is relative to global temperatures at the end of the 20th century.<ref>Temperature change in years 2090-2099 relative to years 1980-1999</ref> The ""likely"" range (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> for the SRES B1 marker scenario is {{convert
column156: 1}}.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> For the highest emissions SRES marker scenario (A1FI), the best estimate for global mean temperature increase is {{convert
column166: 1}}.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> The range in temperature projections partly reflects (1) the choice of [[economics of global warming#Emissions scenarios
column167: emissions scenario]], and (2) the ""[[climate sensitivity]]"".<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column169: date=November 2012}} For (1), different scenarios make different assumptions of future social and economic development (e.g., [[economic growth]], [[population projection
column171: energy policies]]), which in turn affects projections of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column173: date=November 2012}} The projected magnitude of warming by 2100 is closely related to the level of cumulative emissions over the 21st century (i.e. total emissions between 2000-2100).<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions""> {{citation
column176: chapter=Ch 2: Which emissions pathways are consistent with a {{val
column180: u=°C}} temperature limit?: Sec 2.2 What determines long-term temperature?
column181: title=The Emissions Gap Report: Are the Copenhagen Accord pledges sufficient to limit global warming to {{val
column188: publisher=UNEP }}, p.28. This publication is also available in [http://www.unep.org/publications/ebooks/emissionsgapreport/ e-book format] </ref> The higher the cumulative emissions over this time period, the greater the level of warming is projected to occur.<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions""/> (2) reflects uncertainty in the response of the climate system to past and future GHG emissions, which is measured by the [[climate sensitivity]]).<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column190: date=November 2012}} Higher estimates of climate sensitivity lead to greater projected warming, while lower estimates of climate sensitivity lead to less projected warming.<ref> {{citation
column191: chapter=Box 8.1 Likelihood of exceeding a temperature increase at equilibrium, in: Ch 8: The Challenge of Stabilisation
column195: p=195}} </ref> Over the next several millennia, projections suggest that global warming could be irreversible.<ref name=""solomon irreversible climate change""/> Even if emissions were drastically reduced, global temperatures would remain close to their highest level for at least 1,000 years (see the later section on [[effects of global warming#Irreversibilities
column202: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-7-2.html Sec 10.7.2 Climate Change Commitment to Year 3000 and Beyond to Equilibrium]
column213: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column214: Two millennia of mean surface temperatures according to different reconstructions from [[Proxy (climate)
column215: climate proxies]], each smoothed on a decadal scale, with the [[instrumental temperature record]] overlaid in black.]]
column216: [[File:Global temperature relative to peak Holocene temperature, based on ocean cores (NASA).png
column220: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column221: Global surface temperature for the past 5.3 million years as inferred from cores of ocean [[sediment]]s taken all around the global ocean. The last 800,000 years are expanded in the lower half of the figure (image credit: [[NASA]]).<ref name=""hansen climate history""/>]]
column222: } Scientists have used various ""proxy"" data to assess past changes in Earth's climate ([[paleoclimate]]).<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""> {{citation
column224: title=NOAA Paleoclimatology Global Warming - The Story: Proxy Data
column227: publisher=NOAA Paleoclimatology Program - NCDC Paleoclimatology Branch }} </ref> Sources of proxy data include historical records (such as [[farmer]]s' logs), [[tree ring]]s, [[coral]]s, [[fossil pollen]], [[ice core]]s, and ocean and lake [[sediment]]s.<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""/> Analysis of these data suggest that recent warming is unusual in the past 400 years, possibly longer.<ref> {{citation
column230: title=Surface Temperature Reconstructions for the Last 2,000 Years
column233: author=Committee on Surface Temperature Reconstructions for the Last 2,000 Years, US National Research Council
column235: isbn=0-309-66144-7 }}, p.3 </ref> By the end of the 21st century, temperatures may increase to a level not experienced since the mid-[[Pliocene]], around 3 million years ago.<ref name=""jansen pliocene""> {{citation
column239: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch6s6-3-2.html Sec. 6.3.2 What Does the Record of the Mid-Pliocene Show?]
column242: 2007}}. </ref> At that time, models suggest that mean global temperatures were about 2–3 °C warmer than pre-industrial temperatures.<ref name=""jansen pliocene""/> Even a 2 °C rise above the pre-industrial level would be outside the range of temperatures experienced by human [[civilization]].<ref name=""hansen climate history""> {{citation
column246: title=NASA GISS: Science Briefs: Earth's Climate History: Implications for Tomorrow
column248: location=New York City, New York, USA
column250: at=[http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/686.htm Footnote 4, in Sec 19.8.2. What does Each Reason for Concern Indicate?]
column251: chapter=Ch 19. Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column259: [[File:Diagram showing ten indicators of global warming.png
column263: alt=Refer to caption and adjacent text
column264: Seven of these indicators would be expected to increase in a warming world and observations show that they are, in fact, increasing. Three would be expected to decrease and they are, in fact, decreasing.<ref> {{harvnb
column268: } [[File:Changes in climate indicators that show global warming.png
column273: This set of graphs show changes in climate indicators over several decades. Each of the different colored lines in each panel represents an independently analyzed set of data. The data come from many different technologies including [[weather station]]s, [[satellite]]s, [[weather balloons]], [[ship]]s and [[buoy]]s.<ref> {{harvnb
column276: p=3}} </ref>]] A broad range of evidence shows that the climate system has warmed.<ref> {{citation
column283: 2007}}. </ref> Evidence of global warming is shown in the graphs opposite. Some of the graphs show a positive [[trend estimation
column284: trend]], e.g., increasing temperature over land and the ocean, and [[current sea level rise
column285: sea level rise]]. Other graphs show a negative trend, e.g., decreased [[snow]] cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]], and declining [[Arctic sea ice]] extent. Evidence of warming is also apparent in living [[Effects of global warming#Observed impacts on biological systems
column286: (biological) systems]].<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> Human activities have contributed to a number of the observed changes in climate.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""> {{citation
column288: chapter= Chapter 9: Understanding and Attributing Climate Change
column293: 2007}}. </ref> This contribution has principally been through the burning of [[fossil fuel]]s, which has led to an increase in the concentration of GHGs in the atmosphere.<ref> {{citation
column297: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-human-and.html Human and Natural Drivers of Climate Change ] }}, in {{harvnb
column299: 2007}}. </ref> Another human influence on the climate are [[sulfur dioxide]] emissions, which are a precursor to the formation of [[sulfate aerosols]] in the atmosphere.<ref> {{cite book
column301: author=Committee on the Science of Climate Change, US National Research Council
column303: title=Climate Change Science: An Analysis of Some Key Questions
column308: isbn=0-309-07574-2 }} </ref> Human-induced warming could lead to [[Effects of global warming#Abrupt or irreversible changes
column309: large-scale, irreversible, and/or abrupt changes]] in physical systems.<ref> {{citation
column313: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html Sec. 3. Projected climate change and its impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column316: title=ESRL News: New Study Shows Climate Change Largely Irreversible
column319: publisher=US Department of Commerce, NOAA, Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL)
column320: date=26 January 2009 }}</ref> An example of this is the melting of [[ice sheet]]s, which contributes to sea level rise.<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> The probability of warming having unforeseen consequences increases with the rate, magnitude, and duration of climate change.<ref> {{cite book
column325: publisher=[[United States National Academy of Sciences]]
column327: date=December 2012}}</ref> === Effects on weather === Observations show that there have been changes in weather.<ref> {{citation
column329: chapter= Chapter 1: Historical Overview of Climate Change Science
column331: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-1-2.html FAQ 1.2 What is the Relationship between Climate Change and Weather?]
column334: 2007}}. </ref> As climate changes, the [[probabilities]] of certain types of weather events are affected. [[File:Projected change in annual average precipitation for the 21st century, based on the SRES A1B emissions scenario, and simulated by the GFDL CM2.1 model.png
column338: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column339: Projected change in annual average precipitation by the end of the 21st century, based on a medium emissions scenario ([[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column340: SRES]] A1B) (Credit: NOAA [[Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory]]).<ref> {{citation
column344: title= GFDL Climate Modeling Research Highlights: Will the Wet Get Wetter and the Dry Drier
column349: title=Will the wet get wetter and the dry drier?
column353: publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory (GFDL)
column354: location=Princeton, NJ, USA }}. Revision 10/15/2008, 4:47:16 PM. </ref>]] Changes have been observed in the amount, intensity, frequency, and type of [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column362: date=November 2012}} Widespread increases in heavy precipitation have occurred, even in places where total rain amounts have decreased. With medium confidence (see [[Effects of global warming#Footnotes
column368: p=8}} </ref> concluded that human influences had contributed to an increase in heavy precipitation events at the global scale. Projections of future changes in precipitation show overall increases in the global average, but with substantial shifts in where and how precipitation falls.<ref name = ""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column370: date=November 2012}} Projections suggest a reduction in rainfall in the [[subtropics]], and an increase in precipitation in subpolar latitudes and some [[equatorial region]]s.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> In other words, regions which are dry at present will in general become even drier, while regions that are currently wet will in general become even wetter.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> This projection does not apply to every locale, and in some cases can be modified by local conditions.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> ==== Extreme weather ==== {{See also
column372: Tropical cyclone#Global warming}} Over most land areas since the 1950s, it is very likely that there have been fewer or warmer cold days and nights.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""> IPCC (2013), Table SPM.1, in [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf Summary for Policymakers, p. 5] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140226155600/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column374: 2013}} </ref> Hot days and nights have also very likely become warmer or more frequent.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Human activities have very likely contributed to these trends.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> There may have been changes in other climate extremes (e.g., [[flood]]s, [[drought]]s and [[tropical cyclone]]s) but these changes are more difficult to identify.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Projections suggest changes in the frequency and intensity of some extreme weather events.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Confidence in projections varies over time.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> ; Near-term projections (2016–2035) Some changes (e.g., more frequent hot days) will probably be evident in the near term, while other near-term changes (e.g., more intense droughts and tropical cyclones) are more uncertain.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> ; Long-term projections (2081–2100) Future climate change will be associated with more very hot days and fewer very cold days.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> The frequency, length and intensity of [[heat wave]]s will very likely increase over most land areas.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Higher growth in anthropogenic GHG emissions will be associated with larger increases in the frequency and severity of temperature extremes.<ref>Stocker, T.F., ''et al.'' (2013), Temperature Extremes, Heat Waves and Warm Spells, in: TFE.9, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf Technical Summary, p. 111] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221070705/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column376: 2013}} </ref> Assuming high growth in GHG emissions (IPCC scenario [[Representative Concentration Pathways
column377: RCP8.5]]), presently dry regions may be affected by an increase in the risk of drought and reductions in [[soil moisture]].<ref>Stocker, T.F., ''et al.'' (2013), Floods and Droughts, in: TFE.9, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf Technical Summary, p. 112] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221070705/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column379: 2013}} </ref> Over most of the mid-latitude land masses and wet tropical regions, extreme precipitation events will very likely become more intense and frequent.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> ; Tropical cyclones At the global scale, the frequency of tropical cyclones will probably decrease or be unchanged.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""> Christensen, J.H.,''et al.'' (2013), Cyclones, in: Executive Summary, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf Chapter 14: Climate Phenomena and their Relevance for Future Regional Climate Change, p. 1220] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221075046/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column381: 2013}} </ref> Global mean tropical cyclone maximum wind speed and precipitation rates will likely increase.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""/> Changes in tropical cyclones will probably vary by region, but these variations are uncertain.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""/> ; Effects of climate extremes The impacts of extreme events on the environment and human society will vary. Some impacts will be beneficial—e.g., fewer cold extremes will probably lead to fewer cold deaths.<ref name=""health summary""/> Overall, however, impacts will probably be mostly negative.<ref> {{citation
column389: chapter= Synthesis Report, Topic 5: The long-term perspective
column391: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains5-2.html Sec. 5.2 Key vulnerabilities, impacts and risks – long-term perspectives] }}, pp. 64–65, in {{harvnb
column394: Retreat of glaciers since 1850}} [[File:Glacier Mass Balance Map.png
column398: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column399: A map of the change in thickness of mountain glaciers since 1970. Thinning in orange and red, thickening in blue.]] [[File:SeaIce-Sept162012 HR.jpg
column404: A map that shows ice concentration on 16 September 2012, along with the extent of the previous record low (yellow line) and the mid-September median extent (black line) setting a new record low that was 18 percent smaller than the previous record and nearly 50 percent smaller than the long-term (1979-2000) average.]] The [[cryosphere]] is made up of areas of the Earth which are covered by snow or ice.<ref> [http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/glossary.html#C ""Cryosphere""], in {{harvnb
column406: 2012}} </ref> Observed changes in the cryosphere include declines in [[Arctic sea ice]] extent,<ref> {{citation
column411: title=Mass Balance of Mountain Glaciers in 2011
column414: 2012}} </ref> and reduced snow cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]].<ref> {{citation
column415: title=2011 Snow Cover in Northern Hemisphere
column418: 2012}} </ref> Solomon ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""ar4 arctic sea ice""> {{citation
column422: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-5-2.html TS.5.2 Large-Scale Projections for the 21st Century]
column425: 2007}} </ref> assessed the potential impacts of climate change on [[summer]]time Arctic sea ice extent. Assuming high growth in greenhouse gas emissions ([[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column426: SRES A2]]), some models projected that Arctic sea ice in the summer could largely disappear by the end of the 21st century.<ref name=""ar4 arctic sea ice""/> More recent projections suggest that the Arctic summers could be ice-free (defined as ice extent less than 1 million square km) as early as 2025-2030.<ref> {{citation
column435: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-4.html Box 10.1: Future Abrupt Climate Change, ‘Climate Surprises’, and Irreversible Changes: Glaciers and ice caps]
column439: p=776}} </ref> and snow cover are projected to continue their widespread retreat.<ref> {{citation
column443: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-3-2.html Sec 10.3.3.2 Changes in Snow Cover and Frozen Ground]
column447: pp=770, 772}} </ref> In the western mountains of [[North America]], increasing temperatures and changes in precipitation are projected to lead to reduced [[snowpack]].<ref> {{citation
column455: p=627}} </ref> Snowpack is the seasonal accumulation of slow-melting snow.<ref> [http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/glossary.html#S ""Snowpack""], in {{harvnb
column457: 2012}} </ref> The melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column458: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s could contribute to sea level rise, especially over long time-scales (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets
column459: Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets]]).<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> Changes in the cryosphere are projected to have social impacts.<ref> Some of these impacts are included in table SPM.2: {{citation
column460: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html#spm2 3 Projected climate change and its impacts: Table SPM.2]
column465: pp=11–12}} </ref> For example, in some regions, glacier retreat could increase the risk of reductions in seasonal water availability.<ref> {{citation
column467: chapter=Ch 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column474: title=Potential impacts of a warming climate on water availability in snow-dominated regions: Abstract
column482: display-authors=etal}} </ref> estimated that more than one-sixth of the [[world's population]] rely on glaciers and snowpack for their water supply. ===Oceans=== {{Main
column483: Effects of global warming on oceans}} The role of the oceans in global warming is complex. The oceans serve as a sink for carbon dioxide, taking up much that would otherwise remain in the atmosphere, but increased levels of {{chem
column485: 2}} have led to [[ocean acidification]]. Furthermore, as the temperature of the oceans increases, they become less able to absorb excess {{chem
column487: 2}}. The ocean have also acted as a sink in absorbing extra heat from the atmosphere.<ref name=""statecl"">{{cite book
column489: publisher = Website of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration: National Climatic Data Center
column490: title = State of the Climate in 2009, as appearing in the July 2010 issue (Vol. 91) of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society (BAMS). Supplemental and Summary Materials: Report at a Glance: Highlights
column494: date=November 2012}} The increase in ocean [[heat content]] is much larger than any other store of [[energy]] in the Earth’s heat balance over the two periods 1961 to 2003 and 1993 to 2003, and accounts for more than 90% of the possible increase in heat content of the Earth system during these periods.<ref>{{citation
column495: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch5s5-2-2-3.html Sec 5.2.2.3 Implications for Earth’s Heat Balance]
column496: chapter=Ch. 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column502: title=Climate Graphics by Skeptical Science: Global Warming Components:
column503: at=Components of global warming for the period 1993 to 2003 calculated from IPCC AR4 5.2.2.3
column505: publisher=Skeptical Science }} </ref> Global warming is projected to have a number of effects on the oceans. Ongoing effects include rising sea levels due to thermal expansion and melting of glaciers and ice sheets, and warming of the ocean surface, leading to increased temperature stratification. Other possible effects include large-scale changes in ocean circulation. ====Acidification==== {{Main
column506: Ocean acidification}} [[File:Changes in aragonite saturation of the world's oceans, 1880-2012 (US EPA).png
column510: alt=refer to caption and image description
column511: This map shows changes in the amount of [[aragonite]] dissolved in [[ocean]] surface waters between the 1880s and the most recent decade (2003-2012).<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/> Historical modeling suggests that since the 1880s, increased {{CO2}} has led to lower [[aragonite]] saturation levels (less availability of minerals) in the oceans around the world.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""> {{Include-USGov
column514: title=Climate Change Indicators in the United States, 2012, 2nd ed: Ocean Acidity: Figure 2. Changes in Aragonite Saturation of the World's Oceans, 1880-2012
column516: url=http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/science/indicators/oceans/acidity.html#fragment-2 }} }} </ref> The largest decreases in aragonite saturation have occurred in [[tropical]] waters.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/> However, decreases in cold areas may be of greater concern because colder waters typically have lower aragonite levels to begin with.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/>]] About one-third of the carbon dioxide emitted by human activity has already been taken up by the oceans.<ref name=""nrc 2008b ocean acidification""> {{cite book
column518: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column522: 2008b}} </ref> As carbon dioxide dissolves in [[sea water]], [[carbonic acid]] is formed, which has the effect of acidifying the ocean, measured as a change in [[pH]]. The uptake of human carbon emissions since the year 1750 has led to an average decrease in pH of 0.1 units.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 ocean acidification""> {{citation
column528: 2007}}. </ref> Projections using the SRES emissions scenarios suggest a further reduction in average global surface ocean pH of between 0.14 and 0.35 units over the 21st century. The effects of ocean acidification on the marine [[biosphere]] have yet to be documented.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 ocean acidification""/> Laboratory experiments suggest beneficial effects for a few species, with potentially highly detrimental effects for a substantial number of species.<ref name=""nrc 2008b ocean acidification""/> With medium confidence, Fischlin ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column530: chapter = Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods, and services
column535: 2007}}. </ref> projected that future ocean acidification and climate change would impair a wide range of [[plankton]]ic and shallow [[benthos
column536: benthic]] marine organisms that use [[aragonite]] to make their shells or skeletons, such as [[coral]]s and marine [[snail]]s ([[pteropoda
column537: pteropods]]), with significant impacts particularly in the Southern Ocean. ====Oxygen depletion==== The amount of oxygen dissolved in the oceans may decline, with adverse consequences for ocean life.<ref>{{Cite journal
column545: title = Abrupt Climate Change and Extinction Events in Earth History
column564: title = Long-term ocean oxygen depletion in response to carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels
column568: Future sea level}} [[File:Trends in global average absolute sea level, 1870-2008 (US EPA).png
column572: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column573: Trends in global average absolute sea level, 1870-2008.<ref> {{cite web
column575: title= Sea Level: Climate Change: US EPA
column578: year=2010 }} </ref>]] There is strong evidence that global sea level rose gradually over the 20th century.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""> {{citation
column580: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column582: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-5-1.html FAQ 5.1 Is Sea Level Rising?]
column587: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column592: 2007}}. </ref> concluded that between the mid-19th and mid-20th centuries, the rate of sea level rise increased. Authors of the IPCC Fourth Assessment Synthesis Report (IPCC AR4 SYR, 2007)<ref name= ""Observed changes in climate and their effects""> {{citation
column596: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms1.html Sec. 1. Observed changes in climate and their effects] }}, p. 5, in {{harvnb
column598: 2007}}. </ref> reported that between the years 1961 and 2003, global average sea level rose at an average rate of 1.8 mm per year (mm/yr), with a range of 1.3–2.3 mm/yr. Between 1993 and 2003, the rate increased above the previous period to 3.1 mm/yr (range of 2.4–3.8 mm/yr). Authors of IPCC AR4 SYR (2007)<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""/> were uncertain whether the increase in rate from 1993 to 2003 was due to [[climate change#Internal forcing mechanisms
column599: natural variations]] in sea level over the time period, or whether it reflected an increase in the underlying long-term trend. There are two main factors that have contributed to observed sea level rise.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""/> The first is [[thermal expansion]]: as ocean water warms, it expands.<ref> {{citation
column603: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/013.htm#b4 Box 2: What causes sea level to change?]
column606: 2007}}. </ref> The second is from the contribution of land-based ice due to increased melting. The major store of water on land is found in glaciers and ice sheets. Anthropogenic forces very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""> {{citation
column610: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-2.html Box TS.1: Treatment of Uncertainties in the Working Group I Assessment]
column613: 2007}}. </ref> contributed to sea level rise during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> There is a widespread consensus that substantial long-term sea level rise will continue for centuries to come.<ref> {{citation
column614: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column618: p=245}}. </ref> In their Fourth Assessment Report, the IPCC<ref> {{citation
column620: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column624: 2007}}. </ref> projected sea level rise to the end of the 21st century using the SRES emissions scenarios. Across the six SRES marker scenarios, sea level was projected to rise by 18 to 59 cm (7.1 to 23.2 in), relative to sea level at the end of the 20th century.<ref>change in sea level by 2090–99, relative to 1980–99</ref> Thermal expansion is the largest component in these projections, contributing 70-75% of the central estimate for all scenarios.<ref> {{citation
column631: 2007}}. </ref> Due to a lack of scientific understanding, this sea level rise estimate does not include all of the possible contributions of ice sheets (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets
column632: Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets]]). An assessment of the [[scientific literature]] on climate change was published in 2010 by the [[US National Research Council]] (US NRC, 2010).<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""> {{citation
column634: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column637: 2010}}. </ref> NRC (2010)<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> described the projections in AR4 (i.e. those cited in the above paragraph) as ""conservative"", and summarized the results of more recent studies. Cited studies suggested a great deal of uncertainty in projections.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> A range of projections suggested possible sea level rise by the end of the 21st century of between 0.56 and 2 m, relative to sea levels at the end of the 20th century.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> ====Ocean temperature rise==== [[File:Heat content700m2000myr.png
column642: Global ocean heat content from 1955-2012]] From 1961 to 2003, the global ocean temperature has risen by 0.10 °C from the surface to a depth of 700 m. There is variability both year-to-year and over longer time scales, with global ocean heat content observations showing high rates of warming for 1991–2003, but some cooling from 2003 to 2007.<ref> {{citation
column644: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column650: date=November 2012}} </ref> The temperature of the Antarctic [[Southern Ocean]] rose by 0.17 °C (0.31 °F) between the 1950s and the 1980s, nearly twice the rate for the world's oceans as a whole.<ref> {{cite journal
column654: title= Warming of the Southern Ocean Since the 1950s
column664: ref=harv }}</ref> As well as having effects on ecosystems (e.g. by melting sea ice, affecting algae that grow on its underside), warming reduces the ocean's ability to absorb {{chem
column667: date=June 2008}} It is likely (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> that anthropogenic forcing contributed to the general warming observed in the upper several hundred metres of the ocean during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> ==Regions== {{Main
column668: Regional effects of global warming}} {{Multiple image
column671: image1=Temperatures across the world in the 1880s (left) and the 1980s (right), as compared to average temperatures from 1951 to 1980 (US EPA).jpg
column672: alt1=Temperatures in most parts of the world were warmer in the 1980s compared to the 1880s
column673: image2= Map of projected global warming across the globe by the 2050s. Projections based on three SRES greenhouse gas emissions scenarios. Data from CMIP3 (2007).jpg
column674: alt2=Future warming across the globe varies according to different projections of greenhouse gas emissions
column676: caption1=Temperatures across the world in the 1880s (left) and the 1980s (right), as compared to average temperatures from 1951 to 1980.<ref> {{cite web
column679: title=Science: Climate Change: US EPA (Climate Change Science Overview)
column682: caption2=Projected changes in average temperatures across the world in the 2050s under three greenhouse gas (GHG) [[Economics of global warming#Emissions scenarios
column683: emissions scenarios]].<ref name=""herring temperature projections""/> }} Regional effects of global warming vary in nature. Some are the result of a generalised global change, such as rising temperature, resulting in local effects, such as melting ice. In other cases, a change may be related to a change in a particular ocean current or weather system. In such cases, the regional effect may be disproportionate and will not necessarily follow the global trend. There are three major ways in which global warming will make changes to regional climate: melting or forming ice, changing the [[hydrological cycle]] (of [[evaporation]] and [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column685: currents in the oceans]] and air flows in the atmosphere. The coast can also be considered a region, and will suffer severe impacts from [[sea level rise]]. ===Observed impacts=== With very high confidence, Rosenzweig ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> concluded that physical and biological systems on all continents and in most oceans had been affected by recent climate changes, particularly regional temperature increases. Impacts include earlier leafing of [[tree]]s and [[plant]]s over many regions; movements of species to higher latitudes and altitudes in the Northern Hemisphere; changes in [[bird migration]]s in Europe, North America and Australia; and shifting of the oceans' [[plankton]] and [[fish]] from cold- to warm-adapted communities.<ref name=""nasa briefs""/> The human influence on the climate can be seen in the geographical pattern of observed warming, with greater temperature increases over land and in [[polar region]]s rather than over the oceans.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""> {{cite book
column687: title=Understanding and Responding to Climate Change. A brochure prepared by the US National Research Council (US NRC)
column688: publisher=[http://dels.nas.edu/basc Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate], National Academy of Sciences
column693: date=November 2012}} Using models, it is possible to identify the human ""signal"" of global warming over both land and ocean areas.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""/>{{Rp
column695: date=November 2012}} ===Projected impacts=== Projections of future climate changes at the regional scale do not hold as high a level of scientific confidence as projections made at the global scale.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""/>{{Rp
column697: date=November 2012}} It is, however, expected that future warming will follow a similar geographical pattern to that seen already, with greatest warming over land and high northern [[latitude]]s, and least over the [[Southern Ocean]] and parts of the [[North Atlantic Ocean]].<ref> {{citation
column701: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-projections-of.html Projections of Future Changes in Climate] }}, in {{harvnb
column703: 2007}}. </ref> Nearly all land areas will very likely warm more than the global average.<ref name=""tar table of robust findings""> {{citation
column710: megadeltas]] are regions that are likely to be especially affected by climate change.<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions""> {{citation
column714: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-3.html Sec. 3.3.3 Especially affected systems, sectors and regions] }}, in {{harvnb
column718: less-developed]] areas are at most risk of experiencing negative impacts due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts""> {{citation
column720: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column722: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Distribution of Impacts, in: Sec 19.3.7 Update on 'Reasons for Concern']
column726: p=796}} </ref> [[Developed countries]] are also vulnerable to climate change.<ref name=""schneider regional vulnerabilities""> {{citation
column728: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column734: p=792}} </ref> For example, developed countries will be negatively affected by increases in the severity and frequency of some [[extreme weather]] events, such as [[heat wave]]s.<ref name=""schneider regional vulnerabilities""/> In all regions, some people can be particularly at risk from climate change, such as the [[poverty
column735: poor]], young [[children]] and the [[elderly]].<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions""/><ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts""/><ref> {{citation
column739: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-2-5.html Sec 7.4.2.5 Social issues and Sec 7.4.3 Key vulnerabilities]
column744: Effects of climate change on humans
column745: Climate change, industry and society}} {{See also
column746: Climate change and gender}} The impacts of climate change can be thought of in terms of sensitivity and vulnerability. ""Sensitivity"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be affected, positively or negatively, by climate change and/or [[climate change#Causes
column747: climate variability]]. ""Vulnerability"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be adversely affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
column752: 2007}}. </ref> The sensitivity of human society to climate change varies. Sectors sensitive to climate change include water resources, coastal zones, human settlements, and human health. Industries sensitive to climate change include [[climate change and agriculture
column759: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/008.htm#24 Sec. 2.4. Many Human Systems are Sensitive to Climate Change, and Some are Vulnerable] }}, in {{harvnb
column763: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column772: 2007–2008 world food price crisis}} [[File:Net crops tropicalvsworld.png
column774: Graph of net crop production worldwide and in selected tropical countries. Raw data from the United Nations. [http://faostat3.fao.org/browse/Q/QC/E]]] Climate change will impact agriculture and food production around the world due to: the effects of elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere, higher temperatures, altered precipitation and [[transpiration]] regimes, increased frequency of extreme events, and modified [[weed]], [[pest (organism)
column777: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column783: p=282}}. </ref> In general, low-latitude areas are at most risk of having decreased crop yields.<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> As of 2007, the effects of regional climate change on agriculture have been small.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""> {{citation
column785: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column790: 2007}}. </ref> Changes in crop [[phenology]] provide important evidence of the response to recent regional climate change.<ref> {{citation
column792: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column797: 2007}}. </ref> Phenology is the study of natural phenomena that recur periodically, and how these phenomena relate to climate and seasonal changes.<ref> {{citation
column802: 2007}}. </ref> A significant advance in phenology has been observed for agriculture and forestry in large parts of the Northern Hemisphere.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> ====Projections==== [[File:Projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming.png
column807: Projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""> [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12877&page=161 Figure 5.1], p.161, in: Sec 5.1 FOOD PRODUCTION, PRICES, AND HUNGER, in: Ch 5: Impacts in the Next Few Decades and Coming Centuries, in: {{harvnb
column809: 2011}} </ref>]] [[File:Projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming.png
column814: Projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""/>]] With low to medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> projected that for about a 1 to 3 °C increase in global mean temperature (by the years 2090-2100, relative to average temperatures in the years 1990–2000), there would be productivity decreases for some [[cereal]]s in low latitudes, and productivity increases in high latitudes. With medium confidence, global production potential was projected to:<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> * increase up to around 3 °C, * very likely decrease above about 3 °C. Most of the studies on global agriculture assessed by Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> had not incorporated a number of critical factors, including changes in extreme events, or the spread of pests and diseases. Studies had also not considered the development of specific practices or technologies to aid [[adaptation to global warming#Agricultural production
column815: adaptation to climate change]].<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""> {{citation
column817: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column823: p=790}}. </ref> The graphs opposite show the projected effects of climate change on selected crop yields.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 text""> Sec 5.1 FOOD PRODUCTION, PRICES, AND HUNGER, [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12877&page=160 pp.160-162], in: Ch 5: Impacts in the Next Few Decades and Coming Centuries, in {{harvnb
column825: 2011}} </ref> Actual changes in yields may be above or below these central estimates.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 text""/> The projections above can be expressed relative to pre-industrial (1750) temperatures.<ref> {{citation
column827: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column829: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-1.html Box 19.2. Reference for temperature levels]
column833: p=783}}. </ref> 0.6 °C of warming is estimated to have occurred between 1750 and 1990-2000. Add 0.6 °C to the above projections to convert them from a 1990-2000 to pre-industrial baseline. =====Food security===== Easterling ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column835: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column837: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch5s5-6-5.html Sec. 5.6.5 Food security and vulnerability]
column840: 2007}}. </ref> assessed studies that made quantitative projections of climate change impacts on [[food security]]. It was noted that these projections were highly uncertain and had limitations. However, the assessed studies suggested a number of fairly robust findings. The first was that climate change would likely increase the number of people at risk of [[hunger]] compared with reference scenarios with no climate change. Climate change impacts depended strongly on projected future social and economic development. Additionally, the magnitude of climate change impacts was projected to be smaller compared to the impact of social and economic development. In 2006, the global estimate for the number of people [[malnutrition
column846: accessdate=2011-07-07 }} </ref> Under the SRES A1, B1, and B2 scenarios (see the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios#Scenario families
column847: SRES article]] for information on each scenario group), projections for the year 2080 showed a reduction in the number of people undernourished of about 560-700 million people, with a global total of undernourished people of 100-240 million in 2080. By contrast, the SRES A2 scenario showed only a small decrease in the risk of hunger from 2006 levels. The smaller reduction under A2 was attributed to the higher projected future population level in this scenario. ====Droughts and agriculture==== Some evidence suggests that droughts have been occurring more frequently because of global warming and they are expected to become more frequent and intense in Africa, southern Europe, the Middle East, most of the Americas, Australia, and Southeast Asia.<ref>{{Cite journal
column851: title = Drought under global warming: A review
column852: journal = Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Climate Change
column857: pmc = }}</ref> However, other research suggests that there has been little change in drought over the past 60 years.<ref>{{Cite journal
column859: title = Little change in global drought over the past 60 years
column871: bibcode = 2012Natur.491..435S }}</ref> Their impacts are aggravated because of increased water demand, population growth, urban expansion, and environmental protection efforts in many areas.<ref>{{Cite journal
column884: bibcode = 2011JHyd..403..157M }}</ref> Droughts result in crop failures and the loss of pasture grazing land for livestock.<ref>{{Cite journal
column892: title = Measuring economic impacts of drought: A review and discussion
column900: Effects of global warming on human health}} Human beings are exposed to climate change through changing weather patterns (temperature, precipitation, sea-level rise and more frequent extreme events) and indirectly through changes in water, air and food quality and changes in ecosystems, agriculture, industry and settlements and the economy (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007:393).<ref name=""health summary""> {{citation
column907: 2007}}. </ref> According to an assessment of the scientific literature by Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007:393),<ref name=""health summary""/> the effects of climate change to date have been small, but are projected to progressively increase in all countries and regions. A study by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO, 2009)<ref> {{cite book
column910: title= Global health risks: mortality and burden of disease attributable to selected major risks
column918: url= http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/global_health_risks/en/index.html }} </ref> estimated the effect of climate change on human health. Not all of the effects of climate change were included in their estimates, for example, the effects of more frequent and extreme storms were excluded. Climate change was estimated to have been responsible for 3% of [[diarrhoea]], 3% of [[malaria]], and 3.8% of [[dengue fever]] deaths worldwide in 2004. Total attributable mortality was about 0.2% of deaths in 2004; of these, 85% were child deaths. ====Projections==== With high confidence, authors of the IPCC AR4 Synthesis report<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report""/>{{Rp
column920: date=November 2012}} projected that climate change would bring some benefits in temperate areas, such as fewer deaths from cold exposure, and some mixed effects such as changes in range and transmission potential of [[malaria]] in [[Africa]]. Benefits were projected to be outweighed by negative health effects of rising temperatures, especially in developing countries. With very high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/>{{Rp
column922: date=November 2012}} concluded that economic development was an important component of possible adaptation to climate change. Economic growth on its own, however, was not judged to be sufficient to insulate the world's population from disease and injury due to climate change. Future vulnerability to climate change will depend not only on the extent of social and economic change, but also on how the benefits and costs of change are distributed in society.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""> {{citation
column926: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-3-2.html Sec. 8.3.2 Future vulnerability to climate change]
column929: 2007}}. </ref> For example, in the 19th century, rapid [[urbanization]] in [[western Europe]] lead to a plummeting in population health.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""/> Other factors important in determining the health of populations include [[education]], the availability of health services, and [[public health
column937: Precipitation during the 20th century and up through 2008 during global warming, the [[NOAA]] estimating an observed trend over that period of 1.87% global precipitation increase per century.]] A number of climate-related trends have been observed that affect [[water resources]]. These include changes in precipitation, the crysosphere and [[surface water]]s (e.g., changes in [[river flows]]).<ref> {{citation
column939: chapter = Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column944: 2007}}. </ref> Observed and projected impacts of climate change on [[freshwater]] systems and their management are mainly due to changes in temperature, sea level and precipitation variability.<ref name=""freshwater impacts""> {{citation
column946: chapter= Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column951: 2007}}. </ref> Sea level rise will extend areas of [[salinization]] of [[groundwater]] and [[estuary
column952: estuaries]], resulting in a decrease in freshwater availability for humans and ecosystems in coastal areas. In an assessment of the [[scientific literature]], Kundzewicz ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""freshwater impacts""/> concluded, with high confidence, that: * the negative impacts of climate change on freshwater systems outweigh the benefits. All of the regions assessed in the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]] ([[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], [[Europe]], [[Latin America]], [[North America]], [[Polar region]]s ([[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]]), and small islands) showed an overall net negative impact of climate change on water resources and freshwater ecosystems. * [[semi-arid climate
column953: Semi-arid]] and [[arid]] areas are particularly exposed to the impacts of climate change on freshwater. With very high confidence, it was judged that many of these areas, e.g., the [[Mediterranean basin]], [[Western United States]], [[Southern Africa]], and north-eastern [[Brazil]], would suffer a decrease in water resources due to climate change. ===Migration and conflict=== {{See also
column955: General circulation models]] project that the future climate change will bring wetter coasts, drier mid-continent areas, and further sea level rise.<ref name=""sar migration""> {{citation
column957: chapter= Chapter 12: Human settlements in a changing climate: impacts and adaptation
column961: 1996}}. </ref> Such changes could result in the gravest effects of climate change through sudden [[human migration]].{{citation needed
column962: date=November 2015}} Millions might be displaced by [[shoreline erosion]]s, river and coastal [[flood]]ing, or severe [[drought]]. Migration related to climate change is likely to be predominantly from [[rural area]]s in [[developing countries]] to towns and [[cities]].<ref name=""sar migration""/>{{Rp
column966: title = Managing social risks: Empower communities to protect themselves
column967: chapter = Part One: Chapter 2: Reducing Human Vulnerability: Helping People Help Themselves
column970: 2010}}. </ref> In the short term climate stress is likely to add incrementally to existing migration patterns rather than generating entirely new flows of people.<ref name=""wdr migration""/>{{Rp
column972: date=November 2012}} It has been argued that environmental degradation, loss of access to resources (e.g., water resources),<ref> {{citation
column979: 2001}}. </ref> and resulting human migration could become a source of political and even [[military conflict]].<ref name=""tar migration""> {{citation
column981: chapter= Chapter 7: Human Settlements, Energy, and Industry
column986: 2001}}. </ref> Factors other than climate change may, however, be more important in affecting conflict. For example, Wilbanks ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column988: chapter = Chapter 7: Industry, settlement and society
column990: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-1.html Sec. 7.4.1 General effects: Box 7.2. Environmental migration]
column993: 2007}}. </ref> suggested that major environmentally influenced conflicts in Africa were more to do with the relative abundance of resources, e.g., [[oil]] and [[diamond]]s, than with resource scarcity. Scott ''et al.'' (2001) placed only low confidence in predictions of increased conflict due to climate change.<ref name=""tar migration""/> A 2013 study found that significant climatic changes were associated with a higher risk of conflict worldwide, and predicted that ""amplified rates of human conflict could represent a large and critical social impact of anthropogenic climate change in both low- and high-income countries.""<ref>{{cite journal
column994: vauthors=Hsiang SM, Burke M, Miguel E
column995: title=Quantifying the influence of climate on human conflict
column1003: url=}}</ref> Similarly, a 2014 study found that higher temperatures were associated with a greater likelihood of violent crime, and predicted that global warming would cause millions of such crimes in the United States alone during the 21st century.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1005: title = Crime, weather, and climate change
column1006: journal = Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
column1011: pages=274–302}}</ref> Military planners are concerned that global warming is a ""threat multiplier"". ""Whether it is poverty, food and water scarcity, diseases, economic instability, or threat of natural disasters, the broad range of changing climatic conditions may be far reaching. These challenges may threaten stability in much of the world"".<ref>{{cite journal
column1016: journal =Proceedings of the US Naval Institute
column1023: Economic impacts of climate change}} [[Aggregate data
column1024: Aggregating]] impacts adds up the total impact of climate change across sectors and/or regions.<ref> [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/annexessglossary-a-d.html Glossary A-D: ""Aggregate impacts""], in {{harvnb
column1027: p=76}} </ref> Examples of aggregate measures include [[Economic impacts of climate change#Distribution of impacts
column1028: economic cost]] (e.g., changes in [[gross domestic product]] (GDP) and the [[Economic impacts of climate change#Marginal impacts
column1029: social cost of carbon]]), changes in ecosystems (e.g., changes over land area from one type of vegetation to another),<ref> {{citation
column1031: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1033: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/677.htm Sec. 19.5.3 Insights and Lessons: Vulnerability over Time: Table 19-5]
column1036: 2001}}. </ref> human health impacts, and the number of people affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
column1038: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1040: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/676.htm Sec. 19.5.2. Insights and Lessons: The Static Picture]
column1043: 2001}}. </ref> Aggregate measures such as economic cost require researchers to make [[value judgement]]s over the importance of impacts occurring in different regions and at different times. ====Observed impacts==== Global losses reveal rapidly rising costs due to extreme weather-related events since the 1970s.<ref> {{citation
column1045: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of observed changes and responses in natural and managed systems
column1047: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-8-5.html Sec. 1.3.8.5 Summary of disasters and hazards]
column1051: Socio-economic]] factors have contributed to the observed trend of global losses, e.g., population growth, increased [[wealth]].<ref name=""disaster losses""> {{citation
column1057: 2001}}. </ref> Part of the growth is also related to regional climatic factors, e.g., changes in precipitation and flooding events. It is difficult to quantify the relative impact of socio-economic factors and climate change on the observed trend.<ref name=""disaster losses""/> The trend does, however, suggest increasing vulnerability of social systems to climate change.<ref name=""disaster losses""/><ref>[http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/billions Billion-Dollar Weather and Climate Disasters]</ref> ====Projected impacts==== The total economic impacts from climate change are highly uncertain.<ref> {{citation
column1059: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1064: 2007}}. </ref> With medium confidence, Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""> {{citation
column1066: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1071: 2001}}. </ref> concluded that world GDP would change by plus or minus a few percent for a small increase in global mean temperature (up to around 2 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level). Most studies assessed by Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""/> projected losses in world GDP for a medium increase in global mean temperature (above 2-3 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level), with increasing losses for greater temperature increases. This assessment is consistent with the findings of more recent studies, as reviewed by Hitz and Smith (2004).<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""> {{citation
column1073: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1075: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Sec. 19.3.7 Update on ‘Reasons for Concern’]
column1078: 2007}}. </ref> Economic impacts are expected to vary regionally.<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/><ref> {{citation
column1080: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1082: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/675.htm Sec. 19.4.3. Distribution of Total Impacts]
column1085: 2001}}. </ref> For a medium increase in global mean temperature (2-3 °C of warming, relative to the average temperature between 1990–2000), market sectors in low-latitude and less-developed areas might experience net costs due to climate change.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> On the other hand, market sectors in high-latitude and developed regions might experience net benefits for this level of warming. A global mean temperature increase above about 2-3 °C (relative to 1990-2000) would very likely result in market sectors across all regions experiencing either declines in net benefits or rises in net costs.<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> Aggregate impacts have also been quantified in non-economic terms. For example, climate change over the 21st century is likely to adversely affect hundreds of millions of people through increased coastal flooding, reductions in water supplies, increased malnutrition and increased health impacts.<ref name=""ar4 synthesis reasons for concern""/> ==Biological systems== {{Main
column1088: Effect of climate change on plant biodiversity
column1089: Effects of climate change on terrestrial animals
column1090: Effects of climate change on marine mammals}} ===Observed impacts on biological systems=== [[File:A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming (low-res).png
column1094: A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming.<ref name=""nasa briefs""> {{cite web
column1097: title=Science Briefs: Warming Climate is Changing Life on Global Scale
column1098: publisher=Website of the US National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Goddard Institute for Space Studies
column1100: accessdate=2011-07-08}} </ref>]] With very high confidence, Rosenzweig ''et al.'' (2007) concluded that recent warming had strongly affected natural biological systems.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> Hundreds of studies have documented responses of [[ecosystem]]s, [[plant]]s, and [[animal]]s to the climate changes that have already occurred.<ref> {{cite book
column1102: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column1107: page = 14 }} </ref> For example, in the Northern Hemisphere, species are almost uniformly moving their ranges northward and up in elevation in search of cooler temperatures.<ref name=""nrc 2008b observed ecosystem impacts""> {{cite book
column1109: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column1114: page = 16 }} </ref> Humans are very likely causing changes in regional temperatures to which plants and animals are responding.<ref name=""nrc 2008b observed ecosystem impacts""/> ===Projected impacts on biological systems=== By the year 2100, ecosystems will be exposed to atmospheric {{chem
column1116: 2}} levels substantially higher than in the past 650,000 years, and global temperatures at least among the highest of those experienced in the past 740,000 years.<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""> {{citation
column1118: chapter= Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column1123: 2007}}. </ref> Significant disruptions of ecosystems are projected to increase with future climate change.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""> {{citation
column1129: 2001}}. </ref> Examples of disruptions include disturbances such as fire, drought, pest [[infestation]], invasion of species, storms, and [[coral bleaching]] events. The stresses caused by climate change, added to other stresses on ecological systems (e.g., land conversion, [[land degradation]], [[harvest]]ing, and [[pollution]]), threaten substantial damage to or complete loss of some unique ecosystems, and [[extinction]] of some critically endangered species.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""/><ref>Van Riper, Charles. (2014) [http://purl.fdlp.gov/GPO/gpo50857 Projecting Climate Effects on Birds and Reptiles of the Southwestern United States.] Reston, Va.: [[United States Department of the Interior
column1130: U.S. Department of the Interior]], [[United States Geological Survey
column1131: U.S. Geological Survey]].</ref> Climate change has been estimated to be a major driver of [[biodiversity]] loss in cool [[conifer]] forests, [[savanna]]s, [[mediterranean climate
column1132: mediterranean-climate]] systems, [[tropical forest]]s, in the [[Arctic tundra]], and in [[coral reef]]s.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""> {{citation
column1134: chapter= Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column1136: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch4s4-4-11.html Sec. 4.4.11 Global synthesis including impacts on biodiversity]
column1140: land-use]] change may be a stronger driver of biodiversity loss at least in the near-term.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> Beyond the year 2050, climate change may be the major driver for biodiversity loss globally.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> A literature assessment by Fischlin ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""/> included a quantitative estimate of the number of species at increased risk of extinction due to climate change. With medium confidence, it was projected that approximately 20 to 30% of plant and animal species assessed so far (in an unbiased [[Sampling (statistics)
column1141: sample]]) would likely be at increasingly high risk of extinction should global mean temperatures exceed a warming of 2 to 3 °C above pre-industrial temperature levels.<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""/> The uncertainties in this estimate, however, are large: for a rise of about 2 °C the percentage may be as low as 10%, or for about 3 °C, as high as 40%, and depending on [[Biota (ecology)
column1142: biota]] (all living [[organism]]s of an area, the [[flora]] and [[fauna]] considered as a unit)<ref> {{citation
column1147: 2007}}. </ref> the range is between 1% and 80%.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> As global average temperature exceeds [[4 Degrees and Beyond International Climate Conference
column1148: 4 °C]] above pre-industrial levels, model projections suggested that there could be significant extinctions (40-70% of species that were assessed) around the globe.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> Assessing whether future changes in ecosystems will be beneficial or detrimental is largely based on how ecosystems are valued by human society.<ref> {{citation
column1151: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column1155: 2008b}}. </ref> For increases in global average temperature exceeding 1.5 to 2.5 °C (relative to global temperatures over the years 1980-1999)<ref> {{citation
column1157: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column1159: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3.html Sec. 3.3 Impacts of future climate changes] }}, in {{harvnb
column1163: 2}} concentrations, projected changes in ecosystems will have predominantly negative consequences for biodiversity and ecosystems goods and [[ecosystem services
column1164: services]], e.g., water and food supply.<ref> {{citation
column1166: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column1168: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-1.html Sec. 3.3.1 Impacts on systems and sectors: Ecosystems] }}, in {{harvnb
column1170: 2007}}. </ref> ==Abrupt or irreversible changes== Physical, ecological and social systems may respond in an abrupt, [[non-linear]] or irregular way to climate change.<ref name=""singularities""/> This is as opposed to a smooth or regular response. A quantitative entity behaves ""irregularly"" when its [[system dynamics
column1172: discontinuous]] (i.e., not smooth), nondifferentiable, unbounded, wildly varying, or otherwise ill-defined.<ref name=""singularities""/> Such behaviour is often termed ""[[Mathematical singularity
column1173: singular]]"". Irregular behaviour in Earth systems may give rise to certain thresholds, which, when crossed, may lead to a large change in the system. Some singularities could potentially lead to severe impacts at regional or global scales.<ref name=""white et al singularities""> {{citation
column1180: 2001}}. </ref> Examples of ""large-scale"" singularities are discussed in the articles on [[abrupt climate change]], [[climate change feedback]] and [[runaway climate change]]. It is possible that human-induced climate change could trigger large-scale singularities, but the probabilities of triggering such events are, for the most part,<ref> ""[F]or the most part"" refers to improved scientific understanding of singularities since the assessment by White ''et al.'' (2001). See: {{citation
column1182: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1184: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Sec. 19.3.7 Update on ‘Reasons for Concern’]
column1187: 2007}}. </ref> poorly understood.<ref name=""white et al singularities""/> With low to medium confidence, Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""singularities""> {{citation
column1189: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1194: 2001}}. </ref> concluded that a rapid warming of more than 3 °C above 1990 levels would exceed thresholds that would lead to large-scale discontinuities in the climate system. Since the assessment by Smith ''et al.'' (2001), improved scientific understanding provides more guidance for two large-scale singularities: the role of [[carbon cycle]] feedbacks in future climate change (discussed below in the section on biogeochemical cycles) and the melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column1195: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s.<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/> ===Biogeochemical cycles=== {{See also
column1196: climate change feedback}} Climate change may have an effect on the [[carbon cycle]] in an interactive ""feedback"" process. A feedback exists where an initial process triggers changes in a second process that in turn influences the initial process. A positive feedback intensifies the original process, and a negative feedback reduces it.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report"">{{harvnb
column1200: date=November 2012}} Models suggest that the interaction of the climate system and the carbon cycle is one where the feedback effect is positive.<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""> {{citation
column1202: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1209: date=November 2012}} Using the A2 SRES emissions scenario, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""/>{{Rp
column1211: date=November 2012}} found that this effect led to additional warming by the years 2090-2100 (relative to the 1990–2000) of 0.1–1.5 °C. This estimate was made with high confidence. The climate projections made in the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report summarized earlier of 1.1–6.4 °C account for this feedback effect. On the other hand, with medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""/>{{Rp
column1213: date=November 2012}} commented that additional releases of GHGs were possible from permafrost, peat lands, wetlands, and large stores of marine hydrates at high latitudes. ===Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets=== With medium confidence, authors of AR4<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""> {{citation
column1219: 2007}}. </ref> concluded that with a global average temperature increase of 1–4 °C (relative to temperatures over the years 1990–2000), at least a partial deglaciation of the [[Greenland ice sheet]], and possibly the [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s would occur. The estimated timescale for partial deglaciation was centuries to millennia, and would contribute {{convert
column1223: m}} or more to sea level rise over this period. ===Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation=== {{See also
column1226: This map shows the general location and direction of the warm surface (red) and cold deep water (blue) currents of the [[thermohaline circulation]]. [[Salinity]] is represented by color in units of the Practical Salinity Scale. Low values (blue) are less saline, while high values (orange) are more saline.<ref> {{cite web
column1228: author=Riebeek, H.. design by R. Simmon
column1229: title=Paleoclimatology: Explaining the Evidence: Explaining Rapid Climate Change: Tales from the Ice
column1235: right]] The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is an important component of the Earth's climate system, characterized by a northward flow of warm, salty water in the upper layers of the [[Atlantic ocean
column1236: Atlantic]] and a southward flow of colder water in the deep Atlantic.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""> {{cite book
column1239: title= Abrupt Climate Change. A report by the US Climate Change Science Program (CCSP) and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column1244: date=November 2012}} The AMOC is equivalently known as the [[thermohaline circulation]] (THC).<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/> Potential impacts associated with MOC changes include reduced warming or (in the case of abrupt change) absolute cooling of northern high-latitude areas near [[Greenland]] and north-western Europe, an increased warming of [[Southern Hemisphere]] high-latitudes, tropical drying, as well as changes to [[marine ecosystem]]s, terrestrial vegetation, oceanic {{chem
column1246: 2}} uptake, oceanic oxygen concentrations, and shifts in fisheries.<ref> {{citation
column1248: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1250: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-5-3.html Sec. 19.3.5.3 Possible changes in the North Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (MOC)]
column1253: 2007}}. </ref> According to an assessment by the US [[Climate Change Science Program]] (CCSP, 2008b),<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1255: date=November 2012}} it is very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1257: date=November 2012}} that the strength of the AMOC will decrease over the course of the 21st century. Warming is still expected to occur over most of the European region downstream of the [[North Atlantic Current]] in response to increasing GHGs, as well as over [[North America]]. Although it is very unlikely (less than 10% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1259: date=November 2012}} that the AMOC will collapse in the 21st century, the potential consequences of such a collapse could be severe.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1261: date=November 2012}} ===Irreversibilities=== ====Commitment to radiative forcing==== Emissions of GHGs are a potentially irreversible commitment to sustained [[radiative forcing]] in the future.<ref name=""albritton irreversible radiative forcing""> {{citation
column1265: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc%5Ftar/wg1/016.htm Sec. C.1 Observed Changes in Globally Well-Mixed Greenhouse Gas Concentrations and Radiative Forcing]
column1268: 2001}}. </ref> The contribution of a GHG to radiative forcing depends on the gas's ability to trap [[infrared]] (heat) radiation, the concentration of the gas in the atmosphere, and the length of time the gas resides in the atmosphere.<ref name=""albritton irreversible radiative forcing""/> {{chem
column1270: 2}} is the most important anthropogenic GHG.<ref name=""ipcc 2007 causes of climate change""> {{citation
column1274: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms2.html Sec. 2. Causes of change] }}, p. 5, in {{harvnb
column1276: 2007}}. </ref> While more than half of the {{chem
column1278: 2}} emitted is currently removed from the atmosphere within a century, some fraction (about 20%) of emitted {{chem
column1280: 2}} remains in the atmosphere for many thousands of years.<ref> {{cite book
column1284: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-10-3.html Frequently Asked Question 10.3: If Emissions of Greenhouse Gases are Reduced, How Quickly do Their Concentrations in the Atmosphere Decrease?]
column1289: 2}} emitted today is potentially an irreversible commitment to sustained radiative forcing over thousands of years. This commitment may not be truly irreversible should techniques be developed to remove {{chem
column1291: 2}} or other GHGs directly from the atmosphere, or to block sunlight to induce cooling.<ref name=""solomon irreversible climate change""> {{cite journal
column1294: title=Irreversible climate change due to carbon dioxide emissions
column1295: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
column1305: display-authors=etal}}</ref> Techniques of this sort are referred to as [[climate engineering
column1306: geoengineering]]. Little is known about the effectiveness, costs or potential [[Unintended consequences
column1307: side-effects]] of geoengineering options.<ref name=""barker geoengineering""> {{citation
column1309: chapter= Chapter 11: Mitigation from a cross-sectoral perspective
column1314: 2007}}. </ref> Some geoengineering options, such as blocking sunlight, would not prevent further [[ocean acidification]].<ref name=""barker geoengineering""/> ====Irreversible impacts==== Human-induced climate change may lead to irreversible impacts on physical, biological, and social systems.<ref> {{citation
column1320: 2001}}. <!-- XX Needs checking. --> </ref> There are a number of examples of climate change impacts that may be irreversible, at least over the timescale of many human generations.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""> {{citation
column1322: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1324: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-2.html Sec.19.2 Criteria for selecting ‘key’ vulnerabilities: Persistence and reversibility]
column1327: 2007}}. </ref> These include the large-scale singularities described above – changes in carbon cycle feedbacks, the melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, and changes to the AMOC.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In biological systems, the extinction of species would be an irreversible impact.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In social systems, unique [[culture]]s may be lost due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> For example, humans living on [[atoll]] islands face risks due to sea-level rise, sea-surface warming, and increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.<ref> {{cite journal
column1337: doi=10.1023/b:clim.0000004559.08755.88 }} This paper was published in 2001 as [http://www.tyndall.ac.uk/sites/default/files/wp9.pdf Tyndall Centre Working Paper 9] </ref> ==Benefits of global warming{{Anchor
column1338: Benefits_of_Global_Warming}}== With a large range of effects, it is unlikely that all effects will be negative. Not only have some positive effects been identified, but there is some published material indicating that a small amount of warming would be good.<ref>[http://pubs.aeaweb.org/doi/pdfplus/10.1257/jep.29.1.217 Tol Correction]</ref> The IPCC cautions that ""Estimates agree on the size of the impact (small relative to economic growth), and 17 of the 20 impact estimates shown in Figure 10-1 are negative. Losses accelerate with greater warming, and estimates diverge."" The identified benefits are listed below. === CO2 fertilisation effect === [[Carbon dioxide
column1339: CO2]] is one of the substances which plants require to grow.
