Increasing its amount in the air contributes to: *Improved agriculture in some high latitude regions <ref>[http://nersp.nerdc.ufl.edu/~vecy/LitSurvey/Mendelsohn.06.pdf Mendelsohn 2006],</ref> *Increased growing season in Greenland <ref>Nyegaard 2007</ref> *Increased productivity of sour orange trees <ref>[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2486.2007.01430.x/abstract Kimball 2007]</ref> *Increased vegetation activity in high northern latitudes <ref>Zhou 2001</ref> *Increased plankton biomass in the North Pacific Subtropical Gyre <ref>Corno 2006</ref> *Recent increase in forest growth <ref>[http://www.pnas.org/content/107/8/3611.abstract McMahon 2010]</ref> *Increased Arctic tundra plant reproduction <ref>[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2486.2010.02319.x/abstract Klady 2010]</ref> === Human health === *Winter deaths will decline as temperatures warm <ref>HPA 2007</ref> === Ice-free Northwest Passage === *Ships will travel on a shorter route between the Pacific and Atlantic oceans <ref>[http://www.sciencemag.org/content/297/5586/1490.summary Kerr 2002]</ref> === Animal population changes === Some animals will benefit from the warming: *Increase in chinstrap and gentoo penguins <ref>[http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/362/1477/67.full Ducklow 2006]</ref> *Bigger marmots <ref>[http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v466/n7305/abs/nature09210.html Ozgul 2010]</ref> ==Scientific opinion== The [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC) has published several major assessments on the effects of global warming.<ref> {{harvnb
column1342: pp=4–7}} </ref> Its most recent comprehensive impact assessment was published in 2014.<ref> {{harvnb
column1344: 2014}} </ref> Publications describing the effects of climate change have also been produced by the following organizations: *[[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] (AAAS)<ref> {{harvnb
column1347: n.d.}} </ref> *A report by the [[Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency]], the [[Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute]], and [[Wageningen University and Research Centre]]<ref> {{harvnb
column1355: 2013}} for other AVOID publications. </ref> *A report by the UK [[Royal Society]] and [[US National Academy of Sciences]]<ref> {{harvnb
column1358: 2014}} </ref> *[[University of New South Wales]] Climate Change Research Centre<ref> {{harvnb
column1365: 2011}} </ref> A report by Molina ''et al.'' (no date)<ref> {{harvnb
column1369:
p=3}} states:
The overwhelming evidence of human-caused climate change documents both current impacts with significant costs and extraordinary future risks to society and natural systems
===NASA data and tools=== NASA has released public data and tools to predict how temperature and rainfall patterns worldwide may change through to the year 2100 caused by increasing carbon dioxide in Earth’s atmosphere. The dataset, shows projected changes worldwide on a regional level simulated by 21 climate models. The data can be viewed on a daily timescale for individual cities and towns and may be used to conduct climate risk assessments to predict the local and global effects of weather dangers, for example droughts, floods, heat waves and declines in agriculture productivity, and help plan responses to global warming effects.{{Cite web
column1370: title = NASA Releases Detailed Global Climate Change Projections
column1372: accessdate = 2015-06-09}}</ref> == See also == {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ; General * [[4 Degrees and Beyond International Climate Conference]] * [[Anthropocene]] * [[Risks to civilization, humans and planet Earth]] * [[Indigenous Peoples Climate Change Assessment Initiative]] * [[Environmental sociology]] ; Regional * [[Arctic Climate Impact Assessment]] * [[Effects of global warming on Australia]] * [[Effects of global warming on India]] * [[Kivalina v. ExxonMobil Corporation]] * [[Climate Change Science Program#Impacts and adaptation
column1373: Bush Administration assessments of impacts and adaptation]] (United States) {{Col-break}} {{Portal
column1376: Environment}} * [[Biological pump]] * [[Climate Vulnerability Monitor]] (CVM) * [[Oceanic anoxic event]] * [[PRECIS (Providing Regional Climates for Impacts Studies)]] * [[Solubility pump]] {{Col-end}} {{Clear}} ==Footnotes== <sup>1</sup> The TAR<ref name=""Uncertainty in the TAR""> {{citation
column1382: 2001}}. </ref> and AR4<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> that are referred to in this article use specific and quantitative language to describe uncertainty. This language is intended to provide an indication of the level of confidence that IPCC authors have about a particular finding. The qualitative language used to describe uncertainty has a quantitative scale associated with it. The quantitative values for qualitative terms are intended to ensure that confidence levels are interpreted correctly. The is because qualitative statements, e.g., using the word ""likely"", can be interpreted differently in quantitative terms.<ref> {{citation
column1389: title= IPCC supporting material: guidance papers on the cross cutting issues of the Third Assessment Report of the IPCC
column1394: publisher= Global Industrial and Social Progress Research Institute (GISPRI)
column1398: date=November 2012}} Confidence levels used in the TAR:<ref> {{citation
column1402: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/023.htm#14 Box 2. Confidence Levels and State of Knowledge]
column1405: 2001}}. </ref> * Very High = 95% or greater * High = 67-95% * Medium = 33-67% * Low = 5-33% * Very Low = 5% or less Confidence statements made in AR4 are listed below:<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> * Very high confidence: At least 9 out of 10 chance of being correct * High confidence: About 8 out of 10 chance "" "" "" * Medium confidence: About 5 out of 10 chance "" "" "" * Low confidence: About 2 out of 10 chance "" "" "" * Very low confidence: Less than a 1 out of 10 chance "" "" "" IPCC (2012)<ref> {{citation
column1410: p=19}} </ref> uses the following terms: ""very low"", ""low"", ""medium"", ""high"", and ""very high confidence"". Unlike the TAR and AR4, the scale is qualitative rather than quantitative. The quantitative values used by IPCC authors are ""subjective"" probabilities,<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/><ref name=""Uncertainty in the TAR""/><ref> {{citation
column1414: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/106.htm Sec. 2.6.2. ""Objective"" and ""Subjective"" Probabilities are not Always Explicitly Distinguished]
column1418: Bayesian]]"" probabilities,<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""> {{cite book
column1420: author= Granger Morgan, M. (Lead Author), H. Dowlatabadi, M. Henrion, D. Keith, R. Lempert, S. McBride, M. Small and T. Wilbanks (Contributing Authors)
column1421: title= Synthesis and Assessment Product 5.2: Best practice approaches for characterizing, communicating, and incorporating scientific uncertainty in decisionmaking. A Report by the U.S. Climate Change Science Program and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column1422: publisher= National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
column1425: url= http://www.globalchange.gov/publications/reports/scientific-assessments/saps/311 }} Tables 2.1 and 2.2 on pages 27-28 show two quantitative scales of uncertainty which are used in the TAR and AR4.</ref> and reflect the expert judgement of IPCC authors. In this formulation, probability is not only a function of an event, but also the state of information that is available to the person making the assessment.<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""/> In this framework, assigned probabilities may change as more or different information becomes available.<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""/> The IPCC also uses another scale to describe the likelihood of a particular event occurring.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> This is different from the confidence scales described above, and it is possible to assign confidence values to statements of likelihood. For example, the judgement that an event is improbable (e.g., rolling a [[dice]] twice and getting a six both times) may be assigned a high level of scientific confidence.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> Also, the probability that an event has an even chance of occurring (e.g., a tossed [[coin]] coming up heads) may also be assigned a high level of confidence.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> == Notes == {{Reflist

column2: This article is primarily about effects during the 21st century. For longer-term effects, see [[Long-term effects of global warming]]. See also [[Effects of global warming on humans]].}} {{Pp-semi-protected
column6: alt=Refer to caption and image description
column7: Summary of climate change impacts.]] [[File:Projected global warming in 2100 for a range of emission scenarios.png
column10: alt=Refer to caption and image description
column11: Projected global warming in 2100 for a range of emission scenarios.]] The '''effects of [[global warming]]''' are the environmental and social changes caused (directly or indirectly) by human emissions of [[greenhouse gas]]es. There is [[scientific opinion on climate change
column12: a scientific consensus that climate change is occurring]], and that human activities are the primary driver.<ref> {{citation
column13: author=Joint-statement by leaders of 18 scientific organizations: American Association for the Advancement of Science, American Chemical Society, American Geophysical Union, American Institute of Biological Sciences, American Meteorological Society, American Society of Agronomy, American Society of Plant Biologists, American Statistical Association, Association of Ecosystem Research Centers, Botanical Society of America, Crop Science Society of America, Ecological Society of America, Natural Science Collections, Alliance Organization of Biological Field Stations, Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, [[Society of Systematic Biologists]], Soil Science Society of America, University Corporation for Atmospheric Research
column15: title=Joint-statement on climate change by leaders of 18 scientific organizations
column18: publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science
column23: df= }}. Archived . </ref> Many impacts of climate change have already been observed, including [[Retreat of glaciers since 1850
column24: glacier retreat]],<ref name=""cramer observed effects"">Cramer, W., ''et al.'', Executive summary, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap18_FINAL.pdf Chapter 18: Detection and attribution of observed impacts] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap18_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), pp.982-984, in {{harvnb
column26: 2014}} </ref> changes in the timing of seasonal events<ref name=""cramer observed effects""/> (e.g., earlier flowering of plants),<ref>Settele, J., ''et al.'', Section 4.3.2.1: Phenology, in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap4_FINAL.pdf Chapter 4: Terrestrial and inland water systems] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap4_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), p.291, in {{harvnb
column28: 2014}} </ref> and changes in agricultural productivity.<ref name=""cramer observed effects""/> Future effects of climate change will vary depending on [[politics of global warming
column29: climate change policies]]<ref name=""adaptation and mitigation"">Oppenheimer, M., ''et al.'', ''Section 19.7.1: Relationship between Adaptation Efforts, Mitigation Efforts, and Residual Impacts,'' in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf Chapter 19: Emergent risks and key vulnerabilities] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1080-1085, in {{harvnb
column31: 2014}} </ref> and [[social development]].<ref>Oppenheimer, M., ''et al.'', ''Section 19.6.2.2. The Role of Adaptation and Alternative Development Pathways,'' in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf Chapter 19: Emergent risks and key vulnerabilities] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1072-1073, in {{harvnb
column33: 2014}} </ref> The two main policies to address climate change are reducing human greenhouse gas emissions ([[climate change mitigation]]) and [[climate change adaptation
column34: adapting to the impacts]] of climate change.<ref name=""climate change policy"">Denton, F., ''et al.'', ''Section 20.3. Contributions to Resilience through Climate Change Responses,'' in: [http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg2/WGIIAR5-Chap20_FINAL.pdf Chapter Climate-resilient pathways: adaptation, mitigation, and sustainable development] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap20_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1113-1118, in {{harvnb
column37: Geoengineering]] is another policy option.<ref name=""climate change policy""/> Near-term climate change policies could significantly affect long-term climate change impacts.<ref name=""adaptation and mitigation""/><ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Section A-3. The Decision-making Context, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.55, in {{harvnb
column39: 2014}} </ref> Stringent mitigation policies might be able to limit global warming (in 2100) to around 2 [[°C]] or below, relative to pre-industrial levels.<ref>SPM.4.1 Long‐term mitigation pathways, in: [http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf Summary for Policymakers], pp.11-15 (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20140702014732/http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf 2 July 2014)], in {{harvnb
column41: 2014}} </ref> Without mitigation, increased [[energy demand]] and extensive use of [[fossil fuel]]s<ref> Clarke, L., ''et al.'', Section 6.3.1.3 Baseline emissions projections from fossil fuels and industry (pp.17-18 of final draft), in: [http://report.mitigation2014.org/drafts/final-draft-postplenary/ipcc_wg3_ar5_final-draft_postplenary_chapter6.pdf Chapter 6: Assessing Transformation Pathways] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020021617/http://report.mitigation2014.org/drafts/final-draft-postplenary/ipcc_wg3_ar5_final-draft_postplenary_chapter6.pdf 20 October 2014]), in: {{harvnb
column43: 2014}} </ref> might lead to global warming of around 4 °C.<ref> Greenhouse Gas Concentrations and Climate Implications, p.14, in {{harvnb
column46: 2014}}. The range given by Prinn and Reilly is 3.3 to 5.5 °C, with a median of 3.9 °C. </ref><ref>SPM.3 Trends in stocks and flows of greenhouse gases and their drivers, in: [http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf Summary for Policymakers], p.8 (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20140702014732/http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf 2 July 2014)], in {{harvnb
column48: 2014}}. The range given by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change is 3.7 to 4.8 °C, relative to pre-industrial levels (2.5 to 7.8 °C including climate uncertainty). </ref> Higher magnitudes of global warming would be more difficult to adapt to,<ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Box TS.8: Adaptation Limits and Transformation, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.89, in {{harvnb
column50: 2014}} </ref> and would increase the risk of negative impacts.<ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Section B-1. Key Risks across Sectors and Regions, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.62, in {{harvnb
column53: attribution of recent climate change}} In this article, ""[[climate change]]"" means a change in climate that persists over a sustained period of time.<ref name=""ipcc definition of climate change""> {{citation
column61: at=Click on the image to open a pop-up that explains the differences between climate change and global warming.
column64: publisher=US EPA }} </ref> The [[World Meteorological Organization]] defines this time period as 30 years.<ref name=""ipcc definition of climate change""/> Examples of climate change include increases in global surface temperature (global warming), changes in [[rainfall]] patterns, and changes in the frequency of [[extreme weather]] events. Changes in climate may be due to natural causes, e.g., changes in the [[sun]]'s output, or due to human activities, e.g., changing the composition of the atmosphere.<ref name=""albritton climate change""/> Any human-induced changes in climate will occur against a background of natural climatic variations<ref name=""albritton climate change""> {{citation
column69: title=Box 1: What drives changes in climate?
column72: 2001}} </ref> and of variations in human activity such as population growth on shores or in arid areas which increase or decrease climate vulnerability.<ref name='NatureTaboo'>{{cite journal
column73: title = Lifting the taboo on adaptation
column88: pmid=17287795}}</ref> Also, the term ""anthropogenic forcing"" refers to the influence exerted on a habitat or chemical environment by humans, as opposed to a natural process.<ref> {{cite web
column90: title=Definition of Anthropogenic Forcing – Chemistry Dictionary and Glossary }} </ref> ==Temperature changes== {{Multiple image
column94: alt1=Global mean surface temperature change since 1880, relative to the 1951–1980 mean, showing a long term warming trend.
column95: image2= Projected global warming over the 21st century using three SRES greenhouse gas emissions scenarios. Data from CMIP3 (2007).png
column98: caption1=Global mean surface temperature change since 1880, relative to the 1951–1980 mean. Source: [http://data.giss.nasa.gov/gistemp/ NASA GISS]
column99: caption2=The graph above shows the average of a set of temperature simulations for the 20th century (black line), followed by projected temperatures for the 21st century based on three greenhouse gas emissions scenarios (colored lines).<ref name=""herring temperature projections""> {{cite web
column104: url= http://www.climatewatch.noaa.gov/article/2012/global-temperature-projections }} </ref> }} This article breaks down some of the impacts of climate change according to different levels of future global warming. This way of describing impacts has, for instance, been used in the IPCC ([[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]]) Assessment Reports on climate change.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""> {{citation
column106: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column111: 2007}}. </ref> The instrumental [[temperature record]] shows global warming of around 0.6 °C during the 20th century.<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""/> ===SRES emissions scenarios=== The future level of global warming is uncertain, but a wide range of estimates (projections) have been made.<ref name=""Overview of GHG emissions scenarios""> {{citation
column113: chapter= Chapter 3: Issues related to mitigation in the long-term context
column118: 2007}} </ref> The IPCC's ""[[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column119: SRES]]"" scenarios have been frequently used to make [[Global climate model#Projections of future climate change
column120: projections of future climate change]].<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column122: date=November 2012}} The SRES scenarios are ""[[Economics of climate change mitigation#Baselines
column123: baseline]]"" (or ""reference"") scenarios, which means that they do not take into account any current or future measures to limit GHG emissions (e.g., the UNFCCC's [[Kyoto Protocol]] and the [[2010 United Nations Climate Change Conference
column126: chapter= Chapter 2, Greenhouse Gas Emission Mitigation Scenarios and Implications
column128: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/080.htm Sec. 2.5.1.1 IPCC Emissions Scenarios and the SRES Process]
column131: 2001}}. </ref> Emissions projections of the SRES scenarios are broadly comparable in range to the baseline emissions scenarios that have been developed by the scientific community.<ref name=""Overview of GHG emissions scenarios""/><ref> {{citation
column137: 2007}}. </ref> In the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]], changes in future global mean temperature were projected using the six SRES ""marker"" emissions scenarios.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""> {{citation
column141: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html#table-spm-1 Sec. 1 3. Projected climate change and its impacts: Table SPM.1] }}, in {{harvnb
column143: 2007}}. </ref> Emissions projections for the six SRES ""marker"" scenarios are representative of the full set of forty SRES scenarios.<ref> {{citation
column145: chapter= Chapter 2, Greenhouse Gas Emission Mitigation Scenarios and Implications
column147: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/081.htm#2514 Sec. 2.5.1.4 Emissions and Other Results of the SRES Scenarios]
column150: 2001}}. </ref> For the lowest emissions SRES marker scenario (""B1"" - see the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column151: SRES]] article for details on this scenario), the best estimate for global mean temperature is an increase of {{convert
column155: 1}}<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> by the end of the 21st century. This projection is relative to global temperatures at the end of the 20th century.<ref>Temperature change in years 2090-2099 relative to years 1980-1999</ref> The ""likely"" range (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> for the SRES B1 marker scenario is {{convert
column161: 1}}.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> For the highest emissions SRES marker scenario (A1FI), the best estimate for global mean temperature increase is {{convert
column171: 1}}.<ref name=""Table of global warming projections""/> The range in temperature projections partly reflects (1) the choice of [[economics of global warming#Emissions scenarios
column172: emissions scenario]], and (2) the ""[[climate sensitivity]]"".<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column174: date=November 2012}} For (1), different scenarios make different assumptions of future social and economic development (e.g., [[economic growth]], [[population projection
column176: energy policies]]), which in turn affects projections of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column178: date=November 2012}} The projected magnitude of warming by 2100 is closely related to the level of cumulative emissions over the 21st century (i.e. total emissions between 2000-2100).<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions""> {{citation
column181: chapter=Ch 2: Which emissions pathways are consistent with a {{val
column185: u=°C}} temperature limit?: Sec 2.2 What determines long-term temperature?
column186: title=The Emissions Gap Report: Are the Copenhagen Accord pledges sufficient to limit global warming to {{val
column193: publisher=UNEP }}, p.28. This publication is also available in [http://www.unep.org/publications/ebooks/emissionsgapreport/ e-book format] </ref> The higher the cumulative emissions over this time period, the greater the level of warming is projected to occur.<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions""/> (2) reflects uncertainty in the response of the climate system to past and future GHG emissions, which is measured by the [[climate sensitivity]]).<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column195: date=November 2012}} Higher estimates of climate sensitivity lead to greater projected warming, while lower estimates of climate sensitivity lead to less projected warming.<ref> {{citation
column196: chapter=Box 8.1 Likelihood of exceeding a temperature increase at equilibrium, in: Ch 8: The Challenge of Stabilisation
column200: p=195}} </ref> Over the next several millennia, projections suggest that global warming could be irreversible.<ref name=""solomon irreversible climate change""/> Even if emissions were drastically reduced, global temperatures would remain close to their highest level for at least 1,000 years (see the later section on [[effects of global warming#Irreversibilities
column207: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-7-2.html Sec 10.7.2 Climate Change Commitment to Year 3000 and Beyond to Equilibrium]
column218: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column219: Two millennia of mean surface temperatures according to different reconstructions from [[Proxy (climate)
column220: climate proxies]], each smoothed on a decadal scale, with the [[instrumental temperature record]] overlaid in black.]]
column221: [[File:Global temperature relative to peak Holocene temperature, based on ocean cores (NASA).png
column225: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column226: Global surface temperature for the past 5.3 million years as inferred from cores of ocean [[sediment]]s taken all around the global ocean. The last 800,000 years are expanded in the lower half of the figure (image credit: [[NASA]]).<ref name=""hansen climate history""/>]]
column227: } Scientists have used various ""proxy"" data to assess past changes in Earth's climate ([[paleoclimate]]).<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""> {{citation
column229: title=NOAA Paleoclimatology Global Warming - The Story: Proxy Data
column232: publisher=NOAA Paleoclimatology Program - NCDC Paleoclimatology Branch }} </ref> Sources of proxy data include historical records (such as [[farmer]]s' logs), [[tree ring]]s, [[coral]]s, [[fossil pollen]], [[ice core]]s, and ocean and lake [[sediment]]s.<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""/> Analysis of these data suggest that recent warming is unusual in the past 400 years, possibly longer.<ref> {{citation
column235: title=Surface Temperature Reconstructions for the Last 2,000 Years
column238: author=Committee on Surface Temperature Reconstructions for the Last 2,000 Years, US National Research Council
column240: isbn=0-309-66144-7 }}, p.3 </ref> By the end of the 21st century, temperatures may increase to a level not experienced since the mid-[[Pliocene]], around 3 million years ago.<ref name=""jansen pliocene""> {{citation
column244: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch6s6-3-2.html Sec. 6.3.2 What Does the Record of the Mid-Pliocene Show?]
column247: 2007}}. </ref> At that time, models suggest that mean global temperatures were about 2–3 °C warmer than pre-industrial temperatures.<ref name=""jansen pliocene""/> Even a 2 °C rise above the pre-industrial level would be outside the range of temperatures experienced by human [[civilization]].<ref name=""hansen climate history""> {{citation
column251: title=NASA GISS: Science Briefs: Earth's Climate History: Implications for Tomorrow
column253: location=New York City, New York, USA
column255: at=[http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/686.htm Footnote 4, in Sec 19.8.2. What does Each Reason for Concern Indicate?]
column256: chapter=Ch 19. Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column264: [[File:Diagram showing ten indicators of global warming.png
column268: alt=Refer to caption and adjacent text
column269: Seven of these indicators would be expected to increase in a warming world and observations show that they are, in fact, increasing. Three would be expected to decrease and they are, in fact, decreasing.<ref> {{harvnb
column273: } [[File:Changes in climate indicators that show global warming.png
column278: This set of graphs show changes in climate indicators over several decades. Each of the different colored lines in each panel represents an independently analyzed set of data. The data come from many different technologies including [[weather station]]s, [[satellite]]s, [[weather balloons]], [[ship]]s and [[buoy]]s.<ref> {{harvnb
column281: p=3}} </ref>]] A broad range of evidence shows that the climate system has warmed.<ref> {{citation
column289: 2007}}. </ref> Evidence of global warming is shown in the graphs opposite. Some of the graphs show a positive [[trend estimation
column290: trend]], e.g., increasing temperature over land and the ocean, and [[current sea level rise
column291: sea level rise]]. Other graphs show a negative trend, e.g., decreased [[snow]] cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]], and declining [[Arctic sea ice]] extent. Evidence of warming is also apparent in living [[Effects of global warming#Observed impacts on biological systems
column292: (biological) systems]].<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> Human activities have contributed to a number of the observed changes in climate.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""> {{citation
column294: chapter= Chapter 9: Understanding and Attributing Climate Change
column300: 2007}}. </ref> This contribution has principally been through the burning of [[fossil fuel]]s, which has led to an increase in the concentration of GHGs in the atmosphere.<ref> {{citation
column304: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-human-and.html Human and Natural Drivers of Climate Change]
column305: title= Human and Natural Drivers of Climate Change }}, in {{harvnb
column307: 2007}}. </ref> Another human influence on the climate are [[sulfur dioxide]] emissions, which are a precursor to the formation of [[sulfate aerosols]] in the atmosphere.<ref> {{cite book
column309: author=Committee on the Science of Climate Change, US National Research Council
column311: title=Climate Change Science: An Analysis of Some Key Questions
column316: isbn=0-309-07574-2 }} </ref> Human-induced warming could lead to [[Effects of global warming#Abrupt or irreversible changes
column317: large-scale, irreversible, and/or abrupt changes]] in physical systems.<ref> {{citation
column321: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html Sec. 3. Projected climate change and its impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column324: title=ESRL News: New Study Shows Climate Change Largely Irreversible
column327: publisher=US Department of Commerce, NOAA, Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL)
column328: date=26 January 2009 }}</ref> An example of this is the melting of [[ice sheet]]s, which contributes to sea level rise.<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> The probability of warming having unforeseen consequences increases with the rate, magnitude, and duration of climate change.<ref> {{cite book
column333: publisher=[[United States National Academy of Sciences]]
column335: date=December 2012}}</ref> === Effects on weather === Observations show that there have been changes in weather.<ref> {{citation
column337: chapter= Chapter 1: Historical Overview of Climate Change Science
column339: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-1-2.html FAQ 1.2 What is the Relationship between Climate Change and Weather?]
column342: 2007}}. </ref> As climate changes, the [[probabilities]] of certain types of weather events are affected. [[File:Projected change in annual average precipitation for the 21st century, based on the SRES A1B emissions scenario, and simulated by the GFDL CM2.1 model.png
column346: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column347: Projected change in annual average precipitation by the end of the 21st century, based on a medium emissions scenario ([[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column348: SRES]] A1B) (Credit: NOAA [[Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory]]).<ref> {{citation
column352: title= GFDL Climate Modeling Research Highlights: Will the Wet Get Wetter and the Dry Drier
column357: title=Will the wet get wetter and the dry drier?
column361: publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory (GFDL)
column362: location=Princeton, NJ, USA }}. Revision 10/15/2008, 4:47:16 PM. </ref>]] Changes have been observed in the amount, intensity, frequency, and type of [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column370: date=November 2012}} Widespread increases in heavy precipitation have occurred, even in places where total rain amounts have decreased. With medium confidence (see [[Effects of global warming#Footnotes
column376: p=8}} </ref> concluded that human influences had contributed to an increase in heavy precipitation events at the global scale. Projections of future changes in precipitation show overall increases in the global average, but with substantial shifts in where and how precipitation falls.<ref name = ""USGCRP exec sum""/>{{Rp
column378: date=November 2012}} Projections suggest a reduction in rainfall in the [[subtropics]], and an increase in precipitation in subpolar latitudes and some [[equatorial region]]s.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> In other words, regions which are dry at present will in general become even drier, while regions that are currently wet will in general become even wetter.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> This projection does not apply to every locale, and in some cases can be modified by local conditions.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> ==== Extreme weather ==== {{See also
column380: Tropical cyclone#Global warming}} Over most land areas since the 1950s, it is very likely that there have been fewer or warmer cold days and nights.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""> IPCC (2013), Table SPM.1, in [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf Summary for Policymakers, p. 5] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140226155600/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column382: 2013}} </ref> Hot days and nights have also very likely become warmer or more frequent.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Human activities have very likely contributed to these trends.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> There may have been changes in other climate extremes (e.g., [[flood]]s, [[drought]]s and [[tropical cyclone]]s) but these changes are more difficult to identify.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Projections suggest changes in the frequency and intensity of some extreme weather events.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Confidence in projections varies over time.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> ; Near-term projections (2016–2035) Some changes (e.g., more frequent hot days) will probably be evident in the near term, while other near-term changes (e.g., more intense droughts and tropical cyclones) are more uncertain.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> ; Long-term projections (2081–2100) Future climate change will be associated with more very hot days and fewer very cold days.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> The frequency, length and intensity of [[heat wave]]s will very likely increase over most land areas.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> Higher growth in anthropogenic GHG emissions will be associated with larger increases in the frequency and severity of temperature extremes.<ref>Stocker, T.F., ''et al.'' (2013), Temperature Extremes, Heat Waves and Warm Spells, in: TFE.9, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf Technical Summary, p. 111] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221070705/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column384: 2013}} </ref> Assuming high growth in GHG emissions (IPCC scenario [[Representative Concentration Pathways
column385: RCP8.5]]), presently dry regions may be affected by an increase in the risk of drought and reductions in [[soil moisture]].<ref>Stocker, T.F., ''et al.'' (2013), Floods and Droughts, in: TFE.9, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf Technical Summary, p. 112] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221070705/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column387: 2013}} </ref> Over most of the mid-latitude land masses and wet tropical regions, extreme precipitation events will very likely become more intense and frequent.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> ; Tropical cyclones At the global scale, the frequency of tropical cyclones will probably decrease or be unchanged.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""> Christensen, J.H.,''et al.'' (2013), Cyclones, in: Executive Summary, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf Chapter 14: Climate Phenomena and their Relevance for Future Regional Climate Change, p. 1220] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221075046/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column389: 2013}} </ref> Global mean tropical cyclone maximum wind speed and precipitation rates will likely increase.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""/> Changes in tropical cyclones will probably vary by region, but these variations are uncertain.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""/> ; Effects of climate extremes The impacts of extreme events on the environment and human society will vary. Some impacts will be beneficial—e.g., fewer cold extremes will probably lead to fewer cold deaths.<ref name=""health summary""/> Overall, however, impacts will probably be mostly negative.<ref> {{citation
column397: chapter= Synthesis Report, Topic 5: The long-term perspective
column399: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains5-2.html Sec. 5.2 Key vulnerabilities, impacts and risks – long-term perspectives] }}, pp. 64–65, in {{harvnb
column402: Retreat of glaciers since 1850}} [[File:Glacier Mass Balance Map.png
column406: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column407: A map of the change in thickness of mountain glaciers since 1970. Thinning in orange and red, thickening in blue.]] [[File:SeaIce-Sept162012 HR.jpg
column412: A map that shows ice concentration on 16 September 2012, along with the extent of the previous record low (yellow line) and the mid-September median extent (black line) setting a new record low that was 18 percent smaller than the previous record and nearly 50 percent smaller than the long-term (1979-2000) average.]] The [[cryosphere]] is made up of areas of the Earth which are covered by snow or ice.<ref> [http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/glossary.html#C ""Cryosphere""], in {{harvnb
column414: 2012}} </ref> Observed changes in the cryosphere include declines in [[Arctic sea ice]] extent,<ref> {{citation
column419: title=Mass Balance of Mountain Glaciers in 2011
column422: 2012}} </ref> and reduced snow cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]].<ref> {{citation
column423: title=2011 Snow Cover in Northern Hemisphere
column426: 2012}} </ref> Solomon ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""ar4 arctic sea ice""> {{citation
column430: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-5-2.html TS.5.2 Large-Scale Projections for the 21st Century]
column433: 2007}} </ref> assessed the potential impacts of climate change on [[summer]]time Arctic sea ice extent. Assuming high growth in greenhouse gas emissions ([[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column434: SRES A2]]), some models projected that Arctic sea ice in the summer could largely disappear by the end of the 21st century.<ref name=""ar4 arctic sea ice""/> More recent projections suggest that the Arctic summers could be ice-free (defined as ice extent less than 1 million square km) as early as 2025-2030.<ref> {{citation
column443: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-4.html Box 10.1: Future Abrupt Climate Change, ‘Climate Surprises’, and Irreversible Changes: Glaciers and ice caps]
column447: p=776}} </ref> and snow cover are projected to continue their widespread retreat.<ref> {{citation
column451: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-3-2.html Sec 10.3.3.2 Changes in Snow Cover and Frozen Ground]
column455: pp=770, 772}} </ref> In the western mountains of [[North America]], increasing temperatures and changes in precipitation are projected to lead to reduced [[snowpack]].<ref> {{citation
column463: p=627}} </ref> Snowpack is the seasonal accumulation of slow-melting snow.<ref> [http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/glossary.html#S ""Snowpack""], in {{harvnb
column465: 2012}} </ref> The melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column466: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s could contribute to sea level rise, especially over long time-scales (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets
column467: Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets]]).<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> Changes in the cryosphere are projected to have social impacts.<ref> Some of these impacts are included in table SPM.2: {{citation
column468: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html#spm2 3 Projected climate change and its impacts: Table SPM.2]
column473: pp=11–12}} </ref> For example, in some regions, glacier retreat could increase the risk of reductions in seasonal water availability.<ref> {{citation
column475: chapter=Ch 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column482: title=Potential impacts of a warming climate on water availability in snow-dominated regions: Abstract
column490: display-authors=etal}} </ref> estimated that more than one-sixth of the [[world's population]] rely on glaciers and snowpack for their water supply. ===Oceans=== {{Main
column491: Effects of global warming on oceans}} The role of the oceans in global warming is complex. The oceans serve as a sink for carbon dioxide, taking up much that would otherwise remain in the atmosphere, but increased levels of {{chem
column493: 2}} have led to [[ocean acidification]]. Furthermore, as the temperature of the oceans increases, they become less able to absorb excess {{chem
column495: 2}}. The ocean have also acted as a sink in absorbing extra heat from the atmosphere.<ref name=""statecl"">{{cite book
column497: publisher = Website of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration: National Climatic Data Center
column498: title = State of the Climate in 2009, as appearing in the July 2010 issue (Vol. 91) of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society (BAMS). Supplemental and Summary Materials: Report at a Glance: Highlights
column502: date=November 2012}} The increase in ocean [[heat content]] is much larger than any other store of [[energy]] in the Earth’s heat balance over the two periods 1961 to 2003 and 1993 to 2003, and accounts for more than 90% of the possible increase in heat content of the Earth system during these periods.<ref>{{citation
column503: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch5s5-2-2-3.html Sec 5.2.2.3 Implications for Earth’s Heat Balance]
column504: chapter=Ch. 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column510: title=Climate Graphics by Skeptical Science: Global Warming Components:
column511: at=Components of global warming for the period 1993 to 2003 calculated from IPCC AR4 5.2.2.3
column513: publisher=Skeptical Science }} </ref> Global warming is projected to have a number of effects on the oceans. Ongoing effects include rising sea levels due to thermal expansion and melting of glaciers and ice sheets, and warming of the ocean surface, leading to increased temperature stratification. Other possible effects include large-scale changes in ocean circulation. ====Acidification==== {{Main
column514: Ocean acidification}} [[File:Changes in aragonite saturation of the world's oceans, 1880-2012 (US EPA).png
column518: alt=refer to caption and image description
column519: This map shows changes in the amount of [[aragonite]] dissolved in [[ocean]] surface waters between the 1880s and the most recent decade (2003-2012).<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/> Historical modeling suggests that since the 1880s, increased {{CO2}} has led to lower [[aragonite]] saturation levels (less availability of minerals) in the oceans around the world.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""> {{Include-USGov
column522: title=Climate Change Indicators in the United States, 2012, 2nd ed: Ocean Acidity: Figure 2. Changes in Aragonite Saturation of the World's Oceans, 1880-2012
column524: url=http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/science/indicators/oceans/acidity.html#fragment-2 }} }} </ref> The largest decreases in aragonite saturation have occurred in [[tropical]] waters.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/> However, decreases in cold areas may be of greater concern because colder waters typically have lower aragonite levels to begin with.<ref name=""us epa 2012 aragonite""/>]] About one-third of the carbon dioxide emitted by human activity has already been taken up by the oceans.<ref name=""nrc 2008b ocean acidification""> {{cite book
column526: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column530: 2008b}} </ref> As carbon dioxide dissolves in [[sea water]], [[carbonic acid]] is formed, which has the effect of acidifying the ocean, measured as a change in [[pH]]. The uptake of human carbon emissions since the year 1750 has led to an average decrease in pH of 0.1 units.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 ocean acidification""> {{citation
column536: 2007}}. </ref> Projections using the SRES emissions scenarios suggest a further reduction in average global surface ocean pH of between 0.14 and 0.35 units over the 21st century. The effects of ocean acidification on the marine [[biosphere]] have yet to be documented.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 ocean acidification""/> Laboratory experiments suggest beneficial effects for a few species, with potentially highly detrimental effects for a substantial number of species.<ref name=""nrc 2008b ocean acidification""/> With medium confidence, Fischlin ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column538: chapter = Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods, and services
column543: 2007}}. </ref> projected that future ocean acidification and climate change would impair a wide range of [[plankton]]ic and shallow [[benthos
column544: benthic]] marine organisms that use [[aragonite]] to make their shells or skeletons, such as [[coral]]s and marine [[snail]]s ([[pteropoda
column545: pteropods]]), with significant impacts particularly in the Southern Ocean. ====Oxygen depletion==== The amount of oxygen dissolved in the oceans may decline, with adverse consequences for ocean life.<ref>{{Cite journal
column553: title = Abrupt Climate Change and Extinction Events in Earth History
column572: title = Long-term ocean oxygen depletion in response to carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels
column576: Future sea level}} [[File:Trends in global average absolute sea level, 1870-2008 (US EPA).png
column580: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column581: Trends in global average absolute sea level, 1870-2008.<ref> {{cite web
column583: title= Sea Level: Climate Change: US EPA
column586: year=2010 }} </ref>]] There is strong evidence that global sea level rose gradually over the 20th century.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""> {{citation
column588: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column590: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-5-1.html FAQ 5.1 Is Sea Level Rising?]
column595: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column600: 2007}}. </ref> concluded that between the mid-19th and mid-20th centuries, the rate of sea level rise increased. Authors of the IPCC Fourth Assessment Synthesis Report (IPCC AR4 SYR, 2007)<ref name= ""Observed changes in climate and their effects""> {{citation
column604: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms1.html Sec. 1. Observed changes in climate and their effects] }}, p. 5, in {{harvnb
column606: 2007}}. </ref> reported that between the years 1961 and 2003, global average sea level rose at an average rate of 1.8 mm per year (mm/yr), with a range of 1.3–2.3 mm/yr. Between 1993 and 2003, the rate increased above the previous period to 3.1 mm/yr (range of 2.4–3.8 mm/yr). Authors of IPCC AR4 SYR (2007)<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""/> were uncertain whether the increase in rate from 1993 to 2003 was due to [[climate change#Internal forcing mechanisms
column607: natural variations]] in sea level over the time period, or whether it reflected an increase in the underlying long-term trend. There are two main factors that have contributed to observed sea level rise.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""/> The first is [[thermal expansion]]: as ocean water warms, it expands.<ref> {{citation
column611: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/013.htm#b4 Box 2: What causes sea level to change?]
column614: 2007}}. </ref> The second is from the contribution of land-based ice due to increased melting. The major store of water on land is found in glaciers and ice sheets. Anthropogenic forces very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""> {{citation
column618: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-2.html Box TS.1: Treatment of Uncertainties in the Working Group I Assessment]
column621: 2007}}. </ref> contributed to sea level rise during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> There is a widespread consensus that substantial long-term sea level rise will continue for centuries to come.<ref> {{citation
column622: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column626: p=245}}. </ref> In their Fourth Assessment Report, the IPCC<ref> {{citation
column628: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column632: 2007}}. </ref> projected sea level rise to the end of the 21st century using the SRES emissions scenarios. Across the six SRES marker scenarios, sea level was projected to rise by 18 to 59 cm (7.1 to 23.2 in), relative to sea level at the end of the 20th century.<ref>change in sea level by 2090–99, relative to 1980–99</ref> Thermal expansion is the largest component in these projections, contributing 70-75% of the central estimate for all scenarios.<ref> {{citation
column639: 2007}}. </ref> Due to a lack of scientific understanding, this sea level rise estimate does not include all of the possible contributions of ice sheets (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets
column640: Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets]]). An assessment of the [[scientific literature]] on climate change was published in 2010 by the [[US National Research Council]] (US NRC, 2010).<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""> {{citation
column642: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column645: 2010}}. </ref> NRC (2010)<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> described the projections in AR4 (i.e. those cited in the above paragraph) as ""conservative"", and summarized the results of more recent studies. Cited studies suggested a great deal of uncertainty in projections.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> A range of projections suggested possible sea level rise by the end of the 21st century of between 0.56 and 2 m, relative to sea levels at the end of the 20th century.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> ====Ocean temperature rise==== [[File:Heat content700m2000myr.png
column650: Global ocean heat content from 1955-2012]] From 1961 to 2003, the global ocean temperature has risen by 0.10 °C from the surface to a depth of 700 m. There is variability both year-to-year and over longer time scales, with global ocean heat content observations showing high rates of warming for 1991–2003, but some cooling from 2003 to 2007.<ref> {{citation
column652: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column658: date=November 2012}} </ref> The temperature of the Antarctic [[Southern Ocean]] rose by 0.17 °C (0.31 °F) between the 1950s and the 1980s, nearly twice the rate for the world's oceans as a whole.<ref> {{cite journal
column662: title= Warming of the Southern Ocean Since the 1950s
column672: ref=harv }}</ref> As well as having effects on ecosystems (e.g. by melting sea ice, affecting algae that grow on its underside), warming reduces the ocean's ability to absorb {{chem
column675: date=June 2008}} It is likely (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> that anthropogenic forcing contributed to the general warming observed in the upper several hundred metres of the ocean during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> ==Regions== {{Main
column676: Regional effects of global warming}} {{Multiple image
column679: image1=Temperatures across the world in the 1880s (left) and the 1980s (right), as compared to average temperatures from 1951 to 1980 (US EPA).jpg
column680: alt1=Temperatures in most parts of the world were warmer in the 1980s compared to the 1880s
column681: image2= Map of projected global warming across the globe by the 2050s. Projections based on three SRES greenhouse gas emissions scenarios. Data from CMIP3 (2007).jpg
column682: alt2=Future warming across the globe varies according to different projections of greenhouse gas emissions
column684: caption1=Temperatures across the world in the 1880s (left) and the 1980s (right), as compared to average temperatures from 1951 to 1980.<ref> {{cite web
column687: title=Science: Climate Change: US EPA (Climate Change Science Overview)
column690: caption2=Projected changes in average temperatures across the world in the 2050s under three greenhouse gas (GHG) [[Economics of global warming#Emissions scenarios
column691: emissions scenarios]].<ref name=""herring temperature projections""/> }} Regional effects of global warming vary in nature. Some are the result of a generalised global change, such as rising temperature, resulting in local effects, such as melting ice. In other cases, a change may be related to a change in a particular ocean current or weather system. In such cases, the regional effect may be disproportionate and will not necessarily follow the global trend. There are three major ways in which global warming will make changes to regional climate: melting or forming ice, changing the [[hydrological cycle]] (of [[evaporation]] and [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column693: currents in the oceans]] and air flows in the atmosphere. The coast can also be considered a region, and will suffer severe impacts from [[sea level rise]]. ===Observed impacts=== With very high confidence, Rosenzweig ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> concluded that physical and biological systems on all continents and in most oceans had been affected by recent climate changes, particularly regional temperature increases. Impacts include earlier leafing of [[tree]]s and [[plant]]s over many regions; movements of species to higher latitudes and altitudes in the Northern Hemisphere; changes in [[bird migration]]s in Europe, North America and Australia; and shifting of the oceans' [[plankton]] and [[fish]] from cold- to warm-adapted communities.<ref name=""nasa briefs""/> The human influence on the climate can be seen in the geographical pattern of observed warming, with greater temperature increases over land and in [[polar region]]s rather than over the oceans.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""> {{cite book
column695: title=Understanding and Responding to Climate Change. A brochure prepared by the US National Research Council (US NRC)
column696: publisher=[http://dels.nas.edu/basc Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate], National Academy of Sciences
column701: date=November 2012}} Using models, it is possible to identify the human ""signal"" of global warming over both land and ocean areas.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""/>{{Rp
column703: date=November 2012}} ===Projected impacts=== Projections of future climate changes at the regional scale do not hold as high a level of scientific confidence as projections made at the global scale.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure""/>{{Rp
column705: date=November 2012}} It is, however, expected that future warming will follow a similar geographical pattern to that seen already, with greatest warming over land and high northern [[latitude]]s, and least over the [[Southern Ocean]] and parts of the [[North Atlantic Ocean]].<ref> {{citation
column709: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-projections-of.html Projections of Future Changes in Climate] }}, in {{harvnb
column711: 2007}}. </ref> Nearly all land areas will very likely warm more than the global average.<ref name=""tar table of robust findings""> {{citation
column718: megadeltas]] are regions that are likely to be especially affected by climate change.<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions""> {{citation
column722: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-3.html Sec. 3.3.3 Especially affected systems, sectors and regions] }}, in {{harvnb
column726: less-developed]] areas are at most risk of experiencing negative impacts due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts""> {{citation
column728: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column730: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Distribution of Impacts, in: Sec 19.3.7 Update on 'Reasons for Concern']
column734: p=796}} </ref> [[Developed countries]] are also vulnerable to climate change.<ref name=""schneider regional vulnerabilities""> {{citation
column736: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column742: p=792}} </ref> For example, developed countries will be negatively affected by increases in the severity and frequency of some [[extreme weather]] events, such as [[heat wave]]s.<ref name=""schneider regional vulnerabilities""/> In all regions, some people can be particularly at risk from climate change, such as the [[poverty
column743: poor]], young [[children]] and the [[elderly]].<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions""/><ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts""/><ref> {{citation
column747: at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-2-5.html Sec 7.4.2.5 Social issues and Sec 7.4.3 Key vulnerabilities]
column752: Effects of climate change on humans
column753: Climate change, industry and society}} {{See also
column754: Climate change and gender}} The impacts of climate change can be thought of in terms of sensitivity and vulnerability. ""Sensitivity"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be affected, positively or negatively, by climate change and/or [[climate change#Causes
column755: climate variability]]. ""Vulnerability"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be adversely affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
column760: 2007}}. </ref> The sensitivity of human society to climate change varies. Sectors sensitive to climate change include water resources, coastal zones, human settlements, and human health. Industries sensitive to climate change include [[climate change and agriculture
column767: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/008.htm#24 Sec. 2.4. Many Human Systems are Sensitive to Climate Change, and Some are Vulnerable] }}, in {{harvnb
column771: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column780: 2007–2008 world food price crisis}} [[File:Net crops tropicalvsworld.png
column782: Graph of net crop production worldwide and in selected tropical countries. Raw data from the United Nations. [http://faostat3.fao.org/browse/Q/QC/E]]] Climate change will impact agriculture and food production around the world due to: the effects of elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere, higher temperatures, altered precipitation and [[transpiration]] regimes, increased frequency of extreme events, and modified [[weed]], [[pest (organism)
column785: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column791: p=282}}. </ref> In general, low-latitude areas are at most risk of having decreased crop yields.<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> As of 2007, the effects of regional climate change on agriculture have been small.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""> {{citation
column793: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column798: 2007}}. </ref> Changes in crop [[phenology]] provide important evidence of the response to recent regional climate change.<ref> {{citation
column800: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column805: 2007}}. </ref> Phenology is the study of natural phenomena that recur periodically, and how these phenomena relate to climate and seasonal changes.<ref> {{citation
column810: 2007}}. </ref> A significant advance in phenology has been observed for agriculture and forestry in large parts of the Northern Hemisphere.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> ====Projections==== [[File:Projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming.png
column815: Projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""> [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12877&page=161 Figure 5.1], p.161, in: Sec 5.1 FOOD PRODUCTION, PRICES, AND HUNGER, in: Ch 5: Impacts in the Next Few Decades and Coming Centuries, in: {{harvnb
column817: 2011}} </ref>]] [[File:Projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming.png
column822: Projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""/>]] With low to medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> projected that for about a 1 to 3 °C increase in global mean temperature (by the years 2090-2100, relative to average temperatures in the years 1990–2000), there would be productivity decreases for some [[cereal]]s in low latitudes, and productivity increases in high latitudes. With medium confidence, global production potential was projected to:<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> * increase up to around 3 °C, * very likely decrease above about 3 °C. Most of the studies on global agriculture assessed by Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> had not incorporated a number of critical factors, including changes in extreme events, or the spread of pests and diseases. Studies had also not considered the development of specific practices or technologies to aid [[adaptation to global warming#Agricultural production
column823: adaptation to climate change]].<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""> {{citation
column825: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column831: p=790}}. </ref> The graphs opposite show the projected effects of climate change on selected crop yields.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 text""> Sec 5.1 FOOD PRODUCTION, PRICES, AND HUNGER, [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12877&page=160 pp.160-162], in: Ch 5: Impacts in the Next Few Decades and Coming Centuries, in {{harvnb
column833: 2011}} </ref> Actual changes in yields may be above or below these central estimates.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 text""/> The projections above can be expressed relative to pre-industrial (1750) temperatures.<ref> {{citation
column835: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column837: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-1.html Box 19.2. Reference for temperature levels]
column841: p=783}}. </ref> 0.6 °C of warming is estimated to have occurred between 1750 and 1990-2000. Add 0.6 °C to the above projections to convert them from a 1990-2000 to pre-industrial baseline. =====Food security===== Easterling ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column843: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column845: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch5s5-6-5.html Sec. 5.6.5 Food security and vulnerability]
column848: 2007}}. </ref> assessed studies that made quantitative projections of climate change impacts on [[food security]]. It was noted that these projections were highly uncertain and had limitations. However, the assessed studies suggested a number of fairly robust findings. The first was that climate change would likely increase the number of people at risk of [[hunger]] compared with reference scenarios with no climate change. Climate change impacts depended strongly on projected future social and economic development. Additionally, the magnitude of climate change impacts was projected to be smaller compared to the impact of social and economic development. In 2006, the global estimate for the number of people [[malnutrition
column854: accessdate=2011-07-07 }} </ref> Under the SRES A1, B1, and B2 scenarios (see the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios#Scenario families
column855: SRES article]] for information on each scenario group), projections for the year 2080 showed a reduction in the number of people undernourished of about 560-700 million people, with a global total of undernourished people of 100-240 million in 2080. By contrast, the SRES A2 scenario showed only a small decrease in the risk of hunger from 2006 levels. The smaller reduction under A2 was attributed to the higher projected future population level in this scenario. ====Droughts and agriculture==== Some evidence suggests that droughts have been occurring more frequently because of global warming and they are expected to become more frequent and intense in Africa, southern Europe, the Middle East, most of the Americas, Australia, and Southeast Asia.<ref>{{Cite journal
column859: title = Drought under global warming: A review
column860: journal = Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Climate Change
column865: pmc = }}</ref> However, other research suggests that there has been little change in drought over the past 60 years.<ref>{{Cite journal
column867: title = Little change in global drought over the past 60 years
column880: pmid=23151587}}</ref> Their impacts are aggravated because of increased water demand, population growth, urban expansion, and environmental protection efforts in many areas.<ref>{{Cite journal
column893: bibcode = 2011JHyd..403..157M }}</ref> Droughts result in crop failures and the loss of pasture grazing land for livestock.<ref>{{Cite journal
column901: title = Measuring economic impacts of drought: A review and discussion
column909: Effects of global warming on human health}} Human beings are exposed to climate change through changing weather patterns (temperature, precipitation, sea-level rise and more frequent extreme events) and indirectly through changes in water, air and food quality and changes in ecosystems, agriculture, industry and settlements and the economy (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007:393).<ref name=""health summary""> {{citation
column916: 2007}}. </ref> According to an assessment of the scientific literature by Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007:393),<ref name=""health summary""/> the effects of climate change to date have been small, but are projected to progressively increase in all countries and regions. A study by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO, 2009)<ref> {{cite book
column919: title= Global health risks: mortality and burden of disease attributable to selected major risks
column927: url= http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/global_health_risks/en/index.html }} </ref> estimated the effect of climate change on human health. Not all of the effects of climate change were included in their estimates, for example, the effects of more frequent and extreme storms were excluded. Climate change was estimated to have been responsible for 3% of [[diarrhoea]], 3% of [[malaria]], and 3.8% of [[dengue fever]] deaths worldwide in 2004. Total attributable mortality was about 0.2% of deaths in 2004; of these, 85% were child deaths. ====Projections==== With high confidence, authors of the IPCC AR4 Synthesis report<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report""/>{{Rp
column929: date=November 2012}} projected that climate change would bring some benefits in temperate areas, such as fewer deaths from cold exposure, and some mixed effects such as changes in range and transmission potential of [[malaria]] in [[Africa]]. Benefits were projected to be outweighed by negative health effects of rising temperatures, especially in developing countries. With very high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/>{{Rp
column931: date=November 2012}} concluded that economic development was an important component of possible adaptation to climate change. Economic growth on its own, however, was not judged to be sufficient to insulate the world's population from disease and injury due to climate change. Future vulnerability to climate change will depend not only on the extent of social and economic change, but also on how the benefits and costs of change are distributed in society.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""> {{citation
column935: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-3-2.html Sec. 8.3.2 Future vulnerability to climate change]
column938: 2007}}. </ref> For example, in the 19th century, rapid [[urbanization]] in [[western Europe]] lead to a plummeting in population health.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""/> Other factors important in determining the health of populations include [[education]], the availability of health services, and [[public health
column946: Precipitation during the 20th century and up through 2008 during global warming, the [[NOAA]] estimating an observed trend over that period of 1.87% global precipitation increase per century.]] A number of climate-related trends have been observed that affect [[water resources]]. These include changes in precipitation, the crysosphere and [[surface water]]s (e.g., changes in [[river flows]]).<ref> {{citation
column948: chapter = Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column953: 2007}}. </ref> Observed and projected impacts of climate change on [[freshwater]] systems and their management are mainly due to changes in temperature, sea level and precipitation variability.<ref name=""freshwater impacts""> {{citation
column955: chapter= Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column960: 2007}}. </ref> Sea level rise will extend areas of [[salinization]] of [[groundwater]] and [[estuary
column961: estuaries]], resulting in a decrease in freshwater availability for humans and ecosystems in coastal areas. In an assessment of the [[scientific literature]], Kundzewicz ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""freshwater impacts""/> concluded, with high confidence, that: * the negative impacts of climate change on freshwater systems outweigh the benefits. All of the regions assessed in the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]] ([[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], [[Europe]], [[Latin America]], [[North America]], [[Polar region]]s ([[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]]), and small islands) showed an overall net negative impact of climate change on water resources and freshwater ecosystems. * [[semi-arid climate
column962: Semi-arid]] and [[arid]] areas are particularly exposed to the impacts of climate change on freshwater. With very high confidence, it was judged that many of these areas, e.g., the [[Mediterranean basin]], [[Western United States]], [[Southern Africa]], and north-eastern [[Brazil]], would suffer a decrease in water resources due to climate change. ===Migration and conflict=== {{See also
column964: General circulation models]] project that the future climate change will bring wetter coasts, drier mid-continent areas, and further sea level rise.<ref name=""sar migration""> {{citation
column966: chapter= Chapter 12: Human settlements in a changing climate: impacts and adaptation
column970: 1996}}. </ref> Such changes could result in the gravest effects of climate change through [[human migration]].<ref>[[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios]], 10.2.5.1. Human Settlements, https://www.ipcc.ch/ipccreports/sres/regional/275.htm</ref> Millions might be displaced by [[shoreline erosion]]s, river and coastal [[flood]]ing, or severe [[drought]]. Migration related to climate change is likely to be predominantly from [[rural area]]s in [[developing countries]] to towns and [[cities]].<ref name=""sar migration""/>{{Rp
column974: title = Managing social risks: Empower communities to protect themselves
column975: chapter = Part One: Chapter 2: Reducing Human Vulnerability: Helping People Help Themselves
column978: 2010}}. </ref> In the short term climate stress is likely to add incrementally to existing migration patterns rather than generating entirely new flows of people.<ref name=""wdr migration""/>{{Rp
column980: date=November 2012}} It has been argued that environmental degradation, loss of access to resources (e.g., water resources),<ref> {{citation
column987: 2001}}. </ref> and resulting human migration could become a source of political and even [[military conflict]].<ref name=""tar migration""> {{citation
column989: chapter= Chapter 7: Human Settlements, Energy, and Industry
column994: 2001}}. </ref> Factors other than climate change may, however, be more important in affecting conflict. For example, Wilbanks ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column996: chapter = Chapter 7: Industry, settlement and society
column998: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-1.html Sec. 7.4.1 General effects: Box 7.2. Environmental migration]
column1001: 2007}}. </ref> suggested that major environmentally influenced conflicts in Africa were more to do with the relative abundance of resources, e.g., [[oil]] and [[diamond]]s, than with resource scarcity. Scott ''et al.'' (2001) placed only low confidence in predictions of increased conflict due to climate change.<ref name=""tar migration""/> A 2013 study found that significant climatic changes were associated with a higher risk of conflict worldwide, and predicted that ""amplified rates of human conflict could represent a large and critical social impact of anthropogenic climate change in both low- and high-income countries.""<ref>{{cite journal
column1002: vauthors=Hsiang SM, Burke M, Miguel E
column1003: title=Quantifying the influence of climate on human conflict
column1011: url=}}</ref> Similarly, a 2014 study found that higher temperatures were associated with a greater likelihood of violent crime, and predicted that global warming would cause millions of such crimes in the United States alone during the 21st century.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1013: title = Crime, weather, and climate change
column1014: journal = Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
column1019: pages=274–302}}</ref> Military planners are concerned that global warming is a ""threat multiplier"". ""Whether it is poverty, food and [[water scarcity]], diseases, economic instability, or threat of natural disasters, the broad range of changing climatic conditions may be far reaching. These challenges may threaten stability in much of the world"".<ref>{{cite journal
column1024: journal =Proceedings of the US Naval Institute
column1031: Economic impacts of climate change}} [[Aggregate data
column1032: Aggregating]] impacts adds up the total impact of climate change across sectors and/or regions.<ref> [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/annexessglossary-a-d.html Glossary A-D: ""Aggregate impacts""], in {{harvnb
column1035: p=76}} </ref> Examples of aggregate measures include [[Economic impacts of climate change#Distribution of impacts
column1036: economic cost]] (e.g., changes in [[gross domestic product]] (GDP) and the [[Economic impacts of climate change#Marginal impacts
column1037: social cost of carbon]]), changes in ecosystems (e.g., changes over land area from one type of vegetation to another),<ref> {{citation
column1039: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1041: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/677.htm Sec. 19.5.3 Insights and Lessons: Vulnerability over Time: Table 19-5]
column1044: 2001}}. </ref> human health impacts, and the number of people affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
column1046: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1048: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/676.htm Sec. 19.5.2. Insights and Lessons: The Static Picture]
column1051: 2001}}. </ref> Aggregate measures such as economic cost require researchers to make [[value judgement]]s over the importance of impacts occurring in different regions and at different times. ====Observed impacts==== Global losses reveal rapidly rising costs due to extreme weather-related events since the 1970s.<ref> {{citation
column1053: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of observed changes and responses in natural and managed systems
column1055: at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-8-5.html Sec. 1.3.8.5 Summary of disasters and hazards]
column1059: Socio-economic]] factors have contributed to the observed trend of global losses, e.g., population growth, increased [[wealth]].<ref name=""disaster losses""> {{citation
column1065: 2001}}. </ref> Part of the growth is also related to regional climatic factors, e.g., changes in precipitation and flooding events. It is difficult to quantify the relative impact of socio-economic factors and climate change on the observed trend.<ref name=""disaster losses""/> The trend does, however, suggest increasing vulnerability of social systems to climate change.<ref name=""disaster losses""/><ref>[http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/billions Billion-Dollar Weather and Climate Disasters]</ref> ====Projected impacts==== The total economic impacts from climate change are highly uncertain.<ref> {{citation
column1067: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1072: 2007}}. </ref> With medium confidence, Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""> {{citation
column1074: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1079: 2001}}. </ref> concluded that world GDP would change by plus or minus a few percent for a small increase in global mean temperature (up to around 2 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level). Most studies assessed by Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""/> projected losses in world GDP for a medium increase in global mean temperature (above 2-3 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level), with increasing losses for greater temperature increases. This assessment is consistent with the findings of more recent studies, as reviewed by Hitz and Smith (2004).<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""> {{citation
column1081: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
