column449: 2013}} </ref> Over most of the mid-latitude land masses and wet tropical regions, extreme precipitation events will very likely become more intense and frequent.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""/> ; Heat waves [[Global warming]] boosts the probability of [[extreme weather]] events, like heat waves, far more than it boosts more moderate events.<ref>{{cite journal
column450: title=Has global warming brought an early summer to the US?
column452: url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn21636-has-global-warming-brought-an-early-summer-to-the-us.html}}</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/11/science/earth/global-warming-makes-heat-waves-more-likely-study-finds.html ''Global Warming Makes Heat Waves More Likely, Study Finds''] 10 July 2012 [[NYT]]</ref><ref>{{cite journal
column457: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
column467: first3=R }}</ref> In the last 30–40 years, heat waves with high humidity have became more frequent and severe. Extremely hot nights have doubled in frequency. The area in which extremely hot summers are observed, has increased 50-100 fold. These changes are not explained by natural variability, and attributed by climate scientists to the influence of [[wikt:anthropogenic
column468: anthropogenic]] climate change. Heat waves with high humidity pose a big risk to human health while heat waves with low humidity lead to dry conditions that increase [[wildfires]]. The mortality from extreme heat is larger than the mortality from hurricanes, lightning, tornadoes, floods, and earthquakes together<ref name=""Heat Waves: The Details"">{{cite web
column472: accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref> See also [[2018 heat wave]]. ; Tropical cyclones At the global scale, the frequency of tropical cyclones will probably decrease or be unchanged.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""> Christensen, J.H.,''et al.'' (2013), Cyclones, in: Executive Summary, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf Chapter 14: Climate Phenomena and their Relevance for Future Regional Climate Change, p. 1220] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221075046/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column474: 2013}} </ref> Global mean tropical cyclone maximum wind speed and precipitation rates will likely increase.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""/> Changes in tropical cyclones will probably vary by region, but these variations are uncertain.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones""/> ; Effects of climate extremes The impacts of extreme events on the environment and human society will vary. Some impacts will be beneficial—e.g., fewer cold extremes will probably lead to fewer cold deaths.<ref name=""health summary""/> Overall, however, impacts will probably be mostly negative.<ref> {{citation
column481: chapter= Synthesis Report, Topic 5: The long-term perspective
column483: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains5-2.html Sec. 5.2 Key vulnerabilities, impacts and risks – long-term perspectives] }}, pp. 64–65, in {{harvnb
column485: 2007}}. </ref> A rise in temperature will cause the glaciers to melt, when water heats up, it expands, both of these factors contribute to a rise in sea levels which will put people living in lowland areas, for example The Netherlands in danger. ===Cryosphere=== {{See also
column486: Retreat of glaciers since 1850}} [[File:Glacier Mass Balance Map.png
column489: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column490: A map of the change in thickness of mountain glaciers since 1970. Thinning in orange and red, thickening in blue.]] [[File:SeaIce-Sept162012 HR.jpg
column494: A map that shows ice concentration on 16 September 2012, along with the extent of the previous record low (yellow line) and the mid-September median extent (black line) setting a new record low that was 18 percent smaller than the previous record and nearly 50 percent smaller than the long-term (1979–2000) average.]] The [[cryosphere]] is made up of areas of the Earth which are covered by snow or ice.<ref> [http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/glossary.html#C ""Cryosphere""], in {{harvnb
column496: 2012}} </ref> Observed changes in the cryosphere include declines in [[Arctic sea ice]] extent,<ref> {{citation
column501: title=Mass Balance of Mountain Glaciers in 2011
column504: 2012}} </ref> and reduced snow cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]].<ref> {{citation
column505: title=2011 Snow Cover in Northern Hemisphere
column508: 2012}} </ref> Solomon ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""ar4 arctic sea ice""> {{citation
column512: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-5-2.html TS.5.2 Large-Scale Projections for the 21st Century]
column515: 2007}} </ref> assessed the potential impacts of climate change on [[summer]]time Arctic sea ice extent. Assuming high growth in greenhouse gas emissions ([[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
column516: SRES A2]]), some models projected that Arctic sea ice in the summer could largely disappear by the end of the 21st century.<ref name=""ar4 arctic sea ice""/> More recent projections suggest that the Arctic summers could be ice-free (defined as ice extent less than 1 million square km) as early as 2025–2030.<ref> {{citation
column525: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-4.html Box 10.1: Future Abrupt Climate Change, ‘Climate Surprises’, and Irreversible Changes: Glaciers and ice caps]
column529: p=776}} </ref> and snow cover are projected to continue their widespread retreat.<ref> {{citation
column533: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-3-2.html Sec 10.3.3.2 Changes in Snow Cover and Frozen Ground]
column537: pp=770, 772}} </ref> In the western mountains of [[North America]], increasing temperatures and changes in precipitation are projected to lead to reduced [[snowpack]].<ref> {{citation
column545: p=627}} </ref> Snowpack is the seasonal accumulation of slow-melting snow.<ref> [http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/glossary.html#S ""Snowpack""], in {{harvnb
column547: 2012}} </ref> The melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column548: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s could contribute to sea level rise, especially over long time-scales (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets
column549: Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets]]).<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> Changes in the cryosphere are projected to have social impacts.<ref> Some of these impacts are included in table SPM.2: {{citation
column550: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html#spm2 3 Projected climate change and its impacts: Table SPM.2]
column555: pp=11–12}} </ref> For example, in some regions, glacier retreat could increase the risk of reductions in seasonal water availability.<ref> {{citation
column557: chapter=Ch 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column564: title=Potential impacts of a warming climate on water availability in snow-dominated regions: Abstract
column573: display-authors=etal}} </ref> estimated that more than one-sixth of the [[world's population]] rely on glaciers and snowpack for their water supply. ===Oceans=== {{Main
column574: Effects of global warming on oceans}} The role of the oceans in global warming is complex. The oceans serve as a sink for carbon dioxide, taking up much that would otherwise remain in the atmosphere, but increased levels of {{chem
column576: 2}} have led to [[ocean acidification]]. Furthermore, as the temperature of the oceans increases, they become less able to absorb excess {{chem
column578: 2}}. The ocean have also acted as a sink in absorbing extra heat from the atmosphere.<ref name=""statecl"">{{cite book
column580: publisher = Website of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration: National Climatic Data Center
column581: title = State of the Climate in 2009, as appearing in the July 2010 issue (Vol. 91) of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society (BAMS). Supplemental and Summary Materials: Report at a Glance: Highlights
column585: date=November 2012}} The increase in ocean [[heat content]] is much larger than any other store of [[energy]] in the Earth's heat balance over the two periods 1961 to 2003 and 1993 to 2003, and accounts for more than 90% of the possible increase in heat content of the Earth system during these periods.<ref>{{citation
column586: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch5s5-2-2-3.html Sec 5.2.2.3 Implications for Earth’s Heat Balance]
column587: chapter=Ch. 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column593: title=Climate Graphics by Skeptical Science: Global Warming Components
column594: at=Components of global warming for the period 1993 to 2003 calculated from IPCC AR4 5.2.2.3
column596: publisher=Skeptical Science }} </ref> Global warming is projected to have a number of effects on the oceans. Ongoing effects include rising sea levels due to thermal expansion and melting of glaciers and ice sheets, and warming of the ocean surface, leading to increased temperature stratification. Other possible effects include large-scale changes in ocean circulation. ====Oxygen depletion==== The amount of oxygen dissolved in the oceans may decline, with adverse consequences for ocean life.<ref>{{Cite journal
column604: title = Abrupt Climate Change and Extinction Events in Earth History
column623: title = Long-term ocean oxygen depletion in response to carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels
column628: Future sea level}} [[File:Trends in global average absolute sea level, 1870-2008 (US EPA).png
column632: alt=refer to caption and adjacent text
column633: Trends in global average absolute sea level, 1870–2008.<ref> {{cite web
column635: title= Sea Level: Climate Change: US EPA
column638: year=2010 }} </ref>]] There is strong evidence that global sea level rose gradually over the 20th century.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""> {{citation
column640: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column642: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-5-1.html FAQ 5.1 Is Sea Level Rising?]
column647: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column652: 2007}}. </ref> concluded that between the mid-19th and mid-20th centuries, the rate of sea level rise increased. Authors of the IPCC Fourth Assessment Synthesis Report (IPCC AR4 SYR, 2007)<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""> {{citation
column656: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms1.html Sec. 1. Observed changes in climate and their effects] }}, p. 5, in {{harvnb
column658: 2007}}. </ref> reported that between the years 1961 and 2003, global average sea level rose at an average rate of 1.8 mm per year (mm/yr), with a range of 1.3–2.3 mm/yr. Between 1993 and 2003, the rate increased above the previous period to 3.1 mm/yr (range of 2.4–3.8 mm/yr). Authors of IPCC AR4 SYR (2007)<ref name=""Observed changes in climate and their effects""/> were uncertain whether the increase in rate from 1993 to 2003 was due to [[climate change#Internal forcing mechanisms
column659: natural variations]] in sea level over the time period, or whether it reflected an increase in the underlying long-term trend. There are two main factors that have contributed to observed sea level rise.<ref name=""FAQ 5.1 is sea level rising""/> The first is [[thermal expansion]]: as ocean water warms, it expands.<ref> {{citation
column663: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/013.htm#b4 Box 2: What causes sea level to change?]
column666: 2007}}. </ref> The second is from the contribution of land-based ice due to increased melting. The major store of water on land is found in glaciers and ice sheets. Anthropogenic forces very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""> {{citation
column670: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-2.html Box TS.1: Treatment of Uncertainties in the Working Group I Assessment]
column673: 2007}}. </ref> contributed to sea level rise during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> There is a widespread consensus that substantial long-term sea level rise will continue for centuries to come.<ref> {{citation
column674: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column678: p=245}}. </ref> In their Fourth Assessment Report, the IPCC<ref> {{citation
column680: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column684: 2007}}. </ref> projected sea level rise to the end of the 21st century using the SRES emissions scenarios. Across the six SRES marker scenarios, sea level was projected to rise by 18 to 59 cm (7.1 to 23.2 in), relative to sea level at the end of the 20th century.<ref>change in sea level by 2090–99, relative to 1980–99</ref> Thermal expansion is the largest component in these projections, contributing 70–75% of the central estimate for all scenarios.<ref> {{citation
column691: 2007}}. </ref> Due to a lack of scientific understanding, this sea level rise estimate does not include all of the possible contributions of ice sheets (see the section on [[effects of global warming#Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets
column692: Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets]]). An assessment of the [[scientific literature]] on climate change was published in 2010 by the [[US National Research Council]] (US NRC, 2010).<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""> {{citation
column694: chapter=7 Sea Level Rise and the Coastal Environment
column697: 2010}}. </ref> NRC (2010)<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> described the projections in AR4 (i.e. those cited in the above paragraph) as ""conservative"", and summarized the results of more recent studies. Cited studies suggested a great deal of uncertainty in projections.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> A range of projections suggested possible sea level rise by the end of the 21st century of between 0.56 and 2 m, relative to sea levels at the end of the 20th century.<ref name=""NRC 2010 projections of sea level rise""/> ====Ocean temperature rise==== [[File:Heat content700m2000myr.png
column701: Global ocean heat content from 1955–2012]] From 1961 to 2003, the global ocean temperature has risen by 0.10 °C from the surface to a depth of 700 m. There is variability both year-to-year and over longer time scales, with global ocean heat content observations showing high rates of warming for 1991–2003, but some cooling from 2003 to 2007.<ref> {{citation
column703: chapter= Chapter 5: Observations: Oceanic Climate Change and Sea Level
column709: date=November 2012}} </ref> The temperature of the Antarctic [[Southern Ocean]] rose by 0.17 °C (0.31 °F) between the 1950s and the 1980s, nearly twice the rate for the world's oceans as a whole.<ref> {{cite journal
column713: title= Warming of the Southern Ocean Since the 1950s
column723: ref=harv }}</ref> As well as having effects on ecosystems (e.g. by melting sea ice, affecting algae that grow on its underside), warming reduces the ocean's ability to absorb {{chem
column726: date=June 2008}} It is likely (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> that anthropogenic forcing contributed to the general warming observed in the upper several hundred metres of the ocean during the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=""hegerl climate change attribution""/> ==Regional effects== {{Main
column727: Regional effects of global warming}} {{Multiple image
column730: image1=Temperatures across the world in the 1880s (left) and the 1980s (right), as compared to average temperatures from 1951 to 1980 (US EPA).jpg
column731: alt1=Temperatures in most parts of the world were warmer in the 1980s compared to the 1880s
column732: image2= Map of projected global warming across the globe by the 2050s. Projections based on three SRES greenhouse gas emissions scenarios. Data from CMIP3 (2007).jpg
column733: alt2=Future warming across the globe varies according to different projections of greenhouse gas emissions
column735: caption1=Temperatures across the world in the 1880s (left) and the 1980s (right), as compared to average temperatures from 1951 to 1980.<ref> {{cite web
column738: title=Science: Climate Change: US EPA (Climate Change Science Overview)
column741: caption2=Projected changes in average temperatures across the world in the 2050s under three greenhouse gas (GHG) [[Economics of global warming#Emissions scenarios
column742: emissions scenarios]].<ref name=""herring temperature projections""/> }} Regional effects of global warming vary in nature. Some are the result of a generalised global change, such as rising temperature, resulting in local effects, such as melting ice. In other cases, a change may be related to a change in a particular ocean current or weather system. In such cases, the regional effect may be disproportionate and will not necessarily follow the global trend. There are three major ways in which global warming will make changes to regional climate: melting or forming ice, changing the [[hydrological cycle]] (of [[evaporation]] and [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column744: currents in the oceans]] and air flows in the atmosphere. The coast can also be considered a region, and will suffer severe impacts from [[sea level rise]]. The [[Arctic]], [[Africa]], small islands and [[Asia]]n [[river delta
column745: megadeltas]] are regions that are likely to be especially affected by climate change.<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions"">{{citation
column747: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-3.html Sec. 3.3.3 Especially affected systems, sectors and regions]
column753: less-developed]] regions are at most risk of experiencing negative impacts due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts"">{{citation
column755: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Distribution of Impacts, in: Sec 19.3.7 Update on 'Reasons for Concern']
column756: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column761: p=796}} </ref> [[Developed countries]] are also vulnerable to climate change.<ref name=""schneider regional vulnerabilities"">{{citation
column764: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column769: p=792}} </ref> For example, developed countries will be negatively affected by increases in the severity and frequency of some [[extreme weather]] events, such as [[heat wave]]s.<ref name=""schneider regional vulnerabilities"" /> In all regions, some people can be particularly at risk from climate change, such as the [[poverty
column770: poor]], young [[children]] and the [[elderly]].<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions"" /><ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts"" /><ref>{{citation
column772: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-2-5.html Sec 7.4.2.5 Social issues and Sec 7.4.3 Key vulnerabilities]
column778: pp=373–376}} </ref> Projections of future climate changes at the regional scale do not hold as high a level of scientific confidence as projections made at the global scale.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure"">{{cite book
column780: title=Understanding and Responding to Climate Change. A brochure prepared by the US National Research Council (US NRC)
column782: publisher=[http://dels.nas.edu/basc Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate], National Academy of Sciences
column786: date=November 2012}} It is, however, expected that future warming will follow a similar geographical pattern to that seen already, with greatest warming over land and high northern [[latitude]]s, and least over the [[Southern Ocean]] and parts of the [[North Atlantic Ocean]].<ref>{{citation
column790: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-projections-of.html Projections of Future Changes in Climate] }}, in {{harvnb
column792: 2007}}. </ref> Nearly all land areas will very likely warm more than the global average.<ref name=""tar table of robust findings"">{{citation
column799: Effects of climate change on humans
column800: Climate change, industry and society}} {{See also
column801: Climate change and gender}} The impacts of climate change can be thought of in terms of sensitivity and vulnerability. ""Sensitivity"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be affected, positively or negatively, by climate change and/or [[climate change#Causes
column802: climate variability]]. ""Vulnerability"" is the degree to which a particular system or sector might be adversely affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
column807: 2007}}. </ref> The sensitivity of human society to climate change varies. Sectors sensitive to climate change include water resources, coastal zones, human settlements, and human health. Industries sensitive to climate change include [[climate change and agriculture
column814: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/008.htm#24 Sec. 2.4. Many Human Systems are Sensitive to Climate Change, and Some are Vulnerable] }}, in {{harvnb
column818: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column827: 2007–2008 world food price crisis}} [[File:Net crops tropicalvsworld.png
column830: Graph of net crop production worldwide and in selected tropical countries. Raw data from the United Nations.<ref>{{cite web
column835: website=faostat3.fao.org}}</ref>]] Climate change will impact agriculture and food production around the world due to: the effects of elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere, higher temperatures, altered precipitation and [[transpiration]] regimes, increased frequency of extreme events, and modified [[weed]], [[pest (organism)
column838: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column844: p=282}}. </ref> In general, low-latitude areas are at most risk of having decreased crop yields.<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> As of 2007, the effects of regional climate change on agriculture have been small.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""> {{citation
column846: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column851: 2007}}. </ref> Changes in crop [[phenology]] provide important evidence of the response to recent regional climate change.<ref> {{citation
column853: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column858: 2007}}. </ref> Phenology is the study of natural phenomena that recur periodically, and how these phenomena relate to climate and seasonal changes.<ref> {{citation
column863: 2007}}. </ref> A significant advance in phenology has been observed for agriculture and forestry in large parts of the Northern Hemisphere.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> ====Projections==== [[File:Projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming.png
column868: Projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""> [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12877&page=161 Figure 5.1], p.161, in: Sec 5.1 FOOD PRODUCTION, PRICES, AND HUNGER, in: Ch 5: Impacts in the Next Few Decades and Coming Centuries, in: {{harvnb
column870: 2011}} </ref>]] [[File:Projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming.png
column875: Projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""/>]] With low to medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> projected that for about a 1 to 3 °C increase in global mean temperature (by the years 2090–2100, relative to average temperatures in the years 1990–2000), there would be productivity decreases for some [[cereal]]s in low latitudes, and productivity increases in high latitudes. With medium confidence, global production potential was projected to:<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> * increase up to around 3 °C, * very likely decrease above about 3 °C. Most of the studies on global agriculture assessed by Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""/> had not incorporated a number of critical factors, including changes in extreme events, or the spread of pests and diseases. Studies had also not considered the development of specific practices or technologies to aid [[adaptation to global warming#Agricultural production
column876: adaptation to climate change]].<ref name=""schneider climate change and agriculture""> {{citation
column878: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column884: p=790}}. </ref> The graphs opposite show the projected effects of climate change on selected crop yields.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 text""> Sec 5.1 FOOD PRODUCTION, PRICES, AND HUNGER, [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12877&page=160 pp.160–162], in: Ch 5: Impacts in the Next Few Decades and Coming Centuries, in {{harvnb
column886: 2011}} </ref> Actual changes in yields may be above or below these central estimates.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 text""/> The projections above can be expressed relative to pre-industrial (1750) temperatures.<ref> {{citation
column888: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column890: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-1.html Box 19.2. Reference for temperature levels]
column894: p=783}}. </ref> 0.6 °C of warming is estimated to have occurred between 1750 and 1990–2000. Add 0.6 °C to the above projections to convert them from a 1990–2000 to pre-industrial baseline. =====Food security===== Easterling ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column896: chapter= Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column898: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch5s5-6-5.html Sec. 5.6.5 Food security and vulnerability]
column901: 2007}}. </ref> assessed studies that made quantitative projections of climate change impacts on [[food security]]. It was noted that these projections were highly uncertain and had limitations. However, the assessed studies suggested a number of fairly robust findings. The first was that climate change would likely increase the number of people at risk of [[hunger]] compared with reference scenarios with no climate change. Climate change impacts depended strongly on projected future social and economic development. Additionally, the magnitude of climate change impacts was projected to be smaller compared to the impact of social and economic development. In 2006, the global estimate for the number of people [[malnutrition
column907: accessdate=2011-07-07 }} </ref> Under the SRES A1, B1, and B2 scenarios (see the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios#Scenario families
column908: SRES article]] for information on each scenario group), projections for the year 2080 showed a reduction in the number of people undernourished of about 560–700 million people, with a global total of undernourished people of 100–240 million in 2080. By contrast, the SRES A2 scenario showed only a small decrease in the risk of hunger from 2006 levels. The smaller reduction under A2 was attributed to the higher projected future population level in this scenario. ====Droughts and agriculture==== Some evidence suggests that droughts have been occurring more frequently because of global warming and they are expected to become more frequent and intense in Africa, southern Europe, the Middle East, most of the Americas, Australia, and Southeast Asia.<ref>{{Cite journal
column912: title = Drought under global warming: A review
column913: journal = Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Climate Change
column918: pmc = }}</ref> However, other research suggests that there has been little change in drought over the past 60 years.<ref>{{Cite journal
column920: title = Little change in global drought over the past 60 years
column933: pmid=23151587}}</ref> Their impacts are aggravated because of increased water demand, population growth, urban expansion, and environmental protection efforts in many areas.<ref>{{Cite journal
column947: bibcode = 2011JHyd..403..157M }}</ref> Droughts result in crop failures and the loss of pasture grazing land for livestock.<ref>{{Cite journal
column955: title = Measuring economic impacts of drought: A review and discussion
column963: Effects of global warming on human health}} Human beings are exposed to climate change through changing weather patterns (temperature, precipitation, sea-level rise and more frequent extreme events) and indirectly through changes in water, air and food quality and changes in ecosystems, agriculture, industry and settlements and the economy (Confalonieri ''et al.'', 2007:393).<ref name=""health summary""> {{citation
column970: 2007}}. </ref> A study by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO, 2009)<ref> {{cite book
column973: title= Global health risks: mortality and burden of disease attributable to selected major risks
column981: url= http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/global_health_risks/en/index.html }} </ref> estimated the effect of climate change on human health. Not all of the effects of climate change were included in their estimates, for example, the effects of more frequent and extreme storms were excluded. Climate change was estimated to have been responsible for 3% of [[diarrhoea]], 3% of [[malaria]], and 3.8% of [[dengue fever]] deaths worldwide in 2004. Total attributable mortality was about 0.2% of deaths in 2004; of these, 85% were child deaths. ====Projections==== With high confidence, authors of the IPCC AR4 Synthesis report<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report""/>{{Rp
column983: date=November 2012}} projected that climate change would bring some benefits in temperate areas, such as fewer deaths from cold exposure, and some mixed effects such as changes in range and transmission potential of [[malaria]] in [[Africa]]. Benefits were projected to be outweighed by negative health effects of rising temperatures, especially in [[Developing country
column984: developing countries]]. With very high confidence, Confalonieri ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""health summary""/>{{Rp
column986: date=November 2012}} concluded that economic development was an important component of possible adaptation to climate change. Economic growth on its own, however, was not judged to be sufficient to insulate the world's population from disease and injury due to climate change. Future vulnerability to climate change will depend not only on the extent of social and economic change, but also on how the benefits and costs of change are distributed in society.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""> {{citation
column990: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-3-2.html Sec. 8.3.2 Future vulnerability to climate change]
column993: 2007}}. </ref> For example, in the 19th century, rapid [[urbanization]] in [[western Europe]] lead to a plummeting in population health.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""/> Other factors important in determining the health of populations include [[education]], the availability of health services, and [[public health
column1001: Precipitation during the 20th century and up through 2008 during global warming, the [[NOAA]] estimating an observed trend over that period of 1.87% global precipitation increase per century.]] A number of climate-related trends have been observed that affect [[water resources]]. These include changes in precipitation, the crysosphere and [[surface water]]s (e.g., changes in [[river flows]]).<ref> {{citation
column1003: chapter = Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column1008: 2007}}. </ref> Observed and projected impacts of climate change on [[freshwater]] systems and their management are mainly due to changes in temperature, sea level and precipitation variability.<ref name=""freshwater impacts""> {{citation
column1010: chapter= Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column1015: 2007}}. </ref> Changes in temperature are a direct correlation to a shift in the precipitation variability because the hydro-logic cycle is reactive to temperature.<ref>{{Cite web
column1017: title=Freshwater (Lakes and Rivers) - The Water Cycle
column1019: access-date=2019-05-01}}</ref> The shift in temperature is mostly caused by human fossil fuel use in the 20th century.<ref name=""earthobservatory.nasa.gov"">{{Cite web
column1025: access-date=2019-05-01}}</ref> According to NASA's statistics the global temperature increase has risen 1.4 degrees Fahrenheit since 1975.<ref name=""earthobservatory.nasa.gov""/> The small but significant temperature increase creates a domino effect of issues because it begins with a shift in precipitation patterns. Excessive precipitation patterns lead to excessive sediment deposition, nutrient pollution, and concentration of minerals in aquifers. The rising global temperature will cause sea level rise and will extend areas of [[Salinity
column1027: estuaries]], resulting in a decrease in freshwater availability for humans and ecosystems in coastal areas. The exposure of rising sea level will push the salt gradient into freshwater deposits and will eventually pollute freshwater sources. In an assessment of the [[scientific literature]], Kundzewicz ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""freshwater impacts""/> concluded, with high confidence, that: * the negative impacts of climate change on freshwater systems outweigh the benefits. All of the regions assessed in the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]] ([[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], [[Europe]], [[Latin America]], [[North America]], [[Polar region]]s ([[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]]), and small islands) showed an overall net negative impact of climate change on water resources and freshwater ecosystems. Freshwater aquifers become minerally concentrated due to the accelerated precipitation patterns and aquifers not adequately storing freshwater. * [[semi-arid climate
column1028: Semi-arid]] and [[arid]] areas are particularly exposed to the impacts of climate change on freshwater. With very high confidence, it was judged that many of these areas, e.g., the [[Mediterranean basin]], [[Western United States]], [[Southern Africa]], and north-eastern [[Brazil]], would suffer a decrease in water resources due to climate change. '''Technological Freshwater Uses:''' Freshwater has become an aiding factor for industrialization in this modern era. It has many uses other than drinking including: domestic use, irrigation, livestock, aquaculture, industrial, mining, public supply, and thermoelectric. These are only some of the general uses of freshwater that further complicate freshwater quality. These components take a large quantity of [[Fresh water
column1029: freshwater]] to implement into technology. For a reference, measured in million gallons per day, public use accounts for roughly 44,000 mg/pd, Domestic use 4,000 mg/pd, Irrigation 128,000 mg/pd, livestock 2,140 mg/pd, aquaculture 8,780 mg/pd, industrial 17,000 mg/pd, mining 2,310 mg/pd, and finally [[Thermoelectric cooling
column1030: thermoelectric]] 143,000 mg/pd. The amount of freshwater being allocated towards technology results for about half of the natural freshwater resource that is actually available to us. With all of these different factors using the freshwater resource that accounts for less than one percent it should be of concern. Current water energy regulations are being made to switch to less energy intensive processes. In turn, lowering water use has a direct link with energy use, significantly lowering amount of emissions. reason being that there is a water-energy nexus and that they work in synergy. Water is needed to produce energy while energy is needed to ""produce"" water.<ref>{{Cite web
column1032: title=The Water-Energy Nexus: Challenges and Opportunities
column1035: access-date=2019-05-01}}</ref> Examining this relationship can significantly lower greenhouse emissions, resulting in slower rates of climate change. ===Migration and conflict=== {{Main
column1038: General circulation models]] project that the future climate change will bring wetter coasts, drier mid-continent areas, and further sea level rise.<ref name=""sar migration""> {{citation
column1040: chapter= Chapter 12: Human settlements in a changing climate: impacts and adaptation
column1044: 1996}}. </ref> Such changes could result in the gravest effects of climate change through [[human migration]].<ref>[[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios]], 10.2.5.1. Human Settlements, https://archive.ipcc.ch/ipccreports/sres/regional/275.htm</ref> Millions might be displaced by [[shoreline erosion]]s, river and coastal [[flood]]ing, or severe [[drought]]. Migration related to climate change is likely to be predominantly from [[rural area]]s in [[developing countries]] to towns and [[cities]].<ref name=""sar migration""/>{{Rp
column1048: title = Managing social risks: Empower communities to protect themselves
column1049: chapter = Part One: Chapter 2: Reducing Human Vulnerability: Helping People Help Themselves
column1052: 2010}}. </ref> In the short term climate stress is likely to add incrementally to existing migration patterns rather than generating entirely new flows of people.<ref name=""wdr migration""/>{{Rp
column1054: date=November 2012}} It has been argued that environmental degradation, loss of access to resources (e.g., water resources),<ref> {{citation
column1061: 2001}}. </ref> and resulting human migration could become a source of political and even [[military conflict]].<ref name=""tar migration""> {{citation
column1063: chapter= Chapter 7: Human Settlements, Energy, and Industry
column1068: 2001}}. </ref> Factors other than climate change may, however, be more important in affecting conflict. For example, Wilbanks ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column1070: chapter = Chapter 7: Industry, settlement and society
column1072: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-1.html Sec. 7.4.1 General effects: Box 7.2. Environmental migration]
column1075: 2007}}. </ref> suggested that major environmentally influenced conflicts in Africa were more to do with the relative abundance of resources, e.g., [[oil]] and [[diamond]]s, than with resource scarcity. Scott ''et al.'' (2001) placed only low confidence in predictions of increased conflict due to climate change.<ref name=""tar migration""/> A 2013 study found that significant climatic changes were associated with a higher risk of conflict worldwide, and predicted that ""amplified rates of human conflict could represent a large and critical social impact of anthropogenic climate change in both low- and high-income countries.""<ref>{{cite journal
column1076: vauthors=Hsiang SM, Burke M, Miguel E
column1077: title=Quantifying the influence of climate on human conflict
column1085: url=}}</ref> Similarly, a 2014 study found that higher temperatures were associated with a greater likelihood of violent crime, and predicted that global warming would cause millions of such crimes in the United States alone during the 21st century.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1087: title = Crime, weather, and climate change
column1088: journal = Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
column1094: pages=274–302}}</ref> A 2018 study in the journal ''Nature Climate Change'' found that previous studies on the relationship between climate change and conflict suffered from [[sampling bias]] and other methodological problems.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1113: bibcode=2018NatCC...8..200A}}</ref> Military planners are concerned that global warming is a ""threat multiplier"". ""Whether it is poverty, food and [[water scarcity]], diseases, economic instability, or threat of natural disasters, the broad range of changing climatic conditions may be far reaching. These challenges may threaten stability in much of the world"".<ref>{{cite journal
column1118: journal =Proceedings of the United States Naval Institute
column1124: url=http://www.usni.org/magazines/proceedings/2013-10/next-security-frontier }}</ref> For example, the onset of [[Arab Spring]] in December 2010 is partly the result of a spike in wheat prices following crop losses from the [[2010 Northern Hemisphere heat waves
column1128: title=Climate Change and Rising Food Prices Heightened Arab Spring
column1130: work=Republished with permission by Scientific American
column1135: title=How the climate crisis could become a food crisis overnight
column1139: Economic impacts of climate change}} [[Aggregate data
column1140: Aggregating]] impacts adds up the total impact of climate change across sectors and/or regions.<ref> [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/annexessglossary-a-d.html Glossary A-D: ""Aggregate impacts""], in {{harvnb
column1143: p=76}} </ref> Examples of aggregate measures include [[Economic impacts of climate change#Distribution of impacts
column1144: economic cost]] (e.g., changes in [[gross domestic product]] (GDP) and the [[Economic impacts of climate change#Marginal impacts
column1145: social cost of carbon]]), changes in ecosystems (e.g., changes over land area from one type of vegetation to another),<ref> {{citation
column1147: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1149: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/677.htm Sec. 19.5.3 Insights and Lessons: Vulnerability over Time: Table 19-5]
column1152: 2001}}. </ref> human health impacts, and the number of people affected by climate change.<ref> {{citation
column1154: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1156: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/676.htm Sec. 19.5.2. Insights and Lessons: The Static Picture]
column1159: 2001}}. </ref> Aggregate measures such as economic cost require researchers to make [[value judgement]]s over the importance of impacts occurring in different regions and at different times. ====Observed impacts==== Global losses reveal rapidly rising costs due to extreme weather-related events since the 1970s.<ref> {{citation
column1161: chapter= Chapter 1: Assessment of observed changes and responses in natural and managed systems
column1163: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-8-5.html Sec. 1.3.8.5 Summary of disasters and hazards]
column1167: Socio-economic]] factors have contributed to the observed trend of global losses, e.g., population growth, increased [[wealth]].<ref name=""disaster losses""> {{citation
column1173: 2001}}. </ref> Part of the growth is also related to regional climatic factors, e.g., changes in precipitation and flooding events. It is difficult to quantify the relative impact of socio-economic factors and climate change on the observed trend.<ref name=""disaster losses""/> The trend does, however, suggest increasing vulnerability of social systems to climate change.<ref name=""disaster losses""/><ref>[http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/billions Billion-Dollar Weather and Climate Disasters]</ref> ====Projected impacts==== The total economic impacts from climate change are highly uncertain.<ref> {{citation
column1175: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1180: 2007}}. </ref> With medium confidence, Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""> {{citation
column1182: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1187: 2001}}. </ref> concluded that world GDP would change by plus or minus a few percent for a small increase in global mean temperature (up to around 2 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level). Most studies assessed by Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""Smith estimate of climate change impacts on GDP""/> projected losses in world GDP for a medium increase in global mean temperature (above 2–3 °C relative to the 1990 temperature level), with increasing losses for greater temperature increases. This assessment is consistent with the findings of more recent studies, as reviewed by Hitz and Smith (2004).<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""> {{citation
column1189: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1191: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Sec. 19.3.7 Update on ‘Reasons for Concern’]
column1194: 2007}}. </ref> Economic impacts are expected to vary regionally.<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/><ref> {{citation
column1196: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1198: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/675.htm Sec. 19.4.3. Distribution of Total Impacts]
column1203: title=This Map Shows How Badly Climate Change Will Impact Each County In The US
column1206: access-date=2019-01-31}}</ref> For a medium increase in global mean temperature (2–3 °C of warming, relative to the average temperature between 1990–2000), market sectors in low-latitude and less-developed areas might experience net costs due to climate change.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""/> On the other hand, market sectors in high-latitude and developed regions might experience net benefits for this level of warming. A global mean temperature increase above about 2–3 °C (relative to 1990–2000) would very likely result in market sectors across all regions experiencing either declines in net benefits or rises in net costs.<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""/> Aggregate impacts have also been quantified in non-economic terms. For example, climate change over the 21st century is likely to adversely affect hundreds of millions of people through increased coastal flooding, reductions in water supplies, increased malnutrition and increased health impacts.<ref name=""ar4 synthesis reasons for concern""/> ==Biological systems== {{Main
column1209: Effect of climate change on plant biodiversity
column1210: Effects of climate change on terrestrial animals
column1211: Effects of climate change on marine mammals}} ===Observed impacts on biological systems=== [[File:A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming (low-res).png
column1215: A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming.<ref name=""nasa briefs""> {{cite web
column1218: title=Science Briefs: Warming Climate is Changing Life on Global Scale
column1219: publisher=Website of the US National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Goddard Institute for Space Studies
column1221: accessdate=2011-07-08}} </ref>]] With very high confidence, Rosenzweig ''et al.'' (2007) concluded that recent warming had strongly affected natural biological systems.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> Hundreds of studies have documented responses of [[ecosystem]]s, [[plant]]s, and [[animal]]s to the climate changes that have already occurred.<ref> {{cite book
column1223: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column1228: page = 14 }} </ref> For example, in the Northern Hemisphere, species are almost uniformly moving their ranges northward and up in elevation in search of cooler temperatures.<ref name=""nrc 2008b observed ecosystem impacts""> {{cite book
column1230: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column1235: page = 16 }} </ref> Humans are very likely causing changes in regional temperatures to which plants and animals are responding.<ref name=""nrc 2008b observed ecosystem impacts""/> ===Projected impacts on biological systems=== By the year 2100, ecosystems will be exposed to atmospheric {{chem
column1237: 2}} levels substantially higher than in the past 650,000 years, and global temperatures at least among the highest of those experienced in the past 740,000 years.<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""> {{citation
column1239: chapter= Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column1244: 2007}}. </ref> Significant disruptions of ecosystems are projected to increase with future climate change.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""> {{citation
column1250: 2001}}. </ref> Examples of disruptions include disturbances such as fire, drought, pest [[infestation]], invasion of species, storms, and [[coral bleaching]] events. The stresses caused by climate change, added to other stresses on ecological systems (e.g., land conversion, [[land degradation]], [[harvest]]ing, and [[pollution]]), threaten substantial damage to or complete loss of some unique ecosystems, and [[extinction]] of some critically endangered species.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""/><ref>Van Riper, Charles. (2014) [https://purl.fdlp.gov/GPO/gpo50857 Projecting Climate Effects on Birds and Reptiles of the Southwestern United States.] Reston, Va.: [[United States Department of the Interior
column1251: U.S. Department of the Interior]], [[United States Geological Survey
column1252: U.S. Geological Survey]].</ref> Climate change has been estimated to be a major driver of [[biodiversity loss]] in cool [[conifer]] forests, [[savanna]]s, [[mediterranean climate
column1253: mediterranean-climate]] systems, [[tropical forest]]s, in the [[Arctic tundra]], and in [[coral reef]]s.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""> {{citation
column1255: chapter= Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column1257: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch4s4-4-11.html Sec. 4.4.11 Global synthesis including impacts on biodiversity]
column1261: land-use]] change may be a stronger driver of biodiversity loss at least in the near-term.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> Beyond the year 2050, climate change may be the major driver for biodiversity loss globally.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> A literature assessment by Fischlin ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""/> included a quantitative estimate of the number of species at increased risk of extinction due to climate change. With medium confidence, it was projected that approximately 20 to 30% of plant and animal species assessed so far (in an unbiased [[Sampling (statistics)
column1262: sample]]) would likely be at increasingly high risk of extinction should global mean temperatures exceed a warming of 2 to 3 °C above pre-industrial temperature levels.<ref name=""fischlin executive summary""/> The uncertainties in this estimate, however, are large: for a rise of about 2 °C the percentage may be as low as 10%, or for about 3 °C, as high as 40%, and depending on [[Biota (ecology)
column1263: biota]] (all living [[organism]]s of an area, the [[flora]] and [[fauna]] considered as a unit)<ref> {{citation
column1268: 2007}}. </ref> the range is between 1% and 80%.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> As global average temperature exceeds [[4 Degrees and Beyond International Climate Conference
column1269: 4 °C]] above pre-industrial levels, model projections suggested that there could be significant extinctions (40–70% of species that were assessed) around the globe.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""/> Assessing whether future changes in ecosystems will be beneficial or detrimental is largely based on how ecosystems are valued by human society.<ref> {{citation
column1272: title = Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
column1276: 2008b}}. </ref> For increases in global average temperature exceeding 1.5 to 2.5 °C (relative to global temperatures over the years 1980–1999)<ref> {{citation
column1278: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column1280: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3.html Sec. 3.3 Impacts of future climate changes] }}, in {{harvnb
column1284: 2}} concentrations, projected changes in ecosystems will have predominantly negative consequences for biodiversity and ecosystems goods and [[ecosystem services
column1285: services]], e.g., water and food supply.<ref> {{citation
column1287: chapter= Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column1289: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-1.html Sec. 3.3.1 Impacts on systems and sectors: Ecosystems] }}, in {{harvnb
column1291: 2007}}. </ref> ==Abrupt or irreversible changes== Physical, ecological and social systems may respond in an abrupt, [[non-linear]] or irregular way to climate change.<ref name=""singularities""/> This is as opposed to a smooth or regular response. A quantitative entity behaves ""irregularly"" when its [[system dynamics
column1293: discontinuous]] (i.e., not smooth), nondifferentiable, unbounded, wildly varying, or otherwise ill-defined.<ref name=""singularities""/> Such behaviour is often termed ""[[Mathematical singularity
column1294: singular]]"". Irregular behaviour in Earth systems may give rise to certain thresholds, which, when crossed, may lead to a large change in the system. Some singularities could potentially lead to severe impacts at regional or global scales.<ref name=""white et al singularities""> {{citation
column1301: 2001}}. </ref> Examples of ""large-scale"" singularities are discussed in the articles on [[abrupt climate change]], [[climate change feedback]] and [[runaway climate change]]. It is possible that human-induced climate change could trigger large-scale singularities, but the probabilities of triggering such events are, for the most part,<ref> ""[F]or the most part"" refers to improved scientific understanding of singularities since the assessment by White ''et al.'' (2001). See: {{citation
column1303: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1305: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Sec. 19.3.7 Update on ‘Reasons for Concern’]
column1308: 2007}}. </ref> poorly understood.<ref name=""white et al singularities""/> With low to medium confidence, Smith ''et al.'' (2001)<ref name=""singularities""> {{citation
column1310: chapter= Chapter 19: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis
column1315: 2001}}. </ref> concluded that a rapid warming of more than 3 °C above 1990 levels would exceed thresholds that would lead to large-scale discontinuities in the [[climate system]]. Since the assessment by Smith ''et al.'' (2001), improved scientific understanding provides more guidance for two large-scale singularities: the role of [[carbon cycle]] feedbacks in future climate change (discussed below in the section on biogeochemical cycles) and the melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column1316: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s.<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/> A 2018 study states that 45% of the environmental problems, including those caused by climate change are interconnected and make the risk of ""domino effect"" bigger. It says also that when fighting those problems, each action, even taken locally, is important.<ref>{{cite journal
column1325: title=Cascading regime shifts within and across scales
column1333: title=Risks of 'domino effect' of tipping points greater than thought, study says
column1338: climate change feedback}} Climate change may have an effect on the [[carbon cycle]] in an interactive ""feedback"" process. A feedback exists where an initial process triggers changes in a second process that in turn influences the initial process. A positive feedback intensifies the original process, and a negative feedback reduces it.<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report"">{{harvnb
column1342: date=November 2012}} Models suggest that the interaction of the climate system and the carbon cycle is one where the feedback effect is positive.<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""> {{citation
column1344: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1351: date=November 2012}} Using the A2 SRES emissions scenario, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""/>{{Rp
column1353: date=November 2012}} found that this effect led to additional warming by the years 2090–2100 (relative to the 1990–2000) of 0.1–1.5 °C. This estimate was made with high confidence. The climate projections made in the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report summarized earlier of 1.1–6.4 °C account for this feedback effect. On the other hand, with medium confidence, Schneider ''et al.'' (2007)<ref name=""Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change""/>{{Rp
column1355: date=November 2012}} commented that additional releases of GHGs were possible from permafrost, peat lands, wetlands, and large stores of marine hydrates at high latitudes. ===Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets=== With medium confidence, authors of AR4<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""> {{citation
column1361: 2007}}. </ref> concluded that with a global average temperature increase of 1–4 °C (relative to temperatures over the years 1990–2000), at least a partial deglaciation of the [[Greenland ice sheet]], and possibly the [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s would occur. The estimated timescale for partial deglaciation was centuries to millennia, and would contribute {{convert
column1365: m}} or more to sea level rise over this period.<ref>{{Cite web
column1367: title=Climate Change Continues To Exacerbate Rising Sea Levels
column1375: This map shows the general location and direction of the warm surface (red) and cold deep water (blue) currents of the [[thermohaline circulation]]. [[Salinity]] is represented by color in units of the Practical Salinity Scale. Low values (blue) are less saline, while high values (orange) are more saline.<ref> {{cite web
column1377: author=Riebeek, H.. design by R. Simmon
column1378: title=Paleoclimatology: Explaining the Evidence: Explaining Rapid Climate Change: Tales from the Ice
column1382: Shutdown of thermohaline circulation}} The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is an important component of the Earth's climate system, characterized by a northward flow of warm, salty water in the upper layers of the [[Atlantic ocean
column1383: Atlantic]] and a southward flow of colder water in the deep Atlantic.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""> {{cite book
column1386: title=Abrupt Climate Change. A report by the US Climate Change Science Program (CCSP) and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column1395: date=November 2012}} The AMOC is equivalently known as the [[thermohaline circulation]] (THC).<ref name=""update of reasons for concern""/> Potential impacts associated with MOC changes include reduced warming or (in the case of abrupt change) absolute cooling of northern high-latitude areas near [[Greenland]] and north-western Europe, an increased warming of [[Southern Hemisphere]] high-latitudes, tropical drying, as well as changes to [[marine ecosystem]]s, terrestrial vegetation, oceanic {{chem
column1397: 2}} uptake, oceanic oxygen concentrations, and shifts in fisheries.<ref> {{citation
column1399: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1401: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-5-3.html Sec. 19.3.5.3 Possible changes in the North Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (MOC)]
column1404: 2007}}. </ref> According to an assessment by the US [[Climate Change Science Program]] (CCSP, 2008b),<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1406: date=November 2012}} it is very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1408: date=November 2012}} that the strength of the AMOC will decrease over the course of the 21st century. Warming is still expected to occur over most of the European region downstream of the [[North Atlantic Current]] in response to increasing GHGs, as well as over [[North America]]. Although it is very unlikely (less than 10% probability, based on expert judgement)<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1410: date=November 2012}} that the AMOC will collapse in the 21st century, the potential consequences of such a collapse could be severe.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""/>{{Rp
column1412: date=November 2012}} ===Irreversibilities=== ====Commitment to radiative forcing==== Emissions of GHGs are a potentially irreversible commitment to sustained [[radiative forcing]] in the future.<ref name=""albritton irreversible radiative forcing""> {{citation
column1416: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc%5Ftar/wg1/016.htm Sec. C.1 Observed Changes in Globally Well-Mixed Greenhouse Gas Concentrations and Radiative Forcing]
column1419: 2001}}. </ref> The contribution of a GHG to radiative forcing depends on the gas's ability to trap [[infrared]] (heat) radiation, the concentration of the gas in the atmosphere, and the length of time the gas resides in the atmosphere.<ref name=""albritton irreversible radiative forcing""/> {{chem
column1421: 2}} is the most important anthropogenic GHG.<ref name=""ipcc 2007 causes of climate change""> {{citation
column1425: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms2.html Sec. 2. Causes of change] }}, p. 5, in {{harvnb
column1427: 2007}}. </ref> While more than half of the {{chem
column1429: 2}} emitted is currently removed from the atmosphere within a century, some fraction (about 20%) of emitted {{chem
column1431: 2}} remains in the atmosphere for many thousands of years.<ref> {{cite book
column1435: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-10-3.html Frequently Asked Question 10.3: If Emissions of Greenhouse Gases are Reduced, How Quickly do Their Concentrations in the Atmosphere Decrease?]
column1440: 2}} emitted today is potentially an irreversible commitment to sustained radiative forcing over thousands of years. This commitment may not be truly irreversible should techniques be developed to remove {{chem
column1442: 2}} or other GHGs directly from the atmosphere, or to block sunlight to induce cooling.<ref name=""solomon irreversible climate change""> {{cite journal
column1445: title=Irreversible climate change due to carbon dioxide emissions
column1446: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
column1456: display-authors=etal}}</ref> Techniques of this sort are referred to as [[climate engineering
column1457: geoengineering]]. Little is known about the effectiveness, costs or potential [[Unintended consequences
column1458: side-effects]] of geoengineering options.<ref name=""barker geoengineering""> {{citation
column1460: chapter= Chapter 11: Mitigation from a cross-sectoral perspective
column1465: 2007}}. </ref> Some geoengineering options, such as blocking sunlight, would not prevent further [[ocean acidification]].<ref name=""barker geoengineering""/> ====Irreversible impacts==== Human-induced climate change may lead to irreversible impacts on physical, biological, and social systems.<ref> {{citation
column1471: 2001}}. <!-- XX Needs checking. --> </ref> There are a number of examples of climate change impacts that may be irreversible, at least over the timescale of many human generations.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""> {{citation
column1473: chapter= Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column1475: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-2.html Sec.19.2 Criteria for selecting ‘key’ vulnerabilities: Persistence and reversibility]
column1478: 2007}}. </ref> These include the large-scale singularities described above – changes in carbon cycle feedbacks, the melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, and changes to the AMOC.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In biological systems, the extinction of species would be an irreversible impact.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In social systems, unique [[culture]]s may be lost due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> For example, humans living on [[atoll]] islands face risks due to sea-level rise, sea-surface warming, and increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.<ref> {{cite journal
column1489: doi=10.1023/b:clim.0000004559.08755.88 }} This paper was published in 2001 as [http://www.tyndall.ac.uk/sites/default/files/wp9.pdf Tyndall Centre Working Paper 9] </ref> ==Scientific opinion== The [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC) has published several major assessments on the effects of global warming.<ref> {{harvnb
column1492: pp=4–7}} </ref> Its most recent comprehensive impact assessment was published in 2014.<ref> {{harvnb
column1494: 2014}} </ref> Publications describing the effects of climate change have also been produced by the following organizations: *[[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] (AAAS)<ref> {{harvnb
column1497: n.d.}} </ref> *A report by the [[Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency]], the [[Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute]], and [[Wageningen University and Research Centre]]<ref> {{harvnb
column1505: 2013}} for other AVOID publications. </ref> *A report by the UK [[Royal Society]] and [[US National Academy of Sciences]]<ref> {{harvnb
column1508: 2014}} </ref> *[[University of New South Wales]] Climate Change Research Centre<ref> {{harvnb
column1520: language=en}}</ref> A report by Molina ''et al.'' (no date)<ref> {{harvnb
column1524:
p=3}} states:
The overwhelming evidence of human-caused climate change documents both current impacts with significant costs and extraordinary future risks to society and natural systems
===NASA data and tools=== NASA has released public data and tools to predict how temperature and rainfall patterns worldwide may change through to the year 2100 caused by increasing carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere. The dataset shows projected changes worldwide on a regional level simulated by 21 climate models. The data can be viewed on a daily timescale for individual cities and towns and may be used to conduct climate risk assessments to predict the local and global effects of weather dangers, for example droughts, floods, heat waves and declines in agriculture productivity, and help plan responses to global warming effects.{{cite web
column1525: title = NASA Releases Detailed Global Climate Change Projections
column1527: accessdate = 2015-06-09}}</ref> == See also == {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ; General * [[4 Degrees and Beyond International Climate Conference]] * [[Anthropocene]] * [[Risks to civilization, humans and planet Earth]] * [[Indigenous Peoples Climate Change Assessment Initiative]] * [[Environmental sociology]] ; Regional * [[Arctic Climate Impact Assessment]] * [[Effects of global warming on Australia]] * {{ill

column1530: Impactos do aquecimento global no Brasil}} * [[Effects of global warming on India]] * ''[[Kivalina v. ExxonMobil Corporation]]'' * [[Climate Change Science Program#Impacts and adaptation
column1531: Bush Administration assessments of impacts and adaptation]] (United States) {{Col-break}} {{Portal
column1534: Environment}} * [[Biological pump]] * [[Climate Vulnerability Monitor]] (CVM) * [[Oceanic anoxic event]] * [[PRECIS (Providing Regional Climates for Impacts Studies)]] * [[Solubility pump]] {{Col-end}} {{Clear}} ==Footnotes== <sup>1</sup> The TAR<ref name=""Uncertainty in the TAR""> {{citation
column1540: 2001}}. </ref> and AR4<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> that are referred to in this article use specific and quantitative language to describe uncertainty. This language is intended to provide an indication of the level of confidence that IPCC authors have about a particular finding. The qualitative language used to describe uncertainty has a quantitative scale associated with it. The quantitative values for qualitative terms are intended to ensure that confidence levels are interpreted correctly. This is because qualitative statements, e.g., using the word ""likely"", can be interpreted differently in quantitative terms.<ref> {{citation
column1547: title= IPCC supporting material: guidance papers on the cross cutting issues of the Third Assessment Report of the IPCC
column1552: publisher= Global Industrial and Social Progress Research Institute (GISPRI)
column1556: date=November 2012}} Confidence levels used in the TAR:<ref> {{citation
column1560: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/023.htm#14 Box 2. Confidence Levels and State of Knowledge]
column1563: 2001}}. </ref> * Very High = 95% or greater * High = 67–95% * Medium = 33–67% * Low = 5–33% * Very Low = 5% or less Confidence statements made in AR4 are listed below:<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> * Very high confidence: At least 9 out of 10 chance of being correct * High confidence: About 8 out of 10 chance "" "" "" * Medium confidence: About 5 out of 10 chance "" "" "" * Low confidence: About 2 out of 10 chance "" "" "" * Very low confidence: Less than a 1 out of 10 chance "" "" "" IPCC (2012)<ref> {{citation
column1568: p=19}} </ref> uses the following terms: ""very low"", ""low"", ""medium"", ""high"", and ""very high confidence"". Unlike the TAR and AR4, the scale is qualitative rather than quantitative. The quantitative values used by IPCC authors are ""subjective"" probabilities,<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/><ref name=""Uncertainty in the TAR""/><ref> {{citation
column1572: at= [http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/106.htm Sec. 2.6.2. ""Objective"" and ""Subjective"" Probabilities are not Always Explicitly Distinguished]
column1576: Bayesian]]"" probabilities,<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""> {{cite book
column1578: author = Granger Morgan, M. (Lead Author), H. Dowlatabadi, M. Henrion, D. Keith, R. Lempert, S. McBride, M. Small and T. Wilbanks (Contributing Authors)
column1579: title = Synthesis and Assessment Product 5.2: Best practice approaches for characterizing, communicating, and incorporating scientific uncertainty in decisionmaking. A Report by the U.S. Climate Change Science Program and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column1580: publisher = National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
column1587: df = }} Tables 2.1 and 2.2 on pages 27–28 show two quantitative scales of uncertainty which are used in the TAR and AR4.</ref> and reflect the expert judgement of IPCC authors. In this formulation, probability is not only a function of an event, but also the state of information that is available to the person making the assessment.<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""/> In this framework, assigned probabilities may change as more or different information becomes available.<ref name=""US CCSP report on uncertainty""/> The IPCC also uses another scale to describe the likelihood of a particular event occurring.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> This is different from the confidence scales described above, and it is possible to assign confidence values to statements of likelihood. For example, the judgement that an event is improbable (e.g., rolling a [[dice]] twice and getting a six both times) may be assigned a high level of scientific confidence.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> Also, the probability that an event has an even chance of occurring (e.g., a tossed [[coin]] coming up heads) may also be assigned a high level of confidence.<ref name=""ipcc ar4 uncertainty""/> == Citations == {{Reflist

column23: pretitle = Some effects of climate change
column35: content2style = height:0px; margin:0 -0.4em; padding:0; display:inline-block; visibility:hidden;
column40: Energy flows between space, the atmosphere, and Earth's surface. Current greenhouse gas levels are causing a [[Radiative forcing
column41: radiative imbalance]] of about 0.9 W/m<sup>2</sup>.<ref>{{cite journal
column42: title=Insights into Earth's Energy Imbalance from Multiple Sources
column43: author=Kevin E. Trenberth and John T. Fasullo
column50: bibcode=2016JCli...29.7495T}}</ref>]] }} The '''effects of global warming''' or '''climate damage''' include far-reaching and long-lasting changes to the [[natural environment]], to [[ecosystems]] and human societies caused directly or indirectly by human emissions of [[greenhouse gas]]es. It also includes the economic and social changes which stem from living in a warmer world. Human caused climate change is one of the threats to [[sustainability]]<ref>{{cite book
column51: title=Perspectives on climate change and sustainability. Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
column61: title=Planetary Boundaries: Exploring the Safe Operating Space for Humanity
column67: doi-access=free}}</ref>. Many physical impacts of global warming are already visible, including [[extreme weather]] events, [[Retreat of glaciers since 1850
column68: glacier retreat]],<ref name=""cramer observed effects"">Cramer, W., ''et al.'', Executive summary, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap18_FINAL.pdf Chapter 18: Detection and attribution of observed impacts] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap18_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), pp.982–984, in {{harvnb
column70: 2014}} </ref> changes in the timing of seasonal events<ref name=""cramer observed effects""/> (e.g., earlier flowering of plants),<ref>Settele, J., ''et al.'', Section 4.3.2.1: Phenology, in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap4_FINAL.pdf Chapter 4: Terrestrial and inland water systems] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap4_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), p.291, in {{harvnb
column72: 2014}} </ref> [[sea level rise]], and [[Arctic sea ice decline
column73: declines in Arctic sea ice]] extent.<ref> {{Cite book
column76: chapter=Ch 9: Understanding and Attributing Climate Change
column82: 2007}} </ref> The future impact of [[global warming]] depends on the extent to which nations implement [[climate change mitigation
column83: prevention efforts]] and reduce [[greenhouse gas]] emissions. [[Ocean acidification]] is not a consequence of global warming, but instead has the same cause: increasing [[Carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere
column84: atmospheric carbon dioxide]]. Climate change has already impacted ecosystems and humans as well.<ref>{{Cite book
column93: chapter-url=https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/sites/2/2019/05/SR15_SPM_version_report_LR.pdf}}</ref> In combination with [[climate variability]], it makes food insecurity worse in many places<ref name="":1"">{{Cite book
column108: pages=3}}</ref> and puts pressure on fresh water supply. This in combination with extreme weather events, leads to negative effects on [[human health]]. Rising temperatures threaten development because of negative effects on economic growth in developing countries.<ref name="":1"" /> The social impact of climate change will be further affected by society's [[Climate change adaptation
column109: efforts to prepare and adapt]].<ref name=""adaptation and mitigation"">Oppenheimer, M., ''et al.'', ''Section 19.7.1: Relationship between Adaptation Efforts, Mitigation Efforts, and Residual Impacts,'' in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf Chapter 19: Emergent risks and key vulnerabilities] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1080–1085, in {{harvnb
column111: 2014}} </ref><ref>Oppenheimer, M., ''et al.'', ''Section 19.6.2.2. The Role of Adaptation and Alternative Development Pathways,'' in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf Chapter 19: Emergent risks and key vulnerabilities] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1072–1073, in {{harvnb
column113: 2014}}</ref> Global warming already contributes to migration in different parts of the world.<ref>[https://www.nrdc.org/onearth/climate-change-already-driving-mass-migration-around-globe Climate Change Is Already Driving Mass Migration Around the Globe], Natural Resources Defense Council, 25 January 2019 </ref> Near-term climate change policies significantly affect long-term climate change impacts.<ref name=""adaptation and mitigation""/><ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Section A-3. The Decision-making Context, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.55, in {{harvnb
column115: 2014}} </ref> Stringent mitigation policies might be able to limit global warming (in 2100) to around 2 [[°C]] or below, relative to pre-industrial levels.<ref>SPM.4.1 Long‐term mitigation pathways, in: {{Cite book
column134: chapter-url=https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/sites/2/2019/05/SR15_SPM_version_report_LR.pdf}}</ref> Without mitigation, increased [[energy demand]] and extensive use of [[fossil fuel]]s<ref> Clarke, L., ''et al.'', Section 6.3.1.3 Baseline emissions projections from fossil fuels and industry (pp.17–18 of final draft), in: [http://report.mitigation2014.org/drafts/final-draft-postplenary/ipcc_wg3_ar5_final-draft_postplenary_chapter6.pdf Chapter 6: Assessing Transformation Pathways] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020021617/http://report.mitigation2014.org/drafts/final-draft-postplenary/ipcc_wg3_ar5_final-draft_postplenary_chapter6.pdf 20 October 2014]), in: {{harvnb
column136: 2014}} </ref> might lead to global warming of around 4 °C.<ref> Greenhouse Gas Concentrations and Climate Implications, p.14, in {{harvnb
column139: 2014}}. The range given by Prinn and Reilly is 3.3 to 5.5 °C, with a median of 3.9 °C. </ref><ref>SPM.3 Trends in stocks and flows of greenhouse gases and their drivers, in: [http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf Summary for Policymakers], p.8 (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20140702014732/http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf 2 July 2014)], in {{harvnb
column141: 2014}}. The range given by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change is 3.7 to 4.8 °C, relative to pre-industrial levels (2.5 to 7.8 °C including climate uncertainty). </ref> Higher magnitudes of global warming would be more difficult to adapt to,<ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Box TS.8: Adaptation Limits and Transformation, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.89, in {{harvnb
column143: 2014}} </ref> and would increase the risk of negative impacts.<ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Section B-1. Key Risks across Sectors and Regions, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.62, in {{harvnb
