column150: Global surface temperature reconstruction over the last millennia using proxy data from tree rings, corals, and ice cores in blue.<ref name='Neukom2019'>{{Cite journal
column163: title=No evidence for globally coherent warm and cold periods over the preindustrial Common Era
column172: pmid=31341300}} .</ref> Observational data is from 1880 to 2019.<ref name=""nasa temperatures"" />]] Global warming refers to the long-term rise in the average temperature of the Earth's [[climate system]]. It is a major aspect of [[climate change]], and has been demonstrated by the instrumental [[temperature record]] which shows global warming of around 1 °C since the pre-industrial period,<ref>{{Cite book
column174: title=WMO statement on the State of the Global Climate in 2018
column187: publisher=Chairperson, Publications Board, World Meteorological Organization
column191: pages=6}}</ref> although the bulk of this (0.9°C) has occurred since 1970.<ref>Even 50-year-old climate models correctly predicted global warming, Science, American Association for the Advancement of Science, 4 December 2019</ref> A wide variety of temperature [[Proxy (climate)
column192: proxies]] together prove that the 20th century was the hottest recorded in the last 2,000 years. Compared to climate variability in the past, current warming is also more globally coherent, affecting 98% of the planet.<ref name='Neukom2019' /><ref>{{Cite web
column194: title=Global extent of climate change is ‘unparalleled’ in past 2,000 years
column200: access-date=2019-11-24}}</ref> The impact on the environment, ecosystems, the animal kingdom, society and humanity depends on how much more the Earth warms.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""> {{citation
column202: title=Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 2007
column204: chapter=Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column208: 2007}}. </ref> The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) [[IPCC Fifth Assessment Report
column209: Fifth Assessment Report]] concluded, ""It is extremely likely that human influence has been the dominant cause of the observed warming since the mid-20th century.""<ref> IPCC (2013). [https://archive.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg1/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf ""Summary for Policymakers"" (PDF)]. IPCC AR5 WG1 2013.</ref> This has been brought about primarily through the burning of [[fossil fuel]]s which has led to a significant increase in the concentration of GHGs in the atmosphere.<ref> {{citation
column213: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-human-and.html Human and Natural Drivers of Climate Change]
column214: title= Human and Natural Drivers of Climate Change }}, in {{harvnb
column216: 2007}}. </ref> ===Emission scenarios=== Individual consumers, corporate decision makers, the fossil fuel industries, government responses and the extent to which different countries agree to cooperate all have a profound impact on how much greenhouse gases the worlds emits. As the crisis and modelling techniques have evolved, the IPCC and other climate scientists have tried a number of different tools to estimate likely greenhouse gas emissions in the future. Representative Concentration Pathways” (RCPs) were based on possible differences in [[radiative forcing]] occurring in the next 100 years but do not include socioeconomic “narratives” to go alongside them.<ref>[https://www.carbonbrief.org/explainer-how-shared-socioeconomic-pathways-explore-future-climate-change Explainer: How 'Shared Socioeconomic Pathways’ explore future climate change], Carbon Brief, 19 April 2018 </ref> Another group of [[Climatology
column218: energy system modellers]] took a different approach known as [[Shared Socioeconomic Pathways]] (SSPs); this is based on how socioeconomic factors such as [[Population growth
column220: urbanisation]] and the rate of technological development might change over the next century. The SSPs describe five different trajectories which describe future climactic developments in the absence of new environmental policies beyond those in place today. They also explore the implications of different climate change mitigation scenarios.<ref>{{cite journal
column224: title=The Shared Socioeconomic Pathways and their energy, land use, and greenhouse gas emissions implications: An overview
column320: doi-access = free }}</ref> === Warming projections === [[File:Projected Change in Temperatures by 2090.svg
column325: CMIP5]] average of climate model projections for 2081–2100 relative to 1986–2005, under low and high emission scenarios.]] The range in temperature projections partly reflects the choice of [[economics of global warming#Emissions scenarios
column326: emissions scenario]], and the degree of ""[[climate sensitivity]]"".<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum"" /> The projected magnitude of warming by 2100 is closely related to the level of cumulative emissions over the 21st century (i.e. total emissions between 2000–2100).<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions""> {{citation
column328: title=The Emissions Gap Report: Are the Copenhagen Accord pledges sufficient to limit global warming to {{val
column336: chapter=Ch 2: Which emissions pathways are consistent with a {{val
column340: u=°C}} temperature limit?: Sec 2.2 What determines long-term temperature?
column344: url-status=dead}}, p.28. This publication is also available in [http://www.unep.org/publications/ebooks/emissionsgapreport/ e-book format] {{webarchive
column346: date=2010-11-25}} </ref> The higher the cumulative emissions over this time period, the greater the level of warming is projected to occur.<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions"" /> [[Climate sensitivity]] reflects uncertainty in the response of the climate system to past and future GHG emissions.<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum"" /> Higher estimates of climate sensitivity lead to greater projected warming, while lower estimates lead to less projected warming.<ref> {{citation
column354: chapter=Box 8.1 Likelihood of exceeding a temperature increase at equilibrium, in: Ch 8: The Challenge of Stabilisation
column355: chapter-url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/d/Chapter_8_The_Challenge_of_Stabilisation.pdf}} </ref> The IPCC's Fifth Report, released in 2014, states that relative to the average from year 1850 to 1900, global surface temperature change by the end of the 21st century is likely to exceed 1.5 °C and may well exceed 2 °C for all RCP scenarios except RCP2.6. It is likely to exceed 2°C for RCP6.0 and RCP8.5, and more likely than not to exceed 2°C for RCP4.5. The IPCC says the pathway with the highest greenhouse gas emissions, RCP 8.5, will lead to a temperature increase of about 4.3˚C by 2100.<ref>RCP 8.5: Business-as-usual or a worst-case scenario, Climate Nexus, retrieved from https://climatenexus.org/climate-change-news/rcp-8-5-business-as-usual-or-a-worst-case-scenario/ </ref> Warming will continue beyond 2100 under all RCP scenarios except RCP2.6.<ref>IPCC, 2013: [https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/2018/02/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf Summary for Policymakers.] In: Climate Change 2013: The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of Working Group I to the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change p.20</ref> The Climate Action Tracker also says mitigation policies currently in place around the world will result in about 3.0°C warming above pre-industrial levels. However, if current plans are not actually implemented, global warming is expected to reach 4.1°C to 4.8°C by 2100. CAT goes on to say there is a substantial gap between national plans and commitments and actual actions so far taken by governments around the world.<ref>[https://climateactiontracker.org/global/temperatures/ Temperatures], Climate Action Tracker</ref> Even if emissions were drastically reduced overnight, the warming process is irreversible because {{CO2}} takes hundreds of years to break down, and global temperatures will remain close to their highest level for at least the next 1,000 years.<ref name=""solomon irreversible climate change""> {{cite journal
column359: title=Irreversible climate change due to carbon dioxide emissions
column360: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
column376: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-7-2.html Sec 10.7.2 Climate Change Commitment to Year 3000 and Beyond to Equilibrium]
column378: display-authors=etal}} </ref> ===Warming in context of Earth's past=== One of the methods scientists use to predict the effects of human-caused climate change, is to investigate past natural changes in climate.<ref>{{Cite web
column380: title=To Predict Effects Of Global Warming, Scientists Looked Back 20,000 Years
column386: access-date=2019-12-29}}</ref> Scientists have used various ""proxy"" data to assess changes in Earth's past climate or [[paleoclimate]].<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""> {{citation
column388: title=NOAA Paleoclimatology Global Warming – The Story: Proxy Data
column391: publisher=NOAA Paleoclimatology Program – NCDC Paleoclimatology Branch }} </ref> Sources of proxy data include historical records such as [[tree rings]], [[ice core]]s, [[coral]]s, and ocean and lake [[sediment]]s.<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""/> The data shows that recent warming has surpassed anything in the last 2,000 years.<ref name=""phys.org"">[https://phys.org/news/2019-07-20th-century-hottest-years.html The 20th century was the hottest in nearly 2,000 years, studies show], 25 July 2019</ref> By the end of the 21st century, temperatures may increase to a level not experienced since the mid-[[Pliocene]], around 3 million years ago.<ref name=""jansen pliocene""> {{cite book
column430: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch6s6-3-2.html Sec. 6.3.2 What Does the Record of the Mid-Pliocene Show?]
column432: chapter-url=http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch6.html}} </ref> At that time, mean global temperatures were about 2–4 °C warmer than pre-industrial temperatures, and the global mean sea level was up to 25 meters higher than it is today.<ref>{{Cite book
column459: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column477: Physical impacts of climate change}} {{Multiple image
column480: image1=Diagram showing ten indicators of global warming.png
column482: image2=Changes in climate indicators that show global warming.png
column486: caption2=Changes in climate indicators over several decades. Each of the different colored lines in each panel represents an independently analyzed set of data. The data come from many different technologies including [[weather station]]s, [[satellite]]s, [[weather balloons]], [[ship]]s and [[buoy]]s.<ref>{{harvnb
column489: p=3}}</ref> }} A broad range of evidence shows that the climate system has warmed.<ref> {{citation
column497: 2007}}. </ref> Evidence of global warming is shown in the graphs (below right) from the US [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] (NOAA). Some of the graphs show a positive [[trend estimation
column498: trend]], e.g., increasing temperature over land and the ocean, and [[current sea level rise
column499: sea level rise]]. Other graphs show a negative trend, such as decreased [[snow]] cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]], and declining [[Arctic sea ice]], both of which are indicative of global warming. Evidence of warming is also [[Effects of global warming#Observed impacts on biological systems
column500: apparent in living (biological) systems]] such as changes in distribution of [[flora]] and [[fauna]] towards the poles.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""> {{citation
column507: chapter=Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column509: display-authors=etal}} </ref> Human-induced warming could lead to large-scale, abrupt and/or [[Irreversible effects of global warming
column514: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html Sec. 3. Projected climate change and its impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column517: title=ESRL News: New Study Shows Climate Change Largely Irreversible
column520: publisher=US Department of Commerce, NOAA, Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL)
column521: date=26 January 2009 }}</ref> An example of this is the melting of [[ice sheet]]s, which contributes to sea level rise.<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""> {{citation
column527: 2007}}. </ref> The probability of warming having unforeseen consequences increases with the rate, magnitude, and duration of climate change.<ref> {{cite book
column532: publisher=[[United States National Academy of Sciences]]
column536: Tropical cyclone#Global warming}} The main impact of global warming on the weather is an increase in extreme weather events such as heat waves, droughts, cyclones, blizzards and rainstorms. Of the 20 costliest climate and weather disasters that have occurred in the United States since 1980, eight have taken place since 2010, four of these in 2017 alone.<ref> [https://www.ucsusa.org/sites/default/files/attach/2018/06/The-Science-Connecting-Extreme-Weather-to-Climate-Change.pdf The science connecting extreme weather to climate change], Fact sheet: Union of Concerned Scientists, June 2018.</ref> Such events will continue to occur more often and with greater intensity.<ref>[https://www.livescience.com/37057-global-warming-effects.html Effects of Global Warming], Live Science, 12 August 2017</ref> Episodes of intense precipitation contribute to flooding, soil erosion, landslides, and damage to structures and crops.<ref> [https://www.ucsusa.org/resources/signs-global-warming-downpours-heavy-snowfalls-and-flooding Early Warning Signs of Global Warming: Downpours, Heavy Snowfalls, and Flooding], Union of Concerned Scientists, 10 November 2003</ref> ==== Precipitation ==== Higher temperatures lead to increased evaporation and surface drying. As the air warms, its water-holding capacity also increases, particularly over the oceans. In general the air can hold about 7% more moisture for every 1 °C of temperature rise.<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""> {{cite book
column537: title=Global Climate Change Impacts in the United States
column549: chapter-url=http://downloads.globalchange.gov/usimpacts/pdfs/climate-impacts-report.pdf}}</ref> In the tropics, there's more than a 10% increase in precipitation for a 1 °C increase in temperature.<ref> Global warming is increasing rainfall rates, The Guardian, 22 March 2017</ref> Changes have already been observed in the amount, intensity, frequency, and type of [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column550: precipitation]]. Extreme precipitation events are sometimes the result of [[atmospheric river]]s - wide paths of atmospheric moisture composed of condensed water vapor.<ref> Atmospheric River Change, Climate Signals, 4 December 2018</ref> Widespread increases in heavy precipitation have occurred even in places where total rain amounts have decreased.<ref> {{citation
column559: chapter-url=https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B1gFp6Ioo3akYklZcWkwWHJud00/edit?pli=1}} </ref> Projections of future changes in precipitation show overall increases in the global average, but with substantial shifts in where and how precipitation falls.<ref name = ""USGCRP exec sum""/> Projections suggest a reduction in rainfall in the [[subtropics]], and an increase in precipitation in subpolar latitudes and some [[equatorial region]]s.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""> {{citation
column563: title=Will the wet get wetter and the dry drier?
column567: publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory (GFDL)
column568: location=Princeton, NJ }}. Revision 10/15/2008, 4:47:16 PM. </ref> In other words, regions which are dry at present will in general become even drier, while regions that are currently wet will in general become even wetter.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> This projection does not apply to every locale, and in some cases can be modified by local conditions.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""/> Although increased rainful will not occur everywhere, models suggest most of the world will have a 16-24% increase in heavy precipitation intensity by 2100.<ref> [https://www.carbonbrief.org/explainer-what-climate-models-tell-us-about-future-rainfall Explainer: What climate models tell us about future rainfall], Carbon Brief 19 January 2018</ref> ==== Temperatures ==== Over most land areas since the 1950s, it is very likely that at all times of year both days and nights have become warmer due to human activities.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""> IPCC (2013), Table SPM.1, in [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf Summary for Policymakers, p. 5] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140226155600/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column570: 2013}} </ref> There may have been changes in other climate extremes (e.g., [[flood]]s, [[drought]]s and [[tropical cyclone]]s) but these changes are more difficult to identify.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes"" /> Projections suggest changes in the frequency and intensity of some extreme weather events.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes"" /> In the U.S. since 1999, two warm weather records have been set or broken for every cold one.<ref name=""2019-03-19-gu"">{{cite web
column573: title=Record high US temperatures outpace record lows two to one, study finds
column578: title=The ratio of warm and cold temperature records is increasingly skewed - Axios
column584: access-date=2019-03-19}}</ref> Some changes (e.g. more frequent hot days) will probably be evident in the near term (2016–2035), while other near-term changes (e.g. more intense droughts and tropical cyclones) are more uncertain.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes"" /> Future climate change will include more very hot days and fewer very cold days.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes"" /> The frequency, length and intensity of [[heat wave]]s will very likely increase over most land areas.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes"" /> Higher growth in anthropogenic GHG emissions would cause more frequent and severe temperature extremes.<ref>Stocker, T.F., ''et al.'' (2013), Temperature Extremes, Heat Waves and Warm Spells, in: TFE.9, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf Technical Summary, p. 111] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221070705/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column586: 2013}} </ref> If GHG emissions grow a lot (IPCC scenario [[Representative Concentration Pathways
column587: RCP8.5]]), already dry regions may have more droughts and less [[soil moisture]].<ref>Stocker, T.F., ''et al.'' (2013), Floods and Droughts, in: TFE.9, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf Technical Summary, p. 112] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221070705/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column589: 2013}} </ref> Over most of the mid-latitude land masses and wet tropical regions, extreme precipitation events will very likely become more intense and frequent.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes"" /> ==== Heat waves ==== [[Global warming]] boosts the probability of [[extreme weather]] events such as [[heat wave]]s<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/11/science/earth/global-warming-makes-heat-waves-more-likely-study-finds.html ''Global Warming Makes Heat Waves More Likely, Study Finds''] 10 July 2012 [[NYT]]</ref><ref>{{cite journal
column594: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
column605: bibcode=2012PNAS..109E2415H }}</ref> where the daily maximum temperature exceeds the average maximum temperature by 5 °C (9 °F) for more than five consecutive days.<ref>[https://www.britannica.com/science/heat-wave-meteorology Heat wave: meteorology]. Encyclopedia Britannica. Retrieved 1 April 2019. </ref> In the last 30–40 years, heat waves with high humidity have become more frequent and severe. Extremely hot nights have doubled in frequency. The area in which extremely hot summers are observed has increased 50-100 fold. These changes are not explained by natural variability, and are attributed by climate scientists to the influence of [[wikt:anthropogenic
column606: anthropogenic]] climate change. Heat waves with high humidity pose a big risk to human health while heat waves with low humidity lead to dry conditions that increase [[wildfires]]. The mortality from extreme heat is larger than the mortality from hurricanes, lightning, tornadoes, floods, and earthquakes together.<ref name=""Heat Waves: The Details"">{{cite web
column610: accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref> ==== Tropical cyclones ==== Global warming not only causes changes in tropical cyclones, it may also make some impacts from them worse via sea level rise. The intensity of tropical cyclones (hurricanes, typhoons, etc.) is projected to increase globally, with the proportion of [[Saffir–Simpson scale
column611: Category 4 and 5]] tropical cyclones increasing. Furthermore, the rate of rainfall is projected to increase, but trends in the future frequency on a global scale are not yet clear.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones"">Christensen, J.H.,''et al.'' (2013), Cyclones, in: Executive Summary, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf Chapter 14: Climate Phenomena and their Relevance for Future Regional Climate Change, p. 1220] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221075046/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column614: chapter= Chapter 6: Extremes, Abrupt Changes and Managing Risks
column633: page= 592 }}</ref> Changes in tropical cyclones will probably vary by region.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones"" /> === On land === ==== Flooding ==== Warmer air holds more water vapor. When this turns to rain, it tends to come in heavy downpours potentially leading to more floods. A 2017 study found that peak precipitation is increasing between 5 and 10% for every one degree Celsius increase.<ref>[https://www.nature.com/articles/nclimate3239 The peak structure and future changes of the relationships between extreme precipitation and temperature], Nature Climate Change volume 7, pp 268–274 (2017) </ref> In the United States and many other parts of the world there has been a marked increase in intense rainfall events which have resulted in more severe flooding.<ref> [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2017/mar/22/global-warming-is-increasing-rainfall-rates Global warming is increasing rainfall rates], The Guardian, 22 March 2017</ref> Estimates of the number of people at risk of coastal flooding from climate-driven sea-level rise varies from 190 million,<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-50236882 Climate change: Sea level rise to affect 'three times more people'], BBC News, 30 October 2019 </ref> to 300 million or even 640 million in a worst-case scenario related to the instability of the Antarctic ice sheet.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/oct/29/rising-sea-levels-pose-threat-to-homes-of-300m-people-study Rising sea levels pose threat to homes of 300m people – study], The Guardian, 29 October 2019 </ref><ref> [https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-019-12808-z New elevation data triple estimates of global vulnerability to sea-level rise and coastal flooding], Nature Communications, Vol 10, Article number: 4844 (2019) </ref> ==== Wildfires ==== Prolonged periods of warmer temperatures typically cause soil and [[underbrush]] to be drier for longer periods, increasing the risk of wildfires. Hot, dry conditions increase the likelihood that wildfires will be more intense and burn for longer once they start.<ref> [https://www.ucsusa.org/resources/global-warming-fueling-increased-wildfire-risks Is Global Warming Fueling Increased Wildfire Risks?] Union of Concerned Scientists, 24 July 2018</ref> Global warming has increased summertime air temperatures in California by over 3.5 degrees Fahrenheit such that the fire season (the time before the winter rains dampen the vegetation) has lengthened by 75 days over previous decades. As a result, since the 1980s, both the size and ferocity of fires in California have increased dramatically. Since the 1970s, the size of the area burned has increased fivefold while fifteen of the 20 largest fires in California have occurred since 2000.<ref> [https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/2019/10/climate-change-california-power-outage/ climate change is contributing to California’s fires], National Geographic</ref> In Australia, the annual number of hot days (above 35°C) and very hot days (above 40°C) has increased significantly in many areas of the country since 1950. The country has always had [[bushfires]] but in 2019, the extent and ferocity of these fires increased dramatically.<ref> [https://time.com/5735660/sydney-bushfires/ As Smoke From Bushfires Chokes Sydney, Australian Prime Minister Dodges on Climate Change], Time 21 November 2019.</ref> For the first time catastrophic bushfire conditions were declared for Greater Sydney. New South Wales and Queensland declared a state of emergency but fires were also burning in South Australia and Western Australia.<ref>[https://www.climatecouncil.org.au/not-normal-climate-change-bushfire-web/ The facts about bushfires and climate change], Climate Council, 13 November 2019</ref> ===Cryosphere=== {{See also
column638: A map that shows ice concentration on 16 September 2012, along with the extent of the previous record low (yellow line) and the mid-September median extent (black line) setting a new record low that was 18 percent smaller than the previous record and nearly 50 percent smaller than the long-term (1979–2000) average.]] The [[cryosphere]] is made up of those parts of the planet which are so cold, they are frozen and covered by snow or ice. This includes ice and snow on land such as the continental ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica, as well as glaciers and areas of snow and permafrost; and ice found on water including frozen parts of the ocean, such as the waters surrounding Antarctica and the Arctic.<ref>[https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/cryosphere.html What is the cryosphere?] National ocean Service</ref> The cryosphere, especially the polar regions, is extremely sensitive to changes in global climate.<ref> [https://serc.carleton.edu/eslabs/cryosphere/1c.html Getting to Know the Cryosphere], Earth Labs</ref> Arctic sea ice began to decline at the beginning of the twentieth century but the rate is accelerating. Since 1979, satellite records indicate the decline in summer sea ice coverage has been about 13% per decade.<ref>[https://www.carbonbrief.org/impacts-of-a-melting-cryosphere-ice-loss-around-the-world Impacts of a melting cryosphere  ice loss around the world], Carbon Brief, 9 June 2011 </ref><ref>{{citation
column646: 2012}}</ref> The thickness of sea ice has also decreased by 66% or 2.0 m over the last six decades with a shift from permanent ice to largely seasonal ice cover.<ref>{{Cite journal
column650: title=Arctic sea ice thickness, volume, and multiyear ice coverage: losses and coupled variability (1958–2018)
column658: doi-access=free}}</ref> While ice-free summers are expected to be rare at 1.5 °C degrees of warming, they are set to occur at least once every decade at a warming level of 2.0 °C.<ref>{{Cite book
column672: chapter-url=https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/sites/2/2019/05/SR15_SPM_version_report_LR.pdf}}</ref> Since the beginning of the twentieth century, there has also been a widespread retreat of [[alpine glaciers]],<ref>{{citation
column673: title=Mass Balance of Mountain Glaciers in 2011
column680: 2012}}</ref> and snow cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]].<ref>{{citation
column681: title=2011 Snow Cover in Northern Hemisphere
column697: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-4.html Box 10.1: Future Abrupt Climate Change, ‘Climate Surprises’, and Irreversible Changes: Glaciers and ice caps]
column700: display-authors=etal}}. </ref> and snow cover are projected to continue their widespread retreat.<ref> {{citation
column708: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-3-3-2.html Sec 10.3.3.2 Changes in Snow Cover and Frozen Ground]
column711: display-authors=etal}}. </ref> The melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column712: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s will continue to contribute to sea level rise over long time-scales.<ref>{{Cite book
column739: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column760: last10=Isla}}</ref> Changes in the cryosphere are projected to have social impacts.<ref> Some of these impacts are included in table SPM.2: {{citation
column761: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html#spm2 3 Projected climate change and its impacts: Table SPM.2]
column766: pp=11–12}} </ref> For example, in some regions, glacier retreat could increase the risk of reductions in seasonal water availability.<ref> {{citation
column768: chapter=Ch 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column775: title = Potential impacts of a warming climate on water availability in snow-dominated regions: Abstract
column788: url-status = dead }}</ref> estimated that more than one-sixth of the [[world's population]] rely on glaciers and snowpack for their water supply. ===Oceans=== {{Main
column789: Effects of global warming on oceans}} [[File:Heat content700m2000myr.png
column793: Global ocean heat content from 1955–2019]] Global warming is projected to have a number of effects on the [[Ocean
column794: oceans]]. Ongoing effects include [[Sea level rise
column795: rising sea levels]] due to thermal expansion and melting of glaciers and ice sheets, and warming of the ocean surface, leading to increased temperature stratification.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite book
column822: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column845: last14=Suga}} </ref> Other possible effects include large-scale changes in ocean circulation. The oceans also serve as a sink for carbon dioxide, taking up much that would otherwise remain in the atmosphere, but increased levels of {{chem
column847: 2}} have led to [[ocean acidification]]. Furthermore, as the temperature of the oceans increases, they become less able to absorb excess {{chem
column849: 2}}. The oceans have also acted as a sink in absorbing extra heat from the atmosphere.<ref name=""statecl"">{{cite book
column851: publisher = Website of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration: National Climatic Data Center
column852: title = State of the Climate in 2009, as appearing in the July 2010 issue (Vol. 91) of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society (BAMS). Supplemental and Summary Materials: Report at a Glance: Highlights
column856: archive-date=2011-02-22 <!-- archive to PDF replaces stale link: http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/bams-state-of-the-climate/2009.php -->
column860: Ocean deoxygenation}} Warmer water cannot contain as much oxygen as cold water, so heating is expected to lead to less oxygen in the ocean. Other processes also play a role: stratification may lead to increases in respiration rates of organic matter, further decreasing oxygen content. The ocean has already lost oxygen, throughout the entire water column and [[Oxygen minimum zone
column861: oxygen minimum zones]] are expanding worldwide.<ref name="":0"" /> This has adverse consequences for ocean life.<ref>{{Cite journal
column869: title = Abrupt Climate Change and Extinction Events in Earth History
column888: title = Long-term ocean oxygen depletion in response to carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels
column891: url = http://orbit.dtu.dk/en/publications/longterm-ocean-oxygen-depletion-in-response-to-carbon-dioxide-emissions-from-fossil-fuels(ae82ab91-9717-4c23-91aa-f8dd0b7fc5bb).html }}</ref> ====Ocean heat uptake==== Oceans have taken up over 90% of the excess heat accumulated on Earth due to global warming.<ref>{{Cite book
column918: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column939: last10=Levin}}</ref> The warming rate varies with depth: at a depth of a thousand metres the warming occurs at a rate of almost 0.4 °C per century (data from 1981-2019), whereas the warming rate at two kilometres depth is only half.<ref>{{Cite book
column966: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column987: last10=Levin}}</ref> The increase in ocean [[heat content]] is much larger than any other store of [[energy]] in the Earth's heat balance and accounts for more than 90% of the increase in heat content of the Earth system, and has accelerated in the 1993-2017 period compared to 1969-1993.<ref>{{Cite book
column1007: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column1009: chapter-url=https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/sites/3/2019/11/09_SROCC_Ch05_FINAL.pdf}}</ref> In 2019 a paper published in the journal [[Science (journal)
column1010: Science]] found the oceans are heating 40% faster than the IPCC predicted just five years before.<ref>{{cite news
column1014: title=New Climate Change Report Says Ocean Warming Is Far Worse Than Expected
column1027: title=How fast are the oceans warming?
column1034: accessdate=11 January 2019}}</ref> As well as having effects on ecosystems (e.g. by melting sea ice affecting [[algae]] that grow on its underside), warming reduces the ocean's ability to absorb {{chem
column1044: title=Sensitivities of marine carbon fluxes to ocean change
column1052: doi-access=free}}</ref> It is likely that the oceans warmed faster between 1993-2017 compared to the period starting in 1969.<ref>{{Cite book
column1079: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column1105: Historical sea level reconstruction and projections up to 2100 published in January 2017 by the U.S. Global Change Research Program.<ref>{{harvnb
column1107: 2017}}.</ref>]] The IPCC's [[Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate
column1108: Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere]] concluded that global mean sea level rose by 0.16 metres between 1901 and 2016.<ref>{{Cite book
column1118: chapter-url=https://report.ipcc.ch/srocc/pdf/SROCC_SPM_Approved.pdf}}</ref> The rate of sea level rise since the industrial revolution in the 19th century has been larger than the rate during the previous two thousand years.<ref>IPCC AR% [https://ar5-syr.ipcc.ch/topic_summary.php Summary for Policy Makers]</ref> Global sea level rise is accelerating, rising 2.5 times faster between 2006 and 2016 than it did during the 20th century.<ref> The Oceans We Know Won’t Survive Climate Change, The Atlantic, 25 September 2019</ref><ref>{{Cite book
column1146: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column1166: last18=Pereira}}</ref> Two main factors contribute to the rise. The first is [[thermal expansion]]: as ocean water warms, it expands. The second is from the melting of land-based ice in glaciers and ice sheets due to global warming.<ref>{{Cite book
column1194: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column1214: last18=Pereira}}</ref> Prior to 2007, thermal expansion was the largest component in these projections, contributing 70–75% of sea level rise.<ref> {{citation
column1225: display-authors=etal}}. </ref> As the impact of global warming has accelerated, melting from glaciers and ice sheets has become the main contributor.<ref> {{Cite book
column1252: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column1273: last10=Isla}}</ref> Even if emission of greenhouse gases stops overnight, sea level rise will continue for centuries to come.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1283: title=Committed sea-level rise under the Paris Agreement and the legacy of delayed mitigation action
column1292: doi-access=free}}</ref> In 2015, a study by Professor James Hansen of Columbia University and 16 other climate scientists said a sea level rise of three metres could be a reality by the end of the century.<ref>[https://www.tvnz.co.nz/one-news/new-zealand/simulation-shows-unavoidable-3m-auckland-sea-level-rise-q02974 Simulation shows ‘unavoidable’ 3m Auckland sea level rise]. TVNZ 25 July 2015.</ref> Another study by scientists at the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute in 2017 using updated projections of Antarctic mass loss and a revised statistical method also concluded that, although it was a low probability, a three-metre rise was possible.<ref>[https://phys.org/news/2017-04-sea-metres.html Sea levels could rise by more than three metres, shows new study], PhysOrg, 26 April 2017 </ref> Rising sea levels will put hundreds of millions of people at risk in low-lying coastal areas in countries such as China, Bangladesh, India and Vietnam.<ref>{{Cite news
column1294: title=Sea level rise to affect 'three times more people'
column1300: Regional effects of global warming}} [[File:Change in Average Temperature.svg
column1304: Average global temperatures from 2010 to 2019 compared to a baseline average from 1951 to 1978. Source: [[Goddard Institute for Space Studies
column1305: NASA]].]] Regional effects of global warming vary in nature. Some are the result of a generalised global change, such as rising temperature, resulting in local effects, such as melting ice. In other cases, a change may be related to a change in a particular ocean current or weather system. In such cases, the regional effect may be disproportionate and will not necessarily follow the global trend. There are three major ways in which global warming will make changes to regional climate: melting or forming ice, changing the [[hydrological cycle]] (of [[evaporation]] and [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column1307: currents in the oceans]] and air flows in the atmosphere. The coast can also be considered a region, and will suffer severe impacts from [[sea level rise]]. The [[Arctic]], [[Africa]], small islands, [[Asia]]n [[river delta
column1308: megadeltas]] and [[Climate change in the Middle East and North Africa
column1309: the Middle East]] are regions that are likely to be especially affected by climate change.<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions"">{{citation
column1311: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-3.html Sec. 3.3.3 Especially affected systems, sectors and regions]
column1318: title=Climate change impacts in the Middle East and Northern Africa (MENA) region and their implications for vulnerable population groups
column1325: less-developed]] regions are at most risk of experiencing negative impacts due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts"">{{citation
column1334: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Distribution of Impacts, in: Sec 19.3.7 Update on 'Reasons for Concern']
column1335: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column1337: display-authors=etal}} </ref> [[Developed countries]] are also vulnerable to climate change.<ref name=""schneider regional vulnerabilities"">{{citation
column1340: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column1345: p=792}} </ref> For example, developed countries will be negatively affected by increases in the severity and frequency of some [[extreme weather]] events, such as [[heat wave]]s.<ref name=""schneider regional vulnerabilities"" /> Projections of future climate changes at the regional scale do not hold as high a level of scientific confidence as projections made at the global scale.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure"">{{cite book
column1347: title=Understanding and Responding to Climate Change. A brochure prepared by the US National Research Council (US NRC)
column1349: publisher=[http://dels.nas.edu/basc Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate], National Academy of Sciences
column1353: date=November 2012}} It is, however, expected that future warming will follow a similar geographical pattern to that seen already, with the greatest warming over land and high northern [[latitude]]s, and least over the [[Southern Ocean]] and parts of the [[North Atlantic Ocean]].<ref>{{citation
column1357: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-projections-of.html Projections of Future Changes in Climate] }}, in {{harvnb
column1359: 2007}}. </ref> Land areas warm faster than ocean, and this feature is even stronger for extreme temperatures. For hot extremes, regions with the most warming include Central and South Europe and Western and central Asia.<ref>{{Cite book
column1386: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column1408: Effects of climate change on humans
column1409: Climate change, industry and society}} {{See also
column1410: Climate change and gender}} The effects of climate change, in combination with the sustained increases in greenhouse gas emissions, have led scientists to characterize it as a ''climate emergency.''<ref>[https://scientistswarning.forestry.oregonstate.edu/sites/sw/files/climate%20emergency%20Ripple%20et%20al.pdf World Scientists’ Warning of a Climate Emergency], In press with Bioscience Magazine.</ref><ref name="":7"">World Scientists’ Warning of a Climate Emergency, William J Ripple, Christopher Wolf, Thomas M Newsome, Phoebe Barnard, William R Moomaw. BioScience, biz088, https://doi.org/10.1093/biosci/biz088. A correction has been published: [https://academic.oup.com/bioscience/advance-article/doi/10.1093/biosci/biz152/5670749 BioScience, biz152], https://doi.org/10.1093/biosci/biz152</ref><ref>[https://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/scientists-around-world-declare-climate-emergency-180973462/ Scientists Around the World Declare ‘Climate Emergency’], Smithsonian Magazine, 5 November 2019 </ref> Some climate researchers<ref>[https://edition.cnn.com/2019/06/04/health/climate-change-existential-threat-report-intl/index.html Climate change could pose 'existential threat' by 2050: report], CNN, 5 June 2019.</ref><ref>[https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-019-03595-0 Climate tipping points — too risky to bet against], Nature, 27 November 2019.</ref> and activists<ref>Greta Thunberg showed the world what it means to lead, ''The Guardian,'' 25 September 2019</ref> have called it an ''existential threat to civilization''. [[File:The change of the mean annual temperature with climate change.jpg
column1412: The possible effect of temperature rise caused by climate change on humans. The black stains, are the areas in wich the mean annual temperature in the year 2020 is higher then 29°C, what is considered as too hot for normal life. The shaded areas, are the areas in which it will be higher than 29°C in the business as usual ([[RCP8.5]]) scenario by the year 2070<ref>{{cite journal
column1421: title=Future of the human climate niche (figure 3)
column1422: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
column1431: doi-access=free }}</ref> e.g., if the global average temperature will rise by 3.2°C, relatively to the pre - industrial baseline<ref>{{cite book
column1432: title=Supplementary Materials Future of the human climate niche
column1435: accessdate=14 June 2020}}</ref>]] The vulnerability and exposure of humans to climate change varies from one economic sector to another and will have different impacts in different countries. Wealthy industrialised countries, which have emitted the most CO<sub>2</sub>, have more resources and so are the least vulnerable to global warming.<ref>{{Cite web
column1437: title=The Industries and Countries Most Vulnerable to Climate Change
column1443: access-date=2019-12-15}}</ref> Economic sectors that are likely to be affected include [[climate change and agriculture
column1444: agriculture]], human health, [[Fisheries and climate change
column1473: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column1496: first10=F.}}</ref> The quality and quantity of [[Fresh water
column1497: freshwater]] will likely be affected almost everywhere. Some people may be particularly at risk from climate change, such as the [[poverty
column1498: poor]], young [[children]] and the [[elderly]].<ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts"" /><ref>{{citation
column1507: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-2-5.html Sec 7.4.2.5 Social issues and Sec 7.4.3 Key vulnerabilities]
column1510: display-authors=etal}} </ref> According to a study published in May 2020, for every degree of temperature rise there will be 1 billion people that will live in areas with temperatures considered as too high for a normal life.<ref>{{cite news
column1513: title=One billion people will live in insufferable heat within 50 years – study
column1526: title=Future of the human climate niche
column1527: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
column1539: Net crop production worldwide and in selected tropical countries. Raw data from the United Nations.<ref>{{cite web
column1544: website=faostat3.fao.org}}</ref>]] Climate change will impact agriculture and food production around the world due to the effects of elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere; higher temperatures; altered precipitation and [[transpiration]] regimes; increased frequency of extreme events; and modified [[weed]], [[pest (organism)
column1554: chapter=Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column1556: display-authors=etal}} </ref> Climate change is projected to negatively affect all four pillars of food security: not only how much food is available, but also how easy food is to access (prices), food quality and how stable the food system is.<ref>{{Cite book
column1600: first15=A. J.}}</ref> ====Food availability==== [[File:Projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming.png
column1605: 2011 projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""> [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12877&page=161 Figure 5.1], p.161, in: Sec 5.1 FOOD PRODUCTION, PRICES, AND HUNGER, in: Ch 5: Impacts in the Next Few Decades and Coming Centuries, in: {{harvnb
column1607: 2011}} </ref>]] [[File:Projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming.png
column1612: 2011 projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""/>]] As of 2019, negative impacts have been observed for some crops in low-latitudes ([[maize]] and wheat), while positive impacts of climate change have been observed in some crops in high-latitudes (maize, wheat, and [[Sugar beet
column1626: IPCC SRCCL DRAFT Summary for Policymakers
column1630: chapter-url=https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/2019/08/Edited-SPM_Approved_Microsite_FINAL.pdf}}</ref> Using different methods to project future crop yields, a consistent picture emerges of global decreases in yield. Maize and [[soybean]] decrease with any warming, whereas rice and wheat production might peak at 3 °C of warming.<ref>{{Cite book
column1675: fisheries]] have already seen their catch decrease because of global warming and changes in [[Biogeochemical cycle
column1676: biochemical cycles]]. In combination with [[overfishing]], warming waters decrease the maximum catch potential.<ref>{{Cite book
column1689: IPCC SROCC DRAFT Summary for Policymakers
column1693: chapter-url=https://report.ipcc.ch/srocc/pdf/SROCC_SPM_Approved.pdf}}</ref> Global catch potential is projected to reduce further in 2050 by less than 4% if emissions are reduced strongly, and by about 8% for very high future emissions, with growth in the [[Arctic Ocean]].<ref>{{Cite book
column1720: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column1743: last10=Levin}}</ref> =====Other aspects of food security===== Climate change impacts depend strongly on projected future social and economic development. {{As of
column1746: df=}}, an estimated 831 million people are undernourished.<ref name="":4"">{{Cite book
column1790: first15=A. J.}}</ref> Under a high emission scenario (RCP6.0), cereals are projected to become 1-29% more expensive in 2050 depending on the socioeconomic pathway, particularly affecting low-income consumers.<ref name="":4"" /> Compared to a no climate change scenario, this would put between 1-181 million extra people at risk of hunger.<ref name="":4"" /> While {{CO2}} is expected to be good for crop productivity at lower temperatures, it does reduce the nutritional values of crops, with for instance wheat having less protein and less of some minerals.<ref>{{Cite book
column1810: chapter-url=https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/sites/4/2019/11/08_Chapter-5.pdf}}</ref> It is difficult to project the impact of climate change on volatility of food prices and use{{Clarify
column1812: date=February 2020}}, but most models projecting the future indicate that prices will become more volatile.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1830: title=Climate Change and Global Food Systems: Potential Impacts on Food Security and Undernutrition
column1839: doi-access=free}}</ref> ====Droughts and agriculture==== Some evidence suggests that droughts have been occurring more frequently because of global warming; and they are expected to become more frequent and intense in Africa, southern Europe, the Middle East, most of the Americas, Australia, and Southeast Asia.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1843: title = Drought under global warming: A review
column1844: journal = Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Climate Change
column1851: bibcode = 2011AGUFM.H42G..01D }}</ref> However, other research suggests that there has been little change in drought over the past 60 years.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1853: title = Little change in global drought over the past 60 years
column1866: pmid=23151587}}</ref> Their impacts are aggravated because of increased water demand, population growth, urban expansion, and environmental protection efforts in many areas.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1880: bibcode = 2011JHyd..403..157M }}</ref> Droughts result in crop failures and the loss of pasture for livestock.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1888: title = Measuring economic impacts of drought: A review and discussion
column1902: Precipitation during the 20th century and through 2008 during global warming: [[NOAA]] estimate an observed trend over that period of 1.87% global precipitation increase per century.]] A number of climate-related trends have been observed that affect [[water resources]]. These include changes in precipitation, the cryosphere and [[surface water]]s (e.g., changes in [[river flows]]).<ref> {{citation
column1909: chapter=Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column1911: display-authors=etal}} </ref> Observed and projected impacts of climate change on [[freshwater]] systems and their management are mainly due to changes in temperature, sea level and precipitation variability.<ref name=""freshwater impacts""> {{citation
column1918: chapter=Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column1920: display-authors=etal}} </ref> Changes in temperature are correlated with variability in precipitation because the [[water cycle]] is reactive to temperature.<ref>{{Cite web
column1922: title=Freshwater (Lakes and Rivers) - The Water Cycle
column1924: access-date=2019-05-01}}</ref> Temperature increases change precipitation patterns. Excessive precipitation leads to excessive sediment deposition, nutrient pollution, and concentration of minerals in [[Aquifer
column1925: aquifers]]. The rising global temperature will cause sea level rise and will extend areas of [[Salinity
column1927: estuaries]], resulting in a decrease in freshwater availability for humans and ecosystems in coastal areas. The rising sea level will push the salt gradient into freshwater deposits and will eventually pollute freshwater sources. The 2014 [[IPCC Fifth Assessment Report
column1928: fifth IPCC assessment report]] concluded that: * Water resources are projected to decrease in most dry [[Subtropics
column1929: subtropical regions]] and [[mid-latitudes]], but increase in high latitudes. As streamflow becomes more variable, even regions with increased water resources can experience additional short-term [[Water scarcity
column1960: date=February 2020}} average of 7% of the [[world population]] is expected to have at least 20% less renewable water resource.<ref name="":5"">{{Cite book
column1988: chapter-url=https://archive.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg2/WGIIAR5-Chap3_FINAL.pdf}}</ref> * Climate change is projected to reduce [[water quality]] before treatment. Even after conventional treatments, risks remain. The quality reduction is a consequence of higher temperatures, more intense rainfall, droughts and disruption of [[Water treatment
column1989: treatment facilities]] during floods.<ref name="":5"" /> * Droughts that stress water supply are expected to increase in [[southern Europe]] and the [[Mediterranean Basin
column1990: Mediterranean region]], [[central Europe]], central and southern [[North America]], [[Central America]], [[Northeast Region, Brazil
column2020: Effects of global warming on human health}} Humans are exposed to climate change through changing weather patterns (temperature, precipitation, sea-level rise and more frequent extreme events) and indirectly through changes in water, air and food quality and changes in ecosystems, agriculture, industry and settlements and the economy.<ref name=""health summary""> {{citation
column2031: display-authors=etal}}. </ref> Air pollution, wildfires, and heat waves caused by global warming have significantly affected human health,<ref>{{Cite journal
column2039: title=Climate change and respiratory health: current evidence and knowledge gaps
column2046: issn=1747-6348}}</ref> and in 2007, the World Health Organization estimated 150,000 people were being killed by climate-change-related issues every year.<ref> [https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/green/news/2007/09/24/3462/the-top-100-effects-of-global-warming/ The Top 100 Effects of Global Warming], Centre for American Progress, 24 September 2007</ref> A study by the [[World Health Organization]]<ref> {{cite book
column2049: title= Global health risks: mortality and burden of disease attributable to selected major risks
column2057: url= http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/global_health_risks/en/index.html }} </ref> concluded that climate change was responsible for 3% of [[diarrhoea]], 3% of [[malaria]], and 3.8% of [[dengue fever]] deaths worldwide in 2004. Total attributable mortality was about 0.2% of deaths in 2004; of these, 85% were child deaths. The effects of more frequent and extreme storms were excluded from this study. ====Projections==== A 2014 study by the [[World Health Organization]]<ref>{{Cite book
column2059: title=Quantitative risk assessment of the effects of climate change on selected causes of death, 2030s and 2050s
column2069: authors=World Health Organization}}</ref> estimated the effect of climate change on human health. Not all of the effects of climate change were included in their estimates, for example, the effects of more frequent and extreme storms were excluded. The report further assumed continued progress in health and growth. Even so, climate change was projected to cause an additional 250 000 additional deaths per year between 2030 and 2050.<ref>[https://www.who.int/publications-detail/cop24-special-report-health-climate-change COP24 special report: health and climate change]. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2018. p.24. Cataloguing-in-Publication (CIP) data. CIP data are available at <nowiki>http://apps.who.int/iris</nowiki>.</ref> With high confidence, authors of the IPCC AR4 Synthesis report<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report"">{{harvnb
column2073: date=November 2012}} projected that climate change would bring some benefits in temperate areas, such as fewer deaths from cold exposure, and some mixed effects such as changes in range and transmission potential of [[malaria]] in [[Africa]]. Benefits were projected to be outweighed by negative health effects of rising temperatures, especially in [[Developing country
column2074: developing countries]]. Economic development is an important component of possible adaptation to climate change. Economic growth on its own, however, is not sufficient to insulate the world's population from disease and injury due to climate change.<ref name=""health summary""/> Future vulnerability to climate change will depend not only on the extent of social and economic change, but also on how the benefits and costs of change are distributed in society.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""> {{citation
column2082: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-3-2.html Sec. 8.3.2 Future vulnerability to climate change]
column2085: display-authors=etal}} </ref> For example, in the 19th century, rapid [[urbanization]] in [[western Europe]] led to heath plummeting.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""/> Other factors important in determining the health of populations include [[education]], the availability of health services, and [[public health
column2086: public-health]] [[infrastructure]].<ref name=""health summary""/> ==== On mental health ==== {{see also
column2087: Eco-anxiety}} In 2018, the American Psychological Association issued a report about the [[effects of climate change on mental health
column2088: impact of climate change on mental health]]. It said that ""gradual, long-term changes in climate can also surface a number of different emotions, including fear, anger, feelings of powerlessness, or exhaustion"".<ref>[https://www.apa.org/news/press/releases/2017/03/climate-mental-health Climate Change's Toll On Mental Health], APA, 29 March 2017</ref> Generally this is likely to have the greatest impact on young people. California social scientist, Renee Lertzman, likens the climate-related stress now affecting teenagers and those in their 20s to [[Cold War]] fears that gripped young [[baby boomers]] who came of age under the threat of nuclear annihilation.<ref> [https://www.sctimes.com/story/news/local/minnesota/2019/04/21/climate-grief-takes-toll-younger-generations-baby-boomers-millenials/3518994002/ 'Climate grief' takes toll on younger generations], SC Times, 21 April 2019.</ref> A 2018 study found that unusually hot days have profound effects on mental health and that global warming could contribute to approximately 26,000 more suicides in the U.S. by 2050.<ref>{{cite web
column2090: title=Climate Change May Cause 26,000 More U.S. Suicides by 2050
column2095: Effects of climate change on island nations}} Gradual but pervasive environmental change and sudden natural disasters both influence the nature and extent of human migration but in different ways. ==== Slow onset ==== Slow-onset disasters and gradual environmental erosion such as desertification, reduction of soil fertility, coastal erosion and sea-level rise are likely to induce long term migration.<ref>[https://www.climateforesight.eu/migrations/environmental-migrants-up-to-1-billion-by-2050/ Environmental Migrants: Up To 1 Billion By 2050], Centro Euro-Mediterraneo sui Cambiamenti Climactici (CMCC) </ref> Migration related to desertification and reduced soil fertility is likely to be predominantly from [[rural area]]s in [[developing countries]] to towns and [[cities]].<ref name=""wdr migration""> {{citation
column2097: title = Managing social risks: Empower communities to protect themselves
column2098: chapter = Part One: Chapter 2: Reducing Human Vulnerability: Helping People Help Themselves
column2101: 2010}}. </ref> Displacement and migration related to sea level rise will mostly affect those who live in cities near the coast. More than 90 US coastal cities are already experiencing chronic flooding and that number is expected to double by 2030.<ref> [https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2019/01/the-world-s-coastal-cities-are-going-under-here-is-how-some-are-fighting-back/ The world’s coastal cities are going under. Here’s how some are fighting back.] World Economic Forum 16 January 2019</ref> Numerous cities in Europe will be affected by rising sea levels; especially in the Netherlands, Spain and Italy.<ref> [https://www.euronews.com/2018/02/02/rising-sea-levels-threat-a-shrinking-european-coastline-in-2100 Rising sea levels threat: a shrinking European coastline in 2100?] Euronews 2 February 2018</ref> Coastal cities in Africa are also under threat due to rapid urbanization and the growth of informal settlements along the coast.<ref>[https://theconversation.com/african-countries-arent-doing-enough-to-prepare-for-rising-sea-levels-103002 African countries aren’t doing enough to prepare for rising sea levels.] The Conversation 16 September, 2018 </ref> According to the World Economic Forum: ""The coming decades will be marked by the rise of ex-cities and climate migrants.""<ref>[https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2019/01/the-world-s-coastal-cities-are-going-under-here-is-how-some-are-fighting-back/ The world’s coastal cities are going under. Here’s how some are fighting back.] World Economic Forum 16 January 2019</ref> Low lying Pacific island nations including Fiji, Kiribati, Nauru, Micronesia, the Marshall Islands, the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Timor Leste and Tonga are especially vulnerable to rising seas. In July 2019, they issued a declaration ""affirming that climate change poses the single greatest threat to the human rights and security of present and future generations of Pacific Island peoples""<ref> [https://drive.google.com/file/d/1cbSloYVSuY4mIZnUUC5ISpZUaV3NTb2y/view Nadi Bay Declaration on the Climate Change Crisis in the Pacific], Nadi Bay, Fiji, 30 July 2019</ref> and claim their lands could become uninhabitable as early as 2030.<ref> [https://www.sciencealert.com/pacific-islanders-are-in-a-climate-crisis-as-rising-sea-levels-threaten-water There's a Climate Threat Facing Pacific Islands That's More Dire Than Losing Land], Science Alert 19 September 2019</ref> The United Nations says there are already 64 million human migrants in the world fleeing wars, hunger, persecution and the effects of global warming.<ref>Environmental Migrants: Up To 1 Billion By 2050, Centro Euro-Mediterraneo sui Cambiamenti Climactici (CMCC) </ref> In 2018, the World Bank estimated that climate change will cause [[internal migration]] of between 31 and 143 million people as they escape crop failures, water scarcity, and sea level rise. The study only included Sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia, and Latin America.<ref> [https://www.nationalgeographic.com/news/2018/03/climate-migrants-report-world-bank-spd/ 143 Million People May Soon Become Climate Migrants], National Geographic, 19 March 2018</ref><ref>{{Cite book
column2103: title=Groundswell: preparing for internal climate migration
column2115: display-authors=etal}}</ref> A 2020 study projects that regions inhabited by a third of the human population could become as hot as the hottest parts of the [[Sahara]] within 50 years without a [[Projections of population growth
column2116: change in patterns of population growth]] and [[human migration
column2119: greenhouse gas emissions are reduced]]. The projected annual average temperature of above 29 °C for these regions would be outside the ""human temperature niche"" and the most affected regions have little [[adaptation to climate change
column2122: title=Climate change: More than 3bn could live in extreme heat by 2070
column2127: title='Near-unlivable' heat for one-third of humans within 50 years if greenhouse gas emissions are not cut
column2132: title=Billions projected to suffer nearly unlivable heat in 2070
column2146: title=Future of the human climate niche
column2147: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
column2156: issn=0027-8424}}</ref> The following matrix shows their projections for population-sizes outside the ""human temperature niche"" – and therefore potential emigrants of their regions – in different [[climate change scenario]]s and [[projections of population growth]]:<ref>{{cite web
column2157: title=Future of the human climate niche
column2176: mean projected global temperature rise of ~1.5 °C ! scope=""col"" width=""30""
column2178: mean projected global temperature rise of ~3.2 °C
column2225: } ==== Sudden onset ==== Sudden-onset natural disasters tend to create mass displacement, which may only be short term. However, [[Hurricane Katrina]] demonstrated that displacement can last a long time. Estimates suggest that a quarter of the one million people<ref> [https://www.datacenterresearch.org/data-resources/katrina/facts-for-impact/ Facts for Features: Katrina Impact], The Data Centre, 26 August 2016</ref> displaced in the Gulf Coast region by Hurricane Katrina had not returned to their homes five years after the disaster.<ref> [https://www.brookings.edu/on-the-record/natural-disasters-conflict-and-human-rights-tracing-the-connections/ Natural Disasters, Conflict, and Human Rights: Tracing the Connections], Brookings 3 March 2010.</ref> Mizutori, the U.N. secretary-general's special representative on disaster risk reduction, says millions of people are also displaced from their homes every year as result of sudden-onset disasters such as intense heatwaves, storms and flooding. She says 'climate crisis disasters' are happening at the rate of one a week.<ref>[https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/un-expert-warns-one-climate-crisis-disaster-occurs-every-week-180972573/ One Climate Crisis Disaster Occurs Every Week, U.N. Official Warns], The Smithsonian magazine, 8 July 2019 </ref> === Conflict === {{Main articles
column2226: Climate security}} A 2013 study found that significant climatic changes were associated with a higher risk of conflict worldwide, and predicted that ""amplified rates of human conflict could represent a large and critical social impact of anthropogenic climate change in both low- and high-income countries.""<ref>{{cite journal
column2227: vauthors=Hsiang SM, Burke M, Miguel E
column2228: title=Quantifying the influence of climate on human conflict
column2236: url=}}</ref> Similarly, a 2014 study found that higher temperatures were associated with a greater likelihood of violent crime, and predicted that global warming would cause millions of such crimes in the United States alone during the 21st century.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2238: title = Crime, weather, and climate change
column2239: journal = Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
column2245: pages=274–302}}</ref> However, a 2018 study in the journal ''Nature Climate Change'' found that previous studies on the relationship between climate change and conflict suffered from [[sampling bias]] and other methodological problems.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2262: bibcode=2018NatCC...8..200A}}</ref> Factors other than climate change may be more important in affecting conflict. For example, Wilbanks ''et al.'' (2007)<ref> {{citation
column2264: chapter = Chapter 7: Industry, settlement and society
column2266: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-1.html Sec. 7.4.1 General effects: Box 7.2. Environmental migration]
column2269: 2007}}. </ref> suggested that major environmentally influenced conflicts in Africa were more to do with the relative abundance of resources, e.g., [[oil]] and [[diamond]]s, than with resource scarcity. Despite these issues, military planners are concerned that global warming is a ""threat multiplier"". ""Whether it is poverty, food and [[water scarcity]], diseases, economic instability, or threat of natural disasters, the broad range of changing climatic conditions may be far reaching. These challenges may threaten stability in much of the world"".<ref>{{cite journal
column2274: journal =Proceedings of the United States Naval Institute
column2280: url=http://www.usni.org/magazines/proceedings/2013-10/next-security-frontier }}</ref> For example, the onset of the [[Arab Spring]] in 2010 was partly the result of a spike in wheat prices following crop losses from the [[2010 Northern Hemisphere heat waves
column2284: title=Climate Change and Rising Food Prices Heightened Arab Spring
column2286: work=Republished with permission by Scientific American
column2291: title=How the climate crisis could become a food crisis overnight
column2295: Economic impacts of climate change}} Economic forecasts of the impact of global warming vary considerably. Researchers have warned that current economic modelling may seriously underestimate the impact of potentially catastrophic climate change, and point to the need for new models that give a more accurate picture of potential damages. Nevertheless, one recent study has found that potential global economic gains if countries implement mitigation strategies to comply with the 2°C target set at the Paris Agreement are in the vicinity of US$17 trillion per year up to 2100 compared to a very high emission scenario.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2303: title=The Effects of Climate Change on GDP by Country and the Global Economic Gains From Complying With the Paris Climate Accord
column2313: bibcode=2018EaFut...6.1153K}}</ref> ====Observed impacts==== Global losses reveal rapidly rising costs due to extreme weather events since the 1970s.<ref> {{citation
column2316: title=Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 2007
column2319: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-8-5.html Sec. 1.3.8.5 Summary of disasters and hazards]
column2320: chapter=Chapter 1: Assessment of observed changes and responses in natural and managed systems
column2325: Socio-economic]] factors have contributed to the observed trend of global losses, such as population growth and increased [[wealth]].<ref name=""disaster losses""> {{citation
column2335: 2001}}. </ref> Part of the growth is also related to regional climatic factors, e.g., changes in precipitation and flooding events. It is difficult to quantify the relative impact of socio-economic factors and climate change on the observed trend.<ref name=""disaster losses""/> The trend does, however, suggest increasing vulnerability of social systems to climate change.<ref name=""disaster losses""/><ref>[http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/billions Billion-Dollar Weather and Climate Disasters]</ref> A 2019 modelling study found that climate change had contributed towards global economic inequality. Wealthy countries in colder regions had either felt little overall economic impact from climate change, or possibly benefited, whereas poor hotter countries countries very likely grew less than if global warming had not occurred.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2341: title=Global warming has increased global economic inequality
column2343: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
column2351: doi-access=free}}</ref> In 2019 global warming contributed to at least 15 sudden onset events that cost more than $1bn each in damage, with more than half of those costing more than $10bn each.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/dec/27/climate-crisis-linked-to-at-least-15-1bn-plus-disasters-in-2019 Climate crisis linked to at least 15 $1bn-plus disasters in 2019], The Guardian, 27 December 2019</ref> ====Projected impacts==== The total economic impacts from climate change are difficult to estimate, but increase for higher temperature changes.<ref>* {{Cite book
column2364: IPCC AR5 WG2 Summary for Policymakers
column2367: chapter-url=https://archive.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg2/ar5_wgII_spm_en.pdf}}</ref> For instance, total damages are estimated to be 90% less if global warming is limited to 1.5 °C compared to 3.66 °C, a warming level chosen to represent no mitigation.<ref name="":9"">{{Cite book
column2394: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column2417: first10=F.}}</ref> One study found a 3.5% reduction in global GDP by the end of the century if warming is limited to 3 °C, excluding the potential effect of [[Tipping points in the climate system
column2418: tipping points]]. Another study noted that global economic impact is underestimated by a factor of two to eight when tipping points are excluded from consideration.<ref name="":9"" /> In 2019 the [[National Bureau of Economic Research]] found that an increase in average global temperature of 0.04 °C per year, without mitigation policies, would reduce world real GDP per person by 7.22% by 2100. Following the [[Paris Agreement]], thereby limiting the temperature increase to 0.01 °C per year, reduces the loss to 1.07%.<ref>{{cite journal
column2431: title=Long-Term Macroeconomic Effects of Climate Change: A Cross-Country Analysis
column2433: accessdate=21 August 2019}}</ref> According to Oxford economics in high emission scenario the temperature will rise by 2 degrees, by the year 2050 what will reduce global GDP by 2.5% - 7.5%. By the year 2100 in this case, the temperature will rise by 4 degrees, what can reduce the global GDP by 30% in the worst case.<ref>{{cite web
column2436: title=Global GDP will suffer at least a 3% hit by 2050 from unchecked climate change, say economists
column2442: Effect of climate change on plant biodiversity
column2443: Effects of climate change on terrestrial animals
column2444: }} [[File:A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming (low-res).png
column2448: A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming.<ref name=""nasa briefs""> {{cite web
column2451: title=Science Briefs: Warming Climate is Changing Life on Global Scale
column2452: publisher=Website of the US National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Goddard Institute for Space Studies
column2454: accessdate=2011-07-08}} </ref>]] Recent warming has strongly affected natural biological systems.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""/> Species worldwide are moving poleward to colder areas. On land, species move to higher elevations, whereas marine species find colder water at greater depths.<ref name="":8"">{{Cite journal
column2478: title=Biodiversity redistribution under climate change: Impacts on ecosystems and human well-being
column2486: pmid=28360268}}</ref> Of the drivers with the biggest global impact on [[nature]], climate change came third over the five decades before 2020, with [[Land development
column2487: change in land use]] and sea use, and direct exploitation of organisms having a larger impact.<ref>{{Cite book
column2489: title=Summary for policymakers of the global assessment report on biodiversity and ecosystem services of the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services.
column2498: display-authors=etal.}}</ref> Significant disruptions of ecosystems are projected to increase with future climate change.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""> {{citation
column2508: chapter-url=http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/vol4/english/026.htm}} </ref> Examples of disruptions include disturbances such as fire, drought, pest [[infestation]], invasion of species, storms, and [[coral bleaching]] events. The stresses caused by climate change, added to other stresses on ecological systems (e.g. land conversion, [[land degradation]], [[harvest]]ing, and [[pollution]]), threaten substantial damage to or complete loss of some unique ecosystems, and [[extinction]] of some critically endangered species.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""/><ref>Van Riper, Charles. (2014) [https://purl.fdlp.gov/GPO/gpo50857 Projecting Climate Effects on Birds and Reptiles of the Southwestern United States.] Reston, Va.: [[United States Department of the Interior
column2509: U.S. Department of the Interior]], [[United States Geological Survey
column2511: interactions between species]] within ecosystems are often disrupted because species from one location do not move to colder habitats at the same rate, giving rise to rapid changes in the functioning of the ecosystem.<ref name="":8"" /> === Terrestrial and wetland systems === Climate change has been estimated to be a major driver of [[biodiversity loss]] in cool [[conifer]] forests, [[savanna]]s, [[mediterranean climate
column2512: mediterranean-climate]] systems, [[tropical forest]]s, and the [[Arctic tundra]].<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""> {{citation
column2514: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch4s4-4-11.html Sec. 4.4.11 Global synthesis including impacts on biodiversity]
column2515: chapter=Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column2520: land-use]] change may be a stronger driver of biodiversity loss, at least in the near-term.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts"" /> Beyond the year 2050, climate change may be the major driver for biodiversity loss globally.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts"" /> Climate change interacts with other pressures such as habitat modification, pollution and [[invasive species]]. Interacting with these pressures, climate change increases extinction risk for a large fraction of terrestrial and freshwater species.<ref>{{Cite book
column2545: chapter=Chapter 4: Terrestrial and Inland Water Systems
column2550: chapter-url=https://archive.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg2/WGIIAR5-Chap4_FINAL.pdf}}</ref> Between 1% and 50% of species in different groups were assessed to be at substantially higher risk of extinction due to climate change.<ref>{{Cite book
column2575: chapter=Chapter 4: Terrestrial and Inland Water Systems
column2580: chapter-url=https://archive.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg2/WGIIAR5-Chap4_FINAL.pdf}}</ref> For increases in global average temperature exceeding 1.5 to 2.5 °C (relative to global temperatures over the years 1980–1999)<ref> {{citation
column2582: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3.html Sec. 3.3 Impacts of future climate changes]
column2583: chapter=Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column2588: 2}} concentrations, projected changes in ecosystems will have predominantly negative consequences for biodiversity and ecosystems goods and [[ecosystem services
column2589: services]], e.g. water and food supply.<ref> {{citation
column2591: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-1.html Sec. 3.3.1 Impacts on systems and sectors: Ecosystems]
column2592: chapter=Section 3: Projected climate change and its impacts
column2596: Effects of climate change on marine mammals}} [[File:Bleached coral (24577819729).jpg
column2598: A part of the [[Great Barrier Reef]] in [[Australia]] in 2016 after a coral bleaching event.]] [[Coral reef
column2599: Warm water coral reefs]] are very sensitive to global warming and [[ocean acidification]].
