Coral reefs provide a [[habitat]] for thousands of species and [[ecosystem services]] such as [[coastal protection]] and food. The resilience of reefs can be improved by curbing local pollution and overfishing: but most warm water coral reefs will disappear even if warming is kept to 1.5 °C.<ref>{{Cite book
column2626: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column2647: first10=F.}}</ref> Coral reefs are not the only [[framework organisms]], organisms that build physical structures that form habitats for other sea creatures affected by climate change: [[mangroves]] and [[seagrass]] are considered to be at moderate risk for lower levels of global warming according to a literature assessment in the [[Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate]].<ref>{{Cite book
column2674: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column2696: Self-reinforcing feedbacks]] amplify and accelerate climate change.<ref>{{cite book
column2720: chapter=Chapter 15: Potential Surprises: Compound Extremes and Tipping Elements
column2728: url-status=live}}</ref> The climate system exhibits ''threshold behaviour'' or [[Tipping points in the climate system
column2729: tipping points]] when these feedbacks lead parts of the Earth system into a new state, such as the runaway loss of ice sheets or the destruction of too many forests.<ref name="":3"">{{cite book
column2753: chapter=Chapter 15: Potential Surprises: Compound Extremes and Tipping Elements
column2762: title=Climate emergency: world 'may have crossed tipping points’
column2767: date=27 November 2019}}</ref> Tipping points are studied using data from [[Paleoclimatology
column2768: Earth's distant past]] and by physical modelling.<ref name="":3"" /> There is already moderate risk of global tipping points at 1 °C above pre-industrial temperatures, and that risk becomes high at 2.5 °C.<ref>{{Cite book
column2795: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column2818: first10=F.}}</ref> Tipping points are ""perhaps the most ‘dangerous’ aspect of future climate changes"", leading to irreversible impacts on society.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2828: title=Stochastic integrated assessment of climate tipping points indicates the need for strict climate policy
column2839: hdl-access=free}}</ref> Many tipping points are interlinked, so that triggering one may lead to a cascade of effects.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2855: title=Climate tipping points — too risky to bet against
column2866: bibcode=2019Natur.575..592L}}</ref> A 2018 study states that 45% of the environmental problems, including those caused by climate change are interconnected and make the risk of a ""domino effect"" bigger.<ref>{{cite journal
column2875: title=Cascading regime shifts within and across scales
column2885: title=Risks of 'domino effect' of tipping points greater than thought, study says
column2889: date=20 December 2018}}</ref> === Amazon rain forest === Rainfall that falls on the [[Amazon rainforest]] is recycled when it [[evaporation
column2890: evaporates]] back into the atmosphere instead of [[surface runoff
column2891: running off]] away from the rainforest. This water is essential for sustaining the rainforest. Due to deforestation the rainforest is losing this ability, exacerbated by climate change which brings more frequent droughts to the area. The higher frequency of droughts seen in the first two decades of the 21st century signal that a tipping point from rainforest to [[savanna]] might be close.<ref>{{cite journal
column2897: title=Amazon tipping point: Last chance for action
column2904: doi-access=free}}</ref> ===Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets=== Future melt of the [[West Antarctic Ice Sheet
column2905: West Antarctic ice sheet]] is potentially abrupt under a high emission scenario, as a consequence of a partial collapse.<ref name="":2"">{{Cite book
column2932: chapter=Chapter 6: Extremes, Abrupt Changes and Managing Risks
column2951: first10=B.}}</ref> Part of the ice sheet is grounded on bedrock below sea level, making it possibly vulnerable to the self-enhancing process of [[marine ice sheet instability]]. A further hypothesis is that ''marine ice cliff instability'' would also contribute to a partial collapse, but limited evidence is available for its importance.<ref>{{Cite book
column2995: first15=G.}}</ref> A partial collapse of the ice sheet would lead to rapid sea level rise and a local decrease in ocean salinity. It would be irreversible on a timescale between decades and millennia.<ref name="":2"" /> In contrast to the West Antarctic ice sheet, melt of the [[Greenland ice sheet]] is projected to be taking place more gradually over millennia.<ref name="":2"" /> Sustained warming between 1 °C (low confidence) and 4 °C (medium confidence) would lead to a complete loss of the ice sheet, contributing 7 m to sea levels globally.<ref>{{Cite book
column3022: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column3043: last10=Isla}}</ref> The ice loss could become irreversible due to a further self-enhancing feedback: the [[elevation-surface mass balance feedback]]. When ice melts on top of the ice sheet, the elevation drops. As air temperature is higher at lower altitude, this promotes further melt.<ref>{{Cite book
column3070: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column3095: This map shows the general location and direction of the warm surface (red) and cold deep water (blue) currents of the [[thermohaline circulation]]. [[Salinity]] is represented by color in units of the Practical Salinity Scale. Low values (blue) are less saline, while high values (orange) are more saline.<ref> {{cite web
column3097: author=Riebeek, H.. design by R. Simmon
column3098: title=Paleoclimatology: Explaining the Evidence: Explaining Rapid Climate Change: Tales from the Ice
column3102: Shutdown of thermohaline circulation}} The [[Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation]] (AMOC). an important component of the Earth's climate system, is a northward flow of warm, salty water in the upper layers of the [[Atlantic ocean
column3103: Atlantic]] and a southward flow of colder water in the deep Atlantic.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""> {{cite book
column3106: title=Abrupt Climate Change. A report by the US Climate Change Science Program (CCSP) and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column3115: date=November 2012}} Potential impacts associated with AMOC changes include reduced warming or (in the case of abrupt change) absolute cooling of northern high-latitude areas near [[Greenland]] and north-western Europe, an increased warming of [[Southern Hemisphere]] high-latitudes, tropical drying, as well as changes to [[marine ecosystem]]s, terrestrial vegetation, oceanic {{chem
column3117: 2}} uptake, oceanic oxygen concentrations, and shifts in fisheries.<ref> {{citation
column3125: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-5-3.html Sec. 19.3.5.3 Possible changes in the North Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (MOC)]
column3126: chapter=Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column3128: display-authors=etal}} </ref> According to a 2019 assessment in the IPCC's [[Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate]] it is very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement) that the strength of the AMOC will decrease further over the course of the 21st century.<ref name="":6"">{{Cite book
column3155: chapter=Chapter 6: Extremes, Abrupt Changes and Managing Risks
column3174: first10=B.}}</ref> Warming is still expected to occur over most of the European region downstream of the [[North Atlantic Current]] in response to increasing GHGs, as well as over [[North America]]. With medium confidence, the IPCC stated that it is very unlikely (less than 10% probability) that the AMOC will collapse in the 21st century.<ref name="":6"" /> The potential consequences of such a collapse could be severe.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change"" />{{Rp
column3176: date=November 2012}} ===Irreversibilities=== ====Warming commitment to {{CO2}} concentrations.==== If emissions of {{CO2}} were to be abruptly stopped and no [[negative emission technologies]] deployed, the Earth's climate would not start moving back to its pre-industrial state. Instead, temperatures would stay elevated at the same level for several centuries. After about a thousand years, 20% to 30% of human-emitted {{CO2}} will remain in the atmosphere, not taken up by the ocean or the land, committing the climate to warming long after emissions have stopped.<ref>{{Cite book
column3203: chapter=Chapter 12: Long-term Climate Change: Projections, Commitments and Irreversibility
column3218: first10=G.}}</ref> Techniques to remove {{CO2}} from the atmosphere, [[carbon dioxide removal]], are a form of [[climate engineering
column3220: reason=Is this saying that reforestation is a form of geoengineering?
column3221: date=February 2020}} Pathways that keep global warming under 1.5 °C rely on large-scale removal of {{CO2}}, which is uncertain and has clear risks.<ref>{{Cite book
column3248: chapter=Chapter 2: Mitigation Pathways Compatible with 1.5°C in the Context of Sustainable Development
column3261: last13=Vilariño}}</ref> ====Irreversible impacts==== There are a number of examples of climate change impacts that may be irreversible, at least over the timescale of many human generations.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""> {{citation
column3269: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-2.html Sec.19.2 Criteria for selecting ‘key’ vulnerabilities: Persistence and reversibility]
column3270: chapter=Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column3272: display-authors=etal}} </ref> These include the large-scale singularities such as the melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, and changes to the AMOC.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In biological systems, the extinction of species would be an irreversible impact.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In social systems, unique [[culture]]s may be lost due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> For example, humans living on [[atoll]] islands face risks due to sea level rise, sea surface warming, and increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.<ref>{{cite journal
column3287: url-status=dead }} This paper was published in 2001 as [http://www.tyndall.ac.uk/sites/default/files/wp9.pdf Tyndall Centre Working Paper 9] {{Webarchive

Epstein, M.D., instructor in medicine at Harvard Medical School; and Ross Gelbspan, Pulitzer Prize–winning journalist and author. Massachusetts School of Law. ** [http://climateprogress.org/2010/02/05/videos-humans-are-changing-the-climate-global-warming-threat-chris-field/#more-18551 ""How we know humans are changing the climate and Why climate change is a clear and present danger""]. Interviews with Christopher Field and [[Michael MacCracken]]. Christopher Field is the director of the Department of Global Ecology at the Carnegie Institution of Washington, professor of biology and environmental earth system science at Stanford University, and the Working Group II Co-Chair for the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Michael MacCracken is the chief scientist for Climate Change Programs at the Climate Institute and a co-author and contributing author for various chapters in the IPCC assessment reports. Climate Progress website, February 5, 2010. *[http://www.businessinsider.com/terrible-effects-of-climate-change-2014-10 25 Devastating Effects Of Climate Change]—''[[Business Insider]]'' (October 11, 2014) {{Global warming}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Effects Of Global Warming}} [[Category:Effects of global warming

column2: Describes the effects created by global warming}} {{For
column3: effects of changes in climate prior to the current period of global warming
column5: small=yes}} [[File:20200118 Global warming and climate change - vertical block diagram - causes effects feedback.png
column9: The primary [[Attribution of recent climate change
column11: NASA: The Causes of Climate Change
column17: p=6}} of global warming and resulting climate change. Some effects constitute [[Climate change feedback
column18: feedback mechanisms]] that intensify climate change and move it toward [[Tipping points in the climate system
column20: NASA: The Study of Earth as an Integrated System
column21: 2016}} ]] The '''effects of climate change''' span the [[physical environment]], [[ecosystems]] and human societies. They also include the economic and social changes which stem from living in a warmer world. Human-caused climate change is one of the threats to [[sustainability]].<ref>{{cite book
column22: title=Perspectives on climate change and sustainability. Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
column32: title=Planetary Boundaries: Exploring the Safe Operating Space for Humanity
column38: doi-access=free}}</ref> Many physical impacts of climate change are already visible, including [[extreme weather]] events, [[Retreat of glaciers since 1850
column39: glacier retreat]],<ref name=""cramer observed effects"">Cramer, W., ''et al.'', Executive summary, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap18_FINAL.pdf Chapter 18: Detection and attribution of observed impacts] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap18_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), pp.982–984, in {{harvnb
column41: 2014}} </ref> changes in the timing of seasonal events (e.g., earlier flowering of plants),<ref>Settele, J., ''et al.'', Section 4.3.2.1: Phenology, in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap4_FINAL.pdf Chapter 4: Terrestrial and inland water systems] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap4_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), p.291, in {{harvnb
column43: 2014}} </ref> [[sea level rise]], and [[Arctic sea ice decline
column44: declines in Arctic sea ice]].<ref> {{Cite book
column47: chapter=Ch 9: Understanding and Attributing Climate Change
column52: 2007}} </ref> The ocean has taken up between 20% and 30% of human-induced [[Carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere
column53: atmospheric carbon dioxide]] since the 1980s, leading to [[ocean acidification]].<ref name=""ReferenceA"">{{Cite book
column56: page=9}}</ref> The ocean is also warming and since 1970 has absorbed more than 90% of the excess heat in the climate system.<ref name=""ReferenceA""/> Climate change has already impacted ecosystems and humans.<ref>{{Cite book
column65: chapter-url=https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/sites/2/2019/05/SR15_SPM_version_report_LR.pdf}}</ref> In combination with [[climate variability]], it makes food insecurity worse in many places<ref name="":1"">{{Cite book
column78: page=3}}</ref> and puts pressure on fresh water supply. This, in combination with extreme weather events, leads to negative effects on [[human health]]. Climate change has also contributed to desertification and land degradation in many regions of the world.<ref>{{Cite book
column81: page=9}}</ref> This has implications for livelihoods as many people are dependent on land for food, feed, fibre, timber and energy.<ref>{{Cite book
column84: page=7}}</ref> Rising temperatures, changing precipitation patterns and the increase in extreme events threaten development because of negative effects on economic growth in developing countries.<ref name="":1"" /> Climate change already contributes to migration in parts of the world.<ref>[https://www.nrdc.org/onearth/climate-change-already-driving-mass-migration-around-globe Climate Change Is Already Driving Mass Migration Around the Globe], Natural Resources Defense Council, 25 January 2019</ref> The future impact of [[global warming
column85: climate change]] depends on the extent to which nations implement [[climate change mitigation
column86: prevention efforts]], reduce [[greenhouse gas emissions]], and [[Climate change adaptation
column87: adapt]] to unavoidable climate change effects.<ref name=""adaptation and mitigation"">Oppenheimer, M., ''et al.'', ''Section 19.7.1: Relationship between Adaptation Efforts, Mitigation Efforts, and Residual Impacts,'' in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf Chapter 19: Emergent risks and key vulnerabilities] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1080–1085, in {{harvnb
column89: 2014}} </ref><ref>Oppenheimer, M., ''et al.'', ''Section 19.6.2.2. The Role of Adaptation and Alternative Development Pathways,'' in: [http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf Chapter 19: Emergent risks and key vulnerabilities] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014746/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-Chap19_FINAL.pdf 20 October 2014]), pp.1072–1073, in {{harvnb
column91: 2014}}</ref> Much of the policy debate concerning [[climate change mitigation]] has been framed by projections for the twenty-first century. The focus on a limited time window obscures some of the problems associated with climate change. Policy decisions made in the next few decades will have profound impacts on the global climate, ecosystems and human societies, not just for this century, but for the next millennia, as near-term climate change policies significantly affect long-term climate change impacts.<ref name=""adaptation and mitigation""/><ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Section A-3. The Decision-making Context, in: [https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.55, in {{harvnb
column117: title=Consequences of twenty-first-century policy for multi-millennial climate and sea-level change
column125: issn=1758-6798}}</ref> Stringent mitigation policies might be able to limit global warming (in 2100) to around 2 [[°C]] or below, relative to pre-industrial levels.<ref>SPM.4.1 Long‐term mitigation pathways, in: {{Cite book
column144: chapter-url=https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/sites/2/2019/05/SR15_SPM_version_report_LR.pdf}}</ref> Without mitigation, increased [[energy demand]] and the extensive use of [[fossil fuel]]s<ref> Clarke, L., ''et al.'', Section 6.3.1.3 Baseline emissions projections from fossil fuels and industry (pp.17–18 of final draft), in: [http://report.mitigation2014.org/drafts/final-draft-postplenary/ipcc_wg3_ar5_final-draft_postplenary_chapter6.pdf Chapter 6: Assessing Transformation Pathways] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141020021617/http://report.mitigation2014.org/drafts/final-draft-postplenary/ipcc_wg3_ar5_final-draft_postplenary_chapter6.pdf 20 October 2014]), in: {{harvnb
column146: 2014}} </ref> may lead to global warming of around 4 °C.<ref> Greenhouse Gas Concentrations and Climate Implications, p.14, in {{harvnb
column149: 2014}}. The range given by Prinn and Reilly is 3.3 to 5.5 °C, with a median of 3.9 °C. </ref><ref>SPM.3 Trends in stocks and flows of greenhouse gases and their drivers, in: [http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf Summary for Policymakers], p.8 (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20140702014732/http://report.mitigation2014.org/spm/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers_approved.pdf 2 July 2014)], in {{harvnb
column151: 2014}}. The range given by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change is 3.7 to 4.8 °C, relative to pre-industrial levels (2.5 to 7.8 °C including climate uncertainty). </ref> With higher magnitudes of global warming, societies and ecosystems will likely encounter limits to how much they can adapt.<ref>Field, C.B., ''et al.'', Box TS.8: Adaptation Limits and Transformation, in: [https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/2018/02/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf Technical summary] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20141018073024/https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WGIIAR5-TS_FINAL.pdf 18 October 2014]), p.89, in {{harvnb
column158: Global surface temperature reconstruction over the last millennia using proxy data from tree rings, corals, and ice cores in blue.<ref name='Neukom2019'>{{Cite journal
column171: title=No evidence for globally coherent warm and cold periods over the preindustrial Common Era
column181: s2cid=198494930}} .</ref> Observational data is from 1880 to 2019.]] Global warming refers to the long-term rise in the average temperature of the Earth's [[climate system]]. It is a major aspect of [[climate change]], and has been demonstrated by the instrumental [[temperature record]] which shows global warming of around 1 °C since the pre-industrial period,<ref name="":10"">{{Cite book
column183: title=WMO statement on the State of the Global Climate in 2018
column196: publisher=Chairperson, Publications Board, World Meteorological Organization
column200: page=6}}</ref> although the bulk of this (0.9 °C) has occurred since 1970.<ref>Even 50-year-old climate models correctly predicted global warming, Science, American Association for the Advancement of Science, 4 December 2019</ref> A wide variety of temperature [[Proxy (climate)
column201: proxies]] together prove that the 20th century was the hottest recorded in the last 2,000 years. Compared to climate variability in the past, current warming is also more globally coherent, affecting 98% of the planet.<ref name='Neukom2019' /><ref>{{Cite web
column203: title=Global extent of climate change is 'unparalleled' in past 2,000 years
column208: access-date=2019-11-24}}</ref> The impact on the environment, ecosystems, the animal kingdom, society and humanity depends on how much more the Earth warms.<ref name=""table of key vulnerabilities""> {{citation
column210: title=Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 2007
column212: chapter=Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column216: 2007}}. </ref> The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) [[IPCC Fifth Assessment Report
column217: Fifth Assessment Report]] concluded, ""It is extremely likely that human influence has been the dominant cause of the observed warming since the mid-20th century.""<ref>IPCC (2013). [https://archive.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg1/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf ""Summary for Policymakers"" (PDF)]. IPCC AR5 WG1 2013.</ref> This has been brought about primarily through the burning of [[fossil fuel]]s which has led to a significant increase in the concentration of GHGs in the atmosphere.<ref> {{citation
column221: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-human-and.html Human and Natural Drivers of Climate Change]
column222: title= Human and Natural Drivers of Climate Change }}, in {{harvnb
column224: 2007}}. </ref> ===Emission scenarios=== Individual consumers, corporate decision makers, the fossil fuel industries, government responses and the extent to which different countries agree to cooperate all have a profound impact on how much greenhouse gases the worlds emits. As the crisis and modelling techniques have evolved, the IPCC and other climate scientists have tried a number of different tools to estimate likely greenhouse gas emissions in the future. Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) were based on possible differences in [[radiative forcing]] occurring in the next 100 years but do not include socioeconomic ""narratives"" to go alongside them.<ref>[https://www.carbonbrief.org/explainer-how-shared-socioeconomic-pathways-explore-future-climate-change Explainer: How 'Shared Socioeconomic Pathways' explore future climate change], Carbon Brief, 19 April 2018</ref> Another group of [[Climatology
column226: energy system modellers]] took a different approach known as [[Shared Socioeconomic Pathways]] (SSPs); this is based on how socioeconomic factors such as [[Population growth
column228: urbanisation]] and the rate of technological development might change over the next century. The SSPs describe five different trajectories which describe future climactic developments in the absence of new environmental policies beyond those in place today. They also explore the implications of different climate change mitigation scenarios.<ref>{{cite journal
column231: title=The Shared Socioeconomic Pathways and their energy, land use, and greenhouse gas emissions implications: An overview
column327: doi-access = free }}</ref> === Warming projections === [[File:Projected Change in Temperatures by 2090.svg
column332: CMIP5]] average of climate model projections for 2081–2100 relative to 1986–2005, under low and high emission scenarios]] The range in temperature projections partly reflects the choice of [[economics of global warming#Emissions scenarios
column333: emissions scenario]], and the degree of ""[[climate sensitivity]]"".<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum"" /> The projected magnitude of warming by 2100 is closely related to the level of cumulative emissions over the 21st century (i.e. total emissions between 2000 and 2100).<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions""> {{citation
column335: title=The Emissions Gap Report: Are the Copenhagen Accord pledges sufficient to limit global warming to {{val
column342: chapter=Ch 2: Which emissions pathways are consistent with a {{val
column346: u=°C}} temperature limit?: Sec 2.2 What determines long-term temperature?
column350: url-status=dead}}, p.28. This publication is also available in [http://www.unep.org/publications/ebooks/emissionsgapreport/ e-book format] {{webarchive
column352: date=2010-11-25}} </ref> The higher the cumulative emissions over this time period, the greater the level of warming is projected to occur.<ref name=""unep cumulative emissions"" /> [[Climate sensitivity]] reflects uncertainty in the response of the climate system to past and future GHG emissions.<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum"" /> Higher estimates of climate sensitivity lead to greater projected warming, while lower estimates lead to less projected warming.<ref> {{citation
column357: chapter=Box 8.1 Likelihood of exceeding a temperature increase at equilibrium, in: Ch 8: The Challenge of Stabilisation
column359: IPCC's Fifth Report]], states that relative to the average from year 1850 to 1900, global surface temperature change by the end of the 21st century is likely to exceed 1.5 °C and may well exceed 2 °C for all [[Representative Concentration Pathway
column360: RCP scenarios]] except RCP2.6. It is likely to exceed 2 °C for RCP6.0 and RCP8.5, and more likely than not to exceed 2 °C for RCP4.5. The pathway with the highest greenhouse gas emissions, RCP8.5, will lead to a temperature increase of about 4.3˚C by 2100.<ref>RCP 8.5: Business-as-usual or a worst-case scenario, Climate Nexus, retrieved from https://climatenexus.org/climate-change-news/rcp-8-5-business-as-usual-or-a-worst-case-scenario/</ref> Warming will continue beyond 2100 under all RCP scenarios except RCP2.6.<ref name="":11"">IPCC, 2013: [https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/2018/02/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf Summary for Policymakers.] In: Climate Change 2013: The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of Working Group I to the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change p.20</ref> Even if emissions were drastically reduced overnight, the warming process is irreversible because {{CO2}} takes hundreds of years to break down, and global temperatures will remain close to their highest level for at least the next 1,000 years.<ref name=""solomon irreversible climate change""> {{cite journal
column364: title=Irreversible climate change due to carbon dioxide emissions
column365: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
column378: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-7-2.html Sec 10.7.2 Climate Change Commitment to Year 3000 and Beyond to Equilibrium]
column380: display-authors=etal}} </ref> Mitigation policies currently in place will result in about 2.9 °C warming above pre-industrial levels. If all unconditional pledges and targets already made by governments will be achieved the temperature will rise by 2.4 °C. If all the 131 countries that actually adopted or only consider to adopt net - zero target will achieve it the temperature will rise by 2.0 °C. However, if current plans are not actually implemented, global warming is expected to reach 4.1 °C to 4.8 °C by 2100. There is a substantial gap between national plans and commitments and actual actions so far taken by governments around the world.<ref>[https://climateactiontracker.org/global/temperatures/ Temperatures], Climate Action Tracker</ref> According to the [[World Meteorological Organization]] report from 2021, there is a 44% chance that the global temperature will temporarily pass the 1.5 limit already in the years 2021 - 2026.<ref>{{cite news
column383: title=Earth Is Barreling Toward 1.5 Degrees Celsius Of Warming, Scientists Warn
column387: date=26 May 2021}}</ref> ===Warming in context of Earth's past=== One of the methods scientists use to predict the effects of human-caused climate change, is to investigate past natural changes in climate.<ref>{{Cite web
column389: title=To Predict Effects Of Global Warming, Scientists Looked Back 20,000 Years
column394: access-date=2019-12-29}}</ref> Scientists have used various ""proxy"" data to assess changes in Earth's past climate or [[paleoclimate]].<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""> {{citation
column396: title=NOAA Paleoclimatology Global Warming – The Story: Proxy Data
column399: publisher=NOAA Paleoclimatology Program – NCDC Paleoclimatology Branch }} </ref> Sources of proxy data include historical records such as [[tree rings]], [[ice core]]s, [[coral]]s, and ocean and lake [[sediment]]s.<ref name=""noaa proxy climate data""/> The data shows that recent warming has surpassed anything in the last 2,000 years.<ref name=""phys.org"">[https://phys.org/news/2019-07-20th-century-hottest-years.html The 20th century was the hottest in nearly 2,000 years, studies show], 25 July 2019</ref> By the end of the 21st century, temperatures may increase to a level not experienced since the mid-[[Pliocene]], around 3 million years ago.<ref name=""jansen pliocene""> {{cite book
column436: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch6s6-3-2.html Sec. 6.3.2 What Does the Record of the Mid-Pliocene Show?]
column438: chapter-url=http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch6.html}} </ref> At that time, mean global temperatures were about 2–4 °C warmer than pre-industrial temperatures, and the global mean sea level was up to 25 meters higher than it is today.<ref>{{Cite book
column462: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column480: Physical impacts of climate change}} {{Multiple image
column483: image1=Diagram showing ten indicators of global warming.png
column485: image2=Changes in climate indicators that show global warming.png
column489: caption2=Changes in climate indicators over several decades. Each of the different colored lines in each panel represents an independently analyzed set of data. The data come from many different technologies including [[weather station]]s, [[satellite]]s, [[weather balloons]], [[ship]]s and [[buoy]]s.<ref>{{harvnb
column492: p=3}}</ref> }} A broad range of evidence shows that the climate system has warmed.<ref> {{citation
column500: 2007}}. </ref> Evidence of global warming is shown in the graphs (below right) from the US [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] (NOAA). Some of the graphs show a positive [[trend estimation
column501: trend]], e.g., increasing temperature over land and the ocean, and [[current sea level rise
column502: sea level rise]]. Other graphs show a negative trend, such as decreased [[snow]] cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]], and declining [[Arctic sea ice]], both of which are indicative of global warming. Evidence of warming is also [[Effects of global warming#Observed impacts on biological systems
column503: apparent in living (biological) systems]] such as changes in distribution of [[flora]] and [[fauna]] towards the poles.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts""> {{citation
column507: chapter=Chapter 1: Assessment of Observed Changes and Responses in Natural and Managed Systems
column509: display-authors=etal}} </ref> Human-induced warming could lead to large-scale, abrupt and/or [[Irreversible effects of global warming
column514: at= [http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms3.html Sec. 3. Projected climate change and its impacts] }}, in {{harvnb
column517: title=ESRL News: New Study Shows Climate Change Largely Irreversible
column520: publisher=US Department of Commerce, NOAA, Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL)
column521: date=26 January 2009 }}</ref> An example of this is the melting of [[ice sheet]]s, which contributes to sea level rise and will continue for thousands of years.<ref name=""magnitudes of impact""> {{Cite book
column545: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column559: last14=Meyssignac}} </ref> The probability of warming having unforeseen consequences increases with the rate, magnitude, and duration of climate change.<ref> {{cite book
column564: publisher=[[United States National Academy of Sciences]]
column570: Tropical cyclone#Global warming}} Global warming leads to an increase in extreme weather events such as heat waves, droughts, cyclones, blizzards and rainstorms.<ref name="":12"" /> Such events will continue to occur more often and with greater intensity.<ref>[https://www.livescience.com/37057-global-warming-effects.html Effects of Global Warming], Live Science, 12 August 2017</ref> Scientists have not only determined that climate change is responsible for trends in weather patterns, some individual extreme weather events have also directly be attributed to climate change.<ref>[https://www.ucsusa.org/sites/default/files/attach/2018/06/The-Science-Connecting-Extreme-Weather-to-Climate-Change.pdf The science connecting extreme weather to climate change], Fact sheet: Union of Concerned Scientists, June 2018.</ref> ==== Precipitation ==== Higher temperatures lead to increased evaporation and surface drying. As the air warms, its water-holding capacity also increases, particularly over the oceans. In general the air can hold about 7% more moisture for every 1 °C of temperature rise.<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum""> {{cite book
column571: title=Global Climate Change Impacts in the United States
column577: chapter-url=http://downloads.globalchange.gov/usimpacts/pdfs/climate-impacts-report.pdf}}</ref> In the tropics, there's more than a 10% increase in precipitation for a 1 °C increase in temperature.<ref>Global warming is increasing rainfall rates, ''The Guardian'', 22 March 2017</ref> Changes have already been observed in the amount, intensity, frequency, and type of [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column578: precipitation]]. Widespread increases in heavy precipitation have occurred even in places where total rain amounts have decreased.<ref> {{citation
column584: chapter-url=https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B1gFp6Ioo3akYklZcWkwWHJud00/edit?pli=1}} </ref> Projections of future changes in precipitation show overall increases in the global average, but with substantial shifts in where and how precipitation falls.<ref name=""USGCRP exec sum"" /> Projections suggest a reduction in rainfall in the [[subtropics]], and an increase in precipitation in subpolar latitudes and some [[equatorial region]]s. In other words, regions which are dry at present will in general become even drier, while regions that are currently wet will in general become even wetter.<ref name=""gfdl rainfall projections""> {{citation
column586: title=Will the wet get wetter and the dry drier?
column593: publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory}}. Revision 10/15/2008, 4:47:16 PM. {{dead link
column594: date=February 2021}}</ref> Although increased rainfall will not occur everywhere, models suggest most of the world will have a 16–24% increase in heavy precipitation intensity by 2100.<ref>{{Cite web
column598: title=Explainer: What climate models tell us about future rainfall
column601: website=Carbon Brief}}</ref> ==== Temperatures ==== As described in the first section, global temperatures have risen by 1 °C and are expected to rise further in the future.<ref name="":10"" /><ref name="":11"" /> Over most land areas since the 1950s, it is very likely that at all times of year both days and nights have become warmer due to human activities.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes""> IPCC (2013), Table SPM.1, in [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf Summary for Policymakers, p. 5] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140226155600/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column603: 2013}} </ref> Night-time temperatures have increased a faster rate than daytime temperatures.<ref>{{Cite journal
column615: title=Diurnal asymmetry to the observed global warming
column623: doi-access=free}}</ref> In the U.S. since 1999, two warm weather records have been set or broken for every cold one.<ref name=""2019-03-19-gu"">{{cite web
column625: title=Record high US temperatures outpace record lows two to one, study finds
column630: title=The ratio of warm and cold temperature records is increasingly skewed - Axios
column636: access-date=2019-03-19}}</ref> Future climate change will include more very hot days and fewer very cold days.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes"" /> The frequency, length and intensity of [[heat wave]]s will very likely increase over most land areas.<ref name=""ar5 wg1 climate extremes"" /> Higher growth in anthropogenic GHG emissions would cause more frequent and severe temperature extremes.<ref>Stocker, T.F., ''et al.'' (2013), Temperature Extremes, Heat Waves and Warm Spells, in: TFE.9, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf Technical Summary, p. 111] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221070705/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_TS_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column638: 2013}} </ref> ==== Heat waves ==== [[Global warming]] boosts the probability of [[extreme weather]] events such as [[heat wave]]s<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/11/science/earth/global-warming-makes-heat-waves-more-likely-study-finds.html ''Global Warming Makes Heat Waves More Likely, Study Finds''] 10 July 2012 [[The New York Times]]</ref><ref>{{cite journal
column643: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
column654: bibcode=2012PNAS..109E2415H }}</ref> where the daily maximum temperature exceeds the average maximum temperature by 5 °C (9 °F) for more than five consecutive days.<ref>[https://www.britannica.com/science/heat-wave-meteorology Heat wave: meteorology]. Encyclopedia Britannica. Retrieved 1 April 2019.</ref> In the last 30–40 years, heat waves with high humidity have become more frequent and severe. Extremely hot nights have doubled in frequency. The area in which extremely hot summers are observed has increased 50–100 fold. These changes are not explained by natural variability, and are attributed by climate scientists to the influence of [[wikt:anthropogenic
column655: anthropogenic]] climate change. Heat waves with high humidity pose a big risk to human health while heat waves with low humidity lead to dry conditions that increase [[wildfires]]. The mortality from extreme heat is larger than the mortality from hurricanes, lightning, tornadoes, floods, and earthquakes together.<ref name=""Heat Waves: The Details"">{{cite web
column659: access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref> ==== Tropical cyclones ==== Global warming not only causes changes in tropical cyclones, it may also make some impacts from them worse via sea level rise. The intensity of tropical cyclones (hurricanes, typhoons, etc.) is projected to increase globally, with the proportion of [[Saffir–Simpson scale
column660: Category 4 and 5]] tropical cyclones increasing. Furthermore, the rate of rainfall is projected to increase, but trends in the future frequency on a global scale are not yet clear.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones"">Christensen, J.H.,''et al.'' (2013), Cyclones, in: Executive Summary, in: [http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf Chapter 14: Climate Phenomena and their Relevance for Future Regional Climate Change, p. 1220] [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221075046/http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_Chapter14_FINAL.pdf (archived PDF)], in {{harvnb
column663: chapter= Chapter 6: Extremes, Abrupt Changes and Managing Risks
column682: page= 592 }}</ref> Changes in tropical cyclones will probably vary by region.<ref name=""christensen 2013 cyclones"" /> === On land === {{Further
column683: Special Report on Climate Change and Land}} In the year 2019 the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] issued a [[Special Report on Climate Change and Land]]. The main statements of the report include: * Humans affect 70% of the ice free land, that play a key role in supplying the needs of humans and in the climate system. * The global food supply have raised what increased [[GHG emission]], but 25% - 30% of the food is lost, 2 billion adults suffer from being [[overweight]] while 821 million people suffer from [[hunger]]. * The rate of [[soil erosion]] is 10 - 20 times higher than the rate of soil accumulation in agricultural areas that use [[no-till farming]]. In areas with [[Tilling (agriculture)
column684: tilling]] it is 100 times higher. Climate Change increases land degradation and desertification. * In the years 1960 - 2013 the area of drylands in drought, increased by 1% per year. * In the year 2015 around 500 million people lived in areas that was impacted by [[desertification]] in the years 1980s - 2000s. * People who live in the areas affected by land degradation and desertification are ""increasingly negatively affected by climate change"". {{Harvnb
column690: p=7,8}} Climate change will also cause soils to warm. In turn, this could cause the [[Soil microbiology
column691: soil microbe]] population size to dramatically increase 40–150%. Warmer conditions would favor growth of certain bacteria species, shifting the bacterial community composition. Elevated carbon dioxide would increase the growth rates of plants and soil microbes, slowing the soil [[carbon cycle]] and favoring [[oligotroph]]s, which are slower-growing and more resource efficient than [[copiotroph]]s.<ref>{{cite journal
column694: title=Soil Microbiomes Under Climate Change and Implications for Carbon Cycling
column714: journal=Annual Review of Environment and Resources
column716: pages=29–59}}</ref> ==== Flooding ==== [[File:4207Typhoons Krosa Lekima & monsoon tidal flooding in Calumpit, Bulacan 19.jpg
column719: High tides]] flooding is increasing due to sea level rise, land subsidence, and the loss of natural barriers.<ref>{{Cite web
column725: website=oceanservice.noaa.gov}}</ref>]] Warmer air holds more water vapor. When this turns to rain, it tends to come in heavy downpours potentially leading to more floods. A 2017 study found that peak precipitation is increasing between 5 and 10% for every one degree Celsius increase.<ref>[https://www.nature.com/articles/nclimate3239 The peak structure and future changes of the relationships between extreme precipitation and temperature], [[Nature Climate Change]] volume 7, pp 268–274 (2017)</ref> In the United States and many other parts of the world there has been a marked increase in intense rainfall events which have resulted in more severe flooding.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2017/mar/22/global-warming-is-increasing-rainfall-rates Global warming is increasing rainfall rates], ''The Guardian'', 22 March 2017</ref> Estimates of the number of people at risk of [[coastal flooding]] from climate-driven sea-level rise varies from 190 million,<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-50236882 Climate change: Sea level rise to affect 'three times more people'], BBC News, 30 October 2019</ref> to 300 million or even 640 million in a worst-case scenario related to the instability of the Antarctic ice sheet.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/oct/29/rising-sea-levels-pose-threat-to-homes-of-300m-people-study Rising sea levels pose threat to homes of 300m people – study], ''The Guardian'', 29 October 2019</ref><ref>{{Cite journal
column731: title=New elevation data triple estimates of global vulnerability to sea-level rise and coastal flooding
column742: issn=2041-1723}}</ref> the Greenland ice sheet is estimated to have reached a point of no return, continuing to melt even if warming stopped. Over time that would submerge many of the world's coastal cities including low-lying islands, especially combined with storm surges and high tides.<ref>{{Cite web
column743: title='A Climate Emergency Unfolding Before Our Eyes.' Arctic Sea Ice Has Shrunk to Almost Historic Levels
column747: Desertification}} Climate change affects multiple factors associated with [[drought]]s, such as how much rain falls and how fast the rain [[Evaporation
column748: evaporates]] again. It is set to increase the severity and frequency of droughts around much of the world.<ref>{{Cite journal
column756: title=Climate Change and Drought: From Past to Future
column763: issn=2198-6061}}</ref> Due to limitations on how much data is available about drought in the past, it is often impossible to confidently [[Attribution of recent climate change
column764: attribute]] droughts to human-induced climate change. Some areas however, such as the [[Mediterranean Sea
column765: Mediterranean]] and [[California]], already show a clear human signature.<ref>{{Cite journal
column773: title=Climate Change and Drought: a Perspective on Drought Indices
column780: issn=2198-6061}}</ref> Their impacts are aggravated because of increased water demand, population growth, urban expansion, and environmental protection efforts in many areas.<ref>{{Cite journal
column792: doi=10.1016/j.jhydrol.2011.03.049}}</ref> ==== Wildfires ==== [[File:Wildfire in the Pacific Northwest (8776249150).jpg
column794: Warm and dry temperatures driven by climate change increase the chance of wildfires.<ref>{{Cite web
column796: title=Media reaction: Australia's bushfires and climate change
column799: website=Carbon Brief}}</ref>]] Prolonged periods of warmer temperatures typically cause soil and [[underbrush]] to be drier for longer periods, increasing the risk of wildfires. Hot, dry conditions increase the likelihood that wildfires will be more intense and burn for longer once they start.<ref>[https://www.ucsusa.org/resources/global-warming-fueling-increased-wildfire-risks Is Global Warming Fueling Increased Wildfire Risks?] Union of Concerned Scientists, 24 July 2018</ref> In [[California]], summer air temperature have increased by over 3.5 °F such that the fire season has lengthened by 75 days over previous decades. As a result, since the 1980s, both the size and ferocity of fires in California have increased. Since the 1970s, the size of the area burned has increased fivefold.<ref>{{Cite web
column803: title=Climate change is contributing to California's fires
column806: website=National Geographic}}</ref> In [[Australia]], the annual number of hot days (above 35 °C) and very hot days (above 40 °C) has increased significantly in many areas of the country since 1950. The country has always had [[bushfires]] but in 2019, the extent and ferocity of these fires increased dramatically.<ref>[https://time.com/5735660/sydney-bushfires/ As Smoke From Bushfires Chokes Sydney, Australian Prime Minister Dodges on Climate Change], Time 21 November 2019.</ref> For the first time catastrophic bushfire conditions were declared for Greater Sydney. New South Wales and Queensland declared a state of emergency but fires were also burning in South Australia and Western Australia.<ref>[https://www.climatecouncil.org.au/not-normal-climate-change-bushfire-web/ The facts about bushfires and climate change], Climate Council, 13 November 2019</ref> ===Cryosphere=== {{See also
column807: Retreat of glaciers since 1850}} [[File:20210125 The Cryosphere - Floating and grounded ice - imbalance - climate change.png
column810: Earth lost 28 trillion tonnes of ice between 1994 and 2017, with melting grounded ice (ice sheets and glaciers) raising the global sea level by 34.6 ±3.1 mm.<ref name=Cryosphere_20210125/> The rate of ice loss has risen by 57% since the 1990s−from 0.8 to 1.2 trillion tonnes per year.<ref name=Cryosphere_20210125>{{cite journal
column844: A map that shows ice concentration on 16 September 2012, along with the extent of the previous record low (yellow line) and the mid-September median extent (black line) setting a new record low that was 18 percent smaller than the previous record and nearly 50 percent smaller than the long-term (1979–2000) average.]] The [[cryosphere]] is made up of those parts of the planet which are so cold, they are frozen and covered by snow or ice. This includes ice and snow on land such as the continental ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica, as well as glaciers and areas of snow and permafrost; and ice found on water including frozen parts of the ocean, such as the waters surrounding Antarctica and the Arctic.<ref>[https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/cryosphere.html What is the cryosphere?] National ocean Service</ref> The cryosphere, especially the polar regions, is extremely sensitive to changes in global climate.<ref>[https://serc.carleton.edu/eslabs/cryosphere/1c.html Getting to Know the Cryosphere], Earth Labs</ref> The [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] issued a [[Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate]]. According to the report climate change caused a massive melting of glaciers, ice sheets, snow and permafrost with generally negative effects on ecosystems and humans. Indigenous knowledge helped to adapt to those effects.<ref name=""SROCC_SPM_20190925"">{{Cite report
column845: series=Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate (SROCC)
column850: url = https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/sites/3/2019/09/SROCC_SPM_HeadlineStatements.pdf }}</ref> Arctic sea ice began to decline at the beginning of the twentieth century but the rate is accelerating. Since 1979, satellite records indicate the decline in summer sea ice coverage has been about 13% per decade.<ref>[https://www.carbonbrief.org/impacts-of-a-melting-cryosphere-ice-loss-around-the-world Impacts of a melting cryosphere  ice loss around the world], Carbon Brief, 9 June 2011</ref><ref>{{citation
column858: 2012}}</ref> The thickness of sea ice has also decreased by 66% or 2.0 m over the last six decades with a shift from permanent ice to largely seasonal ice cover.<ref>{{Cite journal
column862: title=Arctic sea ice thickness, volume, and multiyear ice coverage: losses and coupled variability (1958–2018)
column869: doi-access=free}}</ref> While ice-free summers are expected to be rare at 1.5 °C degrees of warming, they are set to occur at least once every decade at a warming level of 2.0 °C.<ref>{{Cite book
column878: chapter-url=https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/sites/2/2019/05/SR15_SPM_version_report_LR.pdf}}</ref> Since the beginning of the twentieth century, there has also been a widespread retreat of [[alpine glaciers]],<ref>{{citation
column879: title=Mass Balance of Mountain Glaciers in 2011
column886: 2012}}</ref> and snow cover in the [[Northern Hemisphere]].<ref>{{citation
column887: title=2011 Snow Cover in Northern Hemisphere
column894: 2012}}</ref> During the 21st century, glaciers and [[snow cover]] are projected to continue their retreat in almost all regions.<ref>{{Cite book
column930: editor-last10=Okem}}</ref> The melting of the [[Greenland ice sheet
column931: Greenland]] and [[West Antarctic ice sheet]]s will continue to contribute to sea level rise over long time-scales.<ref>{{Cite book
column955: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column976: Effects of global warming on oceans}} [[File:Heat content700m2000myr.png
column980: Global ocean heat content from 1955 to 2019]] Global warming is projected to have a number of effects on the [[ocean]]s. Ongoing effects include [[Sea level rise
column981: rising sea levels]] due to thermal expansion and melting of glaciers and ice sheets, and warming of the ocean surface, leading to increased temperature stratification.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite book
column1005: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column1028: last14=Suga}} </ref> Other possible effects include large-scale changes in ocean circulation. The oceans also serve as a sink for carbon dioxide, taking up much that would otherwise remain in the atmosphere, but increased levels of {{chem
column1030: 2}} have led to [[ocean acidification]]. Furthermore, as the temperature of the oceans increases, they become less able to absorb excess {{chem
column1032: 2}}. The oceans have also acted as a sink in absorbing extra heat from the atmosphere.<ref name=""statecl"">{{cite book
column1034: publisher = Website of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration: National Climatic Data Center
column1035: title = State of the Climate in 2009, as appearing in the July 2010 issue (Vol. 91) of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society (BAMS). Supplemental and Summary Materials: Report at a Glance: Highlights
column1039: archive-date=2011-02-22 <!-- archive to PDF replaces stale link: http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/bams-state-of-the-climate/2009.php -->
column1042: date=November 2012}} According to a [[Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate]] published by the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]], climate change has different impacts on the oceans, including an increase in [[marine heatwave]]s, shift in species distribution, [[ocean deoxygenation]].<ref name=""SROCC_SPM_20190925""/> The decline in mixing of the ocean layers piles up warm water near the surface while reducing cold, deep water circulation. The reduced up and down mixing enhanced global warming. Furthermore, energy available for tropical cyclones and other storms is expected to increase, [[nutrient]]s for fish in the upper ocean layers are set to decrease, as well as the capacity of the oceans to [[Carbon sink
column1047: title=Mixing of the planet's ocean waters is slowing down, speeding up global warming, study finds
column1051: issn=0190-8286}}</ref> ==== Sea Ice ==== Sea ice reflects 50% to 70% of the incoming solar radiation, while 6% of the incoming solar engery is reflected by the ocean. With less solar energy, the sea ice absorbs and holds the surface colder, which can be a positive feedback toward climate change.<ref>{{Cite web
column1052: title=Thermodynamics: Albedo {{!}} National Snow and Ice Data Center
column1056: Ocean deoxygenation}} Warmer water cannot contain as much oxygen as cold water, so heating is expected to lead to less oxygen in the ocean. Other processes also play a role: stratification may lead to increases in respiration rates of organic matter, further decreasing oxygen content. The ocean has already lost oxygen, throughout the entire water column and [[oxygen minimum zone]]s are expanding worldwide.<ref name="":0"" /> This has adverse consequences for ocean life.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1064: title = Abrupt Climate Change and Extinction Events in Earth History
column1084: title = Long-term ocean oxygen depletion in response to carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels
column1086: bibcode = 2009NatGe...2..105S }}</ref> ====Ocean heat uptake==== Oceans have taken up over 90% of the excess heat accumulated on Earth due to global warming.<ref>{{Cite book
column1110: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column1130: last10=Levin}}</ref> The warming rate varies with depth: at a depth of a thousand metres the warming occurs at a rate of almost 0.4 °C per century (data from 1981 to 2019), whereas the warming rate at two kilometres depth is only half.<ref>{{Cite book
column1154: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column1174: last10=Levin}}</ref> The increase in ocean [[heat content]] is much larger than any other store of [[energy]] in the Earth's heat balance and accounts for more than 90% of the increase in heat content of the Earth system, and has accelerated in the 1993–2017 period compared to 1969–1993.<ref>{{Cite book
column1194: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column1196: chapter-url=https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/sites/3/2019/11/09_SROCC_Ch05_FINAL.pdf}}</ref> In 2019 a paper published in the journal [[Science (journal)
column1197: Science]] found the oceans are heating 40% faster than the IPCC predicted just five years before.<ref>{{cite news
column1201: title=New Climate Change Report Says Ocean Warming Is Far Worse Than Expected
column1214: title=How fast are the oceans warming?
column1224: access-date=11 January 2019}}</ref> As well as having effects on ecosystems (e.g. by melting sea ice affecting [[algae]] that grow on its underside), warming reduces the ocean's ability to absorb {{chem
column1234: title=Sensitivities of marine carbon fluxes to ocean change
column1242: doi-access=free}}</ref> It is likely that the oceans warmed faster between 1993 and 2017 compared to the period starting in 1969.<ref>{{Cite book
column1266: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column1291: Historical sea level reconstruction and projections up to 2100 published in January 2017 by the [[U.S. Global Change Research Program]]]] The IPCC's [[Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate
column1292: Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere]] concluded that global mean sea level rose by 0.16 metres between 1901 and 2016.<ref>{{Cite book
column1301: chapter-url=https://report.ipcc.ch/srocc/pdf/SROCC_SPM_Approved.pdf}}</ref> The rate of sea level rise since the industrial revolution in the 19th century has been larger than the rate during the previous two thousand years.<ref>IPCC AR% [https://ar5-syr.ipcc.ch/topic_summary.php Summary for Policy Makers]</ref> Global sea level rise is accelerating, rising 2.5 times faster between 2006 and 2016 than it did during the 20th century.<ref>The Oceans We Know Won't Survive Climate Change, The Atlantic, 25 September 2019</ref><ref>{{Cite book
column1325: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column1345: last18=Pereira}}</ref> Two main factors contribute to the rise. The first is [[thermal expansion]]: as ocean water warms, it expands. The second is from the melting of land-based ice in glaciers and ice sheets due to global warming.<ref>{{Cite book
column1369: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column1389: last18=Pereira}}</ref> Prior to 2007, thermal expansion was the largest component in these projections, contributing 70–75% of sea level rise.<ref> {{citation
column1397: display-authors=etal}}. </ref> As the impact of global warming has accelerated, melting from glaciers and ice sheets has become the main contributor.<ref>{{Cite book
column1421: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column1441: last10=Isla}}</ref> Even if emission of greenhouse gases stops overnight, sea level rise will continue for centuries to come.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1451: title=Committed sea-level rise under the Paris Agreement and the legacy of delayed mitigation action
column1461: doi-access=free}}</ref> In 2015, a study by Professor James Hansen of Columbia University and 16 other climate scientists said a sea level rise of three metres could be a reality by the end of the century.<ref>[https://www.tvnz.co.nz/one-news/new-zealand/simulation-shows-unavoidable-3m-auckland-sea-level-rise-q02974 Simulation shows 'unavoidable' 3m Auckland sea level rise]. TVNZ 25 July 2015.</ref> Another study by scientists at the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute in 2017 using updated projections of Antarctic mass loss and a revised statistical method also concluded that, although it was a low probability, a three-metre rise was possible.<ref>[https://phys.org/news/2017-04-sea-metres.html Sea levels could rise by more than three metres, shows new study], PhysOrg, 26 April 2017 </ref> Rising sea levels will put hundreds of millions of people at risk in low-lying coastal areas in countries such as China, Bangladesh, India and Vietnam.<ref>{{Cite news
column1463: title=Sea level rise to affect 'three times more people'
column1467: access-date=2019-11-26}}</ref> ==Wildlife and nature== [[File:A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming (low-res).png
column1471: A vast array of physical and biological systems across the Earth are being affected by human-induced global warming.<ref name=""nasa briefs""> {{cite web
column1474: title=Science Briefs: Warming Climate is Changing Life on Global Scale
column1477: publisher=Website of the US National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Goddard Institute for Space Studies}} </ref>]]{{Main
column1482: }} Recent warming has strongly affected natural biological systems.<ref name=""rosenzweig observed impacts"" /> Species worldwide are moving poleward to colder areas. On land, species move to higher elevations, whereas marine species find colder water at greater depths.<ref name="":8"">{{Cite journal
column1506: title=Biodiversity redistribution under climate change: Impacts on ecosystems and human well-being
column1515: s2cid=206653576}}</ref> Of the drivers with the biggest global impact on [[nature]], climate change ranks third over the five decades before 2020, with only [[Land development
column1516: change in land use]] and sea use, and direct exploitation of organisms having a greater impact.<ref>{{Cite book
column1520: title=Summary for policymakers of the global assessment report on biodiversity and ecosystem services of the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services.
column1525: display-authors=etal.}}</ref> The impacts of climate change in nature and nature's contributions to humans are projected to become more pronounced in the next few decades.<ref>{{Cite book
column1529: title=Summary for policymakers of the global assessment report on biodiversity and ecosystem services of the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services.
column1534: display-authors=etal.}}</ref> Examples of climatic disruptions include fire, drought, pest [[infestation]], invasion of species, storms, and [[coral bleaching]] events. The stresses caused by climate change, added to other stresses on ecological systems (e.g. land conversion, [[land degradation]], [[harvest]]ing, and [[pollution]]), threaten substantial damage to or complete loss of some unique ecosystems, and [[extinction]] of some critically endangered species.<ref name=""tar synthesis ecosystems""> {{citation
column1541: chapter-url=http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/vol4/english/026.htm}} </ref><ref>Van Riper, Charles. (2014) [https://purl.fdlp.gov/GPO/gpo50857 Projecting Climate Effects on Birds and Reptiles of the Southwestern United States.] Reston, Va.: [[United States Department of the Interior
column1542: U.S. Department of the Interior]], [[United States Geological Survey
column1544: interactions between species]] within ecosystems are often disrupted because species from one location do not move to colder habitats at the same rate, giving rise to rapid changes in the functioning of the ecosystem.<ref name="":8"" /> [[File:Лежка моржей на острове Нортбрук.jpg
column1546: The Arctic is heating up twice as fast as the global mean. Seas are on track to rise one to four feet higher by 2100, threatening coastal habitats.<ref name=""February 23"">{{Cite web
column1550: title=Global Climate Change: What You Need to Know
column1556: Effects of climate change on terrestrial animals
column1557: Effect of climate change on plant biodiversity}} Climate change has been estimated to be a major driver of [[biodiversity loss]] in cool [[conifer]] forests, [[savanna]]s, [[mediterranean climate
column1558: mediterranean-climate]] systems, [[tropical forest]]s, and the [[Arctic tundra]].<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts""> {{citation
column1560: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch4s4-4-11.html Sec. 4.4.11 Global synthesis including impacts on biodiversity]
column1561: chapter=Chapter 4: Ecosystems, their properties, goods and services
column1566: land-use]] change may be a stronger driver of biodiversity loss, at least in the near-term.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts"" /> Beyond the year 2050, climate change may be the major driver for biodiversity loss globally.<ref name=""global ecosystem impacts"" /> Climate change interacts with other pressures such as habitat modification, pollution and [[invasive species]]. Interacting with these pressures, climate change increases extinction risk for a large fraction of terrestrial and freshwater species.<ref>{{Cite book
column1588: chapter=Chapter 4: Terrestrial and Inland Water Systems
column1593: chapter-url=https://archive.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg2/WGIIAR5-Chap4_FINAL.pdf}}</ref> Between 1% and 50% of species in different groups were assessed to be at substantially higher risk of extinction due to climate change.<ref>{{Cite book
column1615: chapter=Chapter 4: Terrestrial and Inland Water Systems
column1621: Effects of climate change on marine mammals}} [[File:Bleached coral (24577819729).jpg
column1623: A part of the [[Great Barrier Reef]] in [[Australia]] in 2016 after a coral bleaching event]] [[Coral reef
column1624: Warm water coral reefs]] are very sensitive to global warming and [[ocean acidification]]. Coral reefs provide a [[habitat]] for thousands of species and [[ecosystem services]] such as [[coastal protection]] and food. The resilience of reefs can be improved by curbing local pollution and overfishing, but 70–90% of today's warm water coral reefs will disappear even if warming is kept to 1.5 °C.<ref>{{Cite book
column1648: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column1668: first10=F.}}</ref> Coral reefs are not the only [[framework organisms]], organisms that build physical structures that form habitats for other sea creatures, affected by climate change: [[mangroves]] and [[seagrass]] are considered to be at moderate risk for lower levels of global warming according to a literature assessment in the [[Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate]].<ref>{{Cite book
column1692: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column1712: first10=F.}}</ref> [[Marine heatwave]]s have seen an increased frequency and have widespread impacts on life in the oceans, such as mass dying events.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1736: title=Marine heatwaves threaten global biodiversity and the provision of ecosystem services
column1746: Harmful algae blooms]] have increased in response to warming waters, [[ocean deoxygenation]] and [[eutrophication]].<ref>{{Cite book
column1770: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column1789: first15=A.}}</ref> Between one-quarter and one-third of our fossil fuel emissions are consumed by the earth's oceans and are now 30 percent more acidic than they were in pre-industrial times. This [[Ocean acidification
column1790: acidification]] poses a serious threat to aquatic life, particularly creatures such as oysters, clams, and coral with calcified shells or skeletons.<ref name=""February 23""/> ==Regional effects== {{Main
column1791: Regional effects of global warming}} [[File:Change in Average Temperature.svg
column1795: Average global temperatures from 2010 to 2019 compared to a baseline average from 1951 to 1978. Source: [[Goddard Institute for Space Studies
column1796: NASA]].]] Regional effects of global warming vary in nature. Some are the result of a generalised global change, such as rising temperature, resulting in local effects, such as melting ice. In other cases, a change may be related to a change in a particular ocean current or weather system. In such cases, the regional effect may be disproportionate and will not necessarily follow the global trend. There are three major ways in which global warming will make changes to regional climate: melting or forming ice, changing the [[hydrological cycle]] (of [[evaporation]] and [[Precipitation (meteorology)
column1798: currents in the oceans]] and air flows in the atmosphere. The coast can also be considered a region, and will suffer severe impacts from [[sea level rise]]. The [[Arctic]], [[Africa]], small islands, [[Asia]]n [[river delta
column1799: megadeltas]] and [[Climate change in the Middle East and North Africa
column1800: the Middle East]] are regions that are likely to be especially affected by climate change.<ref name=""ar4 especially affected regions"">{{citation
column1802: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-3-3.html Sec. 3.3.3 Especially affected systems, sectors and regions]
column1809: title=Climate change impacts in the Middle East and Northern Africa (MENA) region and their implications for vulnerable population groups
column1820: less-developed]] regions are at most risk of experiencing negative impacts due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts"">{{citation
column1826: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-7.html Distribution of Impacts, in: Sec 19.3.7 Update on 'Reasons for Concern']
column1827: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column1829: display-authors=etal}} </ref> [[Developed countries]] are also [[Climate change vulnerability
column1830: vulnerable to climate change]]. For example, developed countries will be negatively affected by increases in the severity and frequency of some [[extreme weather]] events, such as [[heat wave]]s.<ref name=""schneider regional vulnerabilities"">{{citation
column1836: chapter=Ch 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change
column1838: display-authors=etal}} </ref> Projections of climate changes at the regional scale do not hold as high a level of scientific confidence as projections made at the global scale.<ref name=""nrc 2008 climate change brochure"">{{cite book
column1841: title=Understanding and Responding to Climate Change. A brochure prepared by the US National Research Council (US NRC)
column1842: publisher=Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate, National Academy of Sciences
column1845: page=9}} </ref> It is, however, expected that future warming will follow a similar geographical pattern to that seen already, with the greatest warming over land and high northern [[latitude]]s, and least over the [[Southern Ocean]] and parts of the [[North Atlantic Ocean]].<ref>{{citation
column1849: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-projections-of.html Projections of Future Changes in Climate]
column1851: chapter-url=http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spm.html}} </ref> Land areas warm faster than ocean, and this feature is even stronger for extreme temperatures. For hot extremes, regions with the most warming include Central and [[Southern Europe]] and [[Western Asia
column1876: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column1896: first10=F.}}</ref> The ten countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) are among the most vulnerable in the world to the negative effects of climate change, however, ASEAN's climate mitigation efforts are not commensurate with the climate change threats the region faces.<ref>{{cite journal
column1911: title=The ASEAN climate and energy paradox
column1919: Effects of climate change on humans
column1920: Climate change, industry and society}} {{See also
column1921: Climate change and gender}} The effects of climate change, in combination with the sustained increases in greenhouse gas emissions, have led scientists to characterize it as a ''climate emergency.''<ref>{{Cite journal
column1933: title=World Scientists' Warning of a Climate Emergency
column1941: doi-access=free}}</ref><ref name="":7"">World Scientists' Warning of a Climate Emergency, William J Ripple, Christopher Wolf, Thomas M Newsome, Phoebe Barnard, William R Moomaw. BioScience, biz088, https://doi.org/10.1093/biosci/biz088. A correction has been published: [https://academic.oup.com/bioscience/advance-article/doi/10.1093/biosci/biz152/5670749 BioScience, biz152], https://doi.org/10.1093/biosci/biz152</ref><ref>[https://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/scientists-around-world-declare-climate-emergency-180973462/ Scientists Around the World Declare 'Climate Emergency'], Smithsonian Magazine, 5 November 2019</ref> Some climate researchers<ref>[https://edition.cnn.com/2019/06/04/health/climate-change-existential-threat-report-intl/index.html Climate change could pose 'existential threat' by 2050: report], CNN, 5 June 2019.</ref><ref>[https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-019-03595-0 Climate tipping points — too risky to bet against], Nature, 27 November 2019.</ref> and activists<ref>Greta Thunberg showed the world what it means to lead, ''The Guardian,'' 25 September 2019</ref> have called it an ''existential threat to civilization''. Some areas may become too hot for humans to live in<ref>{{cite news
column1945: title=One billion people will live in insufferable heat within 50 years – study
column1958: title=Future of the human climate niche
column1959: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
column1966: doi-access=free}}</ref> while people in some areas may experience displacement triggered by flooding and other climate change related disasters.<ref>{{Cite journal
column1974: title=Climate change-induced impacts on urban flood risk influenced by concurrent hazards
column1981: issn=1753-318X}}</ref> The vulnerability and exposure of humans to climate change varies from one economic sector to another and will have different impacts in different countries. Wealthy industrialised countries, which have emitted the most CO<sub>2</sub>, have more resources and so are the least vulnerable to global warming.<ref>{{Cite web
column1983: title=The Industries and Countries Most Vulnerable to Climate Change
column1988: access-date=2019-12-15}}</ref> Economic sectors that are likely to be affected include [[climate change and agriculture
column1989: agriculture]], human health, [[Fisheries and climate change
column2015: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column2038: first10=F.}}</ref> The quality and quantity of [[Fresh water
column2039: freshwater]] will likely be affected almost everywhere. Some people may be particularly at risk from climate change, such as the [[poverty
column2040: poor]], young children and the elderly.<ref name=""schneider distribution of impacts"" /><ref>{{citation
column2046: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch7s7-4-2-5.html Sec 7.4.2.5 Social issues and Sec 7.4.3 Key vulnerabilities]
column2049: display-authors=etal}} </ref> According to the [[World Health Organization]], between 2030 and 2050, ""climate change is expected to cause about 250,000 additional deaths per year.""<ref>{{Cite web
column2053: website=www.who.int}}</ref> As global temperatures increase, so does the number of heat stress, heatstroke, and cardiovascular and kidney disease deaths and illnesses.<ref name=""February 23""/> Air pollution generated by fossil fuel combustion is both a major driver of global warming and – in parallel and for comparison – the [[List of causes of death by rate#Air pollution
column2054: cause of a large number of annual deaths]] with some estimates as high as {{Hover title
column2055: A review of this and a more nuanced assessment of mortality impacts in terms of contribution to death, rather than number of deceased, may be needed
column2058: reason=A review of this and a more nuanced assessment of mortality impacts in terms of contribution to death, rather than number of deceased, may be needed}} excess deaths during 2018.<ref>{{cite news
column2061: title=Fossil fuel pollution causes one in five premature deaths globally: study
column2078: title=Global mortality from outdoor fine particle pollution generated by fossil fuel combustion: Results from GEOS-Chem
column2088: issn=0013-9351}}</ref> It may be difficult to predict or attribute deaths to anthropogenic global warming or its particular drivers as many effects – such as possibly contributing to human conflict and socioeconomic disruptions – and their mortality impacts could be highly indirect or hard to evaluate. ===Food security=== {{Main
column2092: }} Climate change will impact agriculture and food production around the world due to the effects of elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere; higher temperatures; altered precipitation and [[transpiration]] regimes; increased frequency of extreme events; and modified [[weed]], [[pest (organism)
column2099: chapter=Chapter 5: Food, Fibre, and Forest Products
column2101: display-authors=etal}} </ref> Climate change is projected to negatively affect all four pillars of food security: not only how much food is available, but also how easy food is to access (prices), food quality and how stable the food system is.<ref>{{Cite book
column2141: first15=A. J.}}</ref> ====Food availability==== [[File:Projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming.png
column2145: 2011 projected changes in crop yields at different latitudes with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""> [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12877&page=161 Figure 5.1], p. 161, in: Sec 5.1 FOOD PRODUCTION, PRICES, AND HUNGER, in: Ch 5: Impacts in the Next Few Decades and Coming Centuries, in: {{harvnb
column2147: 2011}} </ref>]] [[File:Projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming.png
column2151: 2011 projected changes in yields of selected crops with global warming. This graph is based on several studies.<ref name=""us nrc 2011 fig 5.1""/>]] As of 2019, negative impacts have been observed for some crops in low-latitudes ([[maize]] and wheat), while positive impacts of climate change have been observed in some crops in high-latitudes (maize, wheat, and [[sugar beet]]s).<ref>{{Cite book
column2160: IPCC SRCCL DRAFT Summary for Policymakers
