column2164: chapter-url=https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/2019/08/Edited-SPM_Approved_Microsite_FINAL.pdf}}</ref> Using different methods to project future crop yields, a consistent picture emerges of global decreases in yield. Maize and [[soybean]] decrease with any warming, whereas rice and wheat production might peak at 3 °C of warming.<ref>{{Cite book
column2205: fisheries]] have already seen their catch decrease because of global warming and changes in [[Biogeochemical cycle
column2206: biochemical cycles]]. In combination with [[overfishing]], warming waters decrease the maximum catch potential.<ref>{{Cite book
column2215: IPCC SROCC DRAFT Summary for Policymakers
column2219: chapter-url=https://report.ipcc.ch/srocc/pdf/SROCC_SPM_Approved.pdf}}</ref> Global catch potential is projected to reduce further in 2050 by less than 4% if emissions are reduced strongly, and by about 8% for very high future emissions, with growth in the [[Arctic Ocean]].<ref>{{Cite book
column2243: chapter=Chapter 5: Changing Ocean, Marine Ecosystems, and Dependent Communities
column2266: last10=Levin}}</ref> =====Other aspects of food security===== Climate change impacts depend strongly on projected future social and economic development. {{As of
column2268: }}, an estimated 831 million people are undernourished.<ref name="":4"">{{Cite book
column2308: first15=A. J.}}</ref> Under a high emission scenario (RCP6.0), cereals are projected to become 1-29% more expensive in 2050 depending on the socioeconomic pathway, particularly affecting low-income consumers.<ref name="":4"" /> Compared to a no climate change scenario, this would put between 1-181 million extra people at risk of hunger.<ref name="":4"" /> While {{CO2}} is expected to be good for crop productivity at lower temperatures, it does reduce the nutritional values of crops, with for instance wheat having less protein and less of some minerals.<ref>{{Cite book
column2328: chapter-url=https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/sites/4/2019/11/08_Chapter-5.pdf}}</ref> It is difficult to project the impact of climate change on utilization (protecting food against spoilage, being healthy enough to absorb nutrients, etc.) and on volatility of [[food prices]]. Most models projecting the future do indicate that prices will become more volatile.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2346: title=Climate Change and Global Food Systems: Potential Impacts on Food Security and Undernutrition
column2354: doi-access=free}}</ref> Droughts result in crop failures and the loss of pasture for livestock.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2362: title = Measuring economic impacts of drought: A review and discussion
column2370: Water security}} A number of climate-related trends have been observed that affect [[water resources]]. These include changes in precipitation, the cryosphere and [[surface water]]s (e.g., changes in [[river flows]]).<ref> {{citation
column2374: chapter=Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column2376: display-authors=etal}} </ref> Observed and projected impacts of climate change on [[freshwater]] systems and their management are mainly due to changes in temperature, sea level and precipitation variability.<ref name=""freshwater impacts""> {{citation
column2380: chapter=Chapter 3: Fresh Water Resources and their Management
column2382: display-authors=etal}} </ref> Changes in temperature are correlated with variability in precipitation because the [[water cycle]] is reactive to temperature.<ref>{{Cite web
column2384: title=Freshwater (Lakes and Rivers) - The Water Cycle
column2386: access-date=2019-05-01}}</ref> Temperature increases change precipitation patterns. Excessive precipitation leads to excessive sediment deposition, nutrient pollution, and concentration of minerals in [[aquifer]]s. The rising global temperature will cause sea level rise and will extend areas of [[Salinity
column2388: estuaries]], resulting in a decrease in freshwater availability for humans and ecosystems in coastal areas. The rising sea level will push the salt gradient into freshwater deposits and will eventually pollute freshwater sources. The 2014 [[IPCC Fifth Assessment Report
column2389: fifth IPCC assessment report]] concluded that: * Water resources are projected to decrease in most dry [[Subtropics
column2390: subtropical regions]] and [[mid-latitudes]], but increase in high latitudes. As streamflow becomes more variable, even regions with increased water resources can experience additional short-term [[Water scarcity
column2417: date=February 2020}} average of 7% of the [[world population]] is expected to have at least 20% less renewable water resource.<ref name="":5"">{{Cite book
column2441: chapter-url=https://archive.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg2/WGIIAR5-Chap3_FINAL.pdf}}</ref> * Climate change is projected to reduce [[water quality]] before treatment. Even after conventional treatments, risks remain. The quality reduction is a consequence of higher temperatures, more intense rainfall, droughts and disruption of [[Water treatment
column2442: treatment facilities]] during floods.<ref name="":5"" /> * Droughts that stress water supply are expected to increase in [[southern Europe]] and the [[Mediterranean Basin
column2443: Mediterranean region]], [[central Europe]], central and southern [[North America]], [[Central America]], [[Northeast Region, Brazil
column2469: Effects of climate change on human health}} Humans are exposed to climate change through changing weather patterns (temperature, precipitation, sea-level rise and more frequent extreme events) and indirectly through changes in water, air and food quality and changes in ecosystems, agriculture, industry and settlements and the economy.<ref name=""health summary""> {{citation
column2477: display-authors=etal}}. </ref> Air pollution, wildfires, and heat waves caused by global warming have significantly affected human health,<ref>{{Cite journal
column2485: title=Climate change and respiratory health: current evidence and knowledge gaps
column2493: issn=1747-6348}}</ref> and in 2007, the World Health Organization estimated 150,000 people were being killed by climate-change-related issues every year.<ref>[https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/green/news/2007/09/24/3462/the-top-100-effects-of-global-warming/ The Top 100 Effects of Global Warming], Centre for American Progress, 24 September 2007</ref> A study by the [[World Health Organization]]<ref> {{cite book
column2496: title= Global health risks: mortality and burden of disease attributable to selected major risks
column2504: url=https://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/global_health_risks/en/index.html }} </ref> concluded that climate change was responsible for 3% of [[diarrhoea]], 3% of [[malaria]], and 3.8% of [[dengue fever]] deaths worldwide in 2004. Total attributable mortality was about 0.2% of deaths in 2004; of these, 85% were child deaths. The effects of more frequent and extreme storms were excluded from this study. The human impacts include both the direct effects of extreme weather, leading to injury and loss of life,<ref>{{Cite web
column2505: title=Human Health: Impacts, Adaptation, and Co-Benefits — IPCC
column2507: access-date=2020-10-11}}</ref> as well as indirect effects, such as [[Malnutrition
column2509: crop failures]]. Various infectious diseases are more easily transmitted in a warmer climate, such as [[dengue fever]], which affects children most severely, and [[malaria]]. Young children are the most vulnerable to food shortages, and together with older people, to extreme heat.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2533: title=The 2019 report of The Lancet Countdown on health and climate change: ensuring that the health of a child born today is not defined by a changing climate
column2542: s2cid=207976337}}</ref> According to a report from the [[United Nations Environment Programme]] and [[International Livestock Research Institute]], climate change can facilitate outbreaks of [[Zoonosis]], e.g. diseases that pass from animals to humans. One example of such outbreaks is the [[COVID-19 pandemic]].<ref>{{cite news
column2545: title=Video: Covid-19 Will Be Just 'One of Many' New Infectious Diseases Spilling Over From Animals to Humans
column2549: publisher=United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI)
column2550: date=13 August 2020}}</ref> A minor further effect are increases of pollen [[Allergen#Seasonal allergy
column2551: season]] lengths and concentrations in some regions of the world.<ref>{{cite news
column2554: title=Achoo! Climate Change Lengthening Pollen Season in U.S., Study Shows
column2571: title=Anthropogenic climate change is worsening North American pollen seasons
column2572: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
column2583: 50px]] Available under [https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ CC BY 4.0].</ref><ref name=""February 23""/> ====Projections==== A 2014 study by the [[World Health Organization]]<ref>{{Cite book
column2584: title=Quantitative risk assessment of the effects of climate change on selected causes of death, 2030s and 2050s
column2589: hdl = 10665/134014}}</ref> estimated the effect of climate change on human health, but not all of the effects of climate change were included in their estimates. For example, the effects of more frequent and extreme storms were excluded. The report further assumed continued progress in health and growth. Even so, climate change was projected to cause an additional 250,000 deaths per year between 2030 and 2050.<ref>[https://www.who.int/publications-detail/cop24-special-report-health-climate-change COP24 special report: health and climate change]. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2018. p.24. Cataloguing-in-Publication (CIP) data. CIP data are available at <nowiki>http://apps.who.int/iris</nowiki>.</ref> The authors of the IPCC AR4 Synthesis report<ref name=""IPCC AR4 Synthesis Report"">{{harvnb
column2593: date=November 2012}} projected with high confidence that climate change will bring some benefits in temperate areas, such as fewer deaths from cold exposure, and some mixed effects such as changes in range and transmission potential of [[malaria]] in [[Africa]]. Benefits were projected to be outweighed by negative health effects of rising temperatures, especially in [[Developing country
column2594: developing countries]]. Economic development is an important component of possible adaptation to climate change. Economic growth on its own, however, is not sufficient to insulate the world's population from disease and injury due to climate change.<ref name=""health summary""/> Future vulnerability to climate change will depend not only on the extent of social and economic change, but also on how the benefits and costs of change are distributed in society.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""> {{citation
column2599: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch8s8-3-2.html Sec. 8.3.2 Future vulnerability to climate change]
column2602: display-authors=etal}} </ref> For example, in the 19th century, rapid [[urbanization]] in [[western Europe]] led to health plummeting.<ref name=""Future vulnerability to climate change health impacts""/> Other factors important in determining the health of populations include [[education]], the availability of health services, and [[public health
column2603: public-health]] [[infrastructure]].<ref name=""health summary""/> Warming above 1.5 degrees can make tropical regions uninhabitable, because the threshold of 35 degrees of [[wet bulb temperature]] (the limit of human adaptation to heat and humidity), will be passed. 43% of the human population live in the tropics.<ref>{{cite web
column2606: title=Keep warming under 1.5°C to stop tropics becoming too hot to live
column2610: access-date=30 May 2021}}</ref> ==== On mental health ==== {{see also
column2611: Psychological impact of climate change}} In 2018, the American Psychological Association issued a report about the [[effects of climate change on mental health
column2612: impact of climate change on mental health]]. It said that ""gradual, long-term changes in climate can also surface a number of different emotions, including fear, anger, feelings of powerlessness, or exhaustion"".<ref>[https://www.apa.org/news/press/releases/2017/03/climate-mental-health Climate Change's Toll On Mental Health], APA, 29 March 2017</ref> Generally this is likely to have the greatest impact on young people. California social scientist, Renee Lertzman, likens the climate-related stress now affecting teenagers and those in their 20s to [[Cold War]] fears that gripped young [[baby boomers]] who came of age under the threat of nuclear annihilation.<ref>[https://www.sctimes.com/story/news/local/minnesota/2019/04/21/climate-grief-takes-toll-younger-generations-baby-boomers-millenials/3518994002/ 'Climate grief' takes toll on younger generations], SC Times, 21 April 2019.</ref> Research has found that although there are heightened emotional experiences linked with acknowledgement and anticipation of climate change and its impact on society, these are inherently adaptive. Furthermore, engaging with these emotional experiences leads to increased resilience, agency, reflective functioning and collective action. Individuals are encouraged to find collective ways of processing their climate related emotional experiences in order to support mental health and well being.<ref>{{cite journal
column2618: title=The responsibility of communicating difficult truths about climate influenced societal disruption and collapse: an introduction to psychological research
column2620: journal=Institute for Leadership and Sustainability (IFLAS) Occasional Papers
column2622: pages=1–39}}</ref> A 2018 study found that unusually hot days have profound effects on mental health and that global warming could contribute to approximately 26,000 more suicides in the U.S. by 2050.<ref>{{cite web
column2624: title=Climate Change May Cause 26,000 More U.S. Suicides by 2050
column2626: date=2018-07-23}}</ref> A study published in April 2020 found that by the end of the 21st century people could be exposed to [[Climate change mitigation
column2627: avoidable]] indoor CO2 levels of up to 1400 ppm, which would be triple the amount commonly experienced outdoors today and, according to the authors, may [[Carbon dioxide#Toxicity
column2628: cut humans' basic decision-making ability indoors by ~25% and complex strategic thinking by ~50%]].<ref>{{cite journal
column2629: title=Rising carbon dioxide levels will make us stupider
column2640: title=Rising CO2 causes more than a climate crisis—it may directly harm our ability to think
column2650: title=Fossil Fuel Combustion Is Driving Indoor CO2 Toward Levels Harmful to Human Cognition
column2662: Effects of climate change on island nations}} Gradual but pervasive environmental change and sudden natural disasters both influence the nature and extent of human migration but in different ways. ==== Slow onset ==== Slow-onset disasters and gradual environmental erosion such as desertification, reduction of soil fertility, coastal erosion and sea-level rise are likely to induce long term migration.<ref>[https://www.climateforesight.eu/migrations/environmental-migrants-up-to-1-billion-by-2050/ Environmental Migrants: Up To 1 Billion By 2050], Centro Euro-Mediterraneo sui Cambiamenti Climactici (CMCC)</ref> Migration related to desertification and reduced soil fertility is likely to be predominantly from [[rural area]]s in [[developing countries]] to towns and cities.<ref name=""wdr migration""> {{citation
column2664: title = Managing social risks: Empower communities to protect themselves
column2665: chapter = Part One: Chapter 2: Reducing Human Vulnerability: Helping People Help Themselves
column2668: 2010}}. </ref> Displacement and migration related to sea level rise will mostly affect those who live in cities near the coast. More than 90 US coastal cities are already experiencing chronic flooding and that number is expected to double by 2030.<ref name=""weforum.org"">[https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2019/01/the-world-s-coastal-cities-are-going-under-here-is-how-some-are-fighting-back/ The world's coastal cities are going under. Here's how some are fighting back.] World Economic Forum 16 January 2019</ref> Numerous cities in Europe will be affected by rising sea levels; especially in the Netherlands, Spain and Italy.<ref>[https://www.euronews.com/2018/02/02/rising-sea-levels-threat-a-shrinking-european-coastline-in-2100 Rising sea levels threat: a shrinking European coastline in 2100?] Euronews 2 February 2018</ref> Coastal cities in Africa are also under threat due to rapid urbanization and the growth of informal settlements along the coast.<ref>[https://theconversation.com/african-countries-arent-doing-enough-to-prepare-for-rising-sea-levels-103002 African countries aren't doing enough to prepare for rising sea levels.] The Conversation 16 September 2018</ref> Low lying Pacific island nations including Fiji, Kiribati, Nauru, Micronesia, the Marshall Islands, the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Timor Leste and Tonga are especially vulnerable to rising seas. In July 2019, they issued a declaration ""affirming that climate change poses the single greatest threat to the human rights and security of present and future generations of Pacific Island peoples""<ref>[https://drive.google.com/file/d/1cbSloYVSuY4mIZnUUC5ISpZUaV3NTb2y/view Nadi Bay Declaration on the Climate Change Crisis in the Pacific], Nadi Bay, Fiji, 30 July 2019</ref> and stated their lands could become uninhabitable as early as 2030.<ref>[https://www.sciencealert.com/pacific-islanders-are-in-a-climate-crisis-as-rising-sea-levels-threaten-water There's a Climate Threat Facing Pacific Islands That's More Dire Than Losing Land], Science Alert 19 September 2019</ref> The United Nations says there are already 64 million human migrants in the world fleeing wars, hunger, persecution and the effects of global warming.<ref>Environmental Migrants: Up To 1 Billion By 2050, Centro Euro-Mediterraneo sui Cambiamenti Climactici (CMCC)</ref> In 2018, the World Bank estimated that climate change will cause [[internal migration]] of between 31 and 143 million people as they escape crop failures, water scarcity, and sea level rise. The study only included Sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia, and Latin America.<ref>[https://www.nationalgeographic.com/news/2018/03/climate-migrants-report-world-bank-spd/ 143 Million People May Soon Become Climate Migrants], National Geographic, 19 March 2018</ref><ref>{{Cite book
column2670: title=Groundswell: preparing for internal climate migration
column2681: display-authors=etal}}</ref> A 2020 study projects that regions inhabited by a third of the human population could become as hot as the hottest parts of the [[Sahara]] within 50 years without a [[Projections of population growth
column2682: change in patterns of population growth]] and without [[human migration
column2684: greenhouse gas emissions are reduced]]. The projected annual average temperature of above 29 °C for these regions would be outside the ""human temperature niche"" – a suggested range for climate biologically suitable for humans based on historical data of mean annual temperatures (MAT) – and the most affected regions have little [[adaptation to climate change
column2687: title=Climate change: More than 3bn could live in extreme heat by 2070
column2701: title=Future of the human climate niche – Supplementary Materials
column2702: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
column2710: pmc=7260949}}</ref> The following matrix shows their projections for population-sizes outside the ""human temperature niche"" – and therefore potential emigrants of their regions – in different [[climate change scenario]]s and [[projections of population growth]] for 2070:<ref>{{cite web
column2711: title=Future of the human climate niche
column2716: A matrix of population growth- and climate change-scenarios
column2732: Mean projected global temperature rise of ~1.5 °C ! scope=""col"" width=""30""
column2734: Mean projected global temperature rise of ~3.2 °C
column2781: } ==== Sudden onset ==== Sudden-onset natural disasters tend to create mass displacement, which may only be short term. However, [[Hurricane Katrina]] demonstrated that displacement can last a long time. Estimates suggest that a quarter of the one million people<ref>[https://www.datacenterresearch.org/data-resources/katrina/facts-for-impact/ Facts for Features: Katrina Impact], The Data Centre, 26 August 2016</ref> displaced in the Gulf Coast region by Hurricane Katrina had not returned to their homes five years after the disaster.<ref>[https://www.brookings.edu/on-the-record/natural-disasters-conflict-and-human-rights-tracing-the-connections/ Natural Disasters, Conflict, and Human Rights: Tracing the Connections], Brookings 3 March 2010.</ref> Mizutori, the U.N. secretary-general's special representative on disaster risk reduction, says millions of people are also displaced from their homes every year as result of sudden-onset disasters such as intense heatwaves, storms and flooding. She says 'climate crisis disasters' are happening at the rate of one a week.<ref>[https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/un-expert-warns-one-climate-crisis-disaster-occurs-every-week-180972573/ One Climate Crisis Disaster Occurs Every Week, U.N. Official Warns], The Smithsonian magazine, 8 July 2019</ref> === Conflict === {{Main
column2782: Climate security}} A 2013 study found that significant climatic changes were associated with a higher risk of conflict worldwide, and predicted that ""amplified rates of human conflict could represent a large and critical social impact of anthropogenic climate change in both low- and high-income countries.""<ref>{{cite journal
column2783: vauthors=Hsiang SM, Burke M, Miguel E
column2785: title=Quantifying the influence of climate on human conflict
column2792: doi=10.1126/science.1235367 }}</ref> Similarly, a 2014 study found that higher temperatures were associated with a greater likelihood of violent crime, and predicted that global warming would cause millions of such crimes in the United States alone during the 21st century.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2794: title = Crime, weather, and climate change
column2795: journal = Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
column2801: pages=274–302}}</ref> Climate change can worsen conflicts by exacerbating tensions over limited resources like drinking water. Climate change has the potential to cause large population dislocations, which can also lead to conflict.<ref>{{cite journal
column2810: pages=343–360}}</ref> However, a 2018 study in the journal ''Nature Climate Change'' found that previous studies on the relationship between climate change and conflict suffered from [[sampling bias]] and other methodological problems.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2829: url=https://researchrepository.murdoch.edu.au/id/eprint/59942/}}</ref> Factors other than climate change are judged to be substantially more important in affecting conflict (based on [[expert elicitation]]). These factors include intergroup [[Social inequality
column2830: inequality]] and low socio-economic development.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2854: title=Climate as a risk factor for armed conflict
column2864: issn=1476-4687}}</ref> Despite these issues, military planners are concerned that global warming is a ""threat multiplier"". ""Whether it is poverty, food and [[water scarcity]], diseases, economic instability, or threat of natural disasters, the broad range of changing climatic conditions may be far reaching. These challenges may threaten stability in much of the world"".<ref>{{cite journal
column2869: journal =Proceedings of the United States Naval Institute
column2875: url=http://www.usni.org/magazines/proceedings/2013-10/next-security-frontier }}</ref> For example, the onset of the [[Arab Spring]] in 2010 was partly the result of a spike in wheat prices following crop losses from the [[2010 Northern Hemisphere heat waves
column2879: title=Climate Change and Rising Food Prices Heightened Arab Spring
column2881: work=Republished with permission by Scientific American
column2886: title=How the climate crisis could become a food crisis overnight
column2890: Economic impacts of climate change}} Economic forecasts of the impact of global warming vary considerably. Researchers have warned that current economic modelling may seriously underestimate the impact of potentially catastrophic climate change, and point to the need for new models that give a more accurate picture of potential damages. Nevertheless, one recent study has found that potential global economic gains if countries implement mitigation strategies to comply with the 2 °C target set at the Paris Agreement are in the vicinity of US$17 trillion per year up to 2100 compared to a very high emission scenario.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2898: title=The Effects of Climate Change on GDP by Country and the Global Economic Gains From Complying With the Paris Climate Accord
column2906: bibcode=2018EaFut...6.1153K}}</ref> Global losses reveal rapidly rising costs due to extreme weather events since the 1970s.<ref name="":12""> {{citation
column2908: title=Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 2007
column2909: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch1s1-3-8-5.html Sec. 1.3.8.5 Summary of disasters and hazards]
column2910: chapter=Chapter 1: Assessment of observed changes and responses in natural and managed systems
column2915: Socio-economic]] factors have contributed to the observed trend of global losses, such as population growth and increased [[wealth]].<ref>{{Citation
column2918: title=Observed and Projected Impacts from Extreme Weather Events: Implications for Loss and Damage
column2920: work=Loss and Damage from Climate Change: Concepts, Methods and Policy Options
column2924: series=Climate Risk Management, Policy and Governance
column2935: doi-access=free}}</ref> Part of the growth is also related to regional climatic factors, e.g., changes in precipitation and flooding events. It is difficult to quantify the relative impact of socio-economic factors and climate change on the observed trend.<ref name=""disaster losses""> {{citation
column2941: 2001}}. </ref> The trend does, however, suggest increasing vulnerability of social systems to climate change.<ref name=""disaster losses""/> A 2019 modelling study found that climate change had contributed towards global economic inequality. Wealthy countries in colder regions had either felt little overall economic impact from climate change, or possibly benefited, whereas poor hotter countries very likely grew less than if global warming had not occurred.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2947: title=Global warming has increased global economic inequality
column2948: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
column2956: pmc=6525504}}</ref> The total economic impacts from climate change are difficult to estimate, but increase for higher temperature changes.<ref>* {{Cite book
column2965: IPCC AR5 WG2 Summary for Policymakers
column2968: chapter-url=https://archive.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg2/ar5_wgII_spm_en.pdf}}</ref> For instance, total damages are estimated to be 90% less if global warming is limited to 1.5 °C compared to 3.66 °C, a warming level chosen to represent no mitigation.<ref name="":9"">{{Cite book
column2992: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5 ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column3015: first10=F.}}</ref> One study found a 3.5% reduction in global [[GDP]] by the end of the century if warming is limited to 3 °C, excluding the potential effect of [[Tipping points in the climate system
column3016: tipping points]]. Another study noted that global economic impact is underestimated by a factor of two to eight when tipping points are excluded from consideration.<ref name="":9"" /> In the Oxford Economics high emission scenario, a temperature rise of 2 degrees by the year 2050 would reduce global GDP by 2.5% - 7.5%. By the year 2100 in this case, the temperature would rise by 4 degrees, which could reduce the global GDP by 30% in the worst case.<ref>{{cite web
column3019: title=Global GDP will suffer at least a 3% hit by 2050 from unchecked climate change, say economists
column3022: access-date=29 March 2020}}</ref> ==Abrupt or irreversible changes== [[Positive feedback
column3023: Self-reinforcing feedbacks]] amplify and accelerate climate change.<ref>{{cite book
column3044: chapter=Chapter 15: Potential Surprises: Compound Extremes and Tipping Elements
column3052: url-status=live}}</ref> The climate system exhibits ''threshold behaviour'' or [[Tipping points in the climate system
column3053: tipping points]] when these feedbacks lead parts of the Earth system into a new state, such as the runaway loss of ice sheets or the destruction of too many forests.<ref name="":3"">{{cite book
column3074: chapter=Chapter 15: Potential Surprises: Compound Extremes and Tipping Elements
column3083: title=Climate emergency: world 'may have crossed tipping points'
column3088: date=27 November 2019}}</ref> Tipping points are studied using data from [[Paleoclimatology
column3089: Earth's distant past]] and by physical modelling.<ref name="":3"" /> There is already moderate risk of global tipping points at 1 °C above pre-industrial temperatures, and that risk becomes high at 2.5 °C.<ref>{{Cite book
column3113: chapter=Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5ºC Global Warming on Natural and Human Systems
column3136: first10=F.}}</ref> Tipping points are ""perhaps the most 'dangerous' aspect of future climate changes"", leading to irreversible impacts on society.<ref>{{Cite journal
column3146: title=Stochastic integrated assessment of climate tipping points indicates the need for strict climate policy
column3156: hdl-access=free}}</ref> Many tipping points are interlinked, so that triggering one may lead to a cascade of effects,<ref>{{Cite journal
column3172: title=Climate tipping points — too risky to bet against
column3180: bibcode=2019Natur.575..592L}}</ref> even well below 2 degrees of warming.<ref>{{cite news
column3183: title=Climate tipping points could topple like dominoes, warn scientists
column3187: date=3 June 2021}}</ref> A 2018 study states that 45% of environmental problems, including those caused by climate change are interconnected and make the risk of a [[domino effect]] bigger.<ref>{{cite journal
column3196: title=Cascading regime shifts within and across scales
column3209: title=Risks of 'domino effect' of tipping points greater than thought, study says
column3213: date=20 December 2018}}</ref> === Amazon rain forest === Rainfall that falls on the [[Amazon rainforest]] is recycled when it [[evaporation
column3214: evaporates]] back into the atmosphere instead of [[surface runoff
column3215: running off]] away from the rainforest. This water is essential for sustaining the rainforest. Due to deforestation the rainforest is losing this ability, exacerbated by climate change which brings more frequent droughts to the area. The higher frequency of droughts seen in the first two decades of the 21st century signal that a tipping point from rainforest to [[savanna]] might be close.<ref>{{cite journal
column3221: title=Amazon tipping point: Last chance for action
column3230: bibcode=2019SciA....5A2949L}}</ref> ===Greenland and West Antarctic Ice sheets=== Future melt of the [[West Antarctic Ice Sheet
column3231: West Antarctic ice sheet]] is potentially abrupt under a high emission scenario, as a consequence of a partial collapse.<ref name="":2"">{{Cite book
column3255: chapter=Chapter 6: Extremes, Abrupt Changes and Managing Risks
column3273: first10=B.}}</ref> Part of the ice sheet is grounded on bedrock below sea level, making it possibly vulnerable to the self-enhancing process of [[marine ice sheet instability]]. A further hypothesis is that ''marine ice cliff instability'' would also contribute to a partial collapse, but limited evidence is available for its importance.<ref>{{Cite book
column3313: first15=G.}}</ref> A partial collapse of the ice sheet would lead to rapid sea level rise and a local decrease in ocean salinity. It would be irreversible on a timescale between decades and millennia.<ref name="":2"" /> In contrast to the West Antarctic ice sheet, melt of the [[Greenland ice sheet]] is projected to be taking place more gradually over millennia.<ref name="":2"" /> Sustained warming between 1 °C (low confidence) and 4 °C (medium confidence) would lead to a complete loss of the ice sheet, contributing 7 m to sea levels globally.<ref>{{Cite book
column3337: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column3357: last10=Isla}}</ref> The ice loss could become irreversible due to a further self-enhancing feedback: the [[elevation-surface mass balance feedback]]. When ice melts on top of the ice sheet, the elevation drops. As air temperature is higher at lower altitude, this promotes further melt.<ref>{{Cite book
column3381: chapter=Chapter 4: Sea Level Rise and Implications for Low Lying Islands, Coasts and Communities
column3405: This map shows the general location and direction of the warm surface (red) and cold deep water (blue) currents of the [[thermohaline circulation]]. [[Salinity]] is represented by color in units of the Practical Salinity Scale. Low values (blue) are less saline, while high values (orange) are more saline.<ref> {{cite web
column3407: author=Riebeek, H.. design by R. Simmon
column3408: title=Paleoclimatology: Explaining the Evidence: Explaining Rapid Climate Change: Tales from the Ice
column3412: Shutdown of thermohaline circulation}} The [[Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation]] (AMOC), an important component of the Earth's climate system, is a northward flow of warm, salty water in the upper layers of the [[Atlantic ocean
column3413: Atlantic]] and a southward flow of colder water in the deep Atlantic.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change""> {{cite book
column3416: title=Abrupt Climate Change. A report by the US Climate Change Science Program (CCSP) and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research
column3424: date=November 2012}} Potential impacts associated with AMOC changes include reduced warming or (in the case of abrupt change) absolute cooling of northern high-latitude areas near [[Greenland]] and north-western Europe, an increased warming of [[Southern Hemisphere]] high-latitudes, tropical drying, as well as changes to [[marine ecosystem]]s, terrestrial vegetation, oceanic {{chem
column3426: 2}} uptake, oceanic oxygen concentrations, and shifts in fisheries.<ref> {{citation
column3431: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-3-5-3.html Sec. 19.3.5.3 Possible changes in the North Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (MOC)]
column3432: chapter=Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column3434: display-authors=etal}} </ref> According to a 2019 assessment in the IPCC's [[Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate]] it is very likely (greater than 90% probability, based on expert judgement) that the strength of the AMOC will decrease further over the course of the 21st century.<ref name="":6"">{{Cite book
column3458: chapter=Chapter 6: Extremes, Abrupt Changes and Managing Risks
column3476: first10=B.}}</ref> Warming is still expected to occur over most of the European region downstream of the [[North Atlantic Current]] in response to increasing GHGs, as well as over [[North America]]. With medium confidence, the IPCC stated that it is very unlikely (less than 10% probability) that the AMOC will collapse in the 21st century.<ref name="":6"" /> The potential consequences of such a collapse could be severe.<ref name=""ccsp abrupt climate change"" />{{Rp
column3478: date=November 2012}} ===Irreversible change=== ====Warming commitment to {{CO2}} concentrations.==== If emissions of {{CO2}} were to be abruptly stopped and no [[negative emission technologies]] deployed, the Earth's climate would not start moving back to its pre-industrial state. Instead, temperatures would stay elevated at the same level for several centuries. After about a thousand years, 20% to 30% of human-emitted {{CO2}} will remain in the atmosphere, not taken up by the ocean or the land, committing the climate to warming long after emissions have stopped.<ref>{{Cite book
column3502: chapter=Chapter 12: Long-term Climate Change: Projections, Commitments and Irreversibility
column3517: first10=G.}}</ref> Pathways that keep global warming under 1.5 °C often rely on large-scale removal of {{CO2}}, which feasibility is uncertain and has clear risks.<ref>{{Cite book
column3541: chapter=Chapter 2: Mitigation Pathways Compatible with 1.5°C in the Context of Sustainable Development
column3554: last13=Vilariño}}</ref> ====Irreversible impacts==== There are a number of examples of climate change impacts that may be irreversible, at least over the timescale of many human generations.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""> {{citation
column3559: at=[http://archive.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-2.html Sec.19.2 Criteria for selecting 'key' vulnerabilities: Persistence and reversibility]
column3560: chapter=Chapter 19: Assessing key vulnerabilities and the risk from climate change
column3562: display-authors=etal}} </ref> These include the large-scale singularities such as the melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, and changes to the AMOC.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In biological systems, the extinction of species would be an irreversible impact.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> In social systems, unique [[culture]]s may be lost due to climate change.<ref name=""schneider irreversibilities""/> For example, humans living on [[atoll]] islands face risks due to sea level rise, sea surface warming, and increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.<ref>{{cite journal
column3578: url-status=dead }} This paper was published in 2001 as [http://www.tyndall.ac.uk/sites/default/files/wp9.pdf Tyndall Centre Working Paper 9] {{Webarchive
